abstract: Men who consider public affairs a mere personal struggle are very positive that the present Cabinet can't stand much longer. abstract: At the outbreak of the rebellion we were the first to relieve the general apprehension as to the financial strength of the loyal States, by demonstrating the proposition that the revolting ones would carry away with them hardly an appreciable portion of the wealth of the country, for the reason that wealth ...
lead_paragraph: At the outbreak of the rebellion we were the first to relieve the general apprehension as to the financial strength of the loyal States, by demonstrating the proposition that the revolting ones would carry away with them hardly an appreciable portion of the wealth of the country, for the reason that wealth must always be in ratio, to the industry of a people in the degree that it is assisted by the contrivances of science and art. Muscular action has long since ceased to be the chief instrument in production. But the use of labor-saving machinery is in direct ratio to the intelligence of the workman. It has been the traditional policy of the Slave States to blindfold labor; of the Free, to enlighten it. Hence the infinite superiority of the latter -- a superiority which has been almost wholly gained within the last twenty years by the progress they have made in the mechanic arts.

abstract: Neutrality Policy; the Ministers and the Opposition
snippet: Neutrality Policy; the Ministers and the Opposition
lead_paragraph: The symptoms of weakness on the part of the Ministry in England are increasing every day; and it is quite evident that nothing but the want of leaders and want of policy on the part of the Opposition prevents a crisis that would result in the ousting of the Palmerston-Russell Cabinet. Everybody is dissatisfied with the position held by England in her relations with foreign Powers, and her internal condition, though the Custom-house returns convey an appearance of prosperity, is by no means satisfactory. She has never recovered the prestige lost by the Crimean war; and every opportunity that has since offered itself of doing so has been suffered to pass, in obedience to considerations which no English Minister in these days dares to overlook.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday, but transacted but little business of general importance. A resolution was adopted to grant the Managers of the Metropolitan Sanitary Fair the sidewalk, for the length of three hundred feet, fronting the Palace Garden grounds, for a temporary structure, with a sidewalk ten feet wide ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday, but transacted but little business of general importance. A resolution was adopted to grant the Managers of the Metropolitan Sanitary Fair the sidewalk, for the length of three hundred feet, fronting the Palace Garden grounds, for a temporary structure, with a sidewalk ten feet wide around it for the passage of pedestrians -- this permission to exist only while the great Fair shall last; and the Croton Board were directed to establish hydrants in the Fair buildings. The resolution granting the use of the Chamber of the Board to the Superior Court, Special Term, for the month of March, was called up by Mr. GROSS, and was adopted. A resolution was adopted directing the Comptroller to make a new issue of Central Park Improvement Fund stock, to the amount of $300,000. Messrs. JACQUES and GROSS advocated economy and a lesser sum, believing $150,000 or so would answer for this year; but their opposition was unavailing, the vote standing 14 to 10. The Board changed the hour of meeting for 4 o'clock P.M., and adjourned to Thursday.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, introduced a bill for the protection of overland emigrants, which appropriates $40,000 to be expended on the roads to Colorado and Idaho. Mr. SUMNER, from the Select Committee on Freedmen and Slavery, presented a long report on the Fugitive Slave Law, accompanied by a bill repealing all laws for the rendition of fugitive slaves to their masters.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, introduced a bill for the protection of overland emigrants, which appropriates $40,000 to be expended on the roads to Colorado and Idaho. Mr. SUMNER, from the Select Committee on Freedmen and Slavery, presented a long report on the Fugitive Slave Law, accompanied by a bill repealing all laws for the rendition of fugitive slaves to their masters. The report is very long, and reviews the relation of Slavery to the Constitution at length. Mr. WILSON, from the Military Committee, reported the House bill extending bounties to April 1, and stated that the Government was enlisting men at the rate of 2,000 per day, which was faster than the Government could take care of them. Discussion ensued, and the bill was finally recommitted to the Military Committee. The disagreement of the Conference Committee on the whisky tax was made the special order for today at one o'clock. Mr. SHERMAN asked the Senate to instruct the committee to report a tax of twenty cents per gallon on whisky on hand July 1. The bill equalizing the pay of soldiers was taken up, and after discussion, without progress, recommitted to the Committee on Military Affairs. The Senate went into Executive Session, and adjourned.

abstract: We print this morning our correspondence from the Department of the South, received via Fortress Monroe, detailing the recent lamentable reverse to our arms in Florida.
lead_paragraph: We print this morning our correspondence from the Department of the South, received via Fortress Monroe, detailing the recent lamentable reverse to our arms in Florida. The painful interest which invests the affair has been enhanced doubtless by Gen. GILLMORE's inexplicable proceeding of stopping the mails, and those to whom the past few days of torturing suspense have seemed more than weeks in duration, will read the accounts with eagerness and relief. The reports show that our brave fellows were led into a trap where they suddenly met an overwhelming force, and, there being no possible door of escape, they were mowed down by the dozen. The list of casualties foots up twelve hundred. The fighting was heroic beyond expression, and as the thrilling details are read many a sigh will be uttered that so much valor resulted in discomfiture. Our forces are reported to be intrenching themselves six miles from Jacksonville.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Reception at New-York
lead_paragraph: There was a numerous and very respectable meeting at Cooper Institute last evening, to do honor to and hear the remarks of Hon. GEO. THOMPSON, the champion of Emancipation in England. He and Major-Gen. FREMONT, who presided, were enthusiastically welcomed. Gen. FREMONT introduced Mr. THOMPSON as the representative of liberal Democracy in England, and the tried friend of America, and said he could scarcely be expected to realize the change which had taken place in the public sentiment of this country since his last sojourn among us, on the question of Slavery.

abstract: Party, the Shock to, of Abolishing Slavery
snippet: Party, the Shock to, of Abolishing Slavery
lead_paragraph: We have somewhere read a French story running somewhat in this wise: Monsieur Feuillet was traveling in a steamboat, when an explosion took place. He was transfixed by an iron spit seven feet long. The spit went in at the abdomen and passed out at the back, so that there were three feet of the spit before and three feet behind. Monsieur Feuillet was conveyed to the nearest hotel. His condition demanded all the resources of art. A surgeon being summoned, felt the patient's pulse, and asked him where he was suffering. "In the abdomen," replied the wounded man. "Indeed! How did it happen to you?" The patient thereupon detailed the sad incident of his being transfixed. The surgeon shook his head, and resumed: "Are they subject to this accident, Sir, in your family? "No," replied the patient, "not that I know. My father and mother are very old and have never been spitted. So with regard to my brothers and sisters, and my uncles and my aunts." "Very well, Sir, I required that information in order to give a correct prognosis. You experience, I suppose, considerable difficulty in lying on your back?" "Yes, Sir; it is, indeed, impossible." "Is it not easier for you to lie on your stomach?" "I experience precisely the same difficulty." "It must, therefore, be much easier for you to lie on your side." "That is the only position I can lie in." "That will suffice, Sir. It only remains to determine upon the treatment. Here the indications are very precise: either we can let the spit alone, but then you will most likely die of inflammation; or we can extract it, but then it is not probable that you will survive the operation. Science, Sir, has its limits; your fate is in your own hands; you can decide for either one treatment or the other."

lead_paragraph: We see that the Congressional Committee, appointed to investigate the charges and rumors of corruption and improper conduct on the part of Government officials, has taken rooms in Wall-street, and is about to commence its labors. We do not believe this is intended to be a mere white-washing affair, but that the committee are determined to search matters to the bottom, let the result be what it may. All honest men must desire this. But this is not enough. The committee must have the hearty cooperation of all the honest men, for all the rogues will combine against them, and with the best of intentions, and with the utmost skill and diligence, they may find that they are utterly unable to accomplish anything unless they do receive such cooperation. How shall they commence? Where, amidst the immense mass of business which has been transacted by Federal officials during the past year even, shall they begin to look for evidence of impropriety? It is of no use for them to catechise the officials themselves -- nothing, will be learned in that way. How shall they get wind of anything that has been wrong unless they are put upon the scent by some one who has been where it was, who has suffered from it himself, or seen or known of others being injured by it?

abstract: Mr. WASHBURNE, of Illinois, (Union,) caused to be read a letter from the Secretary of the Treasury, saying that it is ascertained from authentic sources that many vessels employed in the cod fishery, obtained salt to cure their fish from the British Prov inces, thereby avoiding the payment of the duty on salt incorporated with their fish, and claiming bounties the same as if they had procured salt which had paid a duty in our own ports. To prevent this, there appeared to be no provision of law. Therefore, the Secretary requested that an act be passed to the effect that hereafter no fishing bounties be allowed unless the claimants satisfactorily show that the salt which they have used has paid duty to the United States.

To prevent this, there appeared to be no provision of law. Therefore, the Secretary requested that an act be passed to the effect that hereafter no fishing bounties be allowed unless the claimants satisfactorily show that the salt which they have used has paid duty to the United States.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. To the habitues of the opera there was last night a disappointment and a surprise. Miss KELLOGG was indisposed and unable to sing; hence "Faust," which had been announced, was impossible, and the management had to go through the prosy and painful operation of transferring many tickets to the next performance of GOUNOD'S work, or of refunding the money paid for the same. This was the disappointment.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- To the habitues of the opera there was last night a disappointment and a surprise. Miss KELLOGG was indisposed and unable to sing; hence "Faust," which had been announced, was impossible, and the management had to go through the prosy and painful operation of transferring many tickets to the next performance of GOUNOD's work, or of refunding the money paid for the same. This was the disappointment. The surprise was occasioned by MISS HARRIS, who at a moment's notice repeated her performance of "Lucia," and before a cold and disappointed audience won the best honors and the most enthusiastic applause that she has yet borne off. The lady was in excellent voice, and being less embarrassed by fright than on the interesting occasion of her debut was able to do full justice to herself. Her performance was really admirable and merited all the applause that it elicited. The artists were all in good condition and added to the general effect of a time representation.

abstract: In the House of Lords on Feb. 15, Earl RUSSELL said: "The noble Earl (the Earl of Derby) put some questions to me the other evening to which I was not at the time prepared to give an answer. He referred to several dispatches and notes of Mr. ADAMS, and expressed a wish to know how far the conduct of Her Majesty's Government had been influenced by those communications.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on Feb. 15, Earl RUSSELL said: "The noble Earl (the Earl of Derby) put some questions to me the other evening to which I was not at the time prepared to give an answer. He referred to several dispatches and notes of Mr. ADAMS, and expressed a wish to know how far the conduct of Her Majesty's Government had been influenced by those communications. I have since been looking to the dates, and so far from the conduct of Her Majesty's Government being influenced by the notes of Mr. ADAMS of the 4th or 5th September, which did not reach me until a day or two later, I find that on the 3d of September the decision was taken to detain and prevent the departure of the iron-clads from Birkenhead. On that day Mr. LAYARD wrote to the Treasury desiring that they should be stopped. On referring to private letters of my own I find that I wrote from Scotland to Lord PALMERSTON on the 3d of September:

abstract: The arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship Bremen, from Southampton Feb. 17, puts us in possession of four days' later news from Europe. The discussion of the American question was continued in the British Parliament.
lead_paragraph: The arrival at this port yesterday of the steamship Bremen, from Southampton Feb. 17, puts us in possession of four days' later news from Europe. The discussion of the American question was continued in the British Parliament. In reply to the assertion of Lord DERBY that the detention of the Liverpool rams was brought about under the pressure of threats by the United States Government, Earl RUSSELL read extracts from correspondence with the American Minister disproving the allegation. In reference to the claims of the United States for damages done by the Alabama and other rebel cruisers, Earl RUSSELL said that the British Government was in no way responsible for the losses, and he trusted that the United States would modify its views on the subject. The rumors that an armistice would soon be proclaimed between the Danes and the allied German forces seem to have been ill-grounded. The Danes, though in sorely tried straits, assert their determination of devoting the whole strength of the nation to the recovery of Schleswig, the whole of which, excepting the towns of Sundervitt and Alsen, they had been compelled to evacuate. On the 13th, the intrencked position of the Danes at Duppel was attacded by the allies, who were unsuccessful, and it was determined that to carry the position by direct assault would involve too much waste of life. Consequently mortar batteries were being erected with a view of dislodging them from their intrenchments. The Prussians had occupied the post of Kiel. The Danish frigate Neil Zuil was cruising in the British Channel after Prussian and Austrian vessels, thereby exciting much interest.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met specially yesterday, their first meeting in over a week. A resolution was adopted requesting the Comptroller to report to the board why he refuses to perfect the purchase of the Fort Gansevoort property.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met specially yesterday, their first meeting in over a week. A resolution was adopted requesting the Comptroller to report to the board why he refuses to perfect the purchase of the Fort Gansevoort property. A resolution by Mr. JONES was adopted; requesting our members of the Legislature to protest against the passage of the proposed act to give over the control and management of our markets to a special commission. A resolution was adopted requesting the Comptroller to give information why the laborers in the departments do not get their pay. The Committee on Arts and Sciences presented reports in favor of procuring a portrait of Ex-Mayor OPdyke, and to purchase Clark Mills' duplicate equestrian statue of Gen. JACKSON at the price of $33,000. Laid over under the rule. An ordinance to create eight additional Assistant Engineers of the Fire Department was presented and laid over. The Board refused to concur in the ordinance directing an issue of bonds to take up and pay the Union Defence Bonds, the Redemption Bonds to be payable Dec. 1, of this year. This will compel the insertion of the needed sum in the Annual Appropriation Bill. A report was presented and laid over in favor of donating a plot of ground on Ward's Island to the "Society for the Protection of Roman Catholic Children in New-York," created by act of the Legislature of 1863. A report adverse to allowing PATRICK F. MCGINN $600 on a sewer contract, for excess of Inspector's fees, caused by extraordinary delay, was approved. The Mayor vetoed the resolution to pay the laborers in the Croton Department $2 per day, because there is no appropriation to meet the increased expense. The Board concurred in appointing the Commissioners of Deeds over the Mayor's veto that were reappointed this year, after a failure of meeting with the Mayor's approval last year, and adjourned to Thursday, at 3 o'clock, P.M.

abstract: Monday evening a most brilliant and enjoyable hop -- it were better, called a ball -- was given at the Metropolitan. The occasion was one in honor of Mr. and Mrs. J.W. FLORENCE, whose hundredth night and over of winning golden opinions in the "Ticket-of-Leave Man" had induced the numerous boarders of this favorite hotel, of which Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE are inmates, and some of their friends outside, to extend to them the compliment. It was indeed a brilliant affair. All around was intelligence, beauty, taste, all around was enjoyment, and all around united in conceding this hop to be the success of the season. To the Messrs. LELAND was intrusted its management and their success in contributing to the pleasure of their guests received more than the ordinary acknowledgements. Enjoyment would have reigned supreme were it not that it had to share its throne with hospitality.

abstract: The news from the Army of the Potomac is up to 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time Gen. CUSTER'S Cavalry were sharply engaged with the enemy beyond Madison Court-house, in the direction of Stannardsville, on LEE's left flank. Madison Court-house was in our possession. Our dispatch states that KILPATRICK had been heard from, and that reports were favorable.
lead_paragraph: The news from the Army of the Potomac is up to 9 o'clock yesterday morning, at which time Gen. CUSTER's Cavalry were sharply engaged with the enemy beyond Madison Court-house, in the direction of Stannardsville, on LEE's left flank. Madison Court-house was in our possession. Our dispatch states that KILPATRICK had been heard from, and that reports were favorable. LEE's communications with Richmond are reported cut. KILPATRICK crossed the Rapidan on Saturday night, and at once penetrated to Spotsylvania Court-house, from which point he was to operate in LEE's rear, even to the very gates of Richmond. A report was current at Culpepper yesterday morning, to the effect that he had whipped HAMPTON's rebel legion badly, and taken several hundred prisoners, including HAMPTON himself. The cavalry operations are the leading feature of the present movement.

abstract: Oo Monday morning about 11 o'clock, Gen. LEDLIE'S Brigade arrived in this City and quartered in the Park Barracks. They came from Fortress Monroe on the steamers Prometheus, Combria and New-Jersy, and are a fine, hardy looking set of men. They were with Gen. McCLELLAN on the Peninsula, and have been in nearly all the battles of the Army of the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: Oo Monday morning about 11 o'clock, Gen. LEDLIE's Brigade arrived in this City and quartered in the Park Barracks. They came from Fortress Monroe on the steamers Prometheus, Combria and New-Jersey, and are a fine, hardy looking set of men. They were with Gen. MCCLELLAN on the Peninsula, and have been in nearly all the battles of the Army of the Potomac. The brigade is composed of the Eighty-first, Ninety-sixth and Ninety-eighth Regiments New-York Volunteers. The Eighty-first Regiment is commanded by Col. JACOB J. DE FORREST. They went into the field, two years ago, 1,050 strong, and return with but 370, all of whom have reenlisted. The gallant Colonel has been with the regiment since its formation; be enrolled the first and the last man, and was desperately wounded at Seven Pines.

abstract: There has been no intelligence, either directly or indi rectly, from Gen. SHERMAN; for several days -- not since his reported arrival at Selma, which still remains to be fully confirmed. A rebel dispatch from Atlanta, dated Feb. 26, states, however, that SHERMAN's advance had reached "Pearly Pear," a point we cannot find on any map, but, undoubtedly east or southeast of Meridian, which point SHERMAN had positively reached by the 20th or 22d of February, for on the latter day Bishop POLK telegraphed to the rebel War Department that SHERMAN had "halted at Meridian, evidently awaiting the arrival of cavalry reinforcements." But as the latest dispatch is also from rebel sources, we may be sure that he did not tarry long at Meridian. The cavalry force which was destined to cooperate with SHERMAN, was SMITH and GRIERSON's expedition from Memphis, which, as is already known, returned to the latter point, having failed in its objects, after penetrating into Mississippi one hundred and thirty miles, or over half way to Meridian. This failure may embarrass SHERMAN considerably, though he can take care of himself abundantly well without cavalry, but he needed such a force to make his march felt by the enemy, especially if he moves across the State of Alabama, as he has across Mississippi. The cause of the failure of the cavalry is said to have been the concentration of all the rebel cavalry at West Point, Miss., to oppose Gen. SMITH'S column. As our force was about ten thousand strong, it ought to have been equal to all the rebel cavalry that Bishop POLK could muster. We are inclined to think that the leader of the expedition was deceived as to the enemy's strength, and that he did not make an earnest attempt to get through, for no severe fighting is reported, and our retreat seems to have been unnecessary. The charge that delay on the start was caused by the slow movements of Pennsylvania and New-Jersey regiments, may have some truth in it, but as there were but two of these regiments, and they new and raw at that, they ought not to have been considered essential to the expedition, or of consequence enough to have caused an hour's delay. The failure is more likely attributable to want of pluck and dash in its Commander. GRIERSON's former exploits were a basis of hope for this expedition, but he was only second in command this time.

The cause of the failure of the cavalry is said to have been the concentration of all the rebel cavalry at West Point, Miss., to oppose Gen. SMITH'S column. As our force was about ten thousand strong, it ought to have been equal to all the rebel cavalry that Bishop POLK could muster. We are inclined to think that the leader of the expedition was deceived as to the enemy's strength, and that he did not make an earnest attempt to get through, for no severe fighting is reported, and our retreat seems to have been unnecessary. The charge that delay on the start was caused by the slow movements of Pennsylvania and New-Jersey regiments, may have some truth in it, but as there were but two of these regiments, and they new and raw at that, they ought not to have been considered essential to the expedition, or of consequence enough to have caused an hour's delay. The failure is more likely attributable to want of pluck and dash in its Commander. GRIERSON's former exploits were a basis of hope for this expedition, but he was only second in command this time.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to protect overland emigration was passed; also the resolution of thanks to reenlisted veterans. Mr. BUCKALEW submitted a minority report on the repeal of the Fugitive Slave Law, which was ordered printed. The $20,000,000 Five-forty Loan Bill was taken up and passed, after some slight amendments, one of which makes the principal of the loan payable in gold. The Senate insisted on its amendment to the Whisky Bill, and agreed to submit the measure again to the House for final action.

abstract: In the Senate, this evening, a message was received from the Governor. Informing the Senate that when he called the attention of the Secretary of War to the inequalities of the draft as detrimental to the State of New-York, that official appointed WILLIAM F. ALLEN, of this State...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, this evening, a message was received from the Governor, informing the Senate that when he called the attention of the Secretary of War to the inequalities of the draft as detrimental to the State of New-York, that official appointed WILLIAM F. ALLEN, of this State, JOHN LOVE, of Indiana, and CHAUNCEY SMITH, of Massachusetts, a commission for determining upon the mode for correcting them. This commission have come to the unanimous conclusion that the enrollment for the State of New-York, under the act of March 3, 1863, was imperfect, erroneous and excessive, especially so with reference to the cities of New-York and Brooklyn. The Commission, after due consideration, recommend that the quota of 60,378 men allotted to this State under the call of the President on Oct. 17, 1863, be reduced to 52,858, with a corresponding reduction under the call of Feb. 1, 1864.

abstract: A serious evil is being committed by numerous towns and counties about New-York, in offering great inducements to bounty brokers, and little or no inducement to recruits. It is done in this way. A town meeting is held, at which the tax-payers raise a certain amount to pay each recruit $300.
lead_paragraph: A serious evil is being committed by numerous towns and counties about New-York, in offering great inducements to bounty brokers, and little or no inducement to recruits. It is done in this way. A town meeting is held, at which the tax-payers raise a certain amount to pay each recruit $300. This is placed in the hands of a committee, and they, to expedite matters and save trouble, make a contract with some man to procure for them the number of recruits they need, binding him to pay each recruit at least $100, but leaving it optional with him whether or no he gives the recruit any more. This is, of course, a great inducement for bounty brokers to send recruits to these places, and very many ignorant men are so enlisted; they receive their $100, and are satisfied until they reach Riker's Island or some other military depot and learn how they have been wronged. Gen. Dix's office is completely overrun with these poor fellows, many of whom have families dependent upon them, asking him to get for them the $200 to which they are justly entitled; he is, however, obliged to inform them that he can do nothing for them. The agreement entered into between the town or county and the broker rendering it impossible. West Farms, Richmond County, S. I., and many other towns and counties have made such contracts. It seems a shame that the recruit who leaves his family to serve his country should have but $100 or $150 to leave with his wife and little ones, and brave the chances of death, which, in many cases, would leave them entirely helpless, while the bounty broker who remains at home at his ease gets $150 or $200 for swindling him. It is also a false idea that such inducements to brokers help recruiting, as the experience of this City well shows; for since the swindling recruits has been diminished they come in nearly twice as fast as they did when it was in full feather.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors have allowed "The Association for the Benefit of Colored Orphans " the sum of $73,089 26 for the loss of their buildings, comprising the well-known Institution of the Colored Orphan Asylum, which will ever figure in history as having been heartlessly destroyed by the mob on the first day of riot rule in this City last July.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors have allowed "The Association for the Benefit of Colored Orphans" the sum of $73,089 26 for the loss of their buildings, comprising the well-known Institution of the Colored Orphan Asylum, which will ever figure in history as having been heartlessly destroyed by the mob on the first day of riot rule in this City last July. The amount claimed by the association was $73,094 26. This is exclusive of a claim for loss of furniture, &c., yet to be acted upon. The difference between the amount claimed and the amount allowed is just $5. Why this difference is made does not appear in the report submitted by the Special Committee who investigated the claim, but the fact itself indicates very close scrutiny and discrimination on their part. ANN and GEORGE GREER, on a claim of $43,231 87 for buildings destroyed, have been allowed only $34,500; and among other items recently allowed are two of $13,053 and $10,000, respectively to L. HERSHBERGER and LOUIS LEVY, for loss of stock in stores.

abstract: Mr. JOSEPH KETCHUM, Sen., aged 82 years, died at his residence in Brooklyn on Tuesday evening, March 1. He was one of the oldest merchants in the produce trade in New-York. On the organization of the old Corn Exchange, in 1853, he was chosen the first President of that institution, and was subsequently elected President of the Corn Exchange Insurance Company. He was held in the highest esteem by a large circle of personal friends. As an upright merchant, no man held a higher rank. His funeral will take place on Friday.

abstract: why Refused by TIMES
lead_paragraph: A paragraph in one of our amiable cotemporaries makes it proper for us to acknowledge the receipt of sundry orders for the insertion of advertisements from the several departments at Washington, as well as from the Custom-house in this City -- and to explain why it is that no more of them appear in our columns. It seems that under some law of Congress the Government is required to pay a uniform rate for its advertising, without regard to the circulation, standing or character of the newspapers through which it is done -- and that rate is about one-fourth of our regular charges. We have, therefore, uniformly declined all Government advertising sent to us on these terms. We have a uniform rate for the insertion of advertisements, which merchants, business men and other private persons who seek the use of our columns for their own interest are required to pay; and we certainly see no reason why we should do the same work and render the same service to the Government for a fourth of the price. This whole matter of Government advertising needs revision. It may be well enough to take precautions against paying excessive charges to newspapers that have only a nominal existence; but Government cannot expect to enjoy the publicity of the leading metropolitan journals at the paltry price which it is now allowed to pay.

abstract: The Damascus at Portland, and the Etna a this port, bring two days later advices from Europe. The news, however, is not particularly important. The war in the Duchies exhibits no new feature. The Prussians and Austrians were devoting all their energies to drive the Danes, said to be 40,000 strong, from their lines of defence at Duppel. A thaw, however, had set in, materially retarding the aggressive operations by making it difficult to move artillery. Copenhagen papers say that the Danish Government have received no propositions for an armistice, and any such proposals stipulating for the evacuation of Schleswig would be inadmissible. Danish ships were cruising in search of shipping belonging to any of the German Powers, and a strong fleet was reported to have arrived off the Island of Alsen to attack the invading Prussian transports. From Great Britain we learn that the Great Eastern was sold at auction to a company formed for purchasing her. It was rumored that Government intended to withdraw the subsidy to the Galway steamship line. It was stated in Paris that the arrangements for the departure of the Archduke MAXIMILIAN for Mexico were complete. In the Italian Chamber of Deputies, the condition of the natives of that country who had been lighting for the Union and been captured by the rebeels, was under consideration. The Minister of Foreign Affairs said that he should employ all the means in his power to obtain their liberties.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The opera of "Macbeth," although one of the best that VERDI has ever written, does not grow in favor with our public. We were astonished to find a thoroughly old-fashioned house last night -- a house that left the manager comfortably in the lurch, with nothing to trouble his mind except a serious loss. The performance of the opera was in all respects admirable, as strangely enough it is apt to be on these otherwise melancholy occasions. Mme. MEDORI was in grand voice, and sang and acted with the greatest spirit. Signor BELLINI was also in excellent trim, and Signor LOTTI added very materially and agreeably to all the ensemble.

abstract: Detectives ELDER and McCORD, of this City, yesterday effected what they regard as a very important arrest. Certainly if all that appears in regard to the case at this stage of it be true the two detectives above named...
lead_paragraph: Detectives ELDER and MCCORD, of this City, yesterday effected what they regard as a very important arrest. Certainly if all that appears in regard to the case at this stage of it be true the two detectives above named have performed a most timely and valuable service. From the testimony which has thus far been adduced, it seems that a short time since the police authorities of this City and Philadelphia received information from a reliable source that there was a well-organized company, having its headquarters in New-York, with a branch of the same located in Philadelphia. That the purpose of this band was to counterfeit a large number of the Treasury notes of the Brazilian Government, and afterward to circulate them throughout the United States and Europe. Officers ELDER and MCCORD were accordingly detailed to work up the case, at least so far as this City was concerned. After diligent efforts, they yesterday succeeded in securing two men, both of whom are believed to be leaders of this band of counterfeiters. Their names are JOSE GASTON, a Portugese, and a Mr. C.A. VAN DE LINDEN, a German merchant doing business at No. 37 Broadway, in this City. The prisoners were taken before Justice HOGAN, at the Tombs Police Court, where considerable evidence was taken against them.

abstract: Major-Gen. BURNSIDE reached the Produce Exchange yesterday before the close of business. He was in citizen's dress, but was very speedily recognized, and introduced to several representative merchants by the President of the Commercial Association, Mr. ARCHIBALD BAXTER.
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. BURNSIDE reached the Produce Exchange yesterday before the close of business. He was in citizen's dress, but was very speedily recognized, and introduced to several representative merchants by the President of the Commercial Association, Mr. ARCHIBALD BAXTER. The gallant officer entered freely into conversation with the merchants present, and seemed highly delighted with the cordiality of his reception, and his obviously great popularity on the floor of 'Change. At the close of the regular business hours, Mr. BAXTER called the assemblage to order, and formally announced the object of the visit of Gen. BURNSIDE.

abstract: Parliament. Debate on U. S. Navy and Prize Courts
snippet: Parliament. Debate on U. S. Navy and Prize Courts
lead_paragraph: The debate in the English House of Commons in reference to the doings of our navy and our Prize Courts, was one of great interest to us. It covered a great deal of ground. Mr. FITZGERALD began it by moving for the papers in relation to the cases of four vessels -- the Springbok, the Science, the Margaret & Jessie, and the Saxon. The Margaret & Jessie was a rebel steamer chased by one of our vessels, as was claimed, within British waters, and fired on there; and the Attorney-General silenced this inquiry at once by saying that there was a controversy as to the facts of the case, which our Government was investigating. The other vessels were English vessels captured by our cruisers, but were separate cases, involving different questions, although all lumped in one inquiry.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a variety of bills were under consideration, and among those noticed was one for the more effectual punishment of drunkenness and vagrancy in New-York; also, to amend the act establishing the Board of Emigrant Commissioners; to establish an asylum for inebriates in New-York; to amend the act creating a Department of Public Charities and Corrections in New-York; relative to statistical records in New-York. Bills were passed incorporating the Staten Island Savings Bank; relative to the enforcement of judgment liens against real estate: incorporating the Richmond County Fire Department; two remonstrances against the riot act were presented, and a petition for another railroad in the City.

abstract: By last night's mails we received files of Richmond papers up to Feb. 29, inclusive. They contain the usual variety of interesting intelligence. From the multitude of dispatches, statements and guesses concerning Gen. SHERMAN's movements in Mississippi, we gather that he withdrew from Meridian about the 22d, and is now on his way back to Vicksburgh.
lead_paragraph: By last night's mails we received files of Richmond papers up to Feb. 29, inclusive. They contain the usual variety of interesting intelligence. From the multitude of dispatches, statements and guesses concerning Gen. SHERMAN's movements in Mississippi, we gather that he withdrew from Meridian about the 22d, and is now on his way back to Vicksburgh. A dispatch to the rebel War Department announces this officially, and it is confirmed from several other sources, though there are reports equally as late, placing him thirty miles east of Meridian, and Gen. POLK on the east side of the Tombigbee, at Demopolis, waiting to give SHERMAN battle, should he cross. These, however, may not be reliable. The rebel press view GRANT's operations at Tunnel Hill with alarm, and construe SHERMAN's movement as a feint to draw troops from JOHNSTON. The Governor of Florida announces the rebel victory at Olustee, and says that Gen. FINNEGAN would pursue our forces to Jacksonville. The rebels had already advanced to Baldwin. LONGSTREET has made a serious retrograde movement, which is differently explained by the rebel papers, some asserting that it was to avoid a flank movement, others that he could no longer subsist his army there. Gen. BRAGG's appointment as virtual Com mander-in-Chief is received by the Richmond Examiner with sarcasm and ridicule, while the Enquirer approves it, affecting to believe that, after all, he is not Commander-in-Chief, but only an advisory officer. On the whole, the tone of the rebel press is less gloomy, as they extract comfort from the late Union repulse in Florida and the withdrawal of SHERMAN, though there is a pang of grief manifest at every bushel of corn or pound of pork that our forces capture, consume or destroy as they move through rebeldom.

abstract: Baseless though we have found such of Gen. McCLELLAN'S excuses for his inactivity as we have thus far had occasion to subject to analysis, it cannot be denied that they belong to an order of facts that are grave, weighty and deserving of full consideration; and, if well grounded, they would go far to justify that delay.
lead_paragraph: Baseless though we have found such of Gen. McCLELLAN's excuses for his inactivity as we have thus far had occasion to subject to analysis, it cannot be denied that they belong to an order of facts that are grave, weighty and deserving of full consideration; and, if well grounded, they would go far to justify that delay. Were it true that the army put into the hands of Gen. MCCLELLAN, instead of being twice or thrice the strength of the rebel force on the Potomac, as we have shown, was in reality doubly outnumbered by an enemy "not less than 150,000 strong, well drilled and equipped, ably commanded and strongly intrenched;" were it true that the roads of Virginia during the Fall of 1861, instead of being unprecedentedly good, as we have proved by the testimony of a cloud of witnesses, were really "unprecedentedly" bad, as he claims -- the facts might well give us pause before passing censure on an inactivity which, however deplorable, would still have had much to warrant it. But the one excuse is as groundless as the other; both have been swept away by a scrutiny of facts; and we now proceed to show that the only remaining excuse he offers is equally without foundation.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, the bill to encourage foreign emigration was taken up and passed. Mr. GRIMES introduced a bill to amend the Act of July, 1862, to establish and equalize the grade of line officers in the navy. Mr. WADE introduced a bill making appropriations to finish certain uncompleted public works. Mr. WILKINSON rose to a personal explanation, and referred to a recent speech of Gov. ANDREW, of Massachusetts, criticising a speech of his (WILKINSON's) in reference to the comparative merits of Eastern and Western armies. Mr. WILKINSON spoke at length, praising the gallantry of the soldiers of the Army of the Potomac, and imputing the want of success to the mismanagement of its leaders. The discussion was participated in by Messrs. JOHNSON, ANTHONY, WADE and WILSON, and took a wide range, including the merits of all the Commanders of the Army of the Potomac. A resolution was adopted, inquiring under whose orders the late movement in Florida was made. The whisky tax came up in its usual turn, and the Senate refused to agree to the House request for instructions to fix the tax at 20 or 40 cents on stocks on hand, but finally concluded to submit the whole subject to a free Committee of Conference, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Rev. J.P. NEWMAN, pastor of the Washington-square M.E. Church, having been assigned by Bishop AMES to take charge of the Methodist churches in New-Orleans, was presented last evening, by the young ladies of his Church, with a beautiful flag. On the banner was inscribed, "New-York to New-Orleans greeting -- from the Washington-square M.E. Church. The meeting was opened with prayer. Several national airs were sung by the choir under the direction of Prof. J.L. BENJAMIN. The presentation speech, made by Miss H.A. KEYSER, was exceedingly beautiful and appropriate. Dr. NEWMAN, in responding, made a very effective address. His allusions to our victories and the freedom of the slave elicited warm applause. The Doctor, during his remarks, referred to the prominent part the Methodist Episcopal Church had taken, toward the suppression of the rebellion, and paid a high compliment to Bishops SIMPSON, AMES and JAMES. He denounced Copperheadism, and stated that he was in favor of peace with Union and Freedom; but if peace could not be had without sacrificing the integrity of the Government and the preservation of the Union, let us have "war, war, forever!" He spoke of the equality of of races, and said that all men were "entitled to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness," and the development of the powers God had given them. The Doctor was frequently interrupted by applause during his remarks. Bishop JAMES followed Dr. NEWMAN in a short speech. The proceedings closed with a song composed for the occasion, sung by a fine quartette, a patriotic song by the choir, and the benediction by Bishop JAMES.

He spoke of the equality of of races, and said that all men were "entitled to life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness," and the development of the powers God had given them. The Doctor was frequently interrupted by applause during his remarks. Bishop JAMES followed Dr. NEWMAN in a short speech. The proceedings closed with a song composed for the occasion, sung by a fine quartette, a patriotic song by the choir, and the benediction by Bishop JAMES.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many or which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: MUNICIPAL REFORM. A most salutary reform is proposed in the mode of conducting City elections, by the Citizens' Association, a newly-organized body of influential citizens. It is that meetings of the people should be called in each ward, and a President and officers elected for a Ward Association. The President will then appoint from the several ward election districts one hundred persons as an Executive Committee, who will apportion themselves into District Committees.
lead_paragraph: MUNICIPAL REFORM. -- A most salutary reform is proposed in the mode of conducting City elections, by the Citizens' Association, a newly-organized body of influential citizens. It is that meetings of the people should be called in each ward, and a President and officers elected for a Ward Association. The President will then appoint from the several ward election districts one hundred persons as an Executive Committee, who will apportion themselves into District Committees. These latter will record all voters in their respective districts, visit them, and induce them, if possible, to become members of the association. Before the period of elections, each District Committee will appoint a member of the association toward a Ward Committee on Candidates, who will examine the claims, qualifications and antecedents of candidates, and finally present a reliable ticket for the suffrages of the ward. In this way, it is thought that nominations will be taken from the hands of corrupt primary electors, and men be elected to office in whom the public may have confidence. The general misgovernment of the City, and the monstrous increase of taxes, has led to this step. The experiment of reform is being pushed with vigor.

abstract: The buildings being erected for the use of the Metropolitan Fair are rapidly approaching completion. Their location (the Palace Garden, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, and Fourteenth and Fifteenth streets) has been well selected, and is of easy access from all parts of the City, by stages and cars. The work is being done by the Fair Committee on Organization, of which Mr. C.E. DETMOLD is Chairman. The ground, according to the present plan, is over two hundred feet square. It will be divided into a grand building, 150 by 160 feet, in which all of the principal stalls will be located. An art gallery, 50 by 160 feet, which will probably contain on the day of exhibition one of the finest collections of paintings and statuary ever brought together in this country; a restaurant, 75 by 95 feet, to which will be attached a spacious kitchen; the machine, printing-press and carriage rooms, and a suitable place for cattle, will be included among the apartments devoted to special purposes.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. They adopted, by unanimous vote, the resolution to purchase and have erected at some suitable place in the City CLARK MILLS' duplicate bronze equestrian statute of JACKSON, at a cost of $33,500. The original cost $52,000, and the mould from which the casts were made has been destroyed by fire, so that there will be no other fac-simile taken. The duplicate was prepared for the State of Virginia, but the rebellion interposed an insurmountable obstacle to the completion of the terms of the contract for it. The board adopted the resolution to appropriate $12,000 for the erection of a monument over the Catholic soldiers' grave-plot in Calvary Cemetery under the auspices of the Joint Committee on National Affairs. This resolution passed both Boards last year, but failed to receive the Mayor's signature, and the year was too near the end to permit it to become a law by default. A resolution to widen the esplanade in front of the City-Hall twenty-nine feet, was referred. The Mayor sent in two memorials, one signed by merchants and owners of real estate, and the other by cartmen in the lower wards, invoking action of the Common Council "to abate the nuisance caused by the form and construction of the rails laid down in Washington, West, Greenwich, South, Water and Front streets." The message and memorials were referred to the Special Committee appointed a short time ago to consider this subject, (on a resolution presented by Alderman RYERS,) and who are now engaged in taking testimony and hearing suggestions pertinent to it. The Mayor also sent in complaints of citizens that the fat-boiling establishment at the foot of West Fortieth-street, and the varnish factory in West Thirty-ninth-street, are nuisances, which also were referred. The Comptroller replied to a resolution of inquiry that some of the laborers in the departments do not get their pay promptly because of delays necessarily incident to a rigid auditing system he has adopted, as required by the charter, which prevents payments of fraudulent pay-rolls till special examinations are made and the improper claims are excluded. These examinations were, by his order, turned over by the Auditor to the City Paymaster, who was required to examine doubtful parties under oath. But Mayor GUNTHER declines to countersign any warrants for payment unless the Auditor certifies. This, the Comptroller says, is impossible, as the Auditor cannot verify what he has not examined, and does not know the correctness of. The resolution to prevent the use of the carriage-way of Battery-place and the sidewalk adjoining Pier No. 1, N.R., from being used for commercial purposes by the temporary storage of casks, bales, &c., was laid over upon the understanding that the obstructions will speedily be removed by the owners. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. on Monday.

abstract: The revenue-cutter Miami was yesterday sent to St. Johns, to take on board the pirates of the Chesapeake, and bring them to this City. Deputy Marshal YOUNG was sent by Marshal MURRAY to proceed on board the cutter to St. Johns to receive the prisoners from the British authorities. The cutter will proceed from here to Halifax, and convoy the Chesapeake to this City.

abstract: Assigned to Duty at Richmond
lead_paragraph: JEFF. DAVIS has assigned Gen. BRAGG, the most unfortunate of all his officers, to duty at Richmond, charged, as the order says, "with the conduct of military operations in the armies of the Confederacy." This, we suppose, is a position analogous to that which Gen. HALLECK has held in our army; and we judge that Gen. BRAGG's duties will be mostly of an advisory, critical, or fancy nature. The post is only created for him as a sort of refuge for one of the rebel President's personal favorites; and the rebel papers are all busy grinning at the appointment, and going over the "melancholy bead-roll" of defeats of which BRAGG has been the hero, and for which he has been crowned with such honors as JEFF. DAVIS can give. But let BRAGG rejoice at his new field of inaction. He has made his last retreat; he has had his last defeat.

abstract: The veteran regiments of this brigade, viz.: The Eighty-first, Ninety-sixth and Ninety-eighth Regiments, New-York State troops, Wednesday left their barracks at the Park, and escorted by the Eighth and Thirty-seventh Militia Begiments, were reviewed at the City Hall by the Mayor and Common Council; they then marched up Broadway, and at the Fifth-avenue Hotel were reviewed by Maj.-Gen. BURNSIDE; from there they marched to the arsenal, corner Thirty-fifth-street and Seventh-avenue, where a collation was prepared for them, and after partaking of it, they were escorted to the Hudson River Railroad depot, and took the cars for Albany. The Eighty-first Regiment was raised in Oswego and Oneida Counties, and is composed of a fine set of men. They were with Gen. MCCLELLAN all through the Peninsular campaign, and were afterward with Gen. FOSTER's Charleston expedition, at which time their Colonel (DE FORREST) was in command of the brigade and won honors for his and their bravery. Since that time they have been in North Carolina doing outpost duty in the Dismal Swamps, fifteen miles from any other troops, and where their pickets were nightly firied upon by the enemy. Their original colors were so torn and service-worn as to be useless, and were sent to the State Department at Albany, where they now are. A second set was presented them by the Messrs. INGERSOLL, of Oneida County.

abstract: Longstreet's Arrival at Richmond
lead_paragraph: -- We hardly think any one need be made unhappy by the announcement which comes to us from Washington, that LONGSTREET's forces have arrived at Richmond. In the Lynchburgh Republican of Feb. 26 we find a statement, taken from the Jonesboro Telegraph of Feb. 24, and the Bristol Gazette of Feb. 25, to the effect that LONGSTREET's forces had fallen back to Greenville and Bull's Gap. In addition, a dispatch from Gen. LONGSTREET himself, dated Greenville, Tenn., Feb. 27, appears in Richmond papers of the 29th. The railroad communication from Greenville to Richmond is notoriously inadequate for the rapid transportation of large bodies of troops, and it would have been a physical impossibility for LONGSTREET's command to reach the rebel capital by that or any other route between the dates named (Feb. 27) and March 2. Then, again, had LONGSTREET left the vicinity of Knoxville to make a rapid movement to Richmond, the papers published at Bristol or Lynchburgh would assuredly have made some reference to the passing of troops through those places. Finally, if LONGSTREET had been ordered east, his troops would unquestionably have been at once incorporated with LEE's army, and the probabilities are altogether against their going further than Gordonsville. It is pretty plain, therefore, that KILPATRICK need not fear finding LONGSTREET's men behind the Richmond fortifications when he shall reach them, as we hope he has already done.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SPRAGUE presented the memorial of merchants of Rhode Island in  behalf of the South American Steamship Company. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, presented a joint resolution of the Legislature of Kansas, praying for the removal of all Indians from that State to the Indian Territory. Mr. WILSON called up the House bill extending bounties to April 1, and he read a letter from the Secretary of War recommending its immediate passage.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SPRAGUE presented the memorial of merchants of Rhode Island, in behalf of the South American Steamship Company. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, presented a joint resolution of the Legislature of Kansas, praying for the removal of all Indians from that State to the Indian Territory. Mr. WILSON called up the House bill extending bounties to April 1, and he read a letter from the Secretary of War recommending its immediate passage. The bill was passed. Mr. DAVIS, of Kentucky, submitted an amendment to the joint resolution amending the Constitution; the amendment provides that no person or negro whose mother or grandmother was a negro, shall be a citizen, or hold any civil or military office; that the States of Maine and Massachusetts shall constitute one State to be called East New-England; the States of New-Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island and Connecticut, another State to be called West New-England. The bill to prevent military interference in elections was called up, and Mr. POWELL addressed the Senate at length in favor of the bill, when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Army and Navy Gasette on Danish and Virginia Campaigns
snippet: Army and Navy Gasette on Danish and Virginia Campaigns
lead_paragraph: The British Army & Navy Gazette calls attention to the recent campaign of Austrians and Prussians in the Duchies, as contrasting, in its energy and efficiency, with the slow and fruitless campaigns in the American civil war. The Allies, it states, had before the battle of the Dannewerke about the same number as the Federalists in the battle of Chancellorsville, and the Danes were not larger than LEE's army; yet in ten days the Danes were defeated a number of times, pursued uninterruptedly, and finally entirely driven out of their ancient possessions. The Gazette finds in this an instance of the value of European organization and discipline, as opposed to our brute confidence in numbers, and our lack of both of those essentials.

abstract: The Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing European advices to the 21st, an interesting telegraphic summary of which has been forwarded. On the 15th inst., after nightfall, the pirate Georgia stealthily vacated her rendezvous in the harbor of Cherbourg, and we may soon expect to hear of her further depredations upon our commerce. Several United States vessels arrived in the roadstead on the night of the Georgia's escape.
lead_paragraph: The Canada arrived at Halifax yesterday, bringing European advices to the 21st, an interesting telegraphic summary of which has been forwarded. On the 15th inst., after nightfall, the pirate Georgia stealthily vacated her rendezvous in the harbor of Cherbourg, and we may soon expect to hear of her further depredations upon our commerce. Several United States vessels arrived in the roadstead on the night of the Georgia's escape. The case of the Pampero had again been before the Court of Exchequer in Edinburgh, and the defendants asked for a dismissal, on the ground that the proceedings were informal. The matter was adjourned, that opportunity for a reply might be afforded the Crown Solicitor. In Parliament, alleged seizures by Federal cruisers of British vessels in neutral waters had been under discussion, and in the course of the debate it was shown that the instructions by the United States Government, to naval officers, was very explicit against capturing under such circumstances, and that if a case of this kind occurred, prompt reparation would doubtless be made. A vague rumor, on the 18th, that France intended soon to recognize the Confederacy,caused a rise of the rebel loan stock, but next day doubts of the truth of the rumor sent the stock back to its old figures. There was no material change in the situation of the Dano-German war. The Austrians, on the 18th, attacked the Danes in their intrenchments at Duppel, and were repulsed. An Austrain fleet of twelve war vessels had been ordered to cruise for the purpose of checkmating Danish naval operations. A growing feeling in favor of the Danes was manifest in the tone of French and English sentiment, while the high handed proceedings of Prussia and Austria were exciting the jealouises of the minor German States to such an extent that opposition was not improbable. The Italian Government were openly purchasing supplies and war material in France, and an impression prevailed that this was ominous of the inauguration of war on the Adriatic. MAXIMILIAN was making farewell visits prior to his departure for his Mexican Kingdom. The Poles, in late operations, had gained further successes over the Russians.

abstract: At the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, held yesterday afternoon, deep and feeling expressions of condolence for the deceased, and sympathy with his remaining relatives, were expressed. The President, A.A. Low, Esq., stated that it was customary with all public bodies to adjourn in respect to the memory of an esteemed departed member; and it was accordingly decided that this ...
lead_paragraph: At the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, held yesterday afternoon, deep and feeling expressions of condolence for the deceased, and sympathy with his remaining relatives, were expressed. The President, A.A. LOW, Esq., stated that it was customary with all public bodies to adjourn in respect to the memory of an esteemed departed member; and it was accordingly decided that this Board adjourn for a fortnight, and that suitable resolutions, expressing the feelings of the Board, be prepared. Mr. JONES, President of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company, read a statement he had prepared, giving a sketch of the life of Mr. TILESTON from the time he joined the Chamber in 1833, since which time he had been connected with the shipping and commercial interests of the City, President of the Phoenix Bank, and had held many offices of trust. Mr. JONES continued for some time, and spoke in high and eulogistic terms of Mr. TILESTON. The Secretary, Mr. JOHN A. STEVENS, after an appropriate speech, presented a suitable preamble and set of resolutions which were unanimously adopted. The funeral took place from the residence of the late Mr. TILESTON, corner Fifth-avenue and Fourteenth-street. The house was filled with numbers of our prominent citizens and the friends and relatives of the deceased. The remains were placed in a handsome rosewood coffin, beautifully ornamented, and on the silver plate of which was engraved:

abstract: Mississippi River Fortifications, The
lead_paragraph: -Few people are aware of the large number of impregnably-fortified works that are being constructed along the Mississippi River by our troops -- mainly by our negro troops. By impregnable we do not mean that all these works are absolutely beyond the possibility of capture by any conceivable force; but simply that they cannot be taken by any enemy that could be marched or massed against them -- not, for instance, by the whole military power of the Southern Confederacy, much less by the combined armies and navies of France and England. The rebels indicated to us what were the strongest natural positions on the river; and some of them they made a hard effort to hold, but in each and every instance they failed for want of the proper appliances. These positions, such as Port Hudson, Vicksburgh and others, have been taken hold of by our troops, and around them have been built new works, compared with which the rebel works were contemptible, while our appliances of artillery and our iron-clad naval supports add indefinitely to their superiority. We venture to say that if JEFF, DAVIS were to marshal all the armies of the South against Vicksburgh, he could not capture it in twenty years, nor, for that matter, in twenty centuries And there are twenty places on the Mississippi River of which the same thing might be said. We should like to inquire of JEFF, DAVIS what he proposes doing about it?

abstract: The great Sanitary Fair of the great-hearted Brooklyn people still pursues its unwavering course of complete success. It will certainly last to-day and to-morrow -- how much, if any, longer, is yet undecided. Though stocks of goods and supplies of eatables are again and again exhausted, they are as often replenished, and the attendance is undiminished. The Picture Gallery still fascinates admiring crowds; the great hall is still thronged with a surging mass of wondering, curious people, intent on inspection and investment; the Knickerbocker Hall and the New-England Kitchen still attest their abundant capacity and complete management, by feeding and sending away satisfied thousands of hungry ones. The Kitchen has been a great institution; it has been managed in a capital manner; the attention at the tables has been faithful beyond expectation; the quality and cooking of the food most excellent, while the good, old time fashions and customs and courtesies of our grandmothers have been a source of enjoyment to an appreciative heart, and have given zest to a vigorous appetite. We know whereof we speak. We entered and ate in cog., and Jerusha administered unto us our fill of pork and beans, pumpkin-pie, apple-sauce and sweet cider. The representation is faithful, for the Brooklyn people have not forgotten the traditions of their ancestors, any more than they have forgotten how to be patriotic, liberal and noble-hearted.

abstract: His Army well fed; Richmond Enquirer's Testimony
snippet: His Army well fed; Richmond Enquirer's Testimony
lead_paragraph: A letter from the camp of the Twenty-third Virginia Regiment, dated Morton's Ford, Feb. 25, says: "All's quiet along our lines. MEADE has evinced no disposition to be hostile since his attempt at an advance on the 6th, which proved a failure, and at which time he undoubtedly found that the 'rebels' were not, as had been reported by some lying Northern journal, in the inner ditches around Richmond. The army is now well clothed and shod, and in better health and spirits than since the war commenced. Every one seems perfectly satisfied with the action of Congress on the Currency, Tax and Military Bills. The Commissariat is doing as well as we have any right to expect. All are furnished with an abundance of good corn meal, moderate rations of bacon and beef, and frequently molasses, sugar and GENUINE coffee. The troops of this army, with but few exceptions, have reenlisted for the war. All of the Twenty-third Virginia, save some twenty odd, have signified their willingness to fight on till the last armed foe is driven from a soil they have so long polluted by their presence."

abstract: -- Mr. FAGNANI, the distinguished artist, who is spending the Winter in the City, brought with him from Paris a most admirable portrait of RICHARD COBDEN, which he has presented to the Metropolitan Fair for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission. He has expressed a wish, in making the donation, that some disposition might be made of it which should secure it a permanent place in some public gallery. It is a most excellent likeness, and Mr. COBDEN's position and eminent services to this country will render it a highly valuable addition to any public collection.

abstract: Recent Military
lead_paragraph: For some weeks, and especially for some days past, the news from the various military expeditions, and their fields of operation, has been perplexingly obscure. The where-abouts of SHERMAN's twenty thousand, and their destination -- the fortunes or misfortunes of SMITH's ten thousand cavalry -- the purposes and prospects of KILPATRICK's gallopade -- have been problems of the most profound and absorbing interest, and only inferior in immediate importance to these were the questions of LONGSTREET's location, of the significance of GRANT's demonstrations from Chattanooga, and of the prospect of a cooperative movement against Mobile from New-Orleans. Beside all these, we were held in suspense for a day or two as to the character and extent of our disaster in Florida.

abstract: And Circulating Amnesty Proc.
lead_paragraph: The Government has appointed a commission to visit all camps where rebels prisoners are confined, and administer to them the oath of allegiance under the Amnesty Proclamation. There will not be any very general rush on the part of these prisoners to avail themselves of the benefits of the amnesty; but if even one in ten of all the rebels in our hands take the oath, it will diminish the army of JEFF. DAVIS by at least four thousand men, or about ten of the average rebel regiments. At a recent visit to a camp of five thousand rebel prisoners, we were informed by the Commandant of the post that over a thousand of them had expressed their anxiety to join our navy. And it may be found that even as large a proportion as this, one-fifth, will come forward from all the camps.

abstract: At the outbreak of the rebellion no business suffered more severely than that of the dry goods merchants of this City, but with characteristic energy they soon set to work to repair their fortunes. Generally, they have met with unexpected prosperity. They are now heartily in earnest to raise funds for the Sanitary Commission, as will be noticed by the list we publish commencing their subscriptions for the Metropolitan Fair. The object is worthy of their liberality. They evidently believe that those who can pursue their avocations in ease and safety at home, should at least aid and comfort the sick and the wounded who fall at the front, fighting our battles.

abstract: U. S. vs. Sally Magee Steamship, >amp;c.-Fees of Appraisers; U. S. vs. Nassau Steamship. Costs in Prize Case
snippet: U. S. vs. Sally Magee Steamship, >amp;c.-Fees of Appraisers; U. S. vs. Nassau Steamship. Costs in Prize Case
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. The Steamer Nassau. -- This case came up on a question of costs. The vessel was condemned as a prize. The libel was filed and prosecuted in the name of the United States District Attorney. Mr. Upton appeared as counsel for captors in the case under the appointment of the Secretary of the Navy. Mr. Sandford appeared as counsel appointed by the two Commanding Officers of the capturing vessels. Bills of costs were taxed and filed in behalf of the District Attorney and Mr. Upton for $1,200 each. Mr. Sanford now claimed to have $1,050 taxed to him for the same class of services charged to have been rendered for the same parties by the District Attorney and Mr. Upton. (Stat. of March 22, 1664.)

abstract: The donations to the Metropolitan Fair are increasing daily. As the time for the exhibition lessens, the entire success of the enterprise becomes more apparent. The contribution of staples are exceedingly large. New-Hampshire has donated a flock of sheep, and Connecticut all sorts of Yankee notions. The Fair grounds, covering an area equal to thirty-three City lots, nearly two acres in extent, will hardly be sufficient to accommodate the different States and Societies desiring to be separately represented. An effort is being made by the Managers of the Fair to secure several buildings in the vicinity of Palace Garden, with the hope of giving to the different Departments all the space required. The contributions from Americans abroad, arriving by almost every ocean steamer, will probably be the most attractive feature of the exhibition. From Rome, Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN sends a book of very valuable engravings of CANOVA's statues. Mr. IVES, of the same City, contributes a bust of Secretary SEWARD. Messrs. CASTELLANI and D'ESTRADA, two celebrated Roman jewelers, have sent splendid specimens of gold cloth and cameos. The very handsome sum of $627 50 has been handed by Mrs. WOOD to the Committee of the Great Fair, as the entire receipts of one evening, generously assigned them, of the Olympic. Salaries, rent, &c., considered, and the munificent sum of about $1,000 is the gift. It would have been much larger had the committee having this especial character of contributions in charge taken some active interest beyond the mere securing and acceptance of a night, and trusting to luck for the rest. Three or four hundred -- indeed, five or six hundred -- more tickets could have been disposed of on this, as on other occasions, were there a zealous interest taken in the matter.

abstract: ALFRED KRETZLER, of Company D, One Hundred and Sixty-second New-York Regiment, who resides at No. 24 Downing-street, in this City, is a fine looking intelligent youth, some twenty-two years of age. At Port Hudson he suffered frightful injuries, and his escape from death was marvelous. A shell burst near him, took off his right leg near the thigh, his right arm above the elbow, broke his jaw and carried away the flesh under it, tore off the flesh of the left thigh, and broke the forefinger of the left hand. From these injuries he recovered, and has been supplied by Surgeon MCDOUGAL, Medical Director of the Department of the East, with an artificial arm and hand, and will be with a leg so soon as the stump will bear it. This young man is but a wreck of his former self, and, of course, unable to resume his trade. He was a member of Hook and Ladder Company No. 6, and the company intend giving a ball for his benefit, on the 1st of April, at Irving Hall. There are none, certainly, with the facts of young KRETZLER's case known to them, who will not heartily aid the generous purpose of No. 6.

abstract: Gen. KILPATRICK has been heard from. Gen. BUTLER telegraphs from Fortress Monroe to the President that the expedition has reached our lines after penetrating the suburbs or outer fortifications of Richmond, and losing 150 men in skirmishes. Among the missing are Cols. DAHLGERN, COOK and LITCHFIELD, the two former supposed to be prisoners. KILPATRICK is said to have destroyed a large portion of the Virginia Central Railroad, several mills along the James River, and other valuable property. But that kind of work will scarcely seem a sufficient motive to the public for the splendid gallop, and curiosity is still keenly felt for an explanation.

abstract: On Thursday the Academy of Music was crowded to its utmost extent with a most brilliant and fashionable audience to witness the third commencement of the Bellevue Hospital Medical College. Long before the hour of opening, the Academy was filled and hundreds were turned away unable to gain even standing-room. The exercises were commenced by the "Wedding March," the orchestra under the lead of Mr. CARL BERGMAN, after which the opening prayer was offered by the Rev. Dr. BEACH. The President of the College, Prof. ISAAC E. TAYLOR, then conferred the degree of Doctor of Medicine on the following gentlemen:

abstract: Mayor GUNTHER has vetoed a resolution of the Common Council authorizing the lease of the upper part of a building in Nassau-street, owned by FERNANDO WOOD, for a District Court, on the ground that the floor as well as the rent is too high, -- that the locality of the building is bad for the purpose, that public proposals ought to have been invited, and that he knows from personal knowledge that "better quarters than those proposed can be had for less than half the money." The lease was to be for ten years at $3,000 a year.

abstract: Laird's Steam-rams, Diplomatic Correspondence on
lead_paragraph: The Tory party in England is trying very hard to excite a popular feeling against Earl RUSSELL and the Government by charging them with having yielded to menaces from the United States. The special instance in which this offence against British pride was committed, according to the statement of Lord DERBY, who leads the attack, was in the decision to stop the departure of the iron-clad steam-rams which were in process of construction at Birkenhead. On the 1st of September, it seems, according to Lord DERBY's statement, Earl RUSSELL informed Mr. ADAMS that there was no evidence sufficient to satisfy the British Government that these vessels were intended for the Confederate service, and that they could not, therefore, interfere to prevent their departure; whereas, on the 8th, he writes to inform him that "instructions have been issued to prevent their departure." As some of our own journals, sharing apparently the Tory sympathy with the rebel cause, have echoed these accusations, and have still further joined that party in attacks upon Mr. SEWARD for his action in the matter, it may be of service to rehearse the facts of the case.
