abstract: In the Senate yesterday, a report from the Secretary of War was presented, giving information respecting the arrest, imprisonment and subsequent discharge of soldiers of the Ninth Minnesota Regiment by the Missouri authorities. A bill, introduced by Mr. NESMITH, granting lands in aid of the construction of a military railroad and telegraph line in Oregon, was referred to the Committee on Public Lands.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, a report from the Secretary of War was presented, giving information respecting the arrest, imprisonment and subsequent discharge of soldiers of the Ninth Minnesota Regiment by the Missouri authorities. A bill, introduced by Mr. NESMITH, granting lands in aid of the construction of a military railroad and telegraph line in Oregon, was referred to the Committee on Public Lands. Mr. POMEROY presented the joint resolution of the Kansas Legislature favoring the donation of money and lands to aid the construction of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railroad. Mr. SHERMAN made a statement respecting the disagreement of the Committee of Conference of both Houses on the Revenue Bill, and said that inasmuch as the disagreement seemed irreconcilable, the Committee on the part of the Senate would recommend, in order to prevent the failure of the bill, that the Senate recede from its amendments. A vote was then taken on the recommendation, which was adopted by 25 against 11. Mr. BROWN called up his bill directing an additional classified census of the population and resources of certain portions of the country, but the passage of the measure was opposed by Mr. GRIMES, and it was referred to the Finance Committee. The special order concerning the interference of the military in elections was called up, and Mr. POWELL resumed his speech in favor of the bill, occupying the time until the hour of adjournment.

abstract: The United States steam transport Thames, Capt. CAREY, arrived at this port last evening, from Beaufort, N.C., and Port Royal, Feb. 28., at 3 P.M., with 3,300 bags cotton, consigned to United States Assistant-Quartermaster. She reports passing Charleston at 10 P.M. of the same night, and heard heavy firing. The steamship Arago would be detained at Port Royal until the 4th inst., to await the return of Gen. GILLMORE from Florida, who will send on dispatches for the Government.

abstract: -- A curious instance of the all-pervading influence and vigilance of the Imperial Government of France is shown in Messrs. DIDOT's great Biographical Dictionary Nouvelle Biographic Generale, which has been in course of publication in Paris for the last ten or twelve years. The volume containing "NAPOLEON" has been kept back since 1861, that justice might be done to the illustrious name, and now appears tardily with a "Biography of NAPOLEON, his Dynasty and the Members of the Bonaparte Family," filling nearly four hundred closely printed pages. The life of NAPOLEON I, ostensibly written by M. RAPETTI, but evidently draws its inspiration from a higher source. It deals less with the warlike aspects of his reign than with his civil policy in regard to France and Europe, and in connection with the Life of Louis Napoleon may be considered an authorized exposition of the Idees Napoleoniennes that have proved of so much vitality in the hands of the "Nephew of his Uncle." An interesting literary article is a sketch of the "Bibliographic Napoleonienne," in 20 pages. The writers say that the mass of works in different languages written on the subject of NAPOLEON, his character, wars, institutions, government, &c., is already so vast that it is impossible for any person to master it, or even acquire a knowledge of its extent. It gives a catalogue raisonne of about two hundred of the leading books relating to his career, but which only form a very small portion of the whole number extant.

abstract: The President has received a dispatch from Gen. BUTLER, stating that Gen. abstract: Gen. Dix has within the last few days had a great number of Bounty Brokers arrested, and has either forced them to disgorge or sent them to Fort Lafayette. On Thursday he collected from them $1,200, and yesterday about the same amount. He is determined if possible to break up this swindling business, and the brokers finding they cannot keep the money are getting tired of it.

abstract: -- The Literary Exhibition of the Euclelan Society of the N.Y. University, held last evening at Niblo's Saloon, was largely attended, many not being able to obtain admittance. The speeches were all good, having the merit of brevity. The oration, by W.F. MORGAN, subject, "Our Literary Future," was exceedingly well delivered, and merited the beautiful floral basket and the enthusiastic applause with which it received. "Patriotism," by E.F. PRESTON, was well spoken. "Our National Emblem," by E.J. MORGAN, was well received. The poem, by Mr. CONWAY, full of wit and pleasant puns, elicited frequent applause. The music, under the direction of HELMSMULLER, was given with usual excellence. Altogether, the affair was successful and expressive of the spirit of the society embodied in its motto, "Always to be Best."

lead_paragraph: This beautiful book is a fine specimen of what the French call Livres de luxe -- works produced in a style which shows that the gratification of a cultivated taste has been aimed at, rather than deference to the usual prudential considerations that limit theoutlay incurred in the "getting up" of a volume. The paper and print leave nothing to be desired, and the illustrations, nearly one hundred in number, including wood cuts and chromo-lithographs of great beauty, reproduce the modern scenery and antiquities of Egypt, either from photographs or other sources of equal authenticity. The book itself is not the dry record of a traveler's progress from day to day. Mr. CLARK, with whose name we are not familiar, but who writes like a practiced author, has been deeply impressed by a visit to the land where the Nile

abstract: On Interference with Elections Bill--Senate
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, March 2. The report made by Senator SUMNER to-day, from the Committee on Slavery and Freedmen, in the bill to secure equality before the law in the courts of the United States, reviews the history of our jurisprudence in respect to the exclusion of colored testimony in the courts, and examines the laws in the several States relative to this subject. South Carolina, it appears, has never had a law excluding such testimony, yet practices exclusion. In concluding this review the report says: "It is difficult to read the provisions in a single State without impatience, but the recurrence of this injustice, expressed with such particularity in no less than fifteen States, makes injustice swell into indignation, especially when it is considered that in every State this injustice is adopted and enforced by the courts of the United States. It further appears that in no State can a slave testify against a white person, excepting that in Maryland he may testify against a white person who is not a Christian. Only under certain circumstances in Delaware and Louisiana can a free negro testify against a white person. The eccentricities of judicial decisions illustrating this branch are numerously cited -- among the consequences of exclusion are mentioned the maltreatment or murder of slaves, with impunity, and the perpetration of crime against white men, in the presence of colored persons, with the same immunity from punishment. The report traces this proscription to the barbarous ages, and makes it the offspring of Slavery originating in ignorance and prejudice. Among the ancient Greeks, a slave's testimony was not believed upon his oath, but was admissible under torture. The Romans adopted similar legal practices. In England, under the common law, this proscription was again recognized. The grounds for such injustice are examined at length, and the report concludes as follows: "It is for Congress to determine whether the proscription shall continue to be maintained."

abstract: THE SANITARY FAIR. -- This is to be the last day of the Fair, but the Academy will be opened for one or two days next week, for the accommodation of the Public Schools. Knickerbocker Hall and the New-England Kitchen will wind up their affairs tonight. There was no diminution in the throng of yesterday and evening -- every department was crowded. Contributions continue to come in. The different Life Insurance Companies sent in about $1,200. The workmen of the Navy-yard did well. Their contribution amounts to $5,000. The receipts from tickets, sales of goods, &c., reached about $15,000. Since the opening of the Fair articles lost by ladies, generally such as shawls, capes, handkerchiefs, &c., amounting to $2.223 16 in value were picked up and returned to the owners, by the Sanitary Fair Police. To-day being the last opportunity, a large crowd may be anticipated. Among the curiosties in the New-England Kitchen, the visitor's eye will be speedily caught by the copy of the Emancipation Proclamation done in pen and ink, by Mr. PAINE, and presented to the Kitchen. It is quite a remarkable specimen of penmanship-illustration. A stately free rises along one border of it, whose root is labeled 1620, the mid-trunk 1776, and the top 1863, where its foliage spreads across and forms the upper border. This, of course, is the Tree of Liberty, of which the Proclamation is so notable a fruit. The lettering of the Proclamation itself is beautifully illustrated; and in the centre is a portrait of the President, drawn with the pen from a photograph by BRADY. The effect of this is more like that of a fine steel engraving than anything done with a pen that we recollect ever to have seen. The likeness is perfect. In one corner of the plate is a section of the between-decks of a man-of-war, with a heavy gun and its gearings, and in the opposite corner a sentinel stands at the foot of the tree. The whole is inclosed in a frame of black walnut, beautifully carved in leaves of laurel and oak. The work is valued at $500, and is to be paid for by subscriptions of $5 each. The subscribers, however, do not propose to draw lots for it, but to make a present of it to President LINCOLN, at the risk of being charged with carrying coals to Newcastle.

abstract: Annual Report of Commissioners, for 1863
lead_paragraph: The Commissioners of Emigration have sent in to the Legislature their annual report, showing the number of persons landed at this port during the year 1863 to be 194,377. Of these, 37,533 were citizens not subject to bonds, and 156,844 aliens, for whom compensation was paid or bonds executed, being an increase in alien emigrants of 80,538 over 1862, 91,315 over 1861, 51,682 over 1860, 77,522 over 1859, 78,255 over 1858, and 26,929 less than in 1857; while the portion to the average of former years, since 1847, is 8,665 less.

abstract: The Third-avenue Railroad is about to be further extended; and although, through its efficient President, WM.A. DARLING, Esq., it has been working most effectually for years from the Astor House to Harlem River, yet the Company, we understand, intend to have it extended through Thirty-fourth-street to the East River, and from the Third-avenue through Fifty-sixth-street to the east side of Fifth-avenue, and from Chatham-street through Chambers-street to the east side of Broadway; and this extension will be operated on without any extra or additional fees. Mr. DARLING, the President, and the other members of the Company are confident of this extension proving a perfect success.

abstract: Ray, Dr. Wm. Porter
lead_paragraph: Dr. WM.P. RAY, the well-known traveler and litterateur, died of malignant small-pox at the hospital at Portsmouth, Va., on the night of the 1st inst. Dr. RAY was a native of Massachusetts, and a pupil of BEN BUTLER, when the latter was a schoolmaster. He entered and was graduated at Harvard College, and subsequently studied at the University of Heidelberg in Germany, from which he received the degree of Doctor of Philosophy. After completing his studies, he began to travel over the various countries of Europe on foot. His wanderings of this nature were probably more extensive than those of any man living, and at one time he wrote a series of interesting sketches of travel and life, under the title of Fourteen Thousand Miles Afoot. He returned to his native country, and studied for the ministry of the Episcopal Church, upon the duties of which he entered at Indianapolis. Before many years he left the ranks of the clergy, and joined those of literature. He came to this City, and for several years before the breaking out of the war was employed mainly in writing for the weekly Press, to which he contributed many fine descriptive and philosophic sketches and articles. After the capture of Norfolk, he went down there, and engaged in various journalistic enterprises. Latterly he has been the special correspondent of the New-York TIMES, writing for that print under the signature of "Tewksbury." He was engaged in writing for us an account of Gen. BUTLER's late movement in the direction of Richmond, when he was seized by the disease which has carried him to the grave.

abstract: Whether Gen. McCLELLAN ever would have  been ready to advance on the enemy, is a problem the solution of which is known only to Omniscience; but the spell was at length broken, not by the motion of McCLELLAN, but by a word of initiative uttered by the President. abstract: Secession and Copperheadism Spurned
lead_paragraph: The first application of the President's plan of restoring the Union has been grandly successful. Through it Louisiana has been brought completely back; and that State is to-day under a civil rule as loyal as that of New-York itself, and many would say even more so. The State officers, which have been elected by a large majority, are most earnest supporters not only of the Government, but of the administration of the Government, and can be implicitly relied upon, whatever be the effort or the sacrifice demanded.

abstract: For twenty-nine years the City Tract Society has been engaged in missionary effort in this City. As its name imports, it was primarily instituted for the purpose of promoting the interests of religion, chiefly by the circulation of tracts, and therefore it is often confounded with the American Tract Society. But the City Tract Society is not a publishing concern; it does not make nor sell books; it is ...
lead_paragraph: For twenty-nine years the City Tract Society has been engaged in missionary effort in this City. As its name imports, it was primarily instituted for the purpose of promoting the interests of religion, chiefly by the circulation of tracts, and therefore it is often confounded with the American Tract Society. But the City Tract Society is not a publishing concern; it does not make nor sell books; it is really a missionary society; its agents go forth as truth-bearers into the tenement-houses, the hospital, the prison, the asylum, the immigrant depot, the military rendezvous and the ship, meeting every man as a brother, and with words of love and deeds of kindness, seeking to draw souls into the way of life. Simple in plan, unostentatious in appearance, it has noiselessly and steadily held on its way, increasing its means and instrumentalities, and extending its influence and adapting its system to the varying wants of its field of labor.

abstract: Jacob F. Muller vs. Ferdinand Stossel. -- This was an an action brought by plaintiff against defendant, who is an emigrant boarding-house keeper, for the value of a trunk left with defendant by plaintiff. Plaintiff owed a bill for board of $6, and he alleges the trunk with its contents, worth $151, was retained as security. Plaintiff attempted to prove a tender of the money and demand of the property. The evidence showed that he went to the defendant's house with the money, placed it on the bar, keeping his hand over it, and said, "Here is the money, but you must not touch it unless you give me my trunk." Defendant's counsel contended that this was not a proper tender, as it was accompanied by language tantamount to a threat. Also that an emigrant boarding-house keeper had the same lien as an innkeeper on the luggage of his guests. The court sustained defendant in both points, and on the first one granted a motion to dismiss the complaint.
lead_paragraph: Jacob F. Muller vs. Ferdinand Stossel. -- This was an an action brought by plaintiff against defendant, who is an emigrant boarding-house keeper, for the value of a trunk left with defendant by plaintiff. Plaintiff owed a bill for board of $6, and he alleges the trunk with its contents, worth $151, was retained as security. Plaintiff attempted to prove a tender of the money and demand of the property. The evidence showed that he went to the defendant's house with the money, placed it on the bar, keeping his hand over it, and said, "Here is the money, but you must not touch it unless you give me my trunk." Defendant's counsel contended that this was not a proper tender, as it was accompanied by language tantamount to a threat. Also that an emigrant boarding-house keeper had the same lien as an innkeeper on the luggage of his guests. The court sustained defendant in both points, and on the first one granted a motion to dismiss the complaint.

abstract: The Twentieth Regiment United States Colored Volunteers, now quartered at Riker's Island, will embark to-morrow morning from this City on their way to the field. The regiment will march down Fifth-avenue, at 11 o'clock, to Fourteenth-street, down Fourteenth-street to Union-square, in front of the Union League Club House, where President KING, of Columbia College, will make the presentation address, which will be responded to by Col. M.B. BARTRAM.
lead_paragraph: The Twentieth Regiment United States Colored Volunteers, now quartered at Riker's Island, will embark to-morrow morning from this City on their way to the field. The regiment will march down Fifth-avenue, at 11 o'clock, to Fourteenth-street, down Fourteenth-street to Union-square, in front of the Union League Club House, where President KING, of Columbia College, will make the presentation address, which will be responded to by Col. M.B. BARTRAM. An address from the ladies, written on parchment by HENRY T. TUCKERMAN, will be presented with the colors, which are of the most costly description. Invitations have been extended to Major-Gen. DIX, Major-Gens. HANCOCK, BURNSIDE, ANDERSON, STANNARD, Gen. JACKSON, and a large number of other military men, who will be present. A full band of forty pieces from Governor's Island has been chosen to furnish the music. This is one of the finest bands in the army. After receiving the colors and partaking of a luncheon, the regiment will march down Broadway at 3 P.M. to the foot of Canal-street, where they will embark in the steamer Ericsson, to report to Gen. BANKS, at New-Orleans. The regiment will be in full marching order, with knapsacks, muskets, white gloves, &c. Their discipline and soldierly bearing are described as highly commendable. The Twentieth Regiment was organized under the auspices of the Union League, and is the second colored regiment that patriotic body has assisted to take the field.

abstract: The net profits of the celebration of WASHINGTON's Birthday Anniversary by the Public Schools of the City of New-York, for the objects of the institute, amounted to $700 37. The first and paramount object is to provide a home and education for the ...
lead_paragraph: The net profits of the celebration of WASHINGTON's Birthday Anniversary by the Public Schools of the City of New-York, for the objects of the institute, amounted to $700 37. The first and paramount object is to provide a home and education for the children of fallen patriot soldiers and sailors, and the "Patriotic Fund," whether procured by National, State or individual contributions, is to be devoted to this main object. Collateral and additional, as opportunities present, it is proposed to create a "Prize Position Fund," to be employed in securing advantages superior to those enjoyed in the "Patriot Orphan Home," to utilize to the world any rare talent or genius discovered in the proteges in any department of literature, science and art. Coming under this head are mentioned scholarships in several of the literary institutions of our land, and gratuitous instruction in studios of science and art.

abstract: FIRE IN WALKER-STREET. At a late hour on Friday night a fire broke out in the third floor of the buildings Nos. 48 and 50 Walker-street. The upper floors were occupied by Messrs S.G. SHAW  Co. as a blank-book manufactory. This firm estimate their loss at over $8,000, principally ...
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN WALKER-STREET. -- At a late hour on Friday night a fire broke out in the third floor of the buildings Nos. 48 and 50 Walker-street. The upper floors were occupied by Messrs J.G. SHAW & CO. as a blank-book manufactory. This firm estimate their loss at over $8,000, principally by water. They are insured as follows: -- On Stock -- Arctic, $5,000; Hartford, $5,000; Western, Massachusetts, $2,500; Phoenix, Hartford, $5,000; Northwestern, Oswego, $3,000; Mechanics', $2,500; Relief, $2,000; Kings County, $2,250; Peter Cooper, $2,500; Springfield Fire and Marine, $2,500; Pacific, $2,500; Home, New-York, $5,000; Exchange, $5,000; Northeastern Fire and Marine of Hartford, $2,500 -- Total, $47,250. On Tools and Machinery -- St. Mark's, $2,000; Firemen's Trust, $500; Relief, $1,000 -- Total, $3,500. The basement and first floor were occupied by Messrs. IVESON, PHINNEY, BLAKEMAN & Co., publishers and wholesale dealers in books. The damage to their stock, by water, is about $3,000. The following are the insurances on their stock: N.Y. Fire & Marine, $2,500; Broadway, $2,500; Merchants', $3,000; North American, $5,000; Equitable, $5,000; Citizens', $5,000; United States, $4,000; Mechanics' & Traders', $2,500; Firemen's, $2,500; Park, $3,000; East River, $5,000; Manhattan, $5,000 -- total, $45,000. JOSIAH LANE, ESQ., is the owner of the buildings. The damage to them is about $1,000. Insured fully in the Continental. Washington and American Insurance Companies. The origin of the fire is unknown.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held a short session yesterday. The legal adviser of the Board (the Corporation Counsel) sent in the opinion, in answer to a resolution of inquiry, that under the law for the special election to be held on Tuesday next, the Inspectors of Election are to canvass the votes.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors held a short session yesterday. The legal adviser of the Board (the Corporation Counsel) sent in the opinion, in answer to a resolution of inquiry, that under the law for the special election to be held on Tuesday next, the Inspectors of Election are to canvass the votes. This leaves no work at all for the district canvassers. The Board directed that the officers of election in the various districts should be notified accordingly. As there will be only one box at each poll, the Board decided that no expense shall be incurred for fitting up polls. The Board having already provided for a supply of ballots, directed the Committee on Printing and Stationery to attend to their proper distribution. By the Comptroller's recommendations authority was given him to borrow $200,000 on County bonds, to pay riot damages. The bonds will bear six per cent. interest, and be redeemable Nov. 12, 1862. The legal adviser was requested to give his opinion whether the County is liable for property destroyed during the riots which belonged to non-residents. Supervisor ELY having met with a bereavement in the loss of his mother, the board passed resolutions condoling and sympathizing with him, and as a further mark of respect to their bereaved colleague, adjourned.

abstract: The employing printers of New-York gave a grand annual dinner at the St. Nicholas Hotel on Monday evening last. A large number of the most prominent proprietors of printing houses of this City and a number from Boston were present. The table was beautifully arranged, and ornamented with statues of JOHN GUTTENBERG, Liberty, WASHINGTON, BENJAMIN FRANKLIN and a Catherdale Gothique, After the dinner had been fully enjoyed, the finest wines were produced, speeches made, toasts drank and a general good time had until a late hour. The President, CHARLES A. ALVORD, made the opening speech, paying a fine compliment to their late President, JOHN F. TROW, and tendering him a vote of thanks for the perfect manner in which he had performed his duties during the past year. Mr. ALVORD said he felt but poorly adequate to perform the duty which devolved upon him, but he would do the best he could. He said he liked the term of Employing Printer, but he liked the term of Master Printer much better, not as meaning masters of men, but masters of the art. He said the printers in this country now produced fine work, which could not be surpassed in any part of Europe, and he urged upon them one and all to work together for the advancement of their art and their own protection. His speech was well received, and frequently interrupted by applause.

abstract: A married lady, residing in the neighborhood of this city, whose husbands holds a position in the Boston Custom-house, has been one of the largest contractors in this State for furnishing supplies to the army. Her contracts during the last year for clothing, are said to have amounted to a half million dollars, and, it is reported, though we are inclined to believe this must be an exaggeration, that the total amount of all her contracts since the commencement of the war, aggregate nearly two millions of dollars. On one of her contracts she lost some money, but on the others has realized handsome profits. The business of this lady having led her to visit Beaufort, N.C., several months since, she saw neglected opportunities for speculation, which she has improved to even more advantage than her Government contracts. She established two wholesale and retail stores at or near Beaufort and Morehead City, then came back to Boston, and contracted for the materials and machinery of a steam saw-mill, the erection of which was carried on under her direction or superintendence, and the mill is now nearly if not quite ready to saw the logs which two hundred contrabands have been cutting for her in the pine forests of North Carolina. A vessel is now lying in port ready for sea, laden with supplies for the regiment of laborers in her employ. The lady to whom we refer is well educated, moves in the best circles of society, and joins with her admirable self-reliance a sound judgment. In a few years we shall doubtless and her retiring from business with an ample fortune and settled down among the millionaires of Beacon-street, or perchance in the expected Back Bay paradise of the Boston aristocracy of exclusives and fashionables. Woman are frequently the successful rivals of men in the most complicated and laborious pursuits of toil and business, and they are more healthful and happy for the exercise of mind and body which they enjoy.

abstract: -For the last four months, it has been of the most imperious necessity to Gen. GRANT that LONGSTREET should somehow or other be got out of East Tennessee. The rebels had an immense advantage of position there, and as long as they held it, it would be almost impossible for Gen. GRANT to advance from Chattanooga. We suppose there is no doubt now that LONGSTREET's army have retreated, and that the bulk of it is back in Virginia. Gen. GRANT will now, doubtless, fortify and render impregnable some one of the many commanding positions in East Tennessee, so as to block such rebel advances on this line in future as might interfere with the operations of his coming campaigns. We do not suppose that position will be Knoxville, as LONGSTREET's long campaign against this point, while in some respects showing its strength, has in very vital matters shown its weakness. Neither can it be Cumberland Gap, though that must be held. Probably our defensive line will be somewhere about Bull's Gap and Greenville, near which LONGSTREET hovered so long, and whose value he proved. In the meantime, LONGSTREET has greatly obliged Gen. GRANT in retreating from East Tennessee, and has furnished to the latter officer an opportunity which he will not be slow in embracing.

abstract: Frenchmen must give up all idea of a free press under the Bonaparte dynasty. A free press is a good thing an excellent thing for Britons or Americans, but it is quite unsuitable, in the opinion of the Emperor, to the temperament of the people of la belle France
lead_paragraph: Frenchmen must give up all idea of a free press under the Bonaparte dynasty. A free press is a good thing -- an excellent thing for Britons or Americans, but it is quite unsuitable, in the opinion of the Emperor, to the temperament of the people of la belle France -- for them the regime of avertissements and interdictions must be perpetual. NAPOLEON's dread of a free press almost amounts to a monomania, and any movement on the part of its advocates is sure to inspire him with alarm -- nay, often leads him to make use of unfair influences to thwart them. A case illustrative of the lengths to which his Majesty will go for this purpose has recently occurred in the French Senate.

abstract: Our special correspondent with Gen. KILPATRICK'S expedition sends us a full and reliable account of the late cavalry raid to the vicinity of Richmond, Virginia. Gen. KILPATRICK, it appears, left Stevensburgh on Sunday evening last,
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent with Gen. KILPATRICK's expedition sends us a full and reliable account of the late cavalry raid to the vicinity of Richmond, Virginia. Gen. KILPATRICK, it appears, left Stevensburgh on Sunday evening last, and went by the way of Chancellorsville and Spottsylvania Court-house to Beaver Dam, where he met the first armed resistance. The enemy were finally repulsed, and 32 prisoners taken. The railroad track for miles on the Central Road and several different stations were destroyed, when the command moved upon Richmond, arriving before that place early Tuesday morning. A fight was kept up within the defences of that place until near night, when Gen. KILPATRICK withdrew. That night he was attacked in camp, and again repulsed the enemy, and also on the following day, arriving Thursday at Williamsburgh with the loss of only about 150 men. Col. DAHLGREN, with a small command; destroyed the railroad at Frederick Hall and on the James River, below Goochland, destroyed the canal, six flouring mills, one saw mill, and the coal mines at Anikin's Bend. The property destroyed is valued at millions of dollars, and is the heaviest loss that has yet been inflicted upon the rebels by a raiding party. Some 300 prisoners were captured, several hundred horses and a large number of negroes. The command lived on the country. Cols. Dahlgren and Litchfield and Maj. Cook are missing.

abstract: Various Proper Modes of
lead_paragraph: -A year ago there was a terrible war among political theorists as to the precise manner in which the reconstruction of the seceded States was to be effected. Scores of nicely-pointed, elaborately-constructed highly constitutional plans were put forward, each of which was the only scientific or possible plan, and vehement debates were waged between the excited adherents to each scheme. Once at that time we suggested that the great work was not likely to be carried out upon any very scientific principle, or any principle that would be uniform as regards details and conditions. In three States the process of political reconstruction is going on -- in Louisiana, Arkansas and Tennessee. In Louisiana the first step taken was by the President, through Gen. BANKS, ordering an election for Governor and State officers, which election has just taken place, and Louisiana will now have a civil government, (limited.) In Arkansas the people first met spontaneously in convention, revised the constitution, abolished Slavery, and themselves inaugurated the measures that will soon result in the election of local civil authorities and national representatives. In Tennessee the first step taken has been in the Military Governor ordering an election throughout the State for county officers, judges, etc.; and after this preliminary labor of reorganizaion is effected, steps will be taken for crowning and completing the work. Each of these different modes of operation, as regards detail, has the approval of the President, and all of them are proper and right. There may be another mode adopted in Mississippi, another in South Carolina, and so on. All modes lead to the same desirable end, though we do not remember that any of them were indicated in advance by the theorizers.

abstract: Welcome by Kansas Legislature and reply
snippet: Welcome by Kansas Legislature and reply
lead_paragraph: Upon his return from his tour of inspection, Gen. CURTIS was formally welcomed by the Kansas Legislature. In a speech acknowledging the honor the General said: "I have just returned from a long and arduous reconnoisance along your Southern and Eastern border. I found no enemy until I had reached a point sixty miles below the Arkansas River. There my advance met with a few hundred of the enemy, who retreated and were pushed back by Col. PHILLIPS. They are still retreating. Nowhere on this side of that point or along the Eastern border do the guerrillas on bushwhackers dare to mass any considerable number of men. Within that range it may be safely said that there is no band of rebels gathered exceeding fifty. I found the soldiers defending the town on either side of the borders in Missouri and Kansas, acting in earnest and cordial cooperation. They are engaged, not in repelling or driving out guerrillas, but to use their favorite expression, killing them off. To illustrate, I found Maj. BIRCH and Capt. KELSO at Neosho, Mo., reporting how many were killed per week or month, as if they were hunting and destroying wolves or other beasts of prey.

abstract: On Tuesday next, the people are to vote upon the question whether the Constitution of our State shall be so amended as to allow voters who have enlisted in the army and left the State to vote at State elections.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday next, the people are to vote upon the question whether the Constitution of our State shall be so amended as to allow voters who have enlisted in the army and left the State to vote at State elections. We do not anticipate much opposition to their being so allowed. The evident fairness of the proposition is such that even the Copperheads dare not make any open opposition to it, though they will doubtless cast here and there a no quietly into the ballot-boxes. The Democratic party in this State is too wise to commit itself against the soldiers. One would think that they would have been too wise everywhere to do so. But in the Pennsylvania Legislature, the other day, when the question was before it, every Democratic Senator voted against allowing soldiers to vote. Perhaps, however, we ought to make some allowance for these Democrats, in consideration of their having just lost all the fruit of their factiousness in keeping the Legislature unorganized for a month or two. The Democrats of New-York, however, would hardly have been guilty of such a display of folly, however great might have been their ill-temper. They might like well enough to prevent the soldiers from voting if they could do it secretly, for that vote has been always cast overwhelmingly against them, but they are too prudent to do it openly; and so the amendment to the Constitution will be adopted.

abstract: Ovation to Twentieth United States Colored Troops at New-York
snippet: Ovation to Twentieth United States Colored Troops at New-York
lead_paragraph: The scene of yesterday was one which marks an era of progress in the political and social history of New-York. A thousand men, with black skins, and clad and equipped with the uniforms and arms of the United States Government, marched from their camp through the most aristocratic and busy streets, received a grand ovation at the hands of the wealthiest and most respectable ladies and gentlemen of New-York, and then moved down Broadway to the steamer which bears them to their destination -- all amid the enthusiastic cheers, the encouraging plaudits, the waving handkerchiefs, the showering bouquets, and other approving manifestations of a hundred thousand of the most loyal of our people.

abstract: The questions which arise ont of the rebellion are innumerable. No sooner has one come up for discussion, and after due consideration been settled, than another one with some new complication in it arises to tax...
lead_paragraph: The questions which arise out of the rebellion are innumerable. No sooner has one come up for discussion, and after due consideration been settled, than another one with some new complication in it arises to tax the brains and the patience not only of newspaper editors, but of courts, diplomatists and statesmen. Here was the case of the Chesapeake, for instance, a new case, extraordinary in some of its features and requiring some careful investigation of principles. That case was discussed, argued pro and con, and our people settled down pretty generally upon the conclusion, that so far as the vessel was concerned, there could be no proper disposal of the case which should not restore her to her owners. And this conclusion has been justified by the decision of the Admiralty Court at Halifax ordering her restoration.

abstract: by T. L., No. 3
lead_paragraph: We have said that, on the doctrine against which we are contending, our eighty years political life, or seeming political life, would present only as series of unwise and irrational proceedings. Aside from the heavy expenditures before mentioned, and whose wisdom or justice could only be maintained on the ground of their being national acts for national purposes, let us call to mind the annexation of Texas, the war with Mexico, the foreign territory thence acquired, the purchase of Florida, the proposed purchase of Cuba for $200,000,000. What meaning in all this, if the secession doctrine, or the State sovereignty doctrine, which is identical with it, has even a shadow of truth! And here we cannot help making the strange practical contradiction that has been manifested in our political course. No men have been more clamorous for what we may call the false nationality, than those who have ever sought to undermine the foundations on which alone our true nationality can rest. Whilst the North has been thus truly national, it has, in the main, been contented with the old bounds, the old territory, so beautifully unique, and which God had so manifestly made for one people, one nation, whereon to dwell apart from all the nations of the earth. To this truly national feeling it was like a "promised land," which the Divine Eye had measured off in that olden time when God made provision for "separating the people," and "determined the fore-appointed bounds of their habitation." We broke this decree in the acquisition of Lousiana, to any extent beyond the mouth of the Mississippi, and hence one most aggravating cause of our national woes. The North was content (we speak generally and mainly) with establishing the nation rather than extending it -- with making sure its foundations -- with making strong its upward growth, instead of weakening it by lateral diffusion with its utter indefiniteness and unnaturalness of circumscribing bound. But whence came the cry of annexation, territoral progress, "manifest destiny," "extension of the area of freedom," the carrying of the American flag, the symbol of our one sovereignty, over Mexico and the American Continent? Whence came filibustering expeditions having ever professedly in view such national objects as these? We heard it first, we have heard it always, from these men, these men of the South, with their partisan allies of the North, who have ever denied our true nationality, or held doctrines utterly inconsistent with any such idea.

abstract: In the Enquirer of Feb. 22 we find this paragraph: "On Saturday last a search was instituted for arms on Belle Isle, but no arms of any description were discovered, save those belonging to the Government operatives. No indications whatever were ...
lead_paragraph: -- In the Enquirer of Feb. 22 we find this paragraph: "On Saturday last a search was instituted for arms on Belle Isle, but no arms of any description were discovered, save those belonging to the Government operatives. No indications whatever were apparent of a plot among the prisoners, and the whole matter turns out to have been a myth. It is a matter of impossibility for any uprising to succeed to any great extent, as cannon, kept constantly shotted, bear upon the Island, and but a signal is needed to sweep the whole encampment; which mode of proceeding is not at all to the liking of Yankees in general, particularly when they know that keeping quiet is their safeguard."

abstract: Hunt, William, English Painter
lead_paragraph: -- The Manchester Examiner, of Feb. 12, says: "Mr. William Hunt, the well known painter in water-colors, died at his residence, Stanhope-street, Hampstead-road, at the age of 74. Mr. Hunt has exhibited in the gallery of the Society of Painters in Water-colors, since 1824. His works hale latterly formed one of the chief attractions of the annual exhibitions, and their absence will create a void that the Society will not easily be able to fill. His exquisite color and delicate manipulation were not more conspicuous than his intense perception of the beauties of those objects of still life which he so loved to paint. Nor were his powers limited to the faithful reproduction of fruit and flowers. As a painter of flesh he was, perhaps, unequalled, and his rendering of humorous phases of rustic life also was sufficient to win him an enduring reputation. His studies of landscape, sea and sky, reveal to the instructed eye a capacity for this branch of art equal to those by which he is more popularly known. Mr. Hunt was an honorary member of the Academy of Amsterdam in addition to being a member of the Water-colour Society. Although of late his infirmity has been greatly increased, Mr. Hunt has never relinquished work, except under temporary excess of indisposition. Debarred in a great measure from the pleasures of society, almost his sole delight was in his work. He may be said to have died in harness, for so lately as last Saturday, he was at his easel until mid-day, and only left it to visit the Gallery in Suffolk street, where the competition pictures of the candidates for associateships of the Water-colour Society were exhibited. Probably the last act of his life was sending his proxies for some of the competitors. During the night between Sunday and Monday, an attack of paralysis supervened upon the indisposition which had manifested itself soon after returning home from the Gallery. There was no return of consciousness, and shortly after 8 o'clock yesterday morning he expired.

abstract: Pardoning Power, The
lead_paragraph: The case of a Mr. TOWNLEY, a man of for tune, who murdered in cold blood a young lady who had rejected his addresses, has been exciting a great deal of agitation in England, owing to the extraordinary manner in which he has escaped punishment. He was duly convicted of the offence; the plea of insanity was set up on the trial without effect, and he was sentenced to death. But some of his personal friends induced a surgeon and two of the "visiting justices" of the jail in which he was confined, to examine him and certify to the Secretary of State that, though he might not have been insane at the time of the commission of the offence, he had since become so, and was then actually non compos. Under these circumstances, the act of Parliament permits the Secretary to remit the capital sentence, and send the criminal to a lunatic asylum, and Sir GEORGE GREY accordingly, without more ado, reprieved TOWNLEY, and put him into the hands of a doctor. The result was a great outcry, as it was widey believed that the culprit owed his escape to his social position rather than to disease. A subsequent examination by more impartial judges established the fact that he was not insane, and he has accordingly been remanded to jail, but his sentence has been commuted to "penal servitude" for life.

abstract: The British have met with an unexpected success in their war against the Maori. They have taken the pah of Rangariri, and killed or captured almost the whole of its garrison. This is regarded as a glorious achievement by the Australasian papers, which magnifies its importance and predicts from it a speedy termination of the New-Zealand rebellion. The following brief narrative of the affair will convey a tolerably correct idea of its nature and significance.

abstract: Feb. 26
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ocean Queen, from Aspinwall Feb. 26, arrived yesterday. The Constitution had arrived at Panama from San Francisco, with $2,600,000 in gold, $2,000,000 of it for England, part of which was on account of the United States Government. Panama was quiet. The "Congress of the Peoples" of the Spanish American States was soon to assemble in Panama. It will take into consideration the encroachments of France and England on the American Continent, and to concert measures for resistance to further attempts at domination by European Powers. A "treaty of alliance" had been agreed upon between Ecuador and Colombia. In Peru a reform in the currency had been established and a new coinage authorized. Business in Chili had been very profitable. Some of the Joint Stock Companies had declared very large dividends.

abstract: The energetic efforts making to fill the ranks of the veteran regiments of the Second Army Corps are to receive further impetus at Tammany Hall, tonight, by a grand war meeting, gotten up under the auspices of the war sachems of that warlike institution. ELIJAH F. PURDY, war-horse, will preside. Gen. HANCOCK, Gen. VIELE, JAS. T. BRADY, Esq., and Judge DEAN, will positively be present and speak. Gens. DIX and MEAGHER, and Recorder HOFFMAN, are also confidently expected. These efforts of the influential sachems and followers of Tammany are so gratifying and patriotic as to insure a very large attendance, and an enthusiastic and liberal response. It will be a very interesting occasion.

abstract: The number of men required under the last call of the President have been so nearly furnished, that the Committee of the Board of Supervisors have suspended payment of the bounties to any more new recruits. There is still a deficiency of about two hundred, but the agents sent to the Army of the Potomac and to Port Royal have secured more than this number, all of whom will receive furloughs, individually, and return home to procure their bounties. The funds now on hand will therefore be kept for the veterans.

abstract: We are very sorry indeed that the opinion entertained for sometime past by many excellent people, that the rebel army and Confederacy were so badly broken down that they would do no more serious fighting this Spring or hence forward, has not been sustained by our latest experiences. The rebels, in their recent encounters, in different parts of the country, with our troops, under Gens. SEYMOUR, SHERMAN, SMITH and PALMER, have fought with their usual obstinacy and pertinacity, and marched with their ordinary celerity. Their small detachments everywhere show fight, and their large armies stand their ground. The rebel backbone is undoubtedly in a frightful condition, and those unacquainted with morbid anatomy might easily imagine that it was quite impossible for the monster to stand erect. But he does stand, nevertheless, and it is wisest for us neither to ignore his vitality nor his power. As long as the armies of LEE and JOHNSTON exist, we shall have a great deal of work to do; and even they, we fear, will have to be killed half a dozen times before they can be accounted dead.

As long as the armies of LEE and JOHNSTON exist, we shall have a great deal of work to do; and even they, we fear, will have to be killed half a dozen times before they can be accounted dead.

abstract: Brooklyn U. S. Sanitary Commission Fair Closed
snippet: Brooklyn U. S. Sanitary Commission Fair Closed
lead_paragraph: The great Sanitary Fair virtually closed on Saturday night, although the Academy proper will be kept open for two or three days longer at greatly reduced prices, in order to accommodate those who felt themselves unable to pay seventy-five cents. Single admissions will hereafter be twenty-five cents, and season tickets will be of no avail. The proceeds of the sale of goods will, as heretofore, be devoted to the purpose for which the fair was established; but the receipts at the door will be kept as a special fund to be distributed to such worthy objects as the Executive and Special Committees may deem most beneficial. The total receipts, as officially announced on Saturday evening, were $365,000. This is independent of a large amount of bills and checks, still uncounted, and which it is estimated will reach from $20,000 to $25,000, making the whole sum realized, above every expense, at from $385,000 to $390,000. The receipts during the coming week will doubtless swell the amount to $400,000. The population of the City of Brooklyn at the last census in 1860, was 266,674 -- it may now be over 300,000 -- thus showing that considerable more than one dollar per head, for each inhabitant, has been given in aid of the Sanitary Commission. The success of the enterprise has been beyond all expectation; and the ladies and gentlemen who devoted all their time in contributing to its success are worthy of all praise

abstract: Our  latest "on to Richmond" attempt has at least this cheerful feature that our forces got nearer to the rebel Capital than any Union force has yet done in any of the numerous attempts upon it.
lead_paragraph: -- Our latest "on to Richmond" attempt has at least this cheerful feature -- that our forces got nearer to the rebel Capital than any Union force has yet done in any of the numerous attempts upon it. "Little Mac" at one time had his army planted within five miles of the city, and in the early part of last year STONEMAN's cavalry got within three. But KILPATRICK last week was actually within two miles and a half of Richmond, having penetrated to the second exterior line of rebel works, and having thrown shells very near to JEFF. DAVIS' head. If we continue to make progress at this rate, we may ultimately hope to enter the city of our desire.

abstract: The "Faust" Matinee on Saturday was an extraordinary success, and will help materially to cover the losses of some of the preceding evenings. Long before the time of opening the doors they were besieged by a dense crowd of ladies.
lead_paragraph: The "Faust" Matinee on Saturday was an extraordinary success, and will help materially to cover the losses of some of the preceding evenings. Long before the time of opening the doors they were besieged by a dense crowd of ladies. When the opera commenced the house was filled, up stairs and down, to its greatest capacity. Many hundred fair ones had to turn from the scene of their anticipated pleasure and decline on inferior entertainments. Not even during the PICCOLOMINI furore was there such an excitement. The performance was in all respects admirable. There was one change in the cast, necessiated by the continued indisposition of Miss KELLOGG. Owing to this cause the role of Margherita had to be entrusted to Mile. FREDERICI-HIMMER, who sang it in German, and was quite successful. The music belongs properly to the mezzo-soprano voice, and is therefore easily within the range of the German prima donna's powers. When Mr. ANSCHUTZ's company gave "Faust" we spoke favorably of Mile. FREDERICI-HIMMER's impersonation of the heroine.It did not suffer by the excellent surroundings of Mr. MARETZEK's company.

abstract: Kilpatrick's Raid to Richmond
lead_paragraph: Our special correspondent with Gen. KILPATRICK's expedition sends us a full and reliable account of the late cavalry raid to the vicinity of Richmond, Virginia. Gen. KILPATRICK, it appears, left Stevensburgh on Sunday evening last, and went by the way of Chancellorsville and Spottsylvania Court-house to Beaver Dam, where he met the first armed resistance. The enemy were finally repulsed, and 32 prisoners taken. The railroad track for miles on the Central Road and several different stations were destroyed when the command moved upon Richmond, arriving before that place early Tuesday morning. A fight was kept up within the defences of that place until near night, when Gen. KILPATRICK withdrew. That night he was attacked in camp, and again repulsed the enemy, and also on the following day, arriving Thursday at Williamsburgh with the loss of only about 150 men. Col. DAHLGREN, with a small command, destroyed the railroad at Frederick Hall and on the James River, below Goochland, destroyed the canal, six flouring mills, one saw mill, and the coal mines at Manikin's Bend. The property destroyed is valued at millions of dollars, and is the heaviest loss that has yet been inflicted upon the rebels by a raiding party. Some 300 prisoners were captured, several hundred horses and a large number of negroes. The command lived on the country. Cols. Dahlgren and Litch-FIELD and Maj. COOK are missing. We also print this morning the rebel accounts of the expedition. It appears that within four hours after the Richmond papers had first announced the passage of the Rapidan by our forces, KILPATRICK's guns were pitching shell into the suburbs of the city. Our own account will be found very full and interesting, as well as being the only one prepared by a special correspondent with the expedition.

abstract: The Ovation to in New-York
lead_paragraph: There has been no more striking manifestation of the marvelous times that are upon us than the scene in our streets at the departure of the first of our colored regiments. Had any man predicted it last year he would have been thought a fool, even by the wisest and most discerning. History abounds with strange contrasts. It always has been an ever-shifting melo-drama. But never, in this land at least, has it presented a transition so extreme and yet so speedy as what our eyes have just beheld.

abstract: Expedition, the
lead_paragraph: The Opposition newspapers are making a good deal of clamor against the Administration on account of the recent disastrous expedition into Florida under Gen. SEYMOUR. It has been alleged that the expedition was undertaken by express direction of President LINCOLN, and that its objects were mainly political, -- the reorganization of the State Government and the election of a member of Congress. In consequence of some statements on the subject in Congress, a resolution was adopted directing the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into it.

abstract: A sad accident occurred on Saturday afternoon last, in front of the premises No. 83 Henry-street, whereby a boy named THOMAS P. MCMAHON, aged 11 years, came to his death by being buried alive. Some workmen were engaged in the work of filling in an old well located in front of the above number, near the sidewalk, when the earth suddenly gave way. A large portion of the sidewalk went down, carrying with it the lad MCMAHON and another boy named WM. KEARNEY, residing at No. 95 Henry-street, and a little girl, named MAGGIE MOORE, of No. 92 Henry-street, hey were all standing near the well at the time, and were carried down a distance of some ten or twelve feet. Fortunately, the mass of falling earth and stones jammed at this distance, and thus two lives were saved. The well was some forty feet deep. The men immediately set to work to rescue the two children, WILLIAM KEARNEY and MAGGIE MOORE, who were seen in the mass below, but the lad MCMAHON, was buried under it; and, moreover, his fall had not been noticed. The little girl was not buried alive, and was promptly rescued, a rope being thrown her. The lad, KEARNEY, was buried up to his cheat; it was ascertained that his body was firmly wedged between a large flagstone and an ash-box, both of which had been carried down into the opening. The earth around consists principally of sand, and was constantly falling upon the imprisoned boy. The danger was imminent, for at any moment the adjoining earth might bury him alive. Sergeant EASTERBROOK, of the Seventh Precinct, was on hand, and aided very materially in the work of saving the boy's lite. After much effort young KEARNEY was rescued, without having sustained serious injuries. As no other person was seen to fall into the excavation, no further search was made at the time. A policeman was, however, stationed there to prevent accidents.

abstract: Neutrality Policy and its Consequences
lead_paragraph: It is remarkable how public injustice and want of faith always come back to plague their authors. During the time of what seemed to European eyes our national dissolution, when the great Republic was breaking up into fragments, the fitting out and sending forth of privateers from British ports to destroy,under a bastard flag, our falling commerce, seemed to many British eyes a highly agreeable and exciting pastime. Ships were openly built, fitted out, armed and manned in Great Britain. When complaints were addressed to the Government, the proofs were either not considered legally sound, or certain public officers were providentially stricken with diseases, so that the suspected ships might escape through their delays. "Dodges" of various kinds were adopted to shield and secure the departure of the dangerous privateers. It needed but a few fast-sailing steamers thus to go forth to destroy half our commerce, as our English friends well knew. When Mr. ADAMS protested in the name of the British Municipal Act, he was told by the public that they must judge of the execution of their own laws, that England could not proceed in violation of law, as some countries were in the habit of doing, and that evidence was exceedingly difficult to procure in such cases. When, standing on a broader platform, he protested against such acts in the name of International Law, and pled the unchanging example of the American Government in similar cases, he was put off with ambiguous declarations and replies, such as that both sides were thus receiving help from Great Britain, and neither had a right to complain.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were noticed for the completion of the Battery extension, and for the better regulation of Manhattan-square. The bill relating to the Trustees of St. Patrick's Cathedral was read and passed. The concurrent resolutions against making any distinction as to the currency in which the interest and principal shall be paid to domestic and foreign holders of State bonds, were called up, and after some discussion, the subject was made the special order or Wednesday. The bill enabling husband and wife to act as witnesses for and against each other was debated at length, and ordered to a third reading.

abstract: The steamship Arago, from Port Royal on the 4th inst., arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing a large number of reenlisted veterans, and twenty of the wounded officers of the Florida expedition. News from Jacksonville is to the 2d inst., ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arago, from Port Royal on the 4th inst., arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing a large number of reenlisted veterans, and twenty of the wounded officers of the Florida expedition. News from Jacksonville is to the 2d inst., at which time reinforcements were rapidly arriving, and Gen. SEYMOUR's position was considered sufficiently formidable to repel any attack. Our troops are a distance of eight miles outside the town. A flag of truce had been sent to the rebels with the request that our wounded should be returned, but it was met by a refusal, on the ground that by this means valuable information would be obtained. The main body of the enemy, under Gen. FINNEGAN, is encamped between Ten Mile Run and Baldwin. In the late battle the rebels admit their loss to have been enormous.

abstract: and His Critics
lead_paragraph: We are very sorry to see that there is another inquiry into the conduct of the Commander of the Army of the Potomac now going on, based on complaints made by officers serving under him. We hope the interests of "eternal truth," or "eternal justice," or some other magnificent abstraction, are promoted by these investigations; for there is nothing more certain than that the discipline of the army will be, if it be not already, utterly destroyed by them. We say deliberately, that there can be nothing better calculated to render our army utterly worthless, than the practice to which Congress and the Government is addicted of listening to charges made by officers against their chief, touching his strategy or tactics. The only complaints which they should ever be permitted to make, or which by any sound and generally adopted theory of military duty, they are permitted to make, are complaints of personal wrong done to themselves, These are fit matters for examination; because examinations may be often necessary, to prevent the General from degenerating into a petty tyrant. But to allow any officer to arraign his superior before any tribunal, -- we do not care how composed, -- to answer for his manner of handling the army in active service, for retreating, or advancing, or fighting, is so subversive of all discipline, of all proper subordination, and all proper sense of responsibility, that we confess we cannot understand how any intelligent friends of the Government, in Congress or out of it, can possibly countenance it.
headline: {'main': 'Gen. Meade and His Critics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Gen. Meade and His Critics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.?VERDI'S always acceptable opera of "Ernani" was played here last night to a fair audience. The cast was excellent, equal in some respects to that famous one which made the opera so popular when it was played some years ago bp the Havana troupe. Mr. MARETZEK'S male artists ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's always acceptable opera of "Ernani" was played here last night to a fair audience. The cast was excellent, equal in some respects to that famous one which made the opera so popular when it was played some years ago bp the Havana troupe. Mr. MARETZEK's male artists are admirable in this young and vigorous kind of music; indeed the trio (MAZZOLENI, BELLINI & BIACHI) is probably as good as any that can be found in the present day. Madame MEDORI sang with dramatic fervor, and was heard to advantage in the many tumultuous pieces with which the opera abounds. The whole performance was in fact a decided success, and might be repeated on the next opera night to the satisfaction of the public and the subscribers.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, numerous petitions for an increase of mail facilities between New-York and Washington were presented. A bill was introduced by Mr. CONNESS to amend the act to aid in the construction of a Pacific Railroad, passed July 1, 1862. The bill for repealing all acts for the rendition of fugitive slaves was made the special order for to-morrow at 12 1/2 o'clock. Mr. SHERMAN introduced some important resolutions concerning the Electoral College, which were referred to the Committee on the Judiciary. The bill to grant lands to aid in the construction of a road from St. Paul to the head of Lake Superior was taken up, and advocated by Messrs. RAMSAY, WILKINSON and JOHNSON, and opposed by Messrs. HOWE and DOOLITTLE.

abstract: Messrs. BONNER, VANDERBILT and BAKER have responded to the suggestion made by the Leader that they should have a trial of speed between their splendid horses, for the benefit of the Sanitary Fair Messrs. VANDERBILT and BAKER have consented to do so if Mr. BONNER would, but the latter declines, as it has been a settled purpose with him not to race him horses for any purpose whatsoever. He donates to the Fair, though, Lady Woodruff conditioned that she be sold at auction. The mare trots in 2:27, and Mr. BONNER offers $6,000 for any horse that can beat this time two seconds. The gift of the "Lady" is a munificent one. Whether Messrs. VANDERBILT and BAKER will have a trial of speed is not yet known. That one would create great interest and result in a handsome contribution to the Fair, there is no doubt.

abstract: The Board of Managers of the Asylum for Colored Orphans notice that in the Annual Report of the Commissioners of Public Charities reference is made to the fact that thanks had not been rendered for past services. The omission was by no means intentional; but the plans which the Board devised for that purpose they unfortunately neglected to execute. The Board, therefore, take the earliest opportunity for correcting the error, by returning sincere thanks. The Commissioners on the 17th of July, received all our children at Blackwell's Island, and kept them there for three months -- thus standing by them and us in times of adversity as they have ever done in those of prosperity. The amount annually received from the Commissioners for the board of children is always credited in our Treasurer's Report, and this year will be found to be the third term. A. SHOTWELL.

abstract: The London Morning Post of the 24th, in its city article, says the reports from Paris are still more positive than before, that confidential negotiations have been entered upon by the French Government, with the Cabinet of St. James, for the joint recognition of the Confederate States; and it is stated that France will act alone in case of a negative reply from England. The City Editor of the Post declines to vouch for these reports.

abstract: Both branches of the Common Council were in session yesterday. Resolutions were adopted by both boards, requiring the Harlem Railroad Company to extend their line for short cars to ...
lead_paragraph: Both branches of the Common Council were in session yesterday. Resolutions were adopted by both boards, requiring the Harlem Railroad Company to extend their line for short cars to Forty-second-street, and also permitting them to extend their road through Thirty-fourth-street to the East River, and also permitting the Third-avenue Railroad to extend their line through Chambers-street to Broadway, through Fifty-seventh-street to Third-avenue, through Thirty-fourth-street to the East River, over the proposed Harlem track, and through One Hundred and Thirtieth-street to Fourth-avenue. The Third-avenue grant is entirely new, but the Harlem grant is identical with the one passed by the Board of Aldermen December 14, 1863, but which was killed by a reference in the Council Board to the Railroad Committee, where it was at the close of the year. There was no debate in the Board of Aldermen on these grants, but in the Council Board Mr. OPDYKE proposed to amend by requiring the Third-avenue Company to pay ten per cent. of their receipts on the extended route into the City Treasury, while Mr. JAQUES proposed to require a license fee for each car. The latter gentleman made a strenuous effort to secure a reference, but Messrs. BRANDON and GROSS held that these extensions were needed by public convenience, and that view of the matter seemed to prevail. In the Board of Aldermen, the City Inspector sent in a much needed ordinance to regulate disinterments within the City limits. In the Council Board, RUSH C, HAWKINS remonstrated against the proposed purchase of CLARK C. MILLS' statue of Gen. JACKSON, which, with the resolution of the Aldermen on that subject was referred to the Commitee on Arts and Sciences. The Aldermen adjourned to 10 o'clock on Wednesday; the Council to 4 o'clock Thursday.

abstract: By the steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 24th, and Queenstown on the 25th of February, we have four days later news from Europe. The rumors of a French recognition of the rebels had assumed a more positive shape than ever. The rebel ram question was up again in the House of Commons on the 23d, and the Attorney-General defended the policy of the Government at length. Several gentlemen made speeches against the Government, and they were replied to by Mr. W.E. FOSTER, Mr. BARING and the Solicitor-General, when a vote was taken on the motion calling for the papers, which stood 153 for, and 178 against -- a majority of twenty-five for the Government. An immense meeting, held at the Rotunda, Dublin, on the evening of the 22d of February, by the O'DONOGHUE and Mr. SULLIVAN, of the Nation, to protest against the erection of a statue to Prince ALBERT in College Green, the Fenian Brotherhood stormed the platform, routed the chairman and committee, and after a desperate fight of fifteen minutes, remained masters of the ground, waving a flag and flourishing a naked sword. It is alleged that some of the combatants wore the American uniform. The excitement and tumult was terrific. The war in the Duchies was not progressing very rapidly. The allies had been severely repulsed in their attack on Duppel. A Vienna dispatch of February 23, announces that the conference proposed by England for a settlement of the Dano-German question had been accepted by Austria and Prussia. There was to be no suspension of arms, but Jutland was not to be further invaded. The Allies were busily engaged in demolishing the Dannewerke, in Schleswig. The political news in France was unimportant.

lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 23d, Mr. SEYMOUR FITZGERALD took the Government to task for seizing the iron-clad rams belonging to Messrs. LAIRD, and asserted that it was done in contravention of the law. In moving for all the correspondence on the subject, he said he should deplore a war with America, but he would rather that the Government should go to war with her than that they should infringe the law of England in consequence of the threats of a foreign Ambassador.

abstract: Wilson vs. Sulzer. Opera Slander Suit
snippet: Wilson vs. Sulzer. Opera Slander Suit
lead_paragraph: Annie Wilson vs. Henrietta Sulzer. -- This was one of the cases tried in the Marine Court last term, known as "The Opera Slander Suits." The plaintiff recovered a judgment against Signorita Sulzer for amount of $250, in an action for camages for using slanderous language to and in regard to plaintiff. Similar suits were instituted against Signor Biachi and Dr. Reisenbergher, which will be tried for the second time at the above term of the Marine Court. In the present case execution was issued against the property of Signorita Sulzer and returned unsatisfied. An execution was then issued against her person, when this motion was made to set aside the proceedings and discharge the defendant, on the ground that she was a married woman.

abstract: Piracy; Chesapeake Case; the Diplomacy of
snippet: Piracy; Chesapeake Case; the Diplomacy of
lead_paragraph: There has been some discussion in the British Parliament concerning the violation of British sovereignty in the pursuit of the Chesapeake pirates into a British Colonial harbor by an American gunboat. Mr. LAYARD, in behalf of Her Majesty's Government, produced a letter addressed to Lord LYONS by Secretary SEWARD, as soon as the facts had reached him and long before the demand of the British Government for redress had reached this country. Mr. SEWARD acknowledges that there was a "direct violation of the sovereignty of Her Majesty," in the case referred to, by the officers of the gunboat Ella & Annie, which acts "the President disapproves and regrets," and though "the President has reason to believe that the proceedings thus disapproved were taken by the officers concerned under the influence of a patriotic and commendable zeal, yet he has "directed that they shall be censured for this violation, and he will take such other means as may be necessary to prevent a recurrence of the grievance complained of." Mr. SEWARD closes by announcing that he is "fully determined to make all the amends that are due to Great Britain in the premises." To these statements Earl RUSSELL promptly responded that "Her Majesty's Government accept that apology in the same spirit in which it has been offered, and are truly glad that the matter has been settled in a manner honorable to both parties, and calculated to improve the friendly relations which Her Majesty's Government are always anxious to maintain with the Government of the United States."

abstract: Relief of, and Southern Loyalists
lead_paragraph: -The people of Boston are taking the lead of the country in the very worthy charity of raising a fund for the relief of the long persecuted and much suffering loyalists of East Tennessee. It is the intention, we believe, to raise by public subscription in Massachusetts, the sum of one hundred thousand dollars, and to use it in the purchase of such articles of food and clothing as are imperatively demanded; and the report made on yesterday by EDWARD EVERETT, who has the matter in charge, shows that in a very short time nearly fifty thousand dollars have been subscribed, mostly in sums of about fifty or one hundred dollars. Some of the most prominent merchants of this City are taking an interest in the same work of charity, as will be seen by a correspondence in another column; and, under their auspices, a public meeting will be held on Thursday of the current week, at which the condition and wants of the people of East Tennessee will be set forth. For three years past the press has been setting before the country the persecutions of these Southern Unionists; and by the terrible nature and long continuance of their sufferings, their needs may now be measured. One of the letters in the correspondence speaks of the "often taxed but always generous liberality" of the merchants of New-York; and although at present their beneficence is flowing mainly to our army through the channels of the Sanitary Commission, we doubt not that in their purses and stores will be found something to supply the wants of the faithful confessors who have upheld our cause through a long night of darkness, and amid sufferings which only heroes could endure and only devils could inflict.

abstract: Contributors should send in their donations of merchandise at once. As the last week for preparation draws near, the work of the committees increases, and it will be utterly impossible to arrange and classify this vast quantity of articles, if they are not received seasonably. An agent is now in waiting daily at the building, in Fourteenth-street, near Sixth-avenue, (formerly Palace Garden,) from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. The express wagons will call and deliver the goods free of expense to the donors when so desired. Do not wait for the last week, else it will be practically impossible to arrange and classify the goods and prepare the printed list. In this connection, it may be mentioned that the Committee on Newspapers will issue, on the 28th of March, a daily journal of twelve pages; and among interesting matter pertaining to the Fair, will be a correct list of contributors and of the articles contributed, with the valuation of the same. It is important that this list should be prepared, as far as may be, before the Fair opens. Hence contributors will aid the management materially by not delaying to send in their goods.

abstract: Every loyal man should make it his duty to deposit a ballot to-day for the civil rights of the soldier who is saving our civil structure from ruin. The very statement of the necessity seems a paradox. It is absurd enough ...
lead_paragraph: Every loyal man should make it his duty to deposit a ballot to-day for the civil rights of the soldier who is saving our civil structure from ruin. The very statement of the necessity seems a paradox. It is absurd enough on its face that we here at home should be called upon to give our fellow-citizens, who are defending the flag with their lives, leave to exercise the right without which the flag would be worthless. Surely, if any class of our people have a stronger claim than any other to a voice in the Government, it is they who are beating down the rebels against the Government. If there be any difference, the citizen in the camp and the field has a better right to the franchise than the citizen in the counting-house or the work-shop; for his services to the country are indisputably greater.

abstract: At an immense meeting held at the Rotunda, Dublin, on the evening of the 22d of February by The O'BONOHUE and Mr. SULLIVAN, of the Nation, to protest against the erection of a statue to Prince ALBERT ...
lead_paragraph: At an immense meeting held at the Rotunda, Dublin, on the evening of the 22d of February, by The O'DONOHUE and Mr. SULLIVAN, of the Nation, to protest against the erection of a statue to Prince ALBERT in College Green, the Freeman Brotherhood stormed the platform, routed the chairman and committee, and after a desperate fight of fifteen minutes remained masters of the ground, waving a flag and flourishing a naked sword. It is alleged that some of the combatants wore the American uniform. The excitement and tumult were terrific.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by ...
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The wholesale dry goods houses of this City are responding nobly to the appeal made in behalf of the Sanitary Fair -- something over $80,000 having been already subscribed, in sums of not less than $1,000 each. A gentleman who arrived at Nashville from Montgomery, February 24th, says SHERMAN chased POLK to the Tombigbee, but could not force him to fight. In those sections of country not traversed by railroads SHERMAN found plenty of supplies, and his army lived on the country.
