abstract: AN EXPLOSION IN THIRTY-EIGHTH-STREET?ONE MAN SERIOUSLY INJURED.?Between 3 and 4 o' clock yesterday morning, an explosion occurred in the alcoholic distillery of Mr. GEORGE MOORE, in West 38th-street, near Tenth-avenue. The shock was
lead_paragraph: AN EXPLOSION IN THIRTY-EIGHTH-STREET -- ONE MAN SERIOUSLY INJURED. -- Between 3 and 4 o' clock yesterday morning, an explosion occurred in the alcoholic distillery of Mr. GEORGE MOORE, in West 38th-street, near Tenth-avenue. The shock was so great that buildings on the adjoining block were shaken to their foundations. The watchman of the premises, named PATRICK PHILLIPS, was seriously injured by falling pieces of the building. He was conveyed to his residence No. 410 West Thirty-eighth-street, where he now lies in a critical condition. The building took fire immediately after the explosion. It was damaged to the extent of about $10,000; insured for $5,000. The explosion occurred in the basement, and the police report that this is the third or fourth time that an occurrence of this kind has taken place within a few months. The cause of it is as yet unascertained.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The unmistakable success of "Faust" leaves the journalist nothing to do but to record its repetition, and to state the significant fact that the house was filled to its greatest capacity. No opera of the modern repertoire has seized the public with so firm a grasp. The annals of music, in truth, hardly hint at its parallel. Some of the best accepted works of the present day were failures on their production, but "Faust" has won instantly the sympathies of every audience, and from the start has been a favorite. The distribution last night restored MISS KELLOGG to her right place as the heroine. No one can fill it so gracefully, modestly and dramatically. Her reception was, of course, genial and kindly; how could it be otherwise in view of her great appreciation of the role and her talent in interpreting it? The cast in other respects was the same as heretofore, and gave abundant satisfaction to an audience, literally overflowing in every part of the house.

abstract: Alabama; the Ravages of the
lead_paragraph: We print this morning some very interesting extracts from our East Indian and European files, concerning the number and whereabouts of the rebel pirates, particularly the Alabama. The public was much disappointed, some time ago, to learn that the report of the blockade of the Alabama, at Amoy, China, was untrue. It was not only not true, but it appears that the Alabama never was further eastward than Singapore, in the Straits of Malacca. From there she sailed on the 24th of December, having taken on board 300 tons of coal, and the same day fell in with the bark Texan Star, otherwise called Martaban, from Moulmein, Burmah, for Singapore, with a cargo of rice. The particulars of the destruction of this vessel are well known. The pirate kept on her course up the Straits, and two days later burned the American ships Sonora and Highlander, both at anchor off North Sands (Sumatra) light-ship. The next heard of her was, that she was in the Gulf of Martaban, about fifty miles south of Rangoon, Burmah. She then seems to have crossed over the Bay of Bengal, swept around Cape Comorin, the southern extremity of India, and sailed up the western coast of that country; for we next hear of the capture of the bark Emma Jane, on the 14th of January, off Ajenga, on the southwestern coast of India. This is the last positive information of her whereabouts, though it was generally supposed she would pursue her course up the coast and touch at Bombay, as the Times of India, (Bombay,) of January 23, speaks of it as not at all unlikely. That journal urged the people to show no favor to the pirates. From these movements it would seem that SEMMES has given up for the present any intention he may have had of visiting the Chinese seas and Pacific Ocean, and we may possibly hear of him next in the vicinity of Cape Town again, as he is probably aware of the absence of the Vanderbilt. The other pirates are the Tuscaloosa, now seized by British authority at Cape Town; the Florida, just escaped from Brest; the Georgia, lately escaped from Cherbourg; the Rappahannock, under surveillance at Calais; and the Pampero, lately seized in the Clyde. The Georgia and Florida will doubtless soon be heard from in their work of destruction.

abstract: Party Struggles in; New Phase of the German Struggle
snippet: Party Struggles in; New Phase of the German Struggle
lead_paragraph: The two great German Powers have consented to pause in their career of conquest. After invading and taking possession of the Duchies, and just on the borders of Jutland, they are now reported to have listened to the suggestions of England, and to have consented to another Convention of the Great Powers, to be assembled again in London. Very few intelligent Germans have ever believed that Austria and Prussia were in earnest in this war. The popular impression has been that their extraordinary energy and activity were due quite as much to fear of the National party at home, as to hostility to Denmark. They were forced to a vigorous campaign, in order to retain the leadership of Germany and to keep down the Federalists.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON introduced a bill providing for the better organization of the Quartermaster's Department.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. WILSON introduced a bill providing for the better organization of the Quartermaster's Department. Referred to the Military Committee. Mr. POWELL called up his resolution for the production of the papers and evidence in the McDowell Military Commission, but, after considerable discussion, the subject was informally postponed. The bill to promote enlistments was taken up, and Mr. BROWN, of Missouri, spoke at length in favor of a general emancipation policy. The bill to equalize the pay of soldiers was taken up, and Mr. DAVIS offered an amendment providing for compensation to loyal owners of slaves taken into the service, and said be would speak at length to-day on the amendment.

abstract: Soldiers' Vote Amendment Ratified
lead_paragraph: The very reasonable anticipation that the people would indorse the amendment to the State Constitution, permitting soldiers to exercise the right of suffrage, was verified by the election held yesterday. The bald justice of the proposition was so palpable, and loyal men felt so well assured that the opposition to the measure would be weak, that there was much carelessness about going to the polls. No special effort was made to roll up a heavy vote; and, judging from the complete returns of this City and Brooklyn, about one-third of the vote ordinarily cast at gubernatorial elections was delivered. Although it would have been vastly more gratifying for the brave fellows who have forsaken home and friends, and risked their lives for the preservation of the national existence, to have received the just compliment of a full vote in a case where there has been little question of their deserts, we are not disposed to complain of the result. It is always difficult in elections, under circumstances marking that yesterday, to overcome the indolence and passiveness of the electors, and had it not been for the services of professional politicians, in this City at least, the amendment might actually have been floored through the sheer indifference of its friends. The Copperheads came out, presumably, in their full strength against it, seldom with an open ballot, but furtively, as is their nature. Our tables show that of the 25,000 votes cast, 6,899 were against the soldiers' rights. Indeed, three of the Wards of the City -- the First, Sixth and Fourteenth -- have won the disgraceful victory of giving small Copperhead majorities. As a set-off to them the Thirty-second Precinct only opposed the amendment by six votes, and the entire City of Brooklyn gave but 600 in the negative against 8,235 in favor.
headline: {'main': 'THE AMENDMENT RATIFIED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE AMENDMENT RATIFIED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The fourteenth annual commencement of this institution took place on Monday evening, the 7th inst. The attendance was very large, and among the audience were numbers of the most distinguished medical gentlemen of the City. Prof. RAPHAEL, Dean of the Faculty, in a short address called the attention of the graduates to the vast responsibilities which they assumed in becoming physicians, and exhorted them, if they did not feel a pure and genuine love for the profession, to abandon it at once. Rev. Dr. J.M. MATHEWS then conferred the degree of Doctor of Medicine on the following gentlemen: David Brekes, John T. Nagle, Otto F.A. Jentz, J.G. Ponle, Justice J. Spreng, Charles C. Terry, Charles Liston Brown, Nelson Place, Jr., and Henry H. Davidson, of New-York; Theodore Frickenstein and William F. Galhaar, of Germany; J.M. Veitia, Fernando Minteguiaga and Francisco Arroyo y Heredia, of Cuba.

abstract: The election, yesterday, on the proposed amendment giving to soldiers and sailors absent on service the right to vote, resulted, as was anticipated it would, in a vote largely in favor of the amendment.
lead_paragraph: The election, yesterday, on the proposed amendment giving to soldiers and sailors absent on service the right to vote, resulted, as was anticipated it would, in a vote largely in favor of the amendment. Loyal citizens did not take the interest in it that they should, and the vote is only a partial indication of the feeling on the question. Very many did not know that an election was being held; around the polls were none of the usual indications -- the booths, the ticket-boxes, the pot-house politicians, &c. On fire plugs or in pockets, for the most part, were deposited the ballots by the zealous Union men who worked at the polls and offered to voters the affirmative ballots. The opposition managers, much stronger than was expected, were secret, shunned the daylight, and, sneaking from the gaze of honest men, did their work in the byeways and holes away from the polls. New-York means emphatically that the soldiers and sailors shall vote, but was too busy to make assurance doubly sure on the question of the amendment. Had it been suspected that the Copperheads would have made the effort they did, the loyal vote would have been overwhelming.

abstract: Yesterday, Rear-Admiral HIRAM PAULDING left this City for Washington, for the purpose of endeavoring to compromise the differences between the employes at the Navy-yard and the Departments.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Rear-Admiral HIRAM PAULDING left this City for Washington, for the purpose of endeavoring to compromise the differences between the employes at the Navy-yard and the Departments. Nearly all the branches of work have recommenced a vigorous movement to obtain increased pay, but it is not now to be characterized by strikes. The laborers held a meeting on Friday last, and resolved to appoint a deputation to go to Washington, and lay their claims before the authorities. The caulkers waited on the Admiral on the same day, and stated that they could get more wages outside than they were paid in the yard; but their determination was to state their case to him and not to strike. The Admiral promised to represent the matter to the Government. The watchmen now get 13 shillings per diem, and they are about to apply for two dollars or 15 shillings. The blacksmiths also ask an advance, and the carpenters are said to be similarly inclined. The decision of the Secretary of the Navy regulates the pay of Navy-yard employes as outside workmen are paid; but the hands now assert that since their wages were increased last, a still further advance has taken place outside; and the present movement aims to affect another "equalization." A Board of Officers is again to investigate the prices paid in the founderies, shipyards and workshops of the metropolis. The laborers and mechanics at the other yards are working with the New-York hands in this matter, and will abide by the result attained here.

lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met yesterday. The Corporation Counsel communicated the opinion, in answer to a resolution of inquiry, that it is altogether optional with the board whether they will pay damages to non-residents for losses of property by the riots. Mr. PURDY expressed the opinion that non-residents should not receive damages where their property is of a kind that does not contribute toward the support of the County. The board adopted a resolution appointing ANTONY EICKOFF Translator to the Courts of Record in the County, at a salary of $2,500, and another resolution was adopted granting a request of Comptroller BRENNAN, that he be allowed to appoint two additional Clerks in the County Bureau, at salaries of $1,000 and $1,200. A third resolution was unanimously adopted in favor of recommending the Legislature to repeal the act of 1855 creating the Record Commission. Thanks were voted to Gov. SEYMOUR at the instance of Mr. ELY, for securing a reduction of the State's quota of troops, whereby the county quota is reduced over 4,000, and is saved $2,000,000. The board decided to hire Nos. 159 and 161 Crosby-street, known as the "Gymnasium," as an armory for the Ninety-ninth Regiment N.Y.S.N.G., at $2,200 per year, for five years. Bills for labor and materials on the Palace Garden building, amounting to $8,070 64, were passed. The board adjourned to Tuesday next, at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: A firemen's fight, while the flames are raging, is deemed a disgrace. A soldiers' fray, in the face of an enemy, is accounted a crime.
lead_paragraph: A firemen's fight, while the flames are raging, is deemed a disgrace. A soldiers' fray, in the face of an enemy, is accounted a crime. We should like to know how much better than either of these was the broil between the Missouri members, in the House, during the debate for supplying means to meet the expenses of the war against the rebellion. The discussion started fitly, but soon degenerated into a miserable personal altercation between the Union representatives of Missouri concerning their respective political antecedents; and this occupied the sitting until the adjournment at a late hour. We published but a small portion of what was sent us. The full report would simply have wearied and disgusted every reader.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen held a short session yesterday, but the proceedings were of great interest. Mayor GUNTHER sent in a message in regard to City railroads. He takes the ground that, by our ancient charters, the right of the control of the streets is wholly in the City, but recognizing recent decisions to the contrary, proposes to ask the Legislature to pass an act requiring all City railroads to pay monthly, ten per cent. of the gross receipts into the City Treasury. He asks the Common Council to sustain him in making such an application at Albany. The Mayor also transmitted proposals of G.E. WINANTS to freight ashes and street sweepings from the City at four cents per load, which is one-half the price paid at present. This offer, the Mayor says, has been rejected by the City Inspector. Both messages were referred -- that in regard to railroads was directed to be printed and a copy sent to each member of the Legislature. The Finance Committee presented a voluminous report in regard to the general subject of taxes and appropriations, together with the annual Appropriation Bill. The report is a lengthy and elaborate effort to demonstrate that the increase of taxation in the City is mainly chargeable to the Board of Supervisors and independent Commissioners created by the Legislature. The report and ordinance were laid over under the rule, and were ordered to be published in a number of papers. The Board adjourned to Friday, at 2 P.M.

abstract: By the arrival of the Nova Scotian at Portland and the Australasian at this port, we have three days later news from Europe -- the dates being to the 28th ult. Affairs between the Danes and Germans are unchanged. The conference proposed by England on the basis of guaranteeing the authority as well as the indivisibility of the Duchies, and preserving the territorial arrangements hitherto existing, met with favor from the Great Powers, including France. Denmark, however, still postponed her reply to the invitation, expecting that the successful defence of her new military positions would give her higher standing in any deliberations than if she joined the conference, with the late defeat still fresh in the minds of her neighbors. Lord PALMERSTON had announced in the House of Commons, that orders had been sent to the Cape of Good Hope to release the pirate Tuscaloosa, whose detention was not justified by international law. In the House of Lords, on the 25th, Earl RUSSELL said that there was no longer any objection to producing the papers in the case of the Mersey rams, and the rebel vessels Saxon and Alabama. The 5th of April has been fixed for the trial of the Pampero case in the Edinburgh Court of Session. The suppression of the African Slave-Trade was under discussion in the House of Commons on the 26th, and Lord PALMERSTON said in reply to a question as to whether the Government intended to station cruisers off the Coast of Cuba, that the more prudent and humane course was to send the vessels to the coast of Africa. The London Post's city article says that private advices from Paris, upon which reliance can be placed, again allude to negotiations now in progress, preparatory to the recognition of the Confederate States by the French Government, although any official acknowledgment of this fact would, at the present, be thought premature and undesirable. The three men arrested for seizing the schooner J.L. Gerily claim to have been justified in their conduct by written authority of the Confederate Government. The counsel for the United States demanded that the prisoners be sent to New-York under the Extradition Treaty. The case was remanded till the 4th inst. The trial of the four Italian conspirators had been concluded in France, two being sentenced to transportation for life, and the other two to twenty years' imprisonment.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the consideration of the repeal of the Fugitive Slave Bill was postponed for one week. A Committee of Conference on the disagreements on the Deficiency Bill was appointed. The resolution calling for the papers and evidence in the MCDOWELL Military Commission was rejected. The bill to equalize the pay of soldiers was taken up, and Mr. DAVIS spoke at length in opposition to colored troops in general. A memorial was presented from the agriculturists of Ohio, asking for a revenue tax of $1 each on dogs, especially as they destroy in Ohio $100,000 worth of sheep annually. The Senate, after executive session, adjourned.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There was a good attendance last night to witness MOZART's masterpiece, "Don Giovanni" -- a work which, apart from its intrinsic merits, has peculiar interest at the present time, when the town is fairly crazy on the subject of a totally different style of music. "Faust" and "Don Giovanni" are as wide asunder as the poles. The simple exquisite melodies of the latter seem to be imperishable, and are as heartily appreciated as, and surely better understood, than the more reticent and vague fancies of GOUNOD. It argues well, however, that both these works are the best favorites of our public. MOZART's opera is famous for restoring the fortunes of managers. It is always sure to draw a good house, and this too is the case with "Faust." May they long run side by side without touching or clashing! It were well for art if it could boast of more such productions.

abstract: Gantry, >amp;c., vs. Doane; Notarial Protest
lead_paragraph: Wm.M. Gantry and Philip L. Freeman vs. Augustus S. Doane, Charles E. Townsend and Gerald Gray. -- This suit was brought against the defendants as makers and indorsers of a promissory note for $2,100. Defendant Doane, the indorser, alone defended the action on the ground that the note was not presented, or properly protested. Plaintiff's counsel offered in evidence the notarial certificate. This was objected to by defendants. Plaintiff's counsel insisted that as there was no affidavit annexed to defendant's answer the notarial certificate was prima facie evidence of the facts therein contained.

abstract: Union men in New-Hampshire, as well as out of it, had painful doubts of how this election would result. Last year the Union can
lead_paragraph: Union men in New-Hampshire, as well as out of it, had painful doubts of how this election would result. Last year the Union candidate received only a plurality of a few hundreds, not a majority at all; and the State, by the subsequent drafts, has since sustained a further depletion of many thousands of Union voters. The recent canvass of the State by the State Union Committee figured out a majority of only about six hundred for Gov. GILMORE; the votes, as polled, show a majority for him of full four thousand.

abstract: Maximilian's Reasons for Wishing a Throne
snippet: Maximilian's Reasons for Wishing a Throne
lead_paragraph: The embryonic Emperor MAXIMILIAN was to arrive in Paris the first week of this month, on his way to the City of Mexico. Our Paris correspondent mentions that one of the reasons impelling MAXIMILIAN to run the risk of his neck in Mexico is that he is in debt eight millions of francs, which he is unable to pay, but which he hopes to be able to pick up in Mexico. This is the most plausible reason we have yet seen given for MAXIMILIAN's foolish eagerness to get a throne. Many are the shifts resorted to by men afflicted with debts they cannot pay, and who are pushed by their creditors. Debt has driven Kings to war, plunder and oppression; under its scourgings, respectable men have been guilty of murder, suicide, arson, and every crime prohibited by the decalogue; it has betrayed gentlemen into trickery and meanness, and ladies into wearing Spring fashions in Midsummer. The case in hand shows that a Hapsburg Prince in debt is as desperate as any other man; but whether the expedient he has resorted to, of getting out of it, will be successful remains to be seen. We do not know what wages MAXIMILIAN expects to get as Emperor of Mexico, but he must needs have a very large annual salary, and subsist very economically, and live to a very old age, if he would save up eight millions of francs during his reign in Mexico. At the very opening of his imperial career he will have to purchase a crown, and a throne, and a whole lot of new clothes; and it is evident that, being already so heavily in debt, he will have to get all these necessaries on credit and thus he will run still farther in debt. If he undertake to travel much through his empire, he will need to buy new garments very often, for we learn by recent advices from Mexico that the robbers who infest every highway in that country, are getting so desperate of late that they enter the diligences and strip all travellers stark naked -- which would be a dreadful plight for an Emperor to be in. We think, therefore, on the whole, that MAXIMILIAN's honorable ambition to pay up his old debts out of his pickings and stealings in the New World, is likely to be blasted; and as there will almost certainly be a scramble for crowns in Europe before many years, we advise him to stay there -- where his chances for getting and keeping one are much better than they are here.

abstract: The mails from Calcutta to Jan. 22, and Hong Kong, Jan. 15, are received, but the news has been anticipated by telegraph. Freights at Shanghai were exorbitantly high. The rate for Cotton to England had risen in a month from £3 17s. 6d. to £5 7s. 6d., owing to the scarcity of shipping and partly to the preference for British vessels in consequence of the presence of the Alabama in Eastern waters. Some transports of registers had been effected. Americans showed a preference for Continental vessels over British.

abstract: We print this morning very full accounts of the recent great raid from late Richmond papers, full files of which, as late as the 8th inst., we received last evening. The details given in these rebel accounts are full of intense interest. They give the first information as to how Col. DAHLGREN and his party met with their misfortune, as well as interesting particulars concerning the whole raid. They admit that it was of a most daring character, and confess that much damage was done. They claim victory, however, because the force did not enter the city, and assert that only the local battalions for city defence, composed of department clerks and citizens, repulsed our forces. DAHLGREN and his party, it seems, were ambushed, and he was standing unconcealed in the road, late at night, demanding his foe to surrender, when a volley was poured upon him, and he fell, pierced with five wounds. His command dispersed in the darkness, but most of them were captured in the morning. The accounts are garnished with the usual extravagant assertions, especially as to the number of prisoners captured, which they claim now reaches four or five hundred. The officers captured had been confined in dungeons, with a private negro soldier with each one as companion. In addition to this, Gen. BUTLER telegraphs that these prisoners are all confined in irons. The papers found on Col. DAHLGREN's person, give the programme to be acted upon in entering the city -- which included the release of the prisoners, the burning of the city, and the capture or killing of DAVIS and his crew, are made the subject of terrible threats by the Richmond journals, and DAVIS is urged to execute, without trial of any kind, all the prisoners taken from our columns. The exchange of prisoners has been resumed, and the rebels claim that it is under the old cartel, and that the questions of negro soldiers and BUTLER's recognition are still in abeyance. Nevertheless, BUTLER seems to be conducting the exchange. SHERMAN, they say, had done great damage in Mississippi.

Being short of coal, she put into Beaufort 4th; was supplied, and sailed Sunday, 6th, for New-York. She was captured Feb. 5, 50 miles
lead_paragraph: The prize steamer Cumberland, Acting-Master L.H. PARTRIDGE, arrived yesterday morning, from Key West, Feb. 28, via Hilton Head, where she landed Judge PHILIP FRAZER and daughter, and sailed on Wednesday at 12 M. Being short of coal, she put into Beaufort 4th; was supplied, and sailed Sunday, 6th, for New-York. She was captured Feb. 5, 50 miles south of Mobile, by the United States steamer De Soto. She has proved herself to be a splendid seaboat and she is a substantial, well built vessel in every respect. She was built in 1847, and most thoroughly constructed; her cabin skylights are emblazoned with the arms of the Earl of Eglington, whose crest also adorns the cabin windows of the prize steamers Scotia, Anglia and Adela, as well as the Cumberland's. The cabins of the Cumberland are fitted up in the most luxurious manner. Her machinery is pronounced faultless, the boilers are new, and the hull being of iron of extra thickness and well braced and fastened, renders her exeedingly stiff in a seaway. She could be easily transformed into a gunboat. The Navy could not make a better selection. She was used as a transport in the Crimean war, has been in the St. Petersburgh and London trade, and once ran in the Galway and New-York line. She is the finest steamship captured during the war. Her cargo is also very valuable; it is sent to New-York with the vessel for sale, and will be advertised in a few days by the United States Marshal of Florida -- JAMES C. CLAPP -- who is on board.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, petitions for and against a Broadway railroad were presented, and also a petition asking action relative to the nuisance of overcrowding cars and stages. A bill was noticed to divide the Seventh Judicial District of New-York and locate the Ninth Judicial District. Bills were introduced authorizing the banks of this State to become banking associations under the laws of Congress. Repealing the act of 1848 regulating telegraph companies; for the completion of the Battery extension, New-York; a bill continuing the improvement of the navigation of the Hudson River was passed. A resolution suggesting full pay to Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON and placing him on the retired list on account of his distinguished services and infirm health was tabled; and another resolution proposing that our representatives in Congress be instructed to vote for a law securing to all the volunteers from this State, under the call of 1861, the bounty of one hundred dollars paid to the full two years men met a similar fate.

abstract: Economy of Force
lead_paragraph: There has undoubtedly been great wastage of men, and consequently of power, in the course of this war. We do not refer to the necessary destruction of life that accompanies all war, but to waste from following wrong military theories, from scatteration, from lack of experience and of system, from carelessness and blundering. We have gotten up great expeditions to accomplish unimportant objects -- some of which expeditions have succeeded while others have failed; and some of those which were failures have been less loss to the country than those which succeeded. Our expeditions to the Carolinas, North and South, for example, have cost us many thousands of men and hundreds of millions of dollars; yet what relative gain has the Union had from them? We have been enabled for some time past to make a pretty effective blockade of the coast line of these two States, and that is about all; but the great results which the country expected would follow those expeditions, such as the capture of Wilmington, Charleston and Savannah, and, above all, the pushing of an army inland as far as Raleigh and Columbia, are not likely to be accomplished soon, if, indeed, they are now thought of at all. So, again, immense numbers of men have been wasted, and are still being wasted, by the stationing of regiments, or parts of regiments, here, there and everywhere in the South, to hold posts, towns, or territory, that are of no earthly, or at all events, of no military account whatever. We doubt not that in the Southwest alone there are twenty thousand men employed in this kind of duty to-day who could profitably be withdrawn and united with either one of the two great armies in whose hands is now lodged the work of crushing out the rebellion. We can judge of the value of each one of these regiments -- we can judge of the wrong that is done to the country in this waste of the national force, by reflecting upon the great difficulty and dreadful expense which we now undergo in this City and elsewhere in raising a regiment of troops. Each of our great armies gains as much, nay, gains twice as much, when one of these detached regiments is drawn in from an unimportant post, as when, after all our trouble, we have succeeded in forwarding to the army a thousand men. We could hope that along with all the new regiments which are now being raised throughout the country, there were also a gathering in and a concentration at the fundamental points, of every regiment, every company, and every man, whose whole power cannot be brought directly and immediately to bear upon the rebel armies. In this way, we would soon be able to plant in Georgia and Virginia two armies of such magnitude, as to make sure and quick work of their opponents.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -It has seemed several times during the last three years that England was about to get into war with this country; but she has never done it. It seemed, during last year, that she was likely to get into war with Russia for Poland; but she didn't. It has seemed lately that she was likely to get into war with Germany or Denmark, it was hard to tell which; but she will probably escape it. We do not blame her for evading these wars which from time she threatens, and which appear imminent. It is the very best thing she can do. KINGLAKE, in his book on the Crimea, is at great pains to warn the world not to count too much on England's pacific disposition; but it is evident that she has not lately been "spilin' for a fight" half as bad as he represents her to have been ten years ago.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a bill providing that the Emancipation Proclamation issued by the President, Jan. 1,1863, be adopted and enacted as a statute of the United States. The Senate then considered the Gold Bill,...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a bill providing that the Emancipation Proclamation issued by the President, Jan. 1, 1863, be adopted and enacted as a statute of the United States. The Senate then considered the Gold Bill, which was discussed briefly, and then postponed until to day. The Senate then proceeded to the consideration of the bill to equalize the pay of colored troops, when Mr. POMEROY took occasion to speak at length with reference to his recent Presidential circular, and the principles of the great party he is building up. The Senate heard him at great length, and then passed the bill -- 31 ayes, 6 noes. The Lake Superior Railroad Bill was then taken up and passed, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Probably very few persons are aware of the fact that the united operations of our City and County Treasuries, amount in the course of a year to about thirty millions of dollars. All the warrants upon the two treasuries are drawn and signed by the Comptroller, and countersigned by the Mayor, and in addition the Clerk of the Board of Supervisors countersigns those on County account, and the Clerk of the Common Council countersigns those on City account. The two treasuries, although distinct in name, are one in fact, the City Chamberlain being, ex-officio, the County Treasurer. abstract: Conveyance
lead_paragraph: -- A petition has been sent to the Legislature asking for some law to prevent the impositions constantly practiced by the railroads and omnibuses of this City in overcrowding their vehicles. We hope it will receive attention. The state of things now existing is utterly disgraceful, and is growing worse and worse. The City cars have always been packed to the extent of their capacity, without the slightest regard to the rights, comfort or convenience of their passengers; but until quite lately it was rare to find an omnibus driver keep on adding to his load after there were already twelve inside. Now, however, not the slightest attention is paid to this circumstance. We have seen policemen in Broadway put three ladies into an omnibus in which every seat had already been taken and paid for. A policeman who will do this ought to be dismissed. In Paris a driver who would allow it to be done would be arrested by the police: here, the police aid the drivers in thus imposing on the public. The proprietors of both omnibuses and railroads seem to have given instructions to pack as many people into their vehicles as they can possibly be made to hold.

abstract: Career of
lead_paragraph: BRAXTON BRAGG has just been appointed to the highest military office under JEFF. DAVIS, and ULYSSES GRANT, by his appointment as Lieutenant-General, assumes the highest rank of any officer in the army of the Union. The respective careers and fortunes of no two military men could be more opposite in character than those of these two ranking officers of the opposing armies. BRAGG's name is synonymous with disaster -- GRANT's with victory. The Richmond Examiner says that BRAGG's "career has been a long, unvaried and complete failure," -- the very reverse of which statement would be nearly the truth concerning GRANT, BRAGG's first undertaking of any importance resulted in his failure at Pensacola; GRANT's first large action was his triumph at Donelson. BRAGG's last battle was at Chattanooga, where his whole army was routed by GRANT. Against GRANT's Vicksburgh we have BRAGG's Murfreesboro; against GRANT's Champion Hills we have BRAGG's Perryville. GRANT flanked the rebels at Bowling Green and Columbus, and BRAGG got flanked at Tullahoma and Shelbyville. GRANT began operations at Cairo, and the sweep of his successive victories, as he marched onward, extended a thousand miles. BRAGG once had his army upon the Ohio, and his successive retreats from there covered several hundred miles. So we might go on, contrasting in still other respects the history of the two Generals who are now the ranking officers in the two armies.

abstract: The New-Jersey Railroad depot, at Jersey City, has for several evenings past been the scene of disturbances, which are growing more violent with every repetition. To protect themselves, as is alleged from fraud, whether by their own agents or passengers, does not appear, the company has revived and made more stringent than ever an absurd regulation, requiring all travellers commuters included, to show their tickets as they enter or leave the depot at Jersey-City. There are but two or three gates through which individuals desiring to take the cars or the ferry-boat, as the case may be, are permitted to pass, and the restriction which the regulation alluded to puts upon their movements, for from four to seven hundred passengers are frequently gathered there at one time, inevitably gives rise to the greatest confusion. On several occasions the passengers have become so irritated at the vexatious delay and the serious inconvenience to which they are subjected that they have attempted to clear a passage for themselves, and the demonstrations finally became so violent that the company was obliged to call in the services of a number of policemen, who are now regularly stationed in the depot to assist in the enforcement of the obnoxious regulations. One or two arrests have been made, but without any perceptible effect in mollifying the multitude, and it is impossible to tell in what the unpleasant excitement may end. Thus far, apparently, the only gainers by the movement are the railroad company and the pickpockets; for the former are getting the ill-will of those who are obliged to patronize them, as rapidly as they could possibly desire it, and the light-fingered gentry reap substantial harvests daily, from the pockets of the excited crowd. In several instances, lately, gentlemen have not only lost their tempers in the excitement, but their pocket-books as well, containing sums between fifty and one hundred dollars.

abstract: The steamship Western Metropolis, from New-Orleans Feb. 29, arrived last evening, bringing out usual files and correspondence. The Era, of the 28th, contains a brief account of the beginning of Admiral FARRAGUT'S operations against Mobile. The bombardment of Fort Powell, at Grant's
lead_paragraph: The steamship Western Metropolis, from New-Orleans Feb. 29, arrived last evening, bringing out usual files and correspondence. The Era, of the 28th, contains a brief account of the beginning of Admiral FARRAGUT's operations against Mobile. The bombardment of Fort Powell, at Grant's Pass, was initiated on the 24th ult., by the mortar flotilla, assisted by several gunboats, and was being prosecuted with vigor. The rebels replied rapidly, but their fire had resulted in only one casualty on our side. At New-Orleans, preparations on a grand scale were in progress for the public inauguration of the new State officers, and the city had been greatly enlivened by a brilliant military parade and review.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, additional petitions and remonstrances for and against the Broadway Railroad, and against overcrowding street cars and stages, were presented. A bill was introduced providing for the voluntary consolidation of railroad companies. The resolution in favor of paying the interest falling due on State stocks in paper money instead of coin was called up, and debated at considerable length. The question was taken on the amendment proposing to pay the accruing interest to foreign bond-holders in coin, and it was lost by a vote of 17 against 9. The original resolution was then adopted. Other subjects of less general interest were also passed upon.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. "Faust" was given here last night to an overwhelming audience. The performance was, in all respects, excellent, and needs but a few words of remark. Signor BIACHI being ...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Faust" was given here last night to an overwhelming audience. The performance was, in all respects, excellent, and needs but a few words of remark. Signor BIACHI being sick, Herr HERMANNS took his place. The last-mentioned gentleman will be remembered as a member of Mr. ANSCHUTZ's German company. He appeared with merited success in the "Merry Wives of Windsor," and in one or two minor parts subsequently rendered, maintained the honorable impression thus awakened. His addition to Mr. MARETZEK's company, last night, was, of course, a matter of necessity, but we think it may hereafter be a matter of choice. Mr. HERMANNS has a voice of beautiful quality, not powerful and striking in delivery, but melodious and appreciable to a large degree. As an actor he is immeasurably the best Mephistophiles we have had here. The rondo of the second act, although sung in German, won a deserved encore mainly because it was sung with an inclsive satanic spirit that has never before been infused into it. Mr. HERMANNS' acting, indeed, throughout was so good that -- whatever may be its precise Goethian value -- it gave a dramatic significance to a role that so far has only been musical in its direct interest. We may add here, as a matter of justice to the gentleman we have named, that he is fully competent to the task of singing the part in Italian, but being called upon at short notice, he had not time to learn the words.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday the Mayor sent in a veto message on the resolutions authorizing the Third-avenue Railroad Company to extend their tracks through ...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday the Mayor sent in a veto message on the resolutions authorizing the Third-avenue Railroad Company to extend their tracks through Chambers-street to Broadway, East Thirty-fourth-street to the ferry, &c., on the ground that the company do not possess the exclusive right to run cars on the Third-avenue, as set forth in the preamble to the resolutions, the grant under which they operate having been given by the Common Council in 1852, and which he regards as a license; that the right sought to be given in the resolutions is in contravention of the Act of 1860 relative to railroads in this City; that no provision is made, as in the case of the Harlem road, to benefit the City treasury by it; and that the Third-avenue Company, although a wealthy corporation, decline to pay the license fees imposed upon them by the City ordinances. The board adopted a resolution in favor of recommending the Legislature to permit the City to donate a plot of land on Ward's Island to the "Society for the Protection of Destitute Roman Catholic Orphan Children in the City of New-York," provided they will use the the same exclusively for buildings to be erected in furtherance of the object of the society. To the resolution of inquiry why he has not perfected the purchase of the Fort Ganeavoot property, Comptroller BRENNAN sent in a communication, accompanied with legal opinions -- all making a lengthy document, which was ordered to be published in [???]. The substance of the whole is, that the lawyers think the mandamus of the Supreme Court, to compel the Comptroller to issue the bonds to pay for the property, likely will be affirmed by the Court of Appeals, and that, in such a event, he would be personally liable for damages, he having overstepped the purely ministerial line of his duty. The Board considered and passed the special order -- the Annual Appropriation Bill -- with an increase of $2,000 to the item for City Dispensaries, and new items as follows: To purchase MILLS' statue of JACKSON, $33,500; to prepare a Division Parade-ground, $40,000; for lithographing and engraving for, and binding of the Corporation Manual, $20,000; Northwestern Dispensary -- construction of new building, $10,000; removal of obstructions in Hell-gate, $40,000; improvement of the Russ pavement, $100,000; resetting boundary monument stones above Fourteenth-street, $40,000; settlement of claims for damages by the powder explosion, foot of East Seventy-eighth-street, $40,000; working Eighth-avenue as a country road, from One Hundred and Forty-second-street to Harlem River, $10,000 -- making a grand total increase of $335,500 over the amount reported by the Finance Committtee, and of $398,049 37 over the estimates of the Comptroller. In a discussion upon the propriety of reducing the Corporation Counsel's contingencies from $30,000 to $20,000, (he had asked for $50,000). Mr. HARDY stated that of last year's fund Mr. DEVELIN had paid out $12,000 during the last quarter, of which $7,200 went to the Assistant Corporation Counsel, as extra pay, over and above a handsome salary. The City Budget now to go before the Council Board, foots up $5,737,568 02, and inclusive of the appropriations to pay that part of the City debt falling due this year, and interest on Stocks and Loans, makes a full total of $8,411,313 23, and added to the County Budget ($5,854,907 65) already passed, a grand total of $14,266,220 88. The board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. of Monday, the 21st instant.

abstract: The report of the Finance Committee of the Board of Aldermen, which we publish in another part of this morning's paper, is a document worthy of careful perusal. It sets forth in detail, and with great fullness, the aggregate expenditures of our City and County, and shows to what branches of the public service their rapid and enormous increase is due. We shall have occasion to refer to the statements of this document hereafter.

abstract: Interview with Gen. Lee. Mr. Waldron's Statement
snippet: Interview with Gen. Lee. Mr. Waldron's Statement
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. F. WALDRON, said to be a respectable and responsible gentleman, a member of the Maryland Legislature, has communicated to a committee of Congress the fact that soon after the battle of Antietam, Gen. MCCLELLAN had an interview of some three hours with Gen. LEE, the Commander of the rebel forces. In a card published over his own signature, Mr. W. states that Gen. LEE came within our lines under his escort, he having received from Gen. MCCLELLAN a pledge of personal safety for both, -- that the interview was held at the suggestion of a mutual friend, and took place two or three days after the battle.

abstract: We very much regret to say that the storm now in part raging, has made a perfect wreck of the ill-fated steamship Bohemian. In the height of the strong northeasterly gale yesterday, every vehicle that could be procured was early engaged for a visit to the scene of the disaster. From our special reporter, who left late yesterday afternoon, we learn that the ship was rapidly breaking up, and that the shores were strewed with the debris of the wreck. Packages of valuable goods came ashore, and many articles were washing about the seaweed, boxes of tea, many of them bursted, gloves, neckties, belts, silks, stockings, and every imaginable article, which were fished up by the multitude present. There were a large number of men present to protect the property, but it was so scattered and so broken up, that it was impossible to secure it all. Indeed, it would have been useless to have attempted it. Spools of cotton, skeins of silk and thread, torn silks, and other fragments were floating about at the mercy of the waves. The saddest walls of all were three bodies that washed ashore, a little girl, a woman and a man. The man was in a state perfectly recognizable, but we have not learned his name. The sea broke in furiously, the billows rushing in as if rejoicing over their prey. It is hardly necessary to speak of the awful grandeur of the scene, to those who are familiar with one of these wild storms on our coast. -- Portland Advertiser, March 8.

abstract: The Philadelphia Telegraph of yesterday says "that a letter has been received from a friend of the late brave Col. DAHLGREN, who served with that unfortunate officer during the recent raid about Richmond, which states emphatically that the so-called 'order' alleged to have been found upon the body of DAHILGREN, was a fabrication and forgery in to...
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Telegraph of yesterday says "that a letter has been received from a friend of the late brave Col. DAHLGREN, who served with that unfortunate officer during the recent raid about Richmond, which states emphatically that the so-called 'order' alleged to have been found upon the body of DAHILGREN, was a fabrication and forgery in to[???]. No such order was ever written, issued, printed, or even considered by the noble young Colonel, as far as his friends are apprized. It is believed that this miserable lie was gotten up for effect, to cover the indignities visited upon the remains of DAHLGREN."

abstract: -We give this morning a letter from a special correspondent containg the details of the recent murder of Messrs. STEVENS and MILLS, in Arizona, and the attack upon Col. BUTTERWORTH's party. The accuracy of this news, when lately telegraphed here from the Pacific coast, was denied by Mr. SYLVESTER MOWRY, of Arizina, but Mr. MOWRY has now acknowledged his error, and confessed that he was himself misled by "-dispatches which were sent to him for the purpose of setting at rest the anxiety of friends of the survivors."

abstract: A system of theft of a startling nature was brought to light before Justice DOWLING, of the Tombs Police Court, yesterday afternoon. It scarcely has a parallel for boldness and knavery in all the accounts of thieving which from time to time are recorded by the press of this City. Seven porters and one clerk, all in the employ of the firm of Messrs. CLAFLIN & Co., wholesale merchants in Church-street and West Broadway, have, by their confession in court, admitted that for months past they have daily robbed their employers by stealing silks, velvets, and other valuable goods. The amount stolen is variously estimated at from $15,000 to $20,000. The firm had unlimited confidence in the honesty of several of these men; they had been with them a long time, and no suspicionof their inte rity was ever entertained until a few days since.

abstract: Boston Post on Editor TIMES and Slavery Constitutional Amendment
snippet: Boston Post on Editor TIMES and Slavery Constitutional Amendment
lead_paragraph: We learn from the Boston Post that "the editor of the NEW-YORK TIMES is reported in Washington as working assiduously to prevent the passage of the act providing for an amendment of the Constitution to abolish Slavery." We think, in spite of the authority quoted, that this is a mistake. If the editor of the TIMES is "working assiduously" anywhere, it is in New-York, and not in Washington. He has cultivated, moreover, with some success, the habit of attending to his own business, and leaving the members of Congress to attend to theirs, and he generally "works" through the columns of the TIMES rather than in the Congressional lobbies. He has expressed the opinion through that channel that there is no occasion whatever just now for the passage of such an act, -- that Slavery is being much more rapidly, certainly and wisely abolished by the action of the Slave States and the movement of our armies than it could be by amending the Constitution, and that the country has nothing to gain by throwing this new bone of contention into the Presidential canvass. Having thus expressed his sentiments on the subject, he is quite willing to leave the whole matter to the wisdom of Congress.

abstract: A private letter from Fortress Montroe, of the 6th inst., says: Last evening, as Gen. KILPATRICK was leaving here to return to his command at Yorktown, news reached Gen. BUTLER that the enemy had been troubling our lines between Portsmouth and Suffolk. Gen. BUTLER at once stopped the Yorktownboat, and a consultation took place between him and Gen. KILPATRICK. The result is, that Gen. KILPATRICK and his command were removed from Yorktown and Portsmouth during last night, and are now with our forces at the lines front of Portsmouth, or on the advance in pursuit of the enemy.

abstract: The Exchange of, the Terms of; Richmond Dispatch
snippet: The Exchange of, the Terms of; Richmond Dispatch
lead_paragraph: According to the Richmond Dispatch, the exchange of prisoners has been resumed, we giving them not only man for man, but 25 per per cent. more, representing the excess in the number of their prisoners in our hands over the number of our prisoners in theirs. In other words, for every hundred prisoners which we receive from the rebels, we deliver one hundred and twenty-five to them -- one hundred being regularly exchanged, and the remaining twenty-five on parole. Eight hundred rebel prisoners have, according to the same authority, been handed over to the Confederate authorities on these terms, and if the arrangement continues, we shall very shortly have no prisoners in our keeping, nor the rebels any in theirs.

abstract: BRUTAL ASSAULT ON A POLICEMAN SOME OF THE GUILTY PARTIES IN CUSTODY. At a late hour on Thursday evening, Officer KEARNEY, of the Twentyfirst Precinct, while patroling his beat in Third-avenue, near Fortieth-street, was suddenly attacked by a gang of young men, whom the police represent as thieves. One of them, without any provocation, threw a potato, which struck the officer on the head.
lead_paragraph: BRUTAL ASSAULT ON A POLICEMAN -- SOME OF THE GUILTY PARTIES IN CUSTODY. -- At a late hour on Thursday evening, Officer KEARNEY, of the Twenty-first Precinct, while patroling his beat in Third-avenue, near Fortieth-street, was suddenly attacked by a gang of young men, whom the police represent as thieves. One of them, without any provocation, threw a potato, which struck the officer on the head. He thereupon made an attempt to arrest his assailant, when the friends of the latter, consisting of more than a dozen, suddenly attacked the officer and beat him about the head and face, inflicting serious, if not dangerous wounds. The policeman held fast to his prisoner, and defended himself in the best manner he could, until Officer COUGHLIN came to his assistance. A desperate struggle then ensued between the two officers and the rowdies, during which the latter were pretty well punished with the policemen's clubs, and four of them, viz.: THOMAS COOLEY, JOHN PICKET, JOHN BRADY and MICHAEL WHALEN, were arrested, the others fled. The police say that BRADY and COOLEY are already under $1,000 bonds each to answer a charge of highway robbery committed recently, only a few steps from where the officer was assaulted. The accused were committed to answer.

abstract: At noon yesterday a most distressing accident occurred on the East River, which resulted in the loss of the lives of seven persons. Since the use of Ricker's Island as a recruiting depot, there has been a ferry established between that place and Port Morris, consisting of an ordinary row boat, which has been used for conveying the friends of soldiers to and from the Island. The boatmen have frequently been cautioned against overloading their frail craft, but have disregarded the caution and continued to carry heavy freights. Yesterday, nine persons, together with three boatmen, started in a small boat for the island. The twelve persons so crowded it that it was with difficulty managed. After reaching a point about a dozen yards from the shore the boat lurched, partially filled with water and sank. Seven of the occupants, namely, JULIA, EVA and LENA ABLE, Mrs. MANLY, a child 7 years of age, a Lieutenant of artillery and a lady, both unknown, CATHERINE KEEFE, ELIZA SCHULTZ and the three boatmen were saved. Among the latter, was one WEEKS, owner of the boat. It is stated that the accident was caused by the Lieutenant who was intoxicated at the time and would not keep his place. There was a rumor last evening that some of the bodies had been recovered, and that an inquest would be held on them this morning.

abstract: Report analyzed, No. 5
lead_paragraph: The Congressional Naval Committee recently appointed by Congress to determine upon a site for a new navy-yard, passed through this City Thursday. The following gentlemen, composing the committee, Hons. Rice, Kelley, Morehead, Rollins, Kasson, Scofield, Deming, Brandagee, Sedgwick, Pike, Broomall and Maj.-Gens. Schenck and Garfield, arrived about 9 o'clock and took quarters at the Astor House. At 11 o'clock an informal meeting was held in parlor No. 34, when it was decided to pay Admiral PAULDING a visit. Accordingly, about 1 1/2 o'clock, the committee proceeded to the Navy-yard, where they were received with the usual honors. At 4 o'clock the gentlemen left the City on one of the Norwich and Worcester boats, for New-London, Conn., which place is prominently spoken of as a favorable location for a navy-yard.

abstract: A young man named JOHN FOUENTY, a native of Hong Kong, China recently arrived in this City, having made his escape from Savannah, Ga., where he was conscripted. JOHN speaks but little English. His story, which is undoubtedly true, is somewhat interesting. He says his people are quite "well to do in China, but owing to some arrangement which he could never exactly understand, he found himself at seven years of age shipped as a coolie on board a vessel bound for Cuba. His term of "apprenticeship" being out at the expiration of four years, he was furnished with money to pay his passage home. He made an arrangement with the captain of a bark which was, as he was informed, to sail direct for China. He paid $30 for his passage, and in four or five days afterward was surprised to find himself in St. Augustine, Florida. The captain explained the matter by saying his passenger shipped under a mistake, and that his vessel was going no further. This was in 1862. Some kind gentlemen, residents of St. Augustine, hearing JOHN's story, took him in charge and sent him to school for a year, when he moved to Savannah. There he learned the cigar-maker's trade. At the breaking out of the rebellion, he was induced to join the rebel army, in which he served for a year. He was then mustered out, being under age. The last rebel Conscription Act brought JOHN under the rule, and he was accordingly notified. Determined not to fight any more under the rebel flag, he seized the first favorable opportunity to make his escape to St. Augustine. The Provost-Marshal of that place kindly furnished him with transportation to New-York. JOHN is now trying to get passage to China, hoping to see his people once more, His news is not of a very late date. He says that before he left Savannah JEFF. DAVIS came there and addressed the people. He was asked the question. "When will the war be over?" JEFF. replied, "Don't, for Heaven's sake, ask me such a question. Not until the Yankees give up." In the latter part of January, there were but three regiments in the city and the fortifications surrounding it. There are but two forts on the river, but the channel has been obstructed in several places, the obstructions extending seven or eight miles below the city. When he left Savannah, flour was $120 per bbl.; beef, $100 do.; boots, $150 a pair; Havana cigars, $2 a piece; board at hotels, $15 per day; mixed drinks, $3 each.

abstract: This battery having reenlisted and recruited to the number of about one hundred men, and being about to return to the war, were handsomely enter  tained by a dinner at National Hall, in Forty-fourthstreet, on Thursday evening last, by a few friends of Capt. WHEELER and the men. A splendid banner was presented to the battery by several lady friends of Capt. W., to supply the place of the old one which ...
lead_paragraph: This battery having reenlisted and recruited to the number of about one hundred men, and being about to return to the war, were handsomely entertained by a dinner at National Hall, in Forty-fourth-street, on Thursday evening last, by a few friends of Capt. WHEELER and the men. A splendid banner was presented to the battery by several lady friends of Capt. W., to supply the place of the old one which was given them in the Autumn of 1861, and which was brought home full of honorable scars, attesting the bravery of the men and the many bloody battles it has been through. The tapestry of the old flag being nearly entire, was neatly transferred to the new one, and the names of the eight principal battles the battery have been engaged in are embroidered on it.

abstract: and Havana Consulate; Havana Consulate and Hon. Horatio Ballard
snippet: and Havana Consulate; Havana Consulate and Hon. Horatio Ballard
lead_paragraph: -- The rejection of the Hon. HORATIO BALLARD, by the Senate, as Consul to Havana, strikes down an honorable, upright, devoted and loyal citizen. Judge BALLARD was a Democrat. At the outbreak of the rebellion he took prompt and earnest ground in favor of the Administration. His zeal and influence for the war indicated him as a suitable candidate for Secretary of State of the State of New-York. He was nominated and elected. In that office he honestly endeavored to do his duty to his country and his party. But in the selection of canal officers he incurred the displeasure of individuals who conspired to defeat his appointment as Consul -- an appointment conferred without his knowledge, but upon convictions of his fitness for the position.
headline: {'main': 'THE HAVANA CONSULATE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE HAVANA CONSULATE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Declination of Presidential Nomination
lead_paragraph: Secretary CHASE has done himself new honor in refusing to let his name be longer used in connection with the Presidential nomination. His letter to the member of the Ohio Senate is very timely, and in all respects very appropriate. He defers gracefully to the almost unanimous decision of the Union members of the Legislature of his own State in favor of the reelection of President LINCOLN; and thus, without unduly sacrificing any honorable ambition, prevents all use of his popularity for any purpose calculated to generate discord among loyal men.

abstract: Bearings upon this Country
lead_paragraph: The relations of the Western Powers to the Schleswig-Holstein imbroglio are very unsatisfactory and critical, and the refusal of Denmark to take part in the conference proposed by England tends still more to complicate matters. The tone of the English Press continues to be strongly in favor of Denmark, and the probabilities of English interference are strong; if it take place, it may be safely predicted that the occupation of the Prussian-Rhine provinces by the French will soon follow, and that this will in turn lead to a movement against Venice on the part of the Italians. This, of course, means neither more nor less than a European war of the first magnitude, and well calculated to try to the uttermost the strength of every Power engaged in it: It would probably result in the dismemberment of Prussia, the reduction of Austria to the second class of Powers, the restoration of Poland, and the consolidation of Italy. These are changes which, of course, all students of foreign politics would watch with great interest; but the results of the war are nevertheless not of so much moment to us at present as the influence which the war itself would exercise on our affairs at home during its progress.

abstract: Chesapeake Case; Rebel Prize Law
lead_paragraph: The most diligent student of history will have to look long, if he would find more impudent assumptions than the rebels have put forth. If any hypothesis has seemed to them more favorable for their purposes than another, they have adopted it in spite of all absurdity. If any principle has stood in their way, they have set it aside, no matter though it were as well settled as the laws of gravitation. Any views of the laws of war, of the principles of finance, of international law, or of internal economies, which has squared with the requirements of any occasion, they have seized just as boldly, and proclaimed just as loudly, though it were contrary to all experience and all philosophy, as if it had been the product of the wisdom of the ages.

abstract: The Exchange of
lead_paragraph: We have the authority of a reliable gentleman from Fortress Monroe for stating that the rebel Gen. FITZHUGH LEE, the son of Gen. ROBERT E. LEE, who has been in our hands as a prisoner of war since the early part of last Summer, was sent to Richmond in the flag of truce-boat that left Fortress Monroe on Friday afternoon, last at 5 o'clock. He was accompanied by Capt. MORGAN, brother of the guerrilla JOHN MORGAN, and by Capt. TYLER and Dr. GREENWOOD, who is also a Colonel. FITZHUGH LEE is exchanged for NEAL, Dow; but one of the motives leading to this exchange, which were at the instance of the Confederate Government was, that the rebels, as a condition of it, consented to exchange Capts. SAWYER and FLYNN for the rebel officers of the same rank. It will be remarked that the two latter officers have been for a long time in Richmond under sentence of death as retaliation for Gen. BURNSIDE's execution of two rebel recruiting officers in Kentucky. On no other condition than the above would the Government have consented to an exchange of FITZHUGH LEE.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a bill was introduced, authorizing the North and East River Railroad route, which is to run through Central Park, to change its route. The bill to authorize the Erie Railroad Company to increase their capital stock eight millions was ordered to a third reading. A bill was introduced requiring all City railroads in New-York to make monthly reports and pay ten per cent, of their gross receipts into the City treasury, and keep in repair the streets through which their tracks run. The enacting clause in the bill relative to legal advertising in the City of New-York, increasing the rates to eighty cents per folio, was stricken out.

abstract: Our correspondent with Gen. Lee's army furnishes us with an account of the movement on Charlottsville, which we are forced to abbreviate in consequence of lack of space. abstract: Magazines for March
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly, (Boston, TICKNOR & FIELDS,) spreads an attractive bill of fare before its readers. The first article that will be generally turned to, in all probability, is BAYARD TAYLOR's paper on WILLIAM MAKEPEACE THACKERAY. Written, as it is, from personal recollections, and relating many interesting traits of character and anecdotes of THACKERAY, it contains more novelty than any of the similar tributes that the English press now teems with. "The Queen of California" is a curious resume of an old romance of chivalry of the Amadis de Gaul cycle. "Esplandiar" wherein the name is given to a country, (twenty-five years before the discovery of our California,) containing no metal but gold. It is described as an island "on the right hand of the Indies;" and it would appear that CORTEZ adopted the name he conferred on the country from the romance, by a strange and almost prophetic anticipation of its riches. "Wet Weather Work, by a Farmer," (Ik. Marvel,) contains the customary blending of solid, and often recondite information on agriculture, with the graceful amenities of the literary essayist. Fiction is represented solely by Miss CHEESEBORO's "Ambassadors in Bonds." "Our Soldiers" and the "Peninsular Campaign" are well written articles on subjects of current interest -- the latter a searching review of the official reports of those operations. The poetry is contributed by JOHN G. WHITTIER, Dr. O.W. HOLMES and ALICE CARY, and sustains the reputation of those writers. Dr. HOLMES' "Our Classmate," written on the death of a fellow student, is a poem that will touch many hearts. Mr. CABOT's learned and thoughtful essay "On the Relation of Art to Nature," is concluded in the present number. Mrs. STOWE continues with spirit her "House and Home Papers;" and ROBERT DALE OWEN finishes his account of a very disagreeable subject, "The Convulsionists of St. Medard." A critical notice of WHITTIER, by D.A. WASSON, ends the list of original papers.

abstract: Victor Hugo is said to be busily engaged correcting the proof-sheets of his work on Shakespeare, which will bear the title, Shakespeare, by V.H., his conscious inferiority not allowing him to place his name on the same page with our great dramatist. It will be published by M. Pag[???] and Messrs. Lacroix & Co., who give him ?2,000 [???] the copyright of the first edition. His other new book, Les Chansons des Rues et des Bois, has been withdrawn [???] the printer, and will not appear before next year. It was Mr. Lacroix who boldly stated his entire capital upon the copyright of Les Meserables, after larger houses had declined to give the great price asked.

abstract: The Police Department of this City have thus far raised the sum of $3,600 for the benefit of the Sanitary Commission. There are several Precincts yet to hear from, and it is believed that when all the donations are in, the amount will not fall short of $4,000 -- probably it will exceed that sum. Many of the officers and men of the force are very active and energetic in the cause.

abstract: "Amercus," Georgia, the point to which several thousands of our prisoners have already been transferred, is a village in the southwestern part of the State on the Southwestern Railroad, which diverges from the Georgia Central Railroad just below Macon. This location is significant -- it shows that the rebels realize that they are gradually being fenced in. From Americus the prisoners can only be removed, for further safe-keeping, to the swamps of Southern Georgia and Florida. The Chattahoochee, the Flint and the Suwanee Rivers traverse this country, and furnish fish, fevers and alligators for the population, now increased by several thousand loyal Unionists.

abstract: On the 25th February, the ship Victory, from Liverpool, arrived here, and on the next day the TIMES gave a detailed statement of the brutality with which the passengers alleged they had been treated, and of the shooting of PATRICK MAGUIRE and THOS. O'BRIEN, and the killing of the latter, by the first mate, COOK. The charges of bad treatment were denied by the agent of the owner, who, in his card, also stated that he felt satisfied that the mate was justified in shooting the passengers referred to. Charges were subsequently made against a portion of the crew for mutiny, but on the hearing before U.S. Commissioner OSBORN he dismissed them, entertaining the opinion that sailors were entitled to certain rights as well as their superiors. BERNARD CASSERLY, Esq., agent for the Commissioners of Emigration, on hearing the allegations of the passengers, took an active interest in their behalf, and through them, in behalf of all emigrants. A warrant was at once taken out for COOK on the charge of murder. He evaded the officers and fled to Boston. Deputy U.S. Marshal MCKAY, and Detective BLACKWELL, of the Harbor Police, had his arrest in charge. His whereabouts were unknown, but he had left some clothing where he had quartered in this City, on which they kept an eye, and a few days since they ascertained he had arranged to have it sent on to Boston on Friday by express. The clothes were sent, but the two officers followed them, and when Boston was reached and COOK presented himself to receive the express package, he was arrested. The officers who have so adroitly managed the matter will be here this morning with their prisoner.

abstract: At Richmond; Plan to Blow Up if Town Assaulted
snippet: At Richmond; Plan to Blow Up if Town Assaulted
lead_paragraph: If the report is true that the rebels had mined the Libby Prison, and placed therein one hundred barrals of powder, to blow up the building and the prisoners in it, upon the entrance of KILPATRICK's troopers, then, but for the loss of brave lives, we could almost wish they had succeeded. For that amount of powder exploding at once, would not only have blown up the Libby, but would have blown the whole City of Richmond from its foundations, and a large part of the Confederacy beside, and JEFF. DAVIS, as well as his Cabinet, and all the other traitorous miscreants, would have been "hoist by his own petard." Last Summer, it will be remembered, we had an explosion of only a few hundred pounds of powder in Seventy-third-street, in this City, which careened vessels over in East River, shook windows of houses seven miles off, and blew all the babies out of their cradles for blocks around. JEFF. DAVIS may take this hint, and if he can't escape by running the blockade, he can at least blow himself, companions and possessions all into eternity with a couple hundred kegs of powder.

abstract: Democracy the, and Emperor Napoleon
lead_paragraph: "All excesses," says WASHINGTON, "are dangerous to liberty;" and there is no country where this saying has been so often verified as in France. As the atrocities of the Reign of Terror brought about that reaction which led to the establishment of the first Empire, so the extravagancies of the Socialists were made to serve as a pretext for the setting up of the second, which has acquired stability from the schism between the Bourgeoise and the Operatives. Since the coup d'etat of '52, the strong hand of the Imperial Government has kept this schism from producing any marked effects, but now it suddenly begins to give signs of vitality once more, and that at a time when the combined efforts of the two great sections of the people are especially needed to sustain the cause of constitutionalism. In Paris, where every man, not a minor or a convict, can be a candidate for the Legislature, or an elector, certain of the working classes have just put forth a manifesto, in which they complain that their order is not properly represented in the Lower Chamber that there is not one among the Deputies who takes the trouble to expound or support their interests, and that they are tired of merely playing the part of voters at the requisition of a group of journalists who assume the exercise of a monopoly in electoral matters. Artisans are eligible to the Corps Legislatif, and they can see no reason why operatives should not be equally privileged. The recent triumph of the Parisians has, it seems opened their eyes. It has demonstrated the force and number of their body. They constitute a vast majority of the electors, and the candidates who get elected by their means have more need of them than they have of the candidates, therefore they are determined that in the next Legislature the "head and brains of France" shall be represented, at least in part, by some of her workers.

abstract: Downing vs. Kelly, Sheriff; Wrongful Levy
snippet: Downing vs. Kelly, Sheriff; Wrongful Levy
lead_paragraph: George R. Downing vs. Kelly, Sheriff. -- Trover for a large amount of diamonds, jewelry and watches levied upon by the defendant, as Sheriff, in 1860, under an attachment issued at the suit of Jacques Shei[???] vs. Samuel Baldwin. The plaintiff claimed under a mortgage executed by Batterson and Baldwin, who were purchasers from Samuel Baldwin. The mortgage to the plaintiff was to secure him for having become surety for Batterson and Baldwin in a replevin suit commenced by them against the present defendant, which was afterward discontinued, and also, to secure notes of Batterson and Baldwin, which they had given to plaintiff on account of the indebtedness of Samuel Baldwin to the firm of G.R. Downing & Co. The principal question contested was the validity of the sale by Samuel Baldwin to Batterson and Baldwin. Sealed verdict ordered. For plaintiff E. Pierrepont and I.R. Cox. For defendant A.J. Vanderpoel and I.T. Townsend.

abstract: Richmond Whig on Moral Support of; Whig Rejoices in Moral Support of Fernando Wood, Pierce and T. H. Seymour
snippet: Richmond Whig on Moral Support of; Whig Rejoices in Moral Support of Fernando Wood, Pierce and T. H. Seymour
lead_paragraph: If there is anything disgusting anywhere, it is the pharisaic assumption with which the rebels occasionally take to themselves all Christian excellencies. Here are a parcel of men who have raised a causeless revolt against a Government which had been nothing but beneficent to them; who have rebelled against free institutions in the interest of Slavery, the "sum of all villianies;" who began their work by robberies the most gigantic, frauds the most dishonest, breaches of faith the most atrocious; who have plunged a nation into civil war and shed oceans of the best blood of the land; who have beggared thousands of families, brought grief and shame into thousands more; who have in the name of liberty perpetrated the most atrocious crimes; who have been guilty of barbarities worthy of savages and utterly innumerable; who have shrunk from no oppression, refrained from no crime; whose whole career has been one of treachery, broken pledges, robbery, extortion and cruelty; and yet every now and then one of the gang will descant upon the purity of their motives, the nobleness and magnanimity of their actions, the glory of their deeds, and the innumerable merits of their cause.
