abstract: The residents of Washington Heights have had this school directly in their midst for many years, but in consequence of the failure of the managers to raise it to the proper standard, only a small portion of the community have sent their children to it, while the remaining and much the larger portion have sent their children to private schools, or to other public schools at a distance from their homes.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Washington Heights have had this school directly in their midst for many years, but in consequence of the failure of the managers to raise it to the proper standard, only a small portion of the community have sent their children to it, while the remaining and much the larger portion have sent their children to private schools, or to other public schools at a distance from their homes. A vacancy occurring in the office of the principal of this school, great exertions were made by the heads of families to find a person, with the proper qualifications of intelligence and character, to fill the position, so that all classes might send their children to this school. Such a person they found in a vice-principal of a neighboring school, (one of the first in the City) numbering over 2,500 scholars, with which he had been connected as teacher and vice-principal for upward of thirteen years. He was also well and favorably known in the Twelfth Ward, and had been from his boyhood. A very large number of students, prepared principally by him, had been from time to time sent from his school to the Free Academy. The people wanted such a man as principal of this school. Unfortunately, just before the matter came up for decision, the decease of the Hon. JAMES C. WILLET, late Commissioner, occurred; and though he was strongly in favor of appointing this principal, a delicate regard for his memory, prevented his colleagues filling the vacancy of Commissioner before the appointment of a principal for this school. A petition recommending the above-mentioned person, signed by upward of one hundred and fifty of the residents in that vicinity, most of them heads of families, and having the true interest of the school at heart, was utterly disregarded, and a stranger, unknown to the people, and who was known to have had his license as teacher revoked by the former Superintendent of Public Schools, in this City, for "immoral and unchaste conduct," was elected in the place of the person desired by the inhabitants. The people deeming this conduct of the majority of the Trustees uncalled for and oppressive, held a public meeting at Mills' Hall, Washington Heights, on Friday night, 4th inst., pursuant to the following call:

abstract: HOSE COMPANY THIRTY TO THEIR FRIENDS  Hose Company No. 30, of No. 244 West Twentyseventh-street, make an earnest appeal to their neighbors and friends to assist them by donations of any kind in their effort in behalf of the Metropolitan Fair.
lead_paragraph: HOSE COMPANY THIRTY TO THEIR FRIENDS. -- Hose Company No. 30, of No. 244 West Twenty-seventh-street, make an earnest appeal to their neighbors and friends to assist them by donations of any kind in their effort in behalf of the Metropolitan Fair. The Carnage House is open from 7 to 10 o'clock, Monday, Wednesday and Friday evenings. Hose Company No. 30 is a first-class organization; their invaluable services in their neighborhood during the riots, as citizen police, as well as firemen, will be remembered. Their friends should see to it, that donations flow in upon them thick and fast. The committee are Messrs. L.D. RECHARDS, JOHN BROWN, L.M. STARRETT, R.M. BELL and W.M. VOSE.

abstract: Our sanctum was yesterday honored by a visit from Col. T.B. THORPE. Frequently as we have pressed the Colonel to call upon us, from some reason or other he did not accept the invitation, probably for fear of just what we are doing -- betraying his penchant toward the craft, editors, printers and their devils! What more natural? Col. THORPE, as everybody knows, was one of the editors of the famous Tropic, and his reminiscences of days agone, his experiences of editorial life, of men and scenes at that time, are instructing and amusing, and would really form subjects for a most entertaining book. We could wish for no more agreeable time than that enlivened by the Colonel's spicy conversation, or for a more humorous sketch than that furnished by the racy pen of the " Bee Hunter." -- New-Orleans Times, Feb. 28.

abstract: The enormous prices of merchandise of every description which have prevailed in the Confederate States for months past are attributable to two primary causes: 1. The excessive and constantly increasing redundancy of the currency; 2. The insufficiency of transportation. The effect of the superabundant currency was to produce an artificial scarcity.

abstract: The Richmond Whig, of March 9, says that it will take about a week more to rebuild the railroad to LEE's army. LEE has sent out his cavalry in all directions to seize everything in the shape of forage and subsistence for his troops. The circuitous route that everything has to come over by railroad renders it impossible for LEE to secure enough over one line to keep his army from suffering, and the farmers in the vicinity are appealed to to come forward with provisions for the troops. In an article on our repulse in Florida, the Whig admits that the rebel force was twice as large as ours.

abstract: the Finances of
lead_paragraph: The public accounts of the Province of Canada have just been submitted to the local Parliament. They appear to show a certain improvement in revenue for the past year; but the expenditure is still largely in advance of the receipts from taxation. The gross out-lay for the year was $14,909,182. Of this sum, however, only $9,760,316 was received from the ordinary sources of revenue; so that there was an actual deficiency of over $5,000,000. In mitigation of this heavy deficiency, the Finance Minister takes credit in striking his balance for over $4,000,000 applied to the redemption of the public debt, and for a further sum credited to the sinking fund. By this means his balance sheet shows thus:

abstract: Some further facts were elicited yesterday in regard to the extensive robberies which have recently been perpetrated in the wholesale silk and dry-goods store of Messrs. HORACE B. CLAFLIN & Co., a full account of which was published in the TIMES of Saturday. Capt. JOURDAN, Sergt. QUINN, and Officer GOLDEN, all of the Sixth Precinct, having received information which led them to believe that a large amount of the stolen goods was in the store of LOUIS ANDREESSEN, No. 218 Fifth-street, went to that place and arrested the proprietor. They then seized his entire stock of goods, amounting in the aggregate to about $1,500. An examination of these goods by Messrs. CLAFLIN & Co., revealed the fact that every article taken from ANDREESSEN's store had been stolen from them. Mr. DANIEL H. CONCKLIN, a member of the firm, positively identified the goods. Moreover the prisoner, ANDREESSEN, has confessed that at the time of purchasing the goods from ROGERS and INGLETON, two of the delinquent porters, he was aware of the fact that the goods had been stolen from some place, but where he did not pretend to know. The goods taken from ANDREESSEN were all conveyed to the Sixth Precinct Station-house.

abstract: -- The Examiner of Feb. 27, says: "Within a few days past a heavy defalcation in bonds has come to the surface of the Register's Bureau of the Confederate State's Treasury Department. The amount, so far as ascertained, is beyond seventy-five thousand dollars, of the class of bonus known as coupons 8's. 7's and 6's per cent., and were unsigned. The Register of the Treasury, ROBERT TYLER, Esq., has instituted a most searching investigation, and an expert in such matters has been at work for several days with some success.

abstract: The Metropolitan Fair Committee on Organization have decided to erect Branch Fair buildings, on the north side of Union-square, which are to be four hundred feet in length and ninety feet in width. The branch is to be devoted to the exhibition of musical instruments, the Children's Department and the Knickerbocker Kitchen. A space will be allotted to Mr. BIERSTADT, the artist, who will have present during the Fair several Rocky Mountain Indian families, who will live according to their fashion when in their native wilds.

abstract: Chesapeake Case; The Release of the Pirates
snippet: Chesapeake Case; The Release of the Pirates
lead_paragraph: We noticed some days since that the Marshal was sending a steamboat off to Halifax to receive and bring here for trial the pirates of the Chesapeake. It occurred to us at the time that it might be a little hasty, inasmuch as the result of the habeas corpus, which had been issued in their case might be such that the vessel would go to Halifax on a fool's errand. The result thus far has been as we feared it might be. The Judge before whom the habeas corpus was heard, decides that the prisoners cannot be delivered up to our authorities, for four reasons. Three of them are merely technical, being that the requisition was informal; that the magistrate who issued the warrant had no authority to issue it, and that if he had, the warrant itself was defective on its face. These are small points, and unimportant, because we take it that our officials can make out a requisition which shall be correct, and that there are magistrates in Halifax who have authority to issue such warrants and who are able to draw them correctly -- and, if these were the only grounds of discharge, a new proceeding would doubtless cure those defects.
headline: {'main': 'New Phase of the Chesapeake Case.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'New Phase of the Chesapeake Case.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Great excitement prevails among the laboring classes in Cold Spring, particularly among those connected with the West Point Foundry, situated in that place, in consequence of a strike for higher wages. On Thursday last about three hundred men stopped work, forming themselves into a Laboring Men's Union, proceeded to the foundry en masse and compelled the men engaged there to quit work and retire to their homes. For the last 1 months over 1,200 men have been employed in this foundry, in which the celebrated Parrott guns are manufactured, and now the entire number is idle, and the works stopped.

abstract: the Bill to Complete
lead_paragraph: -- A bill is pending in the State Legislature for the completion of the Chenango Canal, which merits the support and effective action of that body. The Chenango Canal was originally constructed in large degree for the purpose of obtaining access to the coal regions of Pennsylvania. It extends from Utica to Binghamton, within about thirty miles of the State line, to which Pennsylvania some years since opened her North Branch Canal, for the express purpose of making a connection with it. It is not easy to understand why this connection has never been made. At the time when the canal policy of the State was so vehemently assailed by the party interests of the day, the work was discontinued, and has never since been resumed. But the reasons for carrying the canal thirty miles further, so as to effect a junction with the North Branch Canal of Pennsylvania, are quite as strong as were those which led to its construction; and they are quite as strong to-day as they ever were. The demand for access to the coal beds of Pennsylvania is constantly increasing, and new sources of traffic and wealth have been from time to time developed.

abstract: The season at the Academy of Music came to a close on Saturday, when a somewhat abbreviated edition of "Faust" was given at the matinee, to an exceedingly charming audience. Mr. MARETZEK, and the leading artists of his admirable troupe, took their departure by the afternoon train for Boston, where they appear to-night, returning to the Metropolis in a fortnight, and opening at the Academy of Music on Easter Monday.
lead_paragraph: The season at the Academy of Music came to a close on Saturday, when a somewhat abbreviated edition of "Faust" was given at the matinee, to an exceedingly charming audience. Mr. MARETZEK, and the leading artists of his admirable troupe, took their departure by the afternoon train for Boston, where they appear to-night, returning to the Metropolis in a fortnight, and opening at the Academy of Music on Easter Monday. The season, we need scarcely say, has been successful, and this in spite of many accidents that might have disturbed the equanimity of any other manager. Mr. MARETZEK, however, has always been equal to the emergency of the moment, and has never suffered the public to be once disappointed. Nearly all his leading artists, at one time or another have been sick, and "Faust," the great card of the season, has from this cause been in danger of postponement. But Mr, MARETZEK contrived to find a substitute at the right moment, and generally an acceptable one. Let us hope that he may be equally fortunate in Boston, where the spring winds usually commit havoc amongst the warblers.

abstract: -- At the suggestion of Mayor GUNTHER, whose administration thus far has been characterized by a very intelligent and independent devotion to the public interests, a bill has been presented to the Legislature requiring all the City railroads to pay ten per cent. of their receipts into the City treasury. This is in conformity, it will be remembered, with the ordinance which was passed last year by the Common Council, granting to the Harlem Railroad Company permission to lay down a track through Broadway. The amount required may or may not be too large, but the principle is just. These companies should contribute something to the City in return for the valuable and exclusive privileges which they enjoy. Up to the present time they have nearly monopolized the streets through which they pass solely for their own advantage -- doing nothing to aid in bearing the burdens of the City, and just as little as possible to accommodate the public. It is quite time we had a thorough reform in the management of these roads.

abstract: Interview with Lee; Truth of Statement Doubtful
snippet: Interview with Lee; Truth of Statement Doubtful
lead_paragraph: -The Commercial states that Mr. FRANCIS WALTON, the author of the story to which we have already alluded, that after the battle of Antietam Gen. MCCLELLAN had a personal interview of three hours with the rebel General LEE, has been summoned before the Congressional Committee on the Conduct of the War, but that he refuses to testify. If this is true, it effectually disposes of his slanderous accusation. The story was in itself highly improbable, and we shall not be in the least surprised if it should prove to have been either the invention of malice or the fancy of a disordered brain. As currency has been given to it, however, the Committee should omit no means of testing it thoroughly.

abstract: The Supervisors, as a Board of County Canvassers, will meet, by law, at noon to-day, to canvass the returns of the recent vote on the question of the proposed amendment to the State constitution to permit electors absent in the service of the National Government to vote. The work of the board will be a mere matter of form, the results of the vote being well known; and as the count to be made involves only the noting of the affirmative and negative vote of each election district, it will be so simple that it can all be accomplished in brief time compared with ordinary canvasses by the board, unless informalities in the returns shall frequently appear, requiring delay to enable corrections to be made.
lead_paragraph: The Supervisors, as a Board of County Canvassers, will meet, by law, at noon to-day, to canvass the returns of the recent vote on the question of the proposed amendment to the State constitution to permit electors absent in the service of the National Government to vote. The work of the board will be a mere matter of form, the results of the vote being well known; and as the count to be made involves only the noting of the affirmative and negative vote of each election district, it will be so simple that it can all be accomplished in brief time compared with ordinary canvasses by the board, unless informalities in the returns shall frequently appear, requiring delay to enable corrections to be made.

abstract: A Lesson from St. Domingo
lead_paragraph: -- Those who are busy in fastening a foreign yoke upon the Mexicans might learn something from the condition of affairs in St. Domingo. That island, like Mexico, was an ancient Spanish colony; and, shortly after our war broke out, the Spaniards, under false pretexts, landed a force on the eastern end of the island, suppressed the Dominican Republic, and established their authority. Ever since then they have been in difficulty, and for the greater part of the time they have been steadily fighting with the Dominicans. By every arrival from Havana during the past year we have had news that additional battalions of royal troops were being sent to St. Domingo, the greater part of whom have been destroyed by disease and the bullets of the Republicans. By the news published this morning, we learn of very large numbers of troops having left Havana, and we are told that the Government at Madrid is "determined to put down the insurrection at any cost." We have no doubt that it has cost them more already than the revenues of the island will return in a century; and yet, when the Spaniards seized the country, we were told how enthusiastically they were received by the populace -- just as we are now told how joyously foreign authority is being welcomed by the Mexicans. If MAXIMILIAN should ever get himself enthroned in Mexico, we venture to say that, as with the foreigners in St. Domingo, he will have steady and bloody fighting with his subjects as long as he attempts to rule them. Peoples who have once tasted republican liberty find colonial bondage or imperial authority very irksome.

abstract: Speech on Pomeroy-Chase Circular
lead_paragraph: The speech of Mr. POMEROY, in the Senate, the other day, in support of the document now known as the "Pomeroy-Chase Circular," contained some very good illustrations of the extraordinary flightiness for which politicians of his way of thinking have for some time made themselves remarkable. Nothing will persuade this school that the rebellion cannot be put down by "forms of belief." Two-thirds of their dissatisfaction with the Administration hitherto has been due to their fixed conviction, that hatred of Slavery is the only qualification required to make a competent and successful General. It is, of course, out of the question to argue with men who are of this way of thinking. People who have learnt so little about war from history, are, of course, not open to conviction at the hands of their neighbors.

abstract: The steamship Morning Star from New-Orleans, Feb. 6, arrived yesterday. She brings intelligence of the arrival at that city of Maj. Gen. W. T. SHERMAN and Staff, from Vicksburgh, thus effectually disposing of any doubts respecting the return of that General from his great raid through Mississippi and Alabama, which might have been engendered by last week's vague telegrams from the West.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Morning Star from New-Orleans, Feb. 6, arrived yesterday. She brings intelligence of the arrival at that city of Maj. Gen. W.T. SHERMAN and Staff, from Vicksburgh, thus effectually disposing of any doubts respecting the return of that General from his great raid through Mississippi and Alabama, which might have been engendered by last week's vague telegrams from the West. His expedition, according to the New-Orleans advices, was very damaging to the rebels by the wholesale destruction of every species of property which was necessary to the subsistence of their armies. Gen. SHERMAN took with him to Vicksburgh an immense train of captured property, including four thousand negroes and eleven hundred mules, besides 500 prisoners. A letter from one of the blockading vessels off Mobile says, that on the 25th ult., the bombardment of Fort Gaines was still being prosecuted vigorously by the gunboats Octorara, Port Royal, Calhoun and Jackson, with one division of the mortar flotilla.

abstract: The Fifty-sixth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, (Tenth Legion,) C.H. VAN WYCK, Colonel Commanding, will be received by the Sons of Orange and Sullivan this forenoon, at the Park Barracks. The escort will move from the Park, at 11 o'clock A.M., and march through Broadway, Astor-place and Fourth-avenue, to the Seventh Regiment Armory, the use of which has been kindly tendered for the occasion. The regimental colors, which were presented by the Sons of Orange and Sullivan to the regiment when leaving for the field two years ago, will be returned to the society for preservation, after which a collation will be served to the regiment -- tickets for which may be had of the Reception Committee, at the Armory. To-night the regiment will go to Newburgh and be received there, and on Wednesday at Middletown.

abstract: the Changes in Command--Grant, Halleck, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: We publish to-day a highly important military order dated on Saturday last, at the War Department. The main provision of the order, and the only one which is of national scope and importance, is that which relieves Gen. HALLECK from the position of General-in-Chief of the Army, and assigns Lieut.-Gen. GRANT to the "command of the armies of the United States." We presume this order confers upon the new Lieutenant-General plenary powers as acting Chief of the National forces, subject, of course, to the approval of the President. If so it be, we are confident that it will give great and general satisfaction throughout the country.

abstract: the Rebel Calumny on
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday morning a letter from Mr. E.A. PAUL, our regular correspondent with the Army of the Potomac, which confirms the belief that the rebel authorities have been guilty of deliberate forgery in regard to the papers said to have been found on the body of Col. DAHLGREN. As published in the Richmond journals, one of those papers contained the direction that on entering Richmond JEFF. DAVIS and his Cabinet were to be killed by our troops. No man of ordinary intelligence would deem this statement credible for a moment. No officer of the American army would ever dream of putting to death civil officers taken captive by such a raid, and no officer in his senses, even if he were barbarous enough to contemplate such a result, would ever put such orders in writing -- not for the guidance of his men, for these were not orders to be issued to his troops, but private memoranda of his own -- simply to damn himself to lasting infamy. Col. DAHLGREN was a high-toned gentleman, incapable of conceiving such a purpose and equally incapable of putting on record such a thought.

abstract: Seymour, Gen. and his Florida Defeat; Reverse and the Copperhead Journals
snippet: Seymour, Gen. and his Florida Defeat; Reverse and the Copperhead Journals
lead_paragraph: The Copperhead journals are doing their utmost to make the Florida reverse tell against the Administration. It strikes us that it is their own policy which has been most damaged by that event. Gen. SEYMOUR, it is now admitted, made a fatal mistake in indiscriminately trusting the loyal professions of the inhabitants along his line of march. He put faith in the general assurance that there was no armed force of any account this side of Tallahassee, and, in that belief, moved carelessly on, until he found himself ambuscaded by twice his numbers. He had observed, from his first disembarkation, the most conciliatory policy toward the people, and unduly trusted to the apparent effect which that policy had wrought. The result was that he was the victim of infamous treachery.

abstract: The excitement in regard to the strike still continues yet, in rather a subdued form. As was stated in our issue of yesterday, it has been found necessary to obtain military assistance. On Saturday afternoon a force of a hundred and twenty men, under the command of Capt. COGSDEN, arrived in Cold Spring from Governor's Island.
lead_paragraph: The excitement in regard to the strike still continues yet, in rather a subdued form. As was stated in our issue of yesterday, it has been found necessary to obtain military assistance. On Saturday afternoon a force of a hundred and twenty men, under the command of Capt. COGSDEN, arrived in Cold Spring from Governor's Island. Much indignation was expressed in consequence of this arrival by the operatives on strike, but nothing beyond an excited state of public mind has as yet been manifested. Three of the ringleaders of the strike were arrested by the military and the Sheriff of the County late on Saturday afternoon. It is rumored that they will be conveyed to Fort Lafayette until such time as a legal trial may be opened. The property and persons of the inhabitants have not been injured, and under the circumstances, the operatives have conducted themselves with greater decorum than was expected. The teachers of the foundry school, fearing that their safety was endangered, left the village late on Saturday afternoon. Sunday passed off very quietly; to the stranger, nothing unusual seemed to engage public attention.

abstract: This veteran regiment, Col. C.H. VAN WYCK, commanding, arrived yesterday on steamer Fulton, from Port Royal. The regiment was organized in 1861, in the counties of Orange and Sullivan, was in the Peninsular campaign under Gen. MCCLELLAN, and in July last was at James Island, S.C. The regiment, better known as the "Tenth Legion," took the field eleven hundred strong, since which it has been reinforced by substitutes and volunteers to the number of 300, making its total force 1,400; of that number it has nearly 860 left, 430 have returned on furlough, and have reenlisted, and nearly 300 are vet in the field. Of its original roster of about forty officers, only the following return with it: Col. VAN WYCK; Adjt. H.B. Loomis; Capts. James Dubois and and A.H. Chittenden; First Lieuts. John Metcalf, J.S. Holmes, C.B. Young, M. Dorsney, N. Crossman and R. Gillett; Second Lieuts. E. Scranston, E. Loomis, S.D. Wheat and W.H. Auchmoody. To-day they will be the recipients of a public reception by the sons of Orange and Sullivan resident in this City, and a collation at the armory of the Seventh Regiment.

abstract: and His Subordinates
lead_paragraph: -- Injustice has been done to Gens. DOUBLEDAY and SICKLES by the newspaper dispatches from Washington, which intimate that they have in any way been concerned in bringing the charges against Gen. MEADE, which have recently been investigated by the Congressional Committee. We have very good authority for saying that nothing whatever can be farther from the truth. They were summoned as witnesses by the committee because their names were introduced in the reports of both Gens, MEADE and HALLECK, in a manner implying censure of their conduct at Gettysburgh. They were summoned by the committee and questioned on the points in regard to which their action was censured, and as a matter of course they were compelled to state what they believed to be the truth. This ought not, in justice, to subject them to the charge or suspicion of having taken any part in the arraignment of Gen. MEADE, and as a matter of fact we believe both those officers have rigidly abstained from any criticism on their Commander, and from any reply to what they deemed erroneous representations of their own conduct in his report.

abstract: By the arrival of the Jura at Portland yesterday, we have five days' later news from Europe, bringing advices down to March 4. The news is not very important. Mr. MASON, the rebel envoy, had returned to London from Paris, where he had been, it is supposed, with reference to the rumored French recognition. The correspondence relative to the alleged case of murder on the bark Saxon, is published. The British Government maintain that if the facts be true, the Federal officer was guilty of murder, and this Government will have to deliver the culprit for trial, and make compensation to the family of the murdered man. Proceedings in Parliament were unimportant. In the House of Comomns the Government barely escaped defeat by one majority on the 3d. The war in Denmark was languishing. The Allies made a reconnoissance toward Duppel on the 2d. Gen. GESLACH had succeeded Gen. DE MEZA in command of the Danish army. Denmark still opposes a conference on the terms proposed. The Federal steamer Kearsage was still at Calais, on the 2d, watching the Rappahannock, so that the rumor, from Boston, of the escape of the latter, is untrue. The visit of the Archduke MAXIMILIAN to Paris is still further postponed. It was rumored that he had renounced his acceptance of the Mexican throue, but this was denied.

abstract: The question of legalizing the action of taxpayers who have voted money to aid drafted men in procuring substitutes, or paying commutation, has from time to time during the present session, excited earnest debate in the Assembly. It appears from the bills introduced that not a few localities in the State have voted to raise money upon this basis. The question of legalizing such action is a delicate one, because of its relations to patriotism.

abstract: Gen. FISKE, the Commander of the district of St. Louis, has just returned from a tour of inspection in Southeast Missouri. He reports that numerous bands of guerrillas have been committing depredations in that section and Northeastern Arkansas, and that some bands are preparing for extensive operations in the Spring. Stringent measures will be immediately taken to drive out or destroy all such bands, and establish law and order throughout the department.

abstract: The Second Fire Zouaves, under command of Lieut.-Col. M. BURNS, left yesterday, per transport, for Alexandria. Since they have been in the City they have recruited about 125 men, being more than they brought home. The men were all in excellent spirits and anxious to get back to their old brigade. A detail was left for recruiting service, so that all who wish to join the regiment may still do so by applying to their tent in the City Hall Park.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, the City Appropriation Bill was received from the other board and referred to the Finance Committee. It is understood that it will be reported at the next meeting of the board. The Comptroller reported that $62,395 were disbursed from the Relief Fund during the fortnight ending March 5, to 13,712 families, comprisieg 13,575 adults and 19,604 children; also, that a balance of $361,732 95 remained in the City Treasury on the 12th inst. The Committee on Lands and Places reported favorably upon the request of Major-Gen. DIX, made some time ago, and approved by the Mayor, for permission to remove the Park Barracks to the Battery, but the report was recommitted by a decided vote. The board adjourned to Wednesday at 2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Needs of New-York
lead_paragraph: We published a letter on Sunday, complaining bitterly of the enormous prices demanded for rooms in the up-town hotels, added to extortion on the part of waiters, porters and chambermaids; and the conclusion the writer seems to have come to is, that we need "twenty more good hotels" in the upper part of the City, and that the organization of hotel companies ought to be facilitated by a general act of the Legislature. We have not the slightest objection, but the contrary, to any movement which promises to provide additional or better hotel accommodations. New-York is becoming every day more and more of a metropolis. The Park and other attractions, social, literary, theatrical and commercial, will render it in future the resort in Winter of a larger and larger number of persons of leisure and fortune, who live in the country or in provincial towns, but will come here during the bad weather.
headline: {'main': 'Hotels versus Homes What New-York Needs.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Hotels versus Homes What New-York Needs.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Russell, Earl, on Federal Enlistments in Ireland
snippet: Russell, Earl, on Federal Enlistments in Ireland
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, on March 1, Lord CLARRICARDE moved for any reports received as to recruiting in Ireland for the North American army. He also asked whether any remonstrances againt such proceedings had been addressed to the Federal Government. He referred to the severity of the law as to the offence of enlisting men for foreign service, even down to a comparatively late period, and stated it was notorious that recruiting for the Federal army had been extensively carried on in Ireland for the last two years. He asked what steps had been taken to prevent it, believing the common law sufficient to repress it if put in force. He described the mode in which the recruiting is carried on, under the pretext of engaging men for industrial works, and contended that the practice ought to be put down with a strong hand. In the course of his speech he related the following facts:

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, numerous petitions and remonstrances against the Harlem Broadway grant were presented. Among bills reported was one incorporating the Corn Exchange Warehouse and Security Company; to prevent encroachments upon the harbor of New-York; against confiscating the Macdougal-street contract agreed to. Mr. LAIMBEER gave notice of a bill to confirm acts in the New-York Supervisors' Office relative to the late riots. Among bills introduced was one to incorporate the Catholic Library Association of Brooklyn; legalizing the volunteer bounty indebtedness, Richmond County; relative to a record in the New-York Police Courts and Court of Special Sessions, and to provide for the settlement of arrears of personal taxes in New-York. A bill was passed legalizing the bounty resolutions of the Brooklyn Common Council; authorizing the Erie Railroad Company to increase their capital stock eight millions, and liquidate three millions of bonds; naming WASHINGTON's Birthday as a legal holiday.

abstract: The New Call
lead_paragraph: The President yesterday issued a call for two hundred thousand more troops, to be enforced by draft on the 15th of April, if not sooner filled by voluntary enlistments. This call is not entirely unexpected. It may not be generally known, but it is nevertheless strictly true, that under the last call for two hundred thousand additional men in February, the Government has actually received a far less number of men than it called for, though most of the States have filled their quotas. The reason is plain. It was announced that the last call was for the purpose of squaring up accounts, and thereupon an extensive system of research and figuring was begun in every State; all loose accounts of Provost-Marshals and State authorities were balanced up; old credits, not before allowed, were brought forward and allowed on the new quota; scattering men, who had enlisted and never been credited, were counted for the first time; enlistments in the naval service have been credited as recently allowed by law; the veteran enlistments, which came in largely, were credited, and aided many localities to escape the draft; every exertion, and many systems of figuring, some of which we fear were not as straightforward as they ought to have been, were used, until many of the States have announced that their quotas were full under all calls, with a surplus. We have in memory at present New-Hampshire, Vermont, Rhode Island, Connecticut, Indiana, Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota and Kansas, and many parts of Michigan, New-York and Massachusetts, all of which have filled their quotas under all calls, and most of them have a surplus left, which is being constantly increased by veteran and volunteer enlistments not heretofore credited. The army has, notwithstanding, been largely and gratifyingly augmented, but not, by any means, to the extent of the last call. That call, as we have said, has been largely exhausted by the credits for old enlistments never before counted. Hence, this new call, though succeeding so rapidly to that of February, can and will be promptly met in most of the States, without any hardship whatever. Many localities have a surplus already to be credited on the new quota, while the necessities of the naval service, including the Marine Corps, offer a larger field than heretofore for the choice of the volunteer. Only in those localities which have been habitually behind in every quota, will the new call be considered as a hardship. This quota filled promptly and honestly, and the army will be so strengthened that we think all future calls can be dispensed with.

abstract: -General Army Order No. 98, which we gave in our issue of yesterday, states that "Major-Gen. HALLECK is, at his own request, relieved from duty as General-in-Chief of the army." This request of the General may be misunderstood by the public without some explanation. The Act of Congress of April 4, 1862, authorizes the President to assign to commands officers of different rank, but not of different grade. Gen. HALLECK was assigned, under this act, to command as General-in-Chief, although there were other Major-Generals of prior date. Now, however, when the higher grade of Lieutenant-General has been created, Gen. HALLECK could not retain his command as General-in-Chief, because the act does not allow him to command an officer of higher grade, like Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. Gen. HALLECK was the first to point out this difficulty after the higher grade had been conferred on his friend, not, indeed, in the spirit of dissatisfaction, but as a matter of law. HALLECK rejoiced in GRANT's promotion, no one probably more than he did, and at the time that he showed the impossibility of his remaining General-in-Chief, expressed his willingness to serve in any other position which the Government might think proper to assign to him. He did not throw up his appointment in dudgeon. Had Gen. HALLECK lived in those times when popular wit or favor bestowed characteristic titles on public men, he might not inaptly have been called the "Unambitious." There is perhaps no officer in the army that wears his breast buttons parted into threes, who is less ambitious, and more ready to serve in any capacity, so that he can serve his country.

Now, however, when the higher grade of Lieutenant-General has been created, Gen. HALLECK could not retain his command as General-in-Chief, because the act does not allow him to command an officer of higher grade, like Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. Gen. HALLECK was the first to point out this difficulty after the higher grade had been conferred on his friend, not, indeed, in the spirit of dissatisfaction, but as a matter of law. HALLECK rejoiced in GRANT's promotion, no one probably more than he did, and at the time that he showed the impossibility of his remaining General-in-Chief, expressed his willingness to serve in any other position which the Government might think proper to assign to him. He did not throw up his appointment in dudgeon. Had Gen. HALLECK lived in those times when popular wit or favor bestowed characteristic titles on public men, he might not inaptly have been called the "Unambitious." There is perhaps no officer in the army that wears his breast buttons parted into threes, who is less ambitious, and more ready to serve in any capacity, so that he can serve his country.

abstract: The British mail steamer from Valparaiso and intermediate ports arrived at Panama yesterday. Her news, which is up to the 16th of February from Valparaiso, and the 27th from Lima and Caliao, is unimportant. From Guavaquil we have dates, via Paita, to 27th February. The Republic was perfectly quiet. Most of the soldiers raised to fight against MOSQUERA'S army had returned to their homes, and planting and trade have resumed their usual course.

abstract: The Finance Committee of the Board of Councilmen yesterday reconsidered the City Appropriation Bill. The meeting was held in private, but all  persons interested in the important subject before the committee had been invited to attend and present such facts and make such requests as they wished to. Messrs. THOMAS BOESE, Clerk of the Board of Education, appeared and presented the views of that board upon what they conceive to be the absolute illegality of reducing their estimates $100,000, which the Board of Aldermen have voted to do. Mr. ANDREW H. GREEN, Comptroller of Central Park, appeared on behalf of the Central Park Commission, to argue what they believe to be an injustice to the commission and the public of reducing their estimate of $150,000 for the maintenance and government of the Park to $130,000, as voted by the Aldermen. Chief Engineer DECKER appeared in behalf of the Fire Department, to give information concerning its needs for the year; and letters in regard to their several departments were received from CHAS. G. CORNELL, Street Commissioner, JOHN E. DEVELIN, Corporation Counsel, and from the Croton Aqueduct Board. The committee will report the budget back to the board this afternoon, at 2 o'clock, when it will be taken up and passed upon.

abstract: Aspect of the
lead_paragraph: The future student of history, as he ponders upon the events of this remarkable revolution, will be especially struck with the singular ebb and flow, at almost regular intervals, of the popular feeling. At one time we are on the heights of confidence and hope, having no doubt of the speedy close of the rebellion, and seeing everything in the most rose-colored hues. At another, without any especial change in the conditions -- after, perhaps, a few misfortunes or blunders -- we are plunged in despondency and gloom, and are ready to believe that nothing has been accomplished or is likely to be.

abstract: Judge Clerke's Decision
lead_paragraph: Our readers will recollect the decision of Judge CLERKE, some time ago, in the case brought by GEO. W. JONES against Mr. SEWARD, for false imprisonment, in which he held that the case could not be transferred to the United States, because the law of the United States, which was set up as a defence, was plainly unconstitutional, and, therefore, the defence was not a "case arising under the Constitution or laws of the United Stares."

abstract: Yesterday, Gov. SEYMOUR, as we learn from our Albany dispatches, signed the Police Bill, which has been in contention for some time past, and which makes Messrs. ACTON, BOSWORTH, BERGEN and MCMURRAY Police Commissioners. We have, from the outset, advocated this bill as the correct and only compromise between the different parties, and as the only one which would be satisfactory to the public. The Governor in signing it has yielded to what has latterly been unequivocally indicated as the popular wish, and has done well and wisely. The first three of the Commissioners named were sworn in by the Secretary of State yesterday; Mr. MCMURRAY was unable to be present at that time. Thus ends, we hope, the embarrassments which have threatened to impair, if not to destroy, the value of a force which so largely owes its efficiency to Mr. ACTON, who will now be preserved to it, with associates whose intelligence, public spirit and capacity no one is disposed to impugn, and whose recognition as Commissioners will give general satisfaction.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a strongly-indorsed petition of one thousand citizens of Louisiana, of African descent, praying for the rights of suffrage in that State. Mr. WILKINSON presented a bill to repeal the Colonization Act. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the reorganization of the artillery of the regular army. Mr. DOOLITTLE introduced a bill for the better collection of taxes in insurrectionary districts. The Diplomatic Appropriation bill was taken up, and an amendment was adopted, mailing the Belgian mission of the first-class, without corresponding pay. Without concluding action on the bill, the Senate adjourned.

Present bounties will be paid to April 1, after which time only one hundred dollars regular bounty will be paid by the Government.

abstract: Gov. Vance's Speech; Speech on N. C. and the War
snippet: Gov. Vance's Speech; Speech on N. C. and the War
lead_paragraph: Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, delivered recently a speech of immense length, which we find in our Richmond files received yesterday. It is an argument against the party in North Carolina -- and we judge from the admissions in this speech that the party is very strong in numbers, if not dominant -- who desire to have a State Convention called, for the purpose, as Gov. VANCE says, of "seceding from the Southern Confederacy and repudiating the whole thing." His grounds of opposition to this are chiefly these three: Firstly, that it would be useless to secede from the Confederacy; secondly, that it would be dangerous; thirdly, that it can't be done.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of petitions were presented for increased railroad and mail facilities between New-York and Washington. Mr. HOWARD introduced a bill for the reorganization of the Invalid Corps, and Mr. WILSON introduced a bill to disqualify for voting or holding office all deserters who are beyond the...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a large number of petitions were presented for increased railroad and mail facilities between New-York and Washington. Mr. HOWARD introduced a bill for the reorganization of the Invalid Corps, and Mr. WILSON introduced a bill to disqualify for voting or holding office all deserters who are beyond the limits of the United, States, but directs the President to issue a proclamation of amnesty dependent upon their return to the service, with no punishment but loss of pay during their absence or their reenlistment in new regiments. Deserters hereafter are to be deprived of these rights of citizenship. The Senate then took up and passed the Diplomatic Appropriation Bill, and then proceeded to consider District of Columbia matters, which occupied its attention until adjournment.

abstract: While spending a few minutes the other day in the office of Mr. RUSSELL, (the gentlemanly agent of "FISH's Kerosene Lamp-Cooking Apparatus,") No. 206 Pearl-street, New-York, we were taken completely by surprise at witnessing the operation of cooking with one of the above arrangements, carried into full and complete effect. It was about dinner time, and Mr. R., probably desirous to satisfy visitors that what he states in his advertisements is actually so, was engaged in preparing his noon-tide meal, "at a cost of one cent;" and we take it upon us to say that a more nicely cooked little dinner we have rarely seen. The modus operandi is alike simple and efficacious -- in fact, by this truly ingenious method, you can at once graduate the process of cooking while making it subservient to every hour of the day or night. It is well worth the while of those desirous to economise in all things to call upon Mr. R. as above, who will presently satisfy them that "Fish's Kerosene Lamp-Cooking Apparatus" is emphatically one of those discoveries deserving of general patronage. -- Rahway Register.
lead_paragraph: While spending a few minutes the other day in the office of Mr. RUSSELL, (the gentlemanly agent of "FISH's Kerosene Lamp-Cooking Apparatus,") No. 206 Pearl-street, New-York, we were taken completely by surprise at witnessing the operation of cooking with one of the above arrangements, carried into full and complete effect. It was about dinner time, and Mr. R., probably desirous to satisfy visitors that what he states in his advertisements is actually so, was engaged in preparing his noon-tide meal, "at a cost of one cent;" and we take it upon us to say that a more nicely cooked little dinner we have rarely seen. The modus operandi is alike simple and efficacious -- in fact, by this truly ingenious method, you can at once graduate the process of cooking while making it subservient to every hour of the day or night. abstract: We learn from the steamer War Eagle that the expedition sent up the Yazoo River at the time SHERMAN moved from Meridian, has resurned from Vicksburgh. It was composed of the Eleventh Illinois, Colonel COATES, and a negro regiment. The expedition reached Fort Pemberton and returned to Yazoo City, Where he disembarked his command and...
lead_paragraph: We learn from the steamer War Eagle that the expedition sent up the Yazoo River at the time SHERMAN moved from Meridian, has resurned from Vicksburgh. It was composed of the Eleventh Illinois, Colonel COATES, and a negro regiment. The expedition reached Fort Pemberton and returned to Yazoo City, Where he disembarked his command and sent his boats to Vicksburgh loaded with cotton. While awaiting the return of his boats he was attacked in Yazoo City by two brigades of rebel cavalry. A very desperate fight ensued, lasting from ten o'clock in the morning until 4 P.M. on Saturday. At times the fight was hand to hand in the streets. The rebels were finally repulsed, and the boats returned on Tuesday. Col. COATES reembarked with his command and returned to Vicksburgh. Our loss was eighteen killed; that of the enemy much greater. An officer from Admiral PORTER's fleet gives the following particulars of the late expedition up Ouchita River. The expedition consisted of the gunboats Ouchita, Osage, Conestoga, Lexington, Hindman and Cricket. No signs of the enemy were seen until approaching Trinity, which was found strongly fortified. The iron-clad Osage, was in advance and allowed to pass without any demonstration on the part of the rebels. Flagship Hineman, tin-clad, followed, and the rebels supposing her a transport, opened a heavy and destructive fire on her, which she bore for sometime, but was compelled to retire with two men killed and eight wounded, the boat being badly used up. The Ouchita then came up and soon silenced the enemies guns, and drove the rebels from the town.

abstract: The extraordinary success which has attended the enterprise of Mr. J.T. ELLIS in opening a central emporium for the sale of Wheeler & Wilson's celebrated Sewing Machines, No. 939 Broadway, corner of Twenty-second-street, has already compelled the proprietor to extend his facilities for meeting the requirements of the public. He has accordingly secured the adjoining premises, at No. 937 Broadway, and the spacious apartments of both buildings are now at his command. This will enable him to keep on hand a larger stock of machines, for sale and to rent, and to meet the heavy demands made upon him by families for the services of operators, a large number of whom Mr. ELLIS keeps steadily at work in manufacturing contributions for the great Metropolitan Sanitary Fair. It is highly creditable to Messrs. Wheeler & Wilson, of whose establishment Mr. ELLIS is a graduate, that they have so liberally extended to him the facilities to establish a successful and profitable business for himself, and at the same time to greatly accommodate the public by the opening of an emporium so convenient of access to all families in want of sewing machines. Mr. ELLIS gives strict personal attention to his business, is very kind and obliging to persons of limited means, and his enterprise commends itself highly to every citizen, who in patronizing him, and realizing every advantage that they could elsewhere obtain, at the same time aid in extending advantages to people of moderate means. -- Sunday Mercury.

abstract: Vigorous and successful exertions were made yesterday for a prompt search for the Italian war steamer seen in distress by the Star of the West, as detailed in our evening edition of Tuesday. A meeting was held at the Italian Consulate yesterday morning, at which several officers and distinguished citizens attended. It was resolved to charter a steamer, and send her to the latitude where the frigate was seen. She was seen March 7, lat. 40° 40′ lon. 64° 24′ at 4 o'clock P.M.; her main topmasts were gone, and on being hailed, the reply was that she was in a sinking condition. The Star of the West lay to and remained in the vicinity until morning, when, seeing nothing of the vessel, she resumed her course. All the probabilities are, and it is generally believed, that the vessel was the Italian man-of-war Re Gualantuomo, which sailed hence on the 3d inst. The North Star has been secured, and at once preparations were made to have her start forthwith. All the necessary materials were quickly put on board, and in the afternoon the fires could have been lighted. A communication reached the Consul from Commodore RADFORD, to the effect that a steamer would be dispatched from the Navy-yard as soon as she could possibly be got ready. The U.S. steamer Proteus, Commander SHUFELT, will leave this morning, or this afternoon at furthest, for the location of the disaster. The Russian and French authorities have also signified their intention to send off each a vessel immediately. An English war steamer in port is also to go, so that at least five steamers will be outward bound this evening on the charitable mission. The Russian corvette is to sail from Hampton Roads. Another meeting of Italian officers and American gentlemen took place last night at the Everett House, where measures were taken to secure the hasty departure of the searching fleet.

abstract: City Inspector's Report of Nuisances Removed in 1863
snippet: City Inspector's Report of Nuisances Removed in 1863
lead_paragraph: From the Report of the City Inspector for 1863, it appears that during the year the officers of the Department gave personal attention to 4,463 written complaints of nuisances sent to the office, of which it was found that no cause existed for ten. Written notices for abatement of nuisances complained of by citizens and detected by the Department officers were served to the number of 8,810, and 10,341 nuisances were abated under written and verbal orders. There was removed from the City 38,615 loads of night-soil, 4,414 dead horses, 267 dead cows, 443 dead goats, 2,738 dead hogs, 4,674 dead dogs and other small animals, 188,269 barrels of offal. 33,290 pounds of unhealthy beef, 12,105 pounds of unhealthy veal, and of other unsound stuff, 52,495 pounds of fish, 7,485 pounds of poultry, 16,390 pounds of pork, 18,721, pounds of tripe, 4,182 pounds of sausages, 180 pounds of venison, 13,515 pounds of cheese, and 141,780 eggs. This shows that the Department accomplished a good deal more besides the work of keeping the streets clean.

abstract: Kentucky is in a ferment over the Congressional bill making slaves liable, in the same manner as white men, to the national military service. She clamors that this enactment is an invasion of her State sovereignty an un
lead_paragraph: Kentucky is in a ferment over the Congressional bill making slaves liable, in the same manner as white men, to the national military service. She clamors that this enactment is an invasion of her State sovereignty -- an unconstitutional interference with her domestic institutions. Some of her hot-heads rave as if really purposing to make common cause with the rebellion, or, at least, to relapse into neutrality, unless Kentucky is spared the application of this measure.

abstract: The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool, March 5, via Queenstown the 6th, arrived at Halifax last evening. Her news is two days later. The Alexandra case would probably be taken up in the English House of Lords before the Easter vacation. In the House of Commons on the 3d, Mr. S. LEFEVRE had made a speech strongly denouncing the proceedings of the British Government in allowing the rebel cruisers to escape, and contending that all such vessels should be prohibited from entering British ports; and if they did, British cruisers should detain them. There had been no further fighting in Denmark; but the latest telegrams announce that the allies had resolved to further invade Jutland, and that their armies were on the march to invest Frederica. NAPOLEON's remonstrance to Prussia against the invasion was reported to be much more mild than that of England. MAXIMILIAN arrived in Paris on the 5th, and all preliminaries being settled, he would leave for Mexico on the 25th inst.

abstract: We have received our usual files of Southern papers, including dates as late as the 14th inst.. They are not so lively or interesting as usual, evidently having to take time to concoct some new tale of horror with which to " fire the Southern heart." To succeed their frenzy over the Kil-...
lead_paragraph: We have received our usual files of Southern papers, including dates as late as the 14th inst. They are not so lively or interesting as usual, evidently having to take time to concoct some new tale of horror with which to " fire the Southern heart." To succeed their frenzy over the Kilpatrick raid, Gen. POLK telegraphed the rebel War Department gleefully when he found Gen. SHERMAN had got back across the Big Black. Military operations everywhere are quite dull with the enemy. JOHNSTON is quiescent at Dalton, LONGSTREET is in statu quo in East Tennessee, LEE is enjoying his Winter stupor in his old position; POLK is safe at Demopolis, on the east side of the Tombigbee, with several other formidable streams of water between him and SHERMAN, and the valiant FINNEGAN has simmered down into the Florida swamps. The rebel currency was being funded at the rate of about one million per day, time expiring April 1st, and six hundred millions to fund. Charleston was receiving its daily chronic dose of shells.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen yesterday concurred in adopting the resolutions granting a plot of land on Ward's Island to "The Society for the Protection of Destitute Roman Catholic Children," the grant to be ratified by the Legislature, at the present or any subsequent session. Messrs. JACQUES and...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen yesterday concurred in adopting the resolutions granting a plot of land on Ward's Island to "The Society for the Protection of Destitute Roman Catholic Children," the grant to be ratified by the Legislature, at the present or any subsequent session. Messrs. JACQUES and OPDYKE strenuously opposed and voted against the resolutions, on the ground that it was in contravention of the charter to make a grant of its property, unless through a sale at public auction, and that to pre-grant a title to be confirmed by higher authority, was illogical and bad legislation. The board also cocurred in authorizing the creation of eight Assistant Engineers of the Fire Department, in addition to the thirteen now acting, but with an amendment to the ordinance that four serve below and four above Fourteenth-street. The Finance Committee reported the City Appropriation Bill, and it was laid over. They report changes in it as follows: Strike out items for improvements at Hell Gate, East River, $40,000; resetting monument stones, $40,000; lithographing and binding Manual, $20,000; working Eighth-avenue, $10,000; and damages by powder explosion, $40,000; reduce items for salaries, City Inspector's Department, $13,772; wells and pumps, $1,000; increase items for Central Park, $20,000; donations (for House of Mercy,) $5,000; fire machines and apparatus, $45,000; Board of Education, $100,000; sewers, repairing and cleaning, $10,000; streets, repairing and repairs, $40,000; water-pipes and laying, $23,250; wharves, piers and slips, (of which $30,000 for dredging,) $65,000. Total decrease, $174,772; total increase, $308,250 -- nett increase, $133,478. The board adjourned to 1 o'clock P. M. on Saturday.

abstract: The Perils of the Times
lead_paragraph: We spoke yesterday of the huge proportions and rapid increase of the public debt as one of the circumstances, perhaps the circumstance, which just now contributes most powerfully to create and spread despondency as to the result of the war. People have up to the present managed to quiet their apprehensions on this score by a sort of blind reliance on the borrowing powers of the Government, and by the insane notion that the entire property of the country could be and was "pledged" for payment of all debts it might contract. A good many writers, who ought to have known better, helped to propagate this delusion, until it at last became quite common to see the difference between the total amount of the public debt, and the estimated value of the real and personal property of the people of the North, gravely set down as a fund on which we could draw for the prosecution of the war to the last cent, as if any people ever consented to the confiscation of all their possessions for the payment of any collective liability, or as if any such measure was physically possible.

abstract: To-day the honors to Ireland's "Patron Saint" are to be paid. The various Hibernian societies will unite in a grand civil and military procession, in accordance with the published programme of the Grand Marshal of the day. The civil societies will form at 10 A.M. in East Broadway, [???]ight resting on Grand-street. The procession will move on the firing of a signal gun. Its arrival at City Hall Park will be announced by a salute of 17 guns. The First Regiment. N.Y.S.N.G., Col. MINTON, will parade in full uniform, and during the line of march join the procession.

They have paid out in bounties and for other necessary purposes nearly four millions of dollars, and have secured 15,979 men. The magnitude of their work and its labor these figures will give an ides of.
lead_paragraph: The quota of New-York City, under the late call for 500,000 men, was completed yesterday, and the Supervisors' Volunteer Committee rested temporarily from their protracted and patriotic labors. They have paid out in bounties and for other necessary purposes nearly four millions of dollars, and have secured 15,979 men. The magnitude of their work and its labor these figures will give an ides of. To them and their employes, and specially to Chairman BLUNT, through whose hands, without the error of a dollar, has all this money passed, is infinite credit due for a success which makes New-York the only city in the Union of any magnitude that has filled its quota. All honor to them and to it. When the last name was recorded the committee signalized the event by firing 100 guns.

abstract: Hanging Union Soldiers by Gen. Pickett
snippet: Hanging Union Soldiers by Gen. Pickett
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning the statement of a Captain of the Second North Carolina Regiment of Union Volunteers, reaffirming the reported recent execution of twenty-four captured members of that regiment, by the rebel Gen. PICKETT. No new details are given, and we confess that we are not yet prepared to consider the horrid report as a fully substantiated fact. Our correspondent can only vouch of his own personal knowledge that the prisoners were taken; but we do not perceive that he has had any peculiar facilities for learning their subsequent fate. He, like all others within our lines, has had to rely upon general rumor. He is, doubtless, himself thoroughly satisfied; but there are certain inherent improbabilities that occasion us some doubt.

abstract: The new Board of Police Commissioners met at headquarters. No. 300 Mulberry-street, at 5 P.M., yesterday. Messrs. ACTON, BOSWORTH and MCMURRAY were present, Mr. BERGEN absent from sickness. On motion of Mr. MCMURRAY, Mr. BOSWORTH was called to the Chair, when the election of a permanent President being in order, on motion of Mr. MCMURRAY, THOMAS C. ACTON was elected as such. No further business was transacted.

abstract: Tuesday evening, Lieut.-Col.DOEBKE, Forty-fifth Regiment, New-York State Volunteers, was the recipient of an exceedingly handsome compilment from the merchant citizens of the Third Ward. He was formerly attached to the police of that precinct, was attacked with patriotic and military ardor, raised a company, and, as Captain, went out with the Regiment; has been a participant in twelve fierce battles, and comes back with the straps of a Lieutenant-Colonel upon him.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday evening, Lieut.-Col.DOEBKE, Forty-fifth Regiment, New-York State Volunteers, was the recipient of an exceedingly handsome compilment from the merchant citizens of the Third Ward. He was formerly attached to the police of that precinct, was attacked with patriotic and military ardor, raised a company, and, as Captain, went out with the Regiment; has been a participant in twelve fierce battles, and comes back with the straps of a Lieutenant-Colonel upon him. He is an intelligent, worthy man and gallant soldier, and the presentation was in acknowledgment, not only of this, but of his faithfulness and efficiency as a patrolman. None better than the merchants of his precinct could appreciate his worth. The sword is a superb one, TIFFANY & CO. the makers, bearing on one side an engraving of the police on drill, on the other the presentation, and for its guard the police shield. The presentation took place at the Broadway Garden, above Springstreet, and PAUL FALK, the proprietor, had prepared for the wants of the assembled guests in the most excellent and the most liberal manner. The table was a model for those who provide for the thirsty and hungry. Inspector CARPENTER made the presentation speech; it was apt, very eloquent and earnest, eliciting the heartiest applause. Lieut.-Col. DOEBKE responded briefly, but with true soldierly warmth of feeling. His acknowledgment of the compliment proved him as worthy of it as did his heroic action in the field.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: In the State Senate yesterday, the most important business transacted was the passage of a bill to prohibit the sale of spirtuous and vinous liquors on Sunday. The Brooklyn Arsenal Bill was reported favorably by the majority of the Committee. Among the bills noticed was one to ...
lead_paragraph: In the State Senate yesterday, the most important business transacted was the passage of a bill to prohibit the sale of spirtuous and vinous liquors on Sunday. The Brooklyn Arsenal Bill was reported favorably by the majority of the Committee. Among the bills noticed was one to close Manhattan and Hamilton squares. Bills were introduced to amend the act to facilitate the acquisition of lands for the extension of the Cro[???] Water Works, and for building reservoirs, also, to authorize the Mayor and Aldermen of New-York to borrow $200,000 for said purposes; to amend the charter of the Market Savings Bank of New-York. The evening session was occupied in the consideration of local laws. Adjourned.

abstract: Saxon, the Bark, Release of by United States District Court; Tuscaloosa; Release by the English Govt. at Cape Town; Remodeling Boundaries of, >amp;c.; Effect of Bombardment
snippet: Saxon, the Bark, Release of by United States District Court; Tuscaloosa; Release by the English Govt. at Cape Town; Remodeling Boundaries of, >amp;c.; Effect of Bombardment
lead_paragraph: The announcement of the seizure of the Tuscaloosa, by the authorities of Cape Town, in consequence of instructions from the British Government, struck our people with surprise. We had not expected so positive and favorable a step from them and the news that that Government has now sent orders to discharge her from the seizure was more surprising still. It was not to be supposed that they would have taken the first step without full consideration. Why then should they thus retrace it? What new light had they received? Was it a new fact, or a new argument?

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. GRIMES submitted a new rule to abolish secret Executive sessions of the Senate. Mr. DAVIS' resolution, inquiring what part Col. T.W. HIGGINSON took in the Burns rescue riot, was laid on the table. The Senate then took up the bill to incorporate the Metropolitan Railroad Company of the District of Columbia, and after lengthy debate, Senator SUMNER's amendment, prohibiting the exclusion of any person on account of color, was adopted by two majority. Adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. GRIMES submitted a new rule to abolish secret Executive sessions of the Senate. Mr. DAVIS' resolution, inquiring what part Col. T.W. The Senate then took up the bill to incorporate the Metropolitan Railroad Company of the District of Columbia, and after lengthy debate, Senator SUMNER's amendment, prohibiting the exclusion of any person on account of color, was adopted by two majority. Adjourned.

abstract: The celebration of the anniversary of Ireland's Patron Saint was more general, yesterday, than on any former occasion. At an early hour the different Irish-American organizations, military and civic, assembled at their different places of meeting, and before 10 o'clock the carrying out of the programme for the proceedings of the day had already begun. At almost every street corner the venders of shamrock and miniature Irish flags drove a flourishing business. Long before the appointed hour for the procession to move, all the thoroughfares along the line of march were thronged by expectant crowds. The day was beautiful.

abstract: JANE FARRELL, a young girl employed as a domestic servant, was tried upon an indictment for grand larceny. The charge was that she had stolen dresses, underclothing and valuables of various descriptions from her mistress. Some of these, it was alleged, had been found in per possession. The evidence did not sustain the charge, and the girl was acquitted.

abstract: THE HOME FOR AGED AND IDIGENT FEMALES. -- The thirteenth annual meeting of the Directors of the Graham Institute, or home for aged, indigent females, was held at the Institution, in Washington-avenue, corner of DeKalb, yesterday noon. Rev. Dr. FARLEY presided. After reading portions of the 71st and 91th Psalms, and a prayer, the Treasurer's report was read, showing that the collections, donations, &c., including the balance on hand, amounted to $11,126 94, and the disbursements $8,104 60. The report of the Corresponding Secretary congratulated the managers on the flourishing condition of the Home, being now free of debt. There are at present fifty-one inmates and seven servants. Three members have been admitted during the year, and three died. The general health of the beneficiaries is good. Owing to the increased price of every article of consumption, the expenditures have been larger than heretofore, and donations are earnestly solicited. The closing address was delivered by Rev. C.D. FOSS, after which the meeting adjourned.
lead_paragraph: THE HOME FOR AGED AND IDIGENT FEMALES. -- The thirteenth annual meeting of the Directors of the Graham Institute, or home for aged, indigent females, was held at the Institution, in Washington-avenue, corner of DeKalb, yesterday noon. abstract: A new attempt at improvement is being made in the Park Barracks -- the establishment of a reading room and library for the soldiers quartered there. An association of ladies asks aid from our citizens for this purpose, which surely needs no recommendation to a humane heart. Their circular thus concludes: "New-York is behind our other great cities in her provision for the aid and comfort of National soldiers while quartered within her limits, though her prosperity depends so largely on their exertions in the field. Philadelphia has won a most honorable name by her munificent arrangements for this object. It is certainly desirable that this City do likewise, and that it be gratefully remembered by thousands of veterans for years to come, for the hospitality, sympathy and care they received from its citizens. To this end contributions are solicited. They should be addressed to EDWARD DELANO, Treasurer, No. 11 East Twelfth street. Contributions of books, periodicals, old and new, illustrated periodicals, &c., are also earnestly called for, and may be sent to No. 86 East Twenty-first street.

abstract: Mobile papers of the 9th of March say the Union forces attempted to land on Dauphin Island, thinking it unoccupied, but happening to catch sight of the Confederate soldiers, concealed and waiting to receive them, they hastily retired, afterward furiously shelling the woods. They also any the Union picket-boats reconnoitre with impunity to the foot of Fort Gaines' wharf.

abstract: Lynch Law at the Far West
snippet: Lynch Law at the Far West
lead_paragraph: -Our fellow-citizens in the very far West, in the mineral territories bordering upon the Rocky Mountains, and in those on the other side of the mountains, are holding Lynch courts in extraordinary number, and carrying out the decrees of that ferocious judge with unprecedented energy. Our latest files from the distant regions of Idaho, Nevada, Utah, etc., contain accounts of executions in numbers that we think were never equaled even in the early days of California settlement, nor in any part of the West.

abstract: County bounty $300 to fill our quota of 6,400, required by the new call for 200,000 men. The bonds to be issued for the $2,000,000 loan will bear six per cent, interest and be payable in sums of $500,000 on the first days of November in 1887, 1888,1899 and 1890. Mr. DAVIS read and submitted a communication in defence of his action as a Commissioner of Harlem Bridge, as assailed In a recent committee report to the Board of Supervisors of Westchester County. Mr. DAVIS [???] the report reflects upon him by mixing up [???] doings of the former with the present Bridge commission -- the extravagant contracts of the Former being imposed by judicial decision upon the latter The board concluded to take cognizance of the whole subject, and appointed Messrs. BLUNT, PURDY, STEWART and CONNER a special committee to investigate the charges of the Westchester committee. Adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. on Monday.
lead_paragraph: County bounty $300 to fill our quota of 6,400, required by the new call for 200,000 men. The bonds to be issued for the $2,000,000 loan will bear six per cent, interest and be payable in sums of $500,000 on the first days of November in 1887, 1888,1899 and 1890. abstract: Economy and War Expenditure
lead_paragraph: There is an impression abroad among the people, which we have already commented upon, that, as greenbacks are so plenty, and every one is feeling so prosperous, it is perfectly right and proper for every one to spend as freely as he likes. There is no sort of conscientious feeling in regard to the duty of economy. The expenditures abroad among the unexampled, even in the history of our wasteful people. Every one, except those dependent on regular salaries, is extravagant to the last degree. The jewelers, and the dealers in expensive goods, assure us that there never was such a demand for the most costly wares. Diamonds, pearls, watches and ornaments, bronzes and carpets, silks and satins, expensive furniture and paintings, wines and costly dinner-ware, are continually sold, and are ornamenting our wealthy houses. Then, in the classes of more moderate means, similar habits on a smaller scale everywhere prevail. The wives and daughters of shop-keepers and upper mechanics, of teachers and preachers, of country lawyers and doctors, still buy their silks, and carpets, and pianos, as if they were as well off as they ever were.

abstract: -The different structures being erected for the use of the Metropolitan Fair, will be finished regardless of many well founded apprehensions, before the 28th inst. At the time it was decided by the Fair Committee on Organization to construct the Branch Fair Buildings, now nearly completed, on Union-square, it was thought they could not be put up in time for the Exhibition. However, the extraordinary enterprise displayed by the carpenters leaves no room for doubting that they will be completed at the time appointed. The main Fair buildings on Fourteenth-street are nearly ready for the arrangement of artiticles for exhibition. The Art Gallery, the Restaurant, and the main area, may be considered ready for occupancy.
