abstract: The Meeting at New-York
lead_paragraph: If there be a serious intention to make Gen. MCCLELLAN a Presidential candidate,his intelligent friends, if he has such, are bound to see that he is put forward in a manner becoming the dignity of the position. They had no right to leave their first mass meeting summoned in his behalf, in this great centre of political influence, to the management of such an unknownand characterless set as, with the single exception of the resurrected AMOS KENDALL, figured at Cooper Institute. That locality has been in times past the seat of a great many political demonstrations, but never of one so utterly without force. With the single exception we have noted, not a person took part in it who was ever before heard of; and even that exception was heard of so long ago that the memory has to struggleto recall him. If there are men of position,of weight, of influence, in this City, who intend to give Gen. MCCLELLAN an earnest support, why do they not show themselves as he first comes into the political field? Why this holding back at the very start of the campaign, when so much depends upon the front displayed? All of Gen. MCCLELLAN'smilitary history shows him to be reluctant to move the first inch without an array so magnificentthat its very sight shall strike consternation;yet in this political enterprise, so difficult as to be almost desperate, he is made to set out with this shabby parcel of nobodies. It is not just. It is not decent. If Gen. MCCLELLANwere not the patriot he is, he would exclaim indignantly, "I'll not march through Coventry with them -- that's flat."

abstract: New-York Legislative Recklessness
lead_paragraph: There is a measure before the British House of Commons, just now, for the creation of a tribunal to hear and pass upon all applications for franchises, such as railroads which affect private or corporate rights, instead of leaving them, as now, to be disposed of by "private bills," after a hearing before a committee. The reasons which call for the change there are the exceedingly unsatisfactory nature of the inquiries into the pros and cons of such applications, which are all that can be made by a parliamentary committee. The members are often not used to such investigations; the rules of evidence are not strictly adhered to in the examination of witnesses, and the sense of responsibility felt by each member of a body which changes every session, is of course very slight. The amount of jobbing which attends the passage of all railroad bills is, therefore, as might be expected, very great. If, however, applicants had to make out their cases before a court, composed as courts of justice are, and guided by the same rules, and acting under the same sense of responsibility, it is believed their public would be vastly better protected against injury than they now are, while to the applicants themselves the delay and expense would be greatly diminished.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 4th, Mr. G.J. SHAW LEFEVER called attention to the course pursued by the agents of the Confederate States of America in fitting out vessels-of-war, and enlisting seamen in the ports of this country, in violation of the laws of neutrally, and moved an address for papers on the subject. The honorable member enumerated the vessels which had been built in this country for the Confederate Government, and said it was impossible to disguise the fact that they were built in accuruance with an organized scheme on the part of the Confederate States, for building, manning, and sending out vessels to prey upon the commerce of the Federal States -- among them were the Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Alexandra, the steamrams, and Pampero.

abstract: THE HUSBAND ARRESTED. -- A woman named BRIDGET BARRY, aged 45 years, residing with her husband in the basement of No. 20 Rose-street, died yesterday afternoon under circumstances which induced the belief that her death was the result of violence at the hands of her husband, MICHAEL BARRY. He was arrested yesterday morning for beating her, but at her request was soon after discharged. While she was able to converse, she informed a Fourth Precinct Policeman that her husband had recently beaten and kicked her very severely. The marks and bruises on her face, head, neck and arms clearly indicated that violence had been inflicted. She died suddenly in the afternoon, and her husband was accordingly rearrested, and is held to await a coroner's investigation, which will be held to-day. The husband says that the bruises upon her person were caused by a fall while she was in state of intoxication. He is a man of low intemperate habits, and keeps a groggery in the front part of his premises.

abstract: sinking of a boat belonging to the French man-of-war Phlegethon, by the steamtug Arctic, by which two of the crew were drowned, has been noticed. It is alleged that the accident was caused by the criminal recklessness of the pilot and officers of the steamer. The Commander of the French corvette has claimed damages for the families of the drowned seamen. The following from the Commander of the Phlegethon apreared in yesterday's Courier des Etats Unis: "On the morning of the 15th instant, a boat from the French corvette Phlegethon, containing ten men, was run down by the tugboat Arctic. Two of the sailors were drowned; a few others of those who were saved were picked up by boats which put off from the shore. The Commander of the Phlegethon would be glad to know the names of the persons who manned these boats, that the might express to them his lively thanks. He would be happy, also, to know the name of the steamer which, happening to be near Castle Garden, came up at once with help to the scene of the accident, under an impulse which does honor to its officers."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the bill to facilitate the carrying of the foreign mails was called up and passed. The bill promoting enlistments came up in order, and occupied the attention of the Senate through the greater part of the session. A long discussion took place on the section which gives to loyal owners of slaves compensation for the wives and children who are freed by virtue of the enlistment of their husbands and fathers. Action on the bill was not concluded, and the Senate adjourned until Monday.

abstract: There seems to have been a very happy accord in a number of instances of late between our own Government and that of Great Britain. The British Government, a few weeks ago, sent instructions to Lord LYONS to ask immediate explanation and redress for the violation of British neutrality by the American gunboat Ellie & Annie pursuing the Chesapeake pirates into the harbor of Halifax; but we have the word of Mr. LAYARD, in the House of Commons, for saying that long before this demand had reached the United States, an ample and satisfactory apology for the violation in question had been offered by the American Secretary of State.

abstract: Peterhoff Case, Judge Betts' Decision
lead_paragraph: We had noticed with some surprise, that throughout the recent debates in the English Parliament upon our Prize Courts, the speakers, in all their complaints of illegality, had not a word to say of the case of the steamer Peterhoff. We were surprised at this, because we Could not but remember the indignation which was loudly expressed in England when the Peterhoff was captured. The capture was declared to be "a discreditable proceeding," an "illegal capture," a "deliberate attempt to magnify and extend the powers of blockade," "a proceeding which called for the serious attention of the country." Earl RUSSELL was specially appealed to "to take measures to prevent its repetition." The Shipping Gazette proposed that the English cruisers on the West India station be directed to convoy vessels, whose papers, like the Peterhoff's, were fair on their face; and the London Times declared that even if the Peterhoff should be condemned by our Prize Courts, the British Government could not acquiesce in such a condemnation.

abstract: -The financial year of this society closes April 1. abstract: Testimonial to
lead_paragraph: The contractors engaged in building an iron-clad vessel of war, and many of our most respectable citizens, who appreciate the noble qualities of mind, and the admiral professional ability of Commodore JOHN RODGERS, have just procured for him a testimonial of their good will, which reflects alike credit on their generosity and good taste. A magnificent silver service, including a splendid tea service, has just been completed at the establishment of WILLIAM GALE & SONS, Broadway, which is to be presented to the Commodore, on Wednesday next. Commodore RODGERS is now in this City, waiting the completion of the great ocean iron-clad Dictator, to command which he has been specially appointed by the Secretary of the Navy. He has been loosely connected with our iron-clad fleet since its organization. After the famous fight at Fort Darling, he was detached from the Galena and ordered to the Weehawken. On his way to Port Royal in this vessel he cut loose from the convoy and went right out to sea during a most terrible hurricane. He subsequently led the attack on Sumter, and captured the rebel iron-clad Atlanta. These acts have elicited the testimonial referred to. It consists of the following pieces:

abstract: -- Amidst the crowd of books that the present Shakespeare mania is giving birth to in England, there is probably no more attractive volume than Life Portraits of Shakespeare, with an Examination of the Authenticity and a History of the Various Representations of the Poet. By J.H. FRISWELL. It is the third book dedicated to the subject, but enjoys the advantages afforded by the new art of photography over the volumes of BOUDEN and WIVELL, who are obliged to be content with engravings of the originals.

abstract: About 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, a serious affray occurred in a 22,000 at No.86 Chathain street, during which Mr. MICHEAL MULLEN, a resident of Baltimore, was shot with a revolver in the abdomen. The wound will, doubtless, prove fatal, A man  names THOMAS DORAN was the perpetrator. He was immediately arrested and is held to await the result. MULLEN was taken to the New-York Hospital, where Coroner RANNEY, yesterday, took his ante-mortem examination.

abstract: Methods of
lead_paragraph: The experience of the war is gradually settling some problems which at first were very doubtful. When the struggle opened, the popular imagination pictured a gallant army of one hundred thousand Union troops marching gayly down through the Southern States as NAPOLEON marched through Prussia before Jena. There seemed no more reason why MCDOWELL and MCCLELLAN should not "invade" the South, than for the French not invading all Europe in the times of the Revolution. The thought of where food and forage for the one hundred thousand were to come from did not trouble the popular mind.

abstract: --Two important works have recently appeared in England on the Primeval Antiquities of the Human Race. They have great Interest for American Ethrologists, on account of the remarkable coincidences that occur between the ancient remains of the
lead_paragraph: -- Two important works have recently appeared in England on the Primeval Antiquities of the Human Race. They have great Interest for American Ethrologists, on account of the remarkable coincidences that occur between the ancient remains of the earliest ages, whether discovered in the Old or New World. One is Prehistoric Annals of Scotland, by Dr. DANIEL WILSON, Professor of History in the University of Toronto. Dr. WILSON was the first to demonstrate from the ancient sepulchral mounds, the existence in the British Isles, of a peculiar race of people, remarkable for their broad or "boat-shaped" crania, and of presumed Tartar affinities, who preceded the Celts in their occupation of the country, His "Prehistoric Annals" is a perfect encyclopedia of all the known facts bearing on the history of the earliest peoples of Scotland, and is beautifully illustrated with drawings of their various relics. The other work alluded to, is published posthumously, the author, JOHN MITCHELL KEMBLE, the pupil of GRIMM, and the best northern scholar of England, having left it unfinished at his premature death. The title is Horoe Feralis, or Studies in the Archaeology of Northern Nations. It has been completed from the author's papers by Dr. LATHAM and Mr. FRANKS of the British Museum. It forms one volume quarto, and is richly illustrated with plates of bone, stone, bronze and iron implements, enameled horse-trappings, mortuary urns and remarkable sepulchral objects. In this connection it may be noted that the unique collection of primeval American antiquities, originally formed by Dr. DAVIS, from excavations in the mounds of Ohio, and since enriched by kindred articles from Peru, Mexico and Central America, is probably lost to this country. The New-York Historical Society had been for some time negotiating for its purchase, but a gentleman of Liverpool, of marked antiquarian tastes, is about securing it, with the intention of dividing the specimens between a museum he is founding in his native town and the British Museum.

abstract: On Friday, MATHEW LYONS, a citizen of South Albemarle, Va., reached here, a refugee. Mr. LYONS is an intelligent, respectable man, 63 years of age, and was in business, keeping a country store. He is a native of Philadelphia, but had lived down South thirty-three years, and had accumulated a property, which he could have disposed of before the rebellion for $68,000. He had always been a Union man, and had persistently refused the oath of allegiance to the Confederacy. By a discreet course he had escaped [???] until after the battle of Gettysburgh, when the chagrin and rage at that defeat rendered the rebel civil and military authorities bitter upon all men with the slightest Union proclivities. The last conscription act, sweeping into the service all from the age of 16 to 55, brought Mr. LYONS under it, and he was notified by Capt. CARRINGTON, of the Virginia Cavalry, that he was "an infernal Abolitionist, came under the act, and must take the oath of allegiance and bear arms." That day Mr. LYONS provided for his wife and children, and that night abandoned his home and property and started for the Union lines. He drove to near Harrisonburgh, where he had to leave his team; he walked some fifty-five miles, flanked the rebel pickets, and met ours near Martinsburgh. Here he was kindly received by the military authorities, and here he took the required oath of allegiance to the United States. During his flight he had several narrow escapes from detection. He laid out six nights, and was sometimes two days without food. He exhibits the effects of such a journey at his age. At Woodstock he secured fifteen dollars in greenbacks, for which he paid two hundred and fifty dollars in Confederate money. He was six weeks reaching the Union lines.

abstract: -About a year ago a movement was begun in the Broadway Tabernacle Church (Rev. Dr. THOMPSON's) to reduce the indebtedness, which amounted to $65,000. The sum of $25,000 was raised at the time, leaving $40,000 unpaid. Recently, a spontaneous movement among the members of the church congregation has resulted in raising the entire amount remaining, so that the church is now enabled to pay off its entire indebtedness and retain the ownership of all its pews. About two-thirds of the amount last raised was obtained by subscription, and the remaining one-third was contributed at the close of the service on Sunday morning last. The church has, in addition to its pew rentals (amounting to about $12,000) contributed more than $11,000 to benevolent objects during the past year, making in the segregate more than $88,000 given for religious purposes in a single year.

abstract: In the Legislature, yesterday, there was not much business done. In the Senate, the General Appropriation Bill was reported. A bill was passed to extend the provisions of the bill legalizing indebtedness created for bounty purposes. The Senate, in Executive Session, confirmed the nomination of Dr. SWINBURNE, of Albany, as Health Officer of the City of New-York. In the Assembly, a bill was reported to prevent the publication of lotteries in this State. The Richmond County Bounty Bill was reported adversely, and the bill to incorporate the New-York Dime Savings Bank favorably. The Eleventh-avenue and High Bridge Railroad Bill, reported adversely on Friday, was reconsidered and recommitted. The bill to regulate the tariff of freight on the Hudson River Railroad was ordered to a third reading.

Burton, deceesed. -- Plaintiff, claiming to be the wife of William E.Burton, the late distinguished comedian, sought by this action to have her dower admeasured in certain real estate whereof Burton died seized. abstract: The steamers Havana and George Washington arrived from New-Orleans yesterday, bringing news to the 12th inst. There was considerable activity in military circles. Gen. BANKS was on the eve of departure for Western Louisiana, probably Alexandria. A fleet of Admiral POR
lead_paragraph: The steamers Havana and George Washington arrived from New-Orleans yesterday, bringing news to the 12th inst. There was considerable activity in military circles. Gen. BANKS was on the eve of departure for Western Louisiana, probably Alexandria. A fleet of Admiral PORTER's gunboats has already started for that place. It was expected that rather formidable works of defence would be encountered by the iron-clads, between the mouth of Red River and Alexandria. Gen. LEE's cavalry had also left New-Orleans, their destination supposed to be to the westward. An order had been issued by Gen. BANKS to hold an election for delegates to a Constitutional Convention on the 18th. The Convention meets in New-Orleans on the 6th of April. There are to be 150 delegates, chosen on a white basis, as per census of 1860. New-Orleans will have sixty-three members.

abstract: Press on Raiding
lead_paragraph: The Richmond rebels have just been demanding, in the most ferocious language, the execution of every one of the Union soldiers taken prisoner in the late raid of Gen. KILPATRICK; and they have hardly got through with this when we learn that they themselves are projecting a raid of the same nature within our lines. They do not announce whether they desire the execution of all their raiders who, in turn, may fall into our hands.

abstract: Sharkey vs. Franklin. Fraudulent Sale of Tobacco
snippet: Sharkey vs. Franklin. Fraudulent Sale of Tobacco
lead_paragraph: Sharkey vs. Franklin. -- This was a motion to vacate an order of arrest made in May last. The affidavits upon which the order was granted allege that the defendant sold to the plaintiff five hundred cases State seed tobacco, amounting, as claimed, to over $25,000, and that he warranted the tobacco to be of the qualities "A" and "B," as represented in the bill or sale; that, on examining the tobacco after the purchase, the plaintiff found that forty of the cases were not as represented, and, although marked "A," they contained tobacco of an inferior quality known as "B," and that the cases had been scraped and the marks thereon had been changed and that the tobacco had evidently been changed, and charging the defendant with knowledge of the fraud, and with falsely representing to the plaintiff that the tobacco was of the first quality; and that the difference in value between the contents of the forty cases and tobacco of the quality represented was nearly $3.000.

abstract: The receipts of contributions is unparalleled in the history of any similar enterprise. Smyrna, Liverpool, Berlin and other cities abroad are adding to the list of contributors. A large number of Americans in Spain have intimated by letter that it is their intention to contribute liberally to the fair. From Paris several cases of paintings have been received, also a valuable portrait of CROMWELL, the gift of Mr. PHALON. Rome sends several valuable articles, among the number a bust of Mr. SEWARD. Miss CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN is one of the principal contributors from that city.

abstract: MEETING OF THE LINCOLN ASSOCIATION OF THE STATES OF NEW-YORK. -- This association assembledat Hope Chapel on Thursday evening, SIMEON DEAPAR, Esq., presiding, Dr. SHEPPARD, late (according to Mr. H.S. SMITH, who introduced him,) an inveterateCopperhead, addressed the meeting. Thoughnot a member of the association, but being invited to address it, he would say a few words as to the motives when had induced him to favor the reelectionof Mr. LINCOLN. He thought it was not prudent in the face of each tremendous [???] as were upon the voluntary, to attempt to change our chief Executive [???] it would such extensive changes in the Government and such a terrible scramble for office and staff. If Mr. LINCOLN should now withdraw his name, there is danger that we might fail of an election by the [???], and the election [???] [???] [???] into House Representatives. Such an extent, in the existing condition of our country, [???] [???] affected with danger. In the best days of the Republic, the, Presidents were reelected once. Suppose there were some abuses in the way of veteran officeholding. Was not that a for less evil than the demoralizing office-hunting, which has been greatly increased by the discountenance of the practive of one reelection of our presidents? Mr. LINCOLN will have had four years' experience. The people have confidence in the integrity of his motives, and they do not fear that he will become an usurper. The secession gentlemen, after a successful conspiracy to divide and defeat the Democratic party, thereby placing Mr. LINCOLN in the Presidential Chair, have been exceedingly discontented and fretful because he was there, and they now insist that he shall be turned out; that there can be no peace until he is turned out; that they will not negotiate with him upon any terms. As these secession gentlemen gave us, of the Northern Democracy, Mr. LINCOLN against our will in 1860. I feel disposed to reciprocate, and give him to them against their willsin 1864, [Laughter and applause,] that they may have the full benefit of his administration, that they may have time to become pacified and reconciled. Those who will not be pacificied or reconciled to the Union upon any terms, out who are determined upon secession and disunion, will realize the propriety of their carrying out their favorite doctrine of disunion, by seceding to some foreign country. In conclusion, the speaker expressed himself in favor of a liberal and conciliatory course toward the friends of all the other candidates of the Union party. He intended to vote for the man that the great Union party should unite upon. There were other speeches made, some good singing, and the meeting adjourned.

abstract: Coroner NAUMANN yesterday held an inquest at the Fourth Precinct Station-house, on the body of Mrs. BRIDGET BARRY, who died at her residence, No. 20 Rose-street, on Friday afternoon, from the effect of blows and kicks received at the hands of her husband, MICHAEL BARRY. The testimony in the case tended to show that MICHAEL, who was nearly all the time intoxicated, had upon several occasions within the two days immediately preceding her death, beaten and kicked his wife about the head, face, arms and neck in a most unmerciful manner. The facts of the case were published in the TIMES of Saturday. At the conclusion of the evidence the Jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that the deceased, BRIDGET BARRY, came to her death by injuries from violence at the hands of MICHAEL BARRY, on the 17th day of March, 1864." The accused husband was thereupon arraigned, and in answer to the usual questions, he said he was 47 years of age, was born in Ireland, resided at No. 20 Rose-street, and by occupation a boarding and lodging-house keeper. He further said that his wife struck him in the eye previous to the quarrel; that he then struck her with his open hand and knocked her against the bed. He was then committed for trial.
lead_paragraph: Coroner NAUMANN yesterday held an inquest at the Fourth Precinct Station-house, on the body of Mrs. BRIDGET BARRY, who died at her residence, No. 20 Rose-street, on Friday afternoon, from the effect of blows and kicks received at the hands of her husband, MICHAEL BARRY. The testimony in the case tended to show that MICHAEL, who was nearly all the time intoxicated, had upon several occasions within the two days immediately preceding her death, beaten and kicked his wife about the head, face, arms and neck in a most unmerciful manner. The facts of the case were published in the TIMES of Saturday. At the conclusion of the evidence the Jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that the deceased, BRIDGET BARRY, came to her death by injuries from violence at the hands of MICHAEL BARRY, on the 17th day of March, 1864." The accused husband was thereupon arraigned, and in answer to the usual questions, he said he was 47 years of age, was born in Ireland, resided at No. 20 Rose-street, and by occupation a boarding and lodging-house keeper. He further said that his wife struck him in the eye previous to the quarrel; that he then struck her with his open hand and knocked her against the bed. He was then committed for trial.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning, a laborer named MICHAEL COOLEY was arrested by Officer LANG, of the Tenth Precinct, on the charge of attempting to murder his wife by shooting her in the head with a revolver. The injuries inflicted were so serious, and the victim in consequence was sinking so rapidly, that yesterday afternoon Coroner WILDEY was noti
lead_paragraph: At an early hour yesterday morning, a laborer named MICHAEL COOLEY was arrested by Officer LANG, of the Tenth Precinct, on the charge of attempting to murder his wife by shooting her in the head with a revolver. The injuries inflicted were so serious, and the victim in consequence was sinking so rapidly, that yesterday afternoon Coroner WILDEY was notified, and he immediately proceed to hold an antemortem examination at the New-York Hospital, whither the unfortunate woman had been conveyed soon after the occurrence. From the testimony given by the wife we learn the following facts. The wife's name is ISSABELLA COOLLY, and with her husband she resided at No. 7 Bayard-street. At about three o'clock yesterday morning her husband returned to his house, having been absent all the night previous to that hour. She had lain down on a sofa as it was her habit to do when her husband was out late, and when she heard his voice at the door she went and opened it for him. Being somewhat vexed that he should have kept her up so long, she told him that he had better go back and pass the remainder of the night at the house where he had spent its last hours. As she turned around to work back, she heard her husband say. "That's enough, here, take the contents of this," or words to that exact, and immediately fixed. The ball entered her head on the right side just over the ear, passing through the skull into the brain, where at now remains.

abstract: For a few days past an embargo has been laid upon the business of Chicago by a general strike among the railroad engineers. There was trouble on the 1st of January, but the roads acceded to the principal demands of the engineers, and harmony was restored. Recently, however, the Chicago, Union, and Galena Road promulgated some new arrangement which was not satisfactory, and their employes immediately refused to work.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Wednesday, March 16, 1864.

abstract: Nothing could possibly be more encouraging to the managers, than the interest taken by the firemen of this City and its vicinity in the Metropolitan Fair. The various engine, took and ladder and hose companies have nearly all appointed committees, and their houses are open two or three evenings each
lead_paragraph: Nothing could possibly be more encouraging to the managers, than the interest taken by the firemen of this City and its vicinity in the Metropolitan Fair. The various engine, took and ladder and hose companies have nearly all appointed committees, and their houses are open two or three evenings each >week, for the reception and exhibition of articles contributed. Already numbers of them have ready and in their parlors a number of articles made and contributed by their lady friends, such as pin cushions, slippers, purses, embroideries, pieces of worsted works, &c., &c., while they have raised in money sums far exceeding their original ideas. Companies which at first were doubtful, but would try to raise $100, now point to their books and show $200 or $300 already subscribed, and many companies will contribute $800 or $1,000, in addition to the goods they will give to ornament their space, and which will, of course, bring in a good fair profit. The general office of the Department, at No. 744 Broadway, near Astorplace, which is under the charge of Assistant Engineer GEORGE ALKER, is doing finely; great numbers of articles, and some very fine and expensive ones, have been contributed by citizens who, though not members, are friends and admirers of the Department, and more are constantly coming in. The ladies, too -- who, until now, have never fairly known or appreciated the brave firemen -- are becoming better acquainted with them, and as their actual knowledge of the department, and the class of men of which it is generally composed, grows better, their interest in it increases, and they are as anxious that the "Fire Department" should be the most attractive "department" in the Fair as are the firemen themselves. The veteran Ex-Chief Engineer, JAMES L. MILLER, Chairman of the Executive Committee, has been untiring in his efforts, and has, by his personal endeavors, enlisted the services of a great number of ladies and merchants in the matter; and to him and SYLVANDS J. MACY, the representative of Hook and Ladder Company No. 9, who has spared neither time nor trouble, and who has both liberally contributed and been successful in getting contributions, Chief Engineer JOHN DECKER, Ex-Chief Engineer HARRY HOWARD, WM. H. WICKHAM, of Hook and Ladder Company No. 15, the entire Executive Committee, the Board of Engineers and Foremen, and numerous other prominent members of the department, the firemen are principally indebted for the success which will certainly crown their efforts. The companies who have reported as being "at work" are as follows:

abstract: The Imperialists and their Allies
lead_paragraph: The entente cordiale between the Imperialists and the British has not yet been restored. The Futai has so far had the advantage over GORDON; and, instead of reproof or punishment for his perfidy at Soochow, he has received honors and praises from Pekin. The wily Mandarin's version of the achievements of himself and his auxiliaries at the siege of the Taeping stronghold, was in fact the first to reach the Chinese metropolis, and of course the account of matters placed his own conduct in the most favorable light. GORDON's services in a subordinate capacity may be com-commended, but it was, nevertheless, the valor and strategy of the Governor himself which chiefly contributed to the triumph of the Confederates. Under these circumstances, it is not at all surprising that Prince KUNG should have written a congratulatory reply to His Excellency, and conferred on him the "Yellow Jacket," one of the highest distinctions in the Empire.

The Spanish steamer Isabel la Calolica had arrived at San Domingo with further reinforcements for the royalists, commanded by Brig.-Gen. lead_paragraph: John B. Borst vs. Ezra Getman. -- The plaintiff in this case made a motion for a new trial on newly discovered evidence on a bill of exceptions, and on the ground of irregularity of the jury. Defendent's counsel showed that the evidence was known to plaintiff before the first trial, and was merety cumulative, and also showed that the only alleged irregularity on the part of the jury consisted in their having accepted an invitation to a dinner given by defendant's counsel, after they had rendered a verdict and been discharged.

abstract: At the McClellan meeting, Cooper Institute, Wednesday evening, a difficulty arose about midway of the building, and there was danger of a man, somewhat intoxicated, being badly injured. To get to the spot through the crowd was impossible; so Officer ADAM ALLAIRE, of the Seventeenth Precinct, at once took the only way, and that over the heads of the mass. He performed rapidly the difficult feat of stepping from chair-back to chair-back over heads, reaching his man just in time to prevent a collision and general disturbance. Capt. CAFFRY, of the Fifteenth Precinct, has commended him for his prompt action and difficult feat-easy feet, one would think -- to the favorable consideration of the Commissioners.
lead_paragraph: At the McClellan meeting, Cooper Institute, Wednesday evening, a difficulty arose about midway of the building, and there was danger of a man, somewhat intoxicated, being badly injured. abstract: Grand Ball on Gov. Hahn's Inauguration
snippet: Grand Ball on Gov. Hahn's Inauguration
lead_paragraph: The grand and stirring events of the 4th of March had their climax in an Inaugural Ball at the Opera House, and it was a fitting close to the imposing scenes of this ever-to-be-remembered day -- the day that witnessed Louisiana reushered into the Union, a free State -- as it were, born a new.

abstract: Gen., Justice Done by Inquiry on Chickamauga Battle
snippet: Gen., Justice Done by Inquiry on Chickamauga Battle
lead_paragraph: -- A brief telegram lately announced as the decision of the Court of Inquiry that has had the case of Gen. CRITTENDEN and his conduct at the battle of Chickamauga under investigation, that that officer was exonerated from all the charges brought against him. It is to be regretted that it is not in accordance with the customs of the service to give full report of such investigation, so that as complete emphasis might be given to the refutation of the charges as was accorded the original reports.

abstract: The New-York Chamber of Commerce, in taking up the question of ocean steam navigation, has laid opportune hold of a subject eminently deserving of immediate and practical consideration. Their memorial, just presented to Congress with the view of prompting the enactment of some measures for the support of the ocean steam commerce of the country, presents a series of facts quite startling in their nature, and offers at the same time suggestions of the gravest significance.

abstract: The announcements at the various places of amusement to-night are as follows: At Mr. WALLACK's Theatre, the "Belle's Stratagem," for the benefit of Miss FANNY MORANT; at Mrs. WOOD's, (the Olympic,) BUCKSTONE's comedy called "Leap Year," cast to the entire strength of the company; at the Winter Garden, the "Ticket-of-Leave-Man" -- (this popular drama was to have been withdrawn during the present week -- the last of Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE's engagement -- but the demands for its repetition were so numerous that it will retain its place on the bills to the end;) at Niblo's Garden, Miss RICHINGS, in the drama, with songs, called the "Enchantress;" at BARNUM's Museum, the new spectacular drama of "Aphrosa," with its fine scenery and beautiful fountain effect.

abstract: -- The ladies of Flushing, hold their fair (auxiliary to the Metropolitan Fair,) on Tuesday, the 22d. We understand they have a handsome collection of articles to dispose of, contributed by the liberal citizens of Flushing and vicinity, as well as some elegant specimens of their own handywork, both ornamental and useful. The entire proceeds are to be handed over to the treasurer of the Metropolitan Fair, as the contribution of Flushing. Should any of our citizens feel disposed to attend, they can return to the City in the evening by the night train, which leaves Flushing at 11 o'clock P.M.

abstract: In the Legislature, on Saturday, there was not much business done. In the Senate, the General Appropriation Bill was reported. A bill was passed to extend the provisions of the bill legalizing indebtedness created for bounty purposes. The Senate, in Executive Session, confirmed the nomination of Dr. SWINBURNE, of Albany, as Health Officer of the City of New-York.

abstract: Grant, Gen., Plans and Purposes
lead_paragraph: "It comes from reliable sources that during one of the consultations at the War Department, while the programme of future operations in Virginia was under discussion, Gen. GRANT expressed his opinion in favor of the adoption of the Peninsular route to Richmond. Some of the confieres -- who they were the public can infer -- objected to it upon the ground that it had already been tried at the expense of defeat to the Union arms. To this Gen. GRANT replied: "Yes, but what other practicable route to Richmond has been tried without defeat, and what other route carried the Army of the Potomac as near to Richmond as that did?'"

abstract: On Marrying Negroes; Marrying by Whites, Tribune, World, Independent
snippet: On Marrying Negroes; Marrying by Whites, Tribune, World, Independent
lead_paragraph: We regret to learn from numerous sources that we are on the point of witnessing intermarriage on a grand scale between the whites and blacks of this Republic. It has, as most of our readers are aware, been long held by logicians of the Democratic school, that once you admit the right of a negro to the possession of his own person, and the receipt of his own wages, you are bound either to marry his sister, or give your daughter in marriage to his son. The formula into which this argument has always been thrown was this: If all blacks are fit to be free every white man is bound to marry a black: "Niggers" are blacks: Therefore every white man is bound to marry a "nigger."

abstract: Dr. JOHN SWINBURNE, who on Saturday was nominated by the Governor, and unanimously confirmed by the Senate, as Health Officer of this port, is a resident of Albany. He is an accomplished physician, one of the ablest surgeons in the State, and, devoted to his profession, is among the foremost in developing its skill and extending its usefulness. Personally, no man possesses more popular qualities, and no man is more deservedly popular. It was Dr. SWINBURNE who, volunteering and leaving a lucrative practice, was sent by the Governor to the Peninsula, where his skill and fidelity were of greatest value. During the seven days' battles, refusing to leave the sick and wounded under his charge, he was taken prisoner, and it was due to his firm and manly appeals to the rebel authorities that much of misery and death were saved, and comforts secured to our suffering soldiers. He will bring to the position of Health Officer all the ability necessary to fill it, and the will to do so faithfully and valuably.
lead_paragraph: Dr. JOHN SWINBURNE, who on Saturday was nominated by the Governor, and unanimously confirmed by the Senate, as Health Officer of this port, is a resident of Albany. abstract: -- Capt. EDWARD GORMAN died in Brooklyn yesterday of consumption. The disease was induced by exposure in the field. On the organization of the One Hundred and Seventy-fifth Regiment, Col. BRYAN, Capt. GORMAN having raised a company, joined this command, which was attached to Gen BANKS' Department. The regiment was engaged in several of the battles of the Southwest, and at the fearful assault on Port Hudson was conspicuous. Here, as elsewhere, Capt. GORMAN distinguished himself; on all occasions he was cool, brave and equal to emergencies. His disease developing itself, he was compelled to resign his commission, to the regret of the regiment, with whom his manly, jovial and generous nature had made him a general favorite. He was well known is this City, and his death, at the early age of thirty-three, will be much deplored. The funeral takes place to-morrow at 2 o'clock P.M., from the residence of Mr. EVERARD, his brother-in-law, No. 88 Washington-street, Brooklyn. The officers and members of the One Hundred and Seventy-fifth regiment now in the City are invited to attend.

abstract: The steamers Havana and George Washington arrived from New-Orleans on Saturday, bringing news to the 12th inst. There was considerable activity in military circles. Gen. BANKS was on the eve of departure for Western Louisiana, probably Alexandria. A fleet of Admiral PORTER's gunboats has already started for that place. It was expected that rather formidable works of defence would be encountered by the iron-clads, between the mouth of Red River and Alexandria. Gen. LEE's cavalry had also left New-Orleans, their destination supposed to be to the westward. An order had been issued by Gen. BANKS to hold an election for delegates to a Constitutional Convention on the 18th. The Convention meets in New-Orleans on the 6th of April. There are to be 150 delegates, chosen on a white basis, as per census of 1860. New-Orleans will have sixty-three members.

abstract: Merriam, Eben, Meteorologist
lead_paragraph: Mr. EBEN MERRIM, well known as a statistician and meteorologist, died at his residence, No. 47 Orange-street, (Brooklyn Heights,) on Saturday afternoon, of dropsy of the liver. Thus has passed away one who devoted alife- time to the scientific and pecuniary benefit of his fellow-men. Mr, MERIAM was born in Concord, Massachusetts, June 17, 1794. and consequently was in the 70th year of his age. Shortly after arriving at his majority he proceeded to Kentucky, where he was engaged for a number of years in the manufacture and purification of saltpetre, as well as other mineral products of the Mammoth Cave, in that State. He subsequently engaged extensively in the dry goods business in Zanesville, Ohio. Upon his removal to New-York about 26 years ago, he was a manufacturer of soap and candles, and entered quite largely into that branch of business, accumulating the foundation for a handsome competence. From his earliest childhood, it may be said Mr. MERIAM exhibited a taste for scientific pursuits, and devoted his attention more particularly to meteorological researches. His records of the latter branch of his studies are intact, end extend even to the day of his death. He originated the idea, founded upon his own private observations, of cycles of atmospherical phenomena, which he advanced in public prints with considerable enthusiasm. He attained extended notoriety in this respect, not only in this country but in Europe, and received many evidences of the correctness of his theory from scientific men abroad. He attained considerable notoriety as a careful compiler of meteorological facts, and was frequently cited before the courts to decides disputed points.

abstract: -Why do not the Third and Fourth avenue Railroads, which terminate in front of the Astor House, put up a waiting-room for passengers on the open space which they occupy? A roof, if nothing more, would be a great public convenience, especially in rainy weather. The Sixth, Eighth, Ninth, and Seventh avenue Roads also terminate within half-a-block of the same spot, and all might join in erecting a building which would afford shelter and comfort to the patrons of them all. It is contrary to usage in this country, we are aware, to pay any attention to the wants of passengers, but these companies might, by a joint effort, strain a point for once, without doing themselves any material injury.

abstract: The anniversary meeting for the American Sunday School Union was held last evening in the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth-avenue, corner of Thirty-seventh-street. The secretary stated that the receipts of the Union for the past year were $51,000; that over 800 new schools had been organized, and 55,000 children gathered into them. Mr. STEPHEN PAXSON, Rev. A.A. WILLETS, of Brooklyn, and others, addressed the audience, after which a large collection was taken up, and the meeting dismissed with the benediction.

abstract: -- The total number of deaths last week was 180, of which 27 were men, 28 women, 57 boys and 48 girls. The principal causes were: inflammation of the lungs and scarlet fever, 19 each; consumption and convulsions, 15 each; croup, 11; congestion of the brain, 8; disease of the heart and dropsy, 7 each; diphtheria, 6; erysipelas, 2; measles, 1; bronchitis, 4, &c., &c. Under one year of age. 36. Natives of the United States, 119; Ireland, 28; England, 4; Germany, 7; British America and Scotland, 1 each.
lead_paragraph: -- The total number of deaths last week was 180, of which 27 were men, 28 women, 57 boys and 48 girls. abstract: Wheeler, Sergt.-Maj. Ogden H., formerly of Brooklyn
snippet: Wheeler, Sergt.-Maj. Ogden H., formerly of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: -The remains of the late Sergt-Maj. OGDEN H. WHEELER, of the First Regiment Ohio Volunteers, were yesterday consigned to their last resting place in Greenwood Cemetery. The funeral ceremonies took place at Plymouth Church, and the pastor, Rev. H.W. BEECHER, officiated on the occasion. The deceased was formerly attached to Plymouth Sunday-school, and subsequently became a member of the church. He emigrated to Ohio before the war broke out, and when hostilities commenced he enlisted, and participating in several battles, was promoted to the position of Sergeant-Major for bravery and good conduct. He passed through all the engagements in which he participated without injury, but at the storming of Missionary Ridge he was struck by a bullet and instantly killed. His remains were brought on here for interment. The children of the Sunday-school were present, ranged on both sides of the gallery. They sang "Shining Shore" and other songs suitable to the occasion. Mr. BEECHER made a brief but very forcible address, in which he extolled the bravery of the deceased, and advised all young men of the Sunday-school, or of his congregation, who had any idea of joining the army, to do so, and not to forget that they were fighting for their country as well as for the freedom of the poor, the ignorant and the dark hued bondman. Many had gone to the war, and he had never yet had occasion to be ashamed of the boys of Plymouth Church. After the services the coffin, which was covered with the American flag, was placed in the hearse and conveyed to the cemetery, escorted by a detail of ten files of the Thirteenth Regiment, under command of Sergt.-Major CORNWELL.

abstract: Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday at No. 1 East Forty-sixth-street, on the body of THOMAS BURNS, a laborer, who was run over in Fourth-avenue, near Forty-sixth-street, by a locomotive belonging to the Harlem Railroad Company. The wheels of the locomotive passed over his abdomen, cutting his body nearly in twain. Instant death was the result. Deceased was at work on the track at the time, and notwithstanding the signals of danger given by the engineer on the approaching train, it seems he failed to get off the track in time to save his life. The jury rendered a verdict of accidental death. BURNS was a single man, aged about forty-four years. He had been in the employ of the Harlem Railroad Company for six or seven years.

abstract: Our Nashville correspondent writes us that the motto and the sentiment of the Tennessee Unionists at the late election in that State was "Emancipation, Confiscation and Extermination." This, of course, does not imply that these Unionists are in favor of exterminating the population of the Southern States. We may expand the motto thus: Emancipation of slaves -- Confiscation of rebel property, and Extermination of the rebellion, root and branch. In every Southern and in every Confederate State, there are large numbers of loyal people, as the present condition of things in the lately Confederate State of Tennessee itself bears witness. A telegraphic dispatch from the Capital of Arkansas, announces that at the election held last week in that State fifteen thousand loyal votes were registered, and ten thousand votes polled. We have no doubt that the same condition of things would be revealed in Alabama, Georgia, and North Carolina to-day, if these States were freed from rebel rule, and the people allowed to express their unbiased opinions. Let the rebellion be utterly exterminated, but after that is done, we shall find in the population of the South excellent elements at hand for reconstruction.

abstract: Last evening the anniversary meeting in New- York for the American Sunday-School Union, was  held in the Presbyterian Brick Church, Rev. Dr. SPRING, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-seventh- street. The church was well filled with an excel lent and intelligent congregation.
lead_paragraph: Last evening the anniversary meeting in New-York for the American Sunday-School Union, was held in the Presbyterian Brick Church, Rev. Dr. SPRING, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-seventh-street. The church was well filled with an excellent and intelligent congregation. Rev. Dr. FERRIS, President of the New-York Sunday-School Union, presided. Rev. JOHN H. BURTIS, one of the Secretaries of the American Sunday-School Union, stated that the contributions from the Sunday Schools of the New-York Sunday-School Union were $6,387 96; contributions paid into the New-York Treasury from other schools in and near the City, $8,830; rom other sources, $12,290; making in all $27,630 34 -- an increase of several thousand dollars. The receipts of the American Sunday School Union for the past year were $51,000. Over 800 new schools have been organized, and 55,000 children gathered into them. The Secretary stated that the Society had greatly prospered during the past year, additional missionaries had been appointed in many of the States, and that these schools and missionaries were permanent. He also said the Union basis is the only basis on which any religious organization can be effected in hundreds of neighborhoods in our land; that this organization must be the Sunday School, for the church cannot be formed to suti the nature of the case; that the Sunday School Missionary service comprehends family visitation, Bible and religious book distribution and forming of the Sunday Schools. He also appealed for larger contributions, and stated that $2,500 had already been promised. Mr. STEPHEN PAXON, of Illinois, for fifteen years Missionary of the Society, addressed the audience, giving his own experience as an introduction. All his education was obtained in a Sunday School after he was thirty years of age. During his service he had organized nearly eleven hundred new schools, and gathered into them nearly 57,000 children. He gave a very interesting history of some of these schools, showing how they had finally developed into churches. His address was a most convincing and instructive one, and was listened to with great attention. Rev. A.A. WILLETS, of Brooklyn, followed in a very eloquent address, commending the Society for its good influence and perfect adaptation to meet the destitution of the land.

abstract: Arkansas, the Restoration of
lead_paragraph: Arkansas has given a larger vote for the Union than even Louisiana, and is also ahead of her in the adoption of a Free State Con stitution. Though the latest reduced "Con- federate" State, it is yet the first of any to reconstitute itself on a Free State basis. It has been admirably prompt both in deciding and executing. Undoubtedly the chief cause of this superior promptitude over Louisiana and Tennessee is the fact that the slave population of the State has been at no time more than one third as large. On account of the comparative newness of the country, the large slaveholders were comparatively very few, and the great majority of the people had no slaves at all. It was only by the most villainous chicanery that the Secession Convention was elected which professed to take Arkansas out of the Union. Slavery did not supply the same stimulus in that State that it did in some of the others. It is not at all strange that when brought back by force, she so much more readily accepts the result, and adapts her social system to the new order of things.

abstract: -- Foreign nations are very naturally taking advantage of the entire disappearance of American steamers en the Atlantic, to take possession of the great commercial route between Europe and America. A company has been formed in France called the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, which announces the speedy completion of two splendid steamers of the new line which they are about to establish between this port and Havre. The first of these, named the Washington, having made a most satisfactory trial trip, may be expected to arrive here in the month of May, to be followed in June by the second vessel, appropriately named the Lafayette. Their regular days of departure will be announced hereafter. These vessels were both built on the Clyde, and are of the largest and best class of sea-going steamers. The company announce that others of a similar character will be put upon the line as soon as possible. This was a favorite route for persons going directly to the Continent, while it was held by those capital vessels the Arago and Fulton, and it can scarcely fail to regain its former popularity. The office of the new company is at No. 7 Broadway, which will be remembered as the headquarters of the old American Havre line.

abstract: The Jewish festival of Purim will be celebrated this evening, by a grand, fancy dress ball, at the Academy of Music. It is recognized as one of the most important of Jewish festivals, as it commemorates the deliverance of the Jews from the tyranny of Haman, who was prime minister to King Ahasuerus. The arrangements for the ball are very extensive, and the ornaments appropriate and beautiful. But one thousand tickets have been issued, and these only to be obtained by personal introduction to a member of the committee, the party introducing being held strictly accountable for the character and conduct of the persons introduced. With such strict rules and such liberal preparations, the ball cannot fail to be one of the best of the season.

abstract: The war in the Southwest continues to furnish its quota of news reports from various points. The railroad is again in running order between Chattanooga, Tenn., and Ringgold, Ga., which is now Gen. THOMAS' advanced post. The mustering officers report that large numbers of Gen. THOMAS' army are still reenlisting as veterans. Dispatches from Strawberry Plains, in East Tennessee,represent the rebels still in large force at Bull's Gap, in numbers as high as twenty thousand. A general belief was entertained there that the rebels meditate another invasion into Kentucky. The guerrillas on the north side of the Cumberland River are again active. Gen. HOBSON's cavalry are after them vigorously, with a prospect of breaking up their operations. The rebel Gen. FORREST is reported to be organizing for a movement into West Tennessee, and Gen. GRIERSON is on the lookout for him.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a report from the Secretary of War was received, containing information as to what orders had been issued by Provost-Marshals affecting elections in the Border States. The Secretary states that no orders were issued by those officers. Mr. GRIMES, of Iowa, offered a resolution of the Legislature of Iowa, in favor of the construction of a military and wagon road from some point on the west side of the Missouri River, in Nebraska Territory, to Gallatin in Idaho. The Senate then took up the bill to promote enlistments, and a long discussion took place on the proposition to pay the loyal owners of slaves for their property when taken by the Government for troops. Without concluding the subject, the Senate went into Executive Session and adjourned.

abstract: The arrangements for the Metropolitan Fair are nearly completed. Under order of Gen. DIX, on the afternoon of the 28th inst., between the hours of 2 and 4, there will be a grand military parade in honor of the inauguration of the Fair, which will take place in the evening of that day. Not less than 10,000 troops will be under arms and participate in the proceedings of the day. The programme for the evening has not yet been announced, but it is understood a large number of distinguished persons, both civil and military, will be present. Speeches will be made and a musical entertainment given.

abstract: The Siege of
lead_paragraph: -- A sentence in the news of yesterday from New-Orleans probably indicates the countermanding of a projected military operation, whose stoppage may be a matter of gratulation rather than regret. The sentence is as follows: "Madisonville, a small town on Lake Pontchartrain, opposite New-Orleans, has been evacuated;" and we judge it means that there is no intention now of advancing an army against Mobile, and opening its siege. We remarked the other day that we could not afford to waste a great army and navy in besieging Mobile, although undoubtedly it was a desirable point to seize at an opportune moment. There was an opportune moment a few weeks ago, and that was when Gen. SHERMAN rushed with his army from Vicksburgh to Meridian. There is little doubt now, as is proved by many things that have lately come to light, that Mobile was the point then really aimed at; but the heavy body of troops which had been moved to Madisonville to cooperate with SHERMAN in the assault, did not "come to time," as was also the case with SMITH'S cavalry at the upper end of the State of Mississippi. Gen. SHERMAN'S march had been so extremely rapid to Meridian, that, on reaching that point, Gen. BANKS' column had not even set out for Pearl River; nor, unfortunately, would it have been ready to do so for some weeks subsequently. As a consequence of this SHERMAN could but retrace his steps, damaging the enemy as much as possible.

abstract: N. C. and the Rebellion; And the Rebellion--Gov. Vance's Speech
snippet: N. C. and the Rebellion; And the Rebellion--Gov. Vance's Speech
lead_paragraph: The Wilkesboro speech of the Governor of North Carolina, on the relations of that State to the Confederacy -- published by us almost in full -- has a special interest. It comes from a man who originally was opposed with his whole soul to the secession movement; it treats of the duties of a Southern State which has had the name of being the most disaffected to the Confederacy; and while some of its language is scurrilous, and most of its conclusions are wrong, it still enforces the rebel side of the case with more than ordinary sense and vigor. It was designed to be an argument and an exhortation to the people of North Carolina against the project of a convention which shall withdraw the State from the Confederacy, in order to obtain peace, which, it seems to be admitted, is now the main desire. Gov. VANCE based his appeal upon four or five considerations. It is well worth while to measure them by a Northern standard -or rather, we should say, by the standard of true Union principles, which our armies are fighting to vindicate.

abstract: The Cincinnati Price Current, in publishing the full report of the pork packing in that city, says: "It will be seen that the past season was a very short one, about the same in this respect, as that of 1859; and the price was the highest paid in any previous year for eleven years, and, indeed, by referring to our statistics back for twenty-five years, we find that the price in no season during that time has been as high as the past season. There is a large falling off in the number packed, as compared with last year, which is to be attributed to the bad failure of the corn crop in this State and Indiana, particularly the latter State, from which a large number of hogs are generally brought to this market. There was also a falling off in the number brought from KentucKy, in consequence of the Government having taken a large number of the hogs fatted in that State.

abstract: Edward Linn vs. David B. Elston. -- This was an action to recover $1,000 damages for an alleged assault and battery. Plaintiff alleged that on the 3d of October, 1862, defendant assaulted and beat him, injuring him severely. The defendant denied that he assaulted plaintiff, and claimed that plaintiff came to his office on that day, used bad language to him, and called him a liar. He ordered him out of the office, and upon his refusing to go, put him out, without using unnecessary violence.

abstract: VAN AMBURGH & CO.'s MENAGERIE. -- The public will regret to see the announcement of the last week but four of this elegant collection of animals and birds. Why the management desire to seek new quarters for them is a mystery. The animals themselves ought not to growl, for their quarters are certainly more beautiful than any they have ever occupied before, and the manager's quarters -- financially speaking -- must have accumulated in great quantities, judging from the vast number of their daily visitors -- sufficient, we should think, to induce them to remain permanently in our City. Natural history is capable of yielding innumerable subjects for valuable study. An opportunity like the present has never before presented itself to the people of our City. As the time is now approaching for its departure, we would advise parents to take the children immediately, and give them the instruction a visit would afford. Three grand performances are given daily. The morning entertainment is preferable for those wishing to avoid a crowd.

abstract: Last evening, a mass meeting on behalf of the working women was held at the Cooper Institute. The hall was well filled with a very respectable and intelligent audience, among whom were numbers of the working women. Hon. CHARLES P. DALY presided. He said the members of the committee had submitted to him a constitution, which should attract the attention and admiration of all who were interested in the welfare and success of the 30,000 working women now employed in all branches of business in this great commercial City. They had more to struggle with than those of the so-called stronger sex, and the object of this society was to protect them from the frauds of designing men who would take from them a portion of their small earnings, or treat them in any way that was not right. He was astonished to hear that married women of comfortable means took employment to supply them with additional spending-money, and thought it necessary that they should leave the field for those who actually need it. And when they knew the great harm they were doing, he was satisfied they would do so. During the afternoon, MYNDERT VAN SCHAICK, Esq., had called on him and presented him with a check for $50 for the society. He hoped others would follow the good example. His speech was received with much enthusiasm. A[???]ts close Miss TERESA ESMONDE read "The Song of the Workingwomen," written by Mrs. ANN S. STEPHENS. At its close a practical workingwoman exhibited a number of articles made for various large mercantile houses, explained the amount of work they required and the prices paid. The following are a few of them:

abstract: The Board of Supervisors yesterday received a letter from Hon. FERNANDO WOOD, asserting the plea of the Westchester Supervisors for not summoning him to testify about the management of Harlem Bridge affairs that his testimony could not be had because of his privilege as a member of Congress, to be an unjust attempt to asperse his character, and declaring his willingness to testify fully upon the subject at any time. The Westchester investigation, he says, he knew nothing about -- was never asked or called to testify before the conductors of it -- till he saw the whole matter in print. The letter was referred to the committee appointed to investigate the charges of the Westchester Supervisors. Mayor GUNTHER sent in a veto on the resolution appointing ANTHONY EICKHOFF translator to the Record and Surrogate's Courts, at a salary of $2,500, on the ground of illegality. The Board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. on next Monday.

abstract: Disposal after Emancipation Proclamation
lead_paragraph: When, on the 1st of January, 1863, the Emancipation Proclamation was issued, and before that event, it was feared that in case such a measure were of any practical effect, the whole of the Northern States would be overrun by negroes from the South. As a first step in the prevention of this calamity, the last Congress appropriated six hundred thousand dollars to carry our freed negroes to the West Indies or to any other place, so that it was beyond the boundaries of this country. About a year ago, the first ship load of some four hundred, sailed from Fortress Monroe to Hayti, and, after a twelve months' trial of that locality, with its fervid climate, fertile soil and negro government, they arrived in this country again last Sunday morning, and landed a short distance from the spot at which they had embarked -- the expense of their voyage both ways having been borne by the Government. As might have been expected, they had suffered much hardship and misery during their stay in Hayti, and were glad of the opportunity to return to this country.

abstract: Matter of Cook. -- This was a habeas corpus for the relief of the relator, Cook, the bounty broker, who desired to be let out on bail. The application was granted, and the bail fixed at $1,500, which was given, and the prisoner was discharged.

abstract: JOHN, W. HUNTER, a Deputy Auditor at the Custom-house, has been arrested on a warrant issued by the United States District-Attorney, for alleged frauds upon the Assistant Treasurer's office. The arrest grew out of two checks -- one of $4,200 and the other of $5,000, which the accused is charged with not having accounted for in the settlement of his accounts. The checks are pronounced by the arrested party to be forgeries perpetrated by a person now confined in Fort Lafayette. The accused most emphatically denies the charges made against him. He was taken before Commissioner STILLWELL, who held him to bail in the sum of $10,000, to answer the charge. Collector BARNEY and S.J. OGDEN gave the required surety, and Mr. HUNTER was released. He has been over thirty years in the Custom-house and has sustained an unsullied character; his innocence of wrong is very generally believed, and his entire exoneration confidently expected.

abstract: The Provost-Marshal-General yesterday issued an important statement, showing the exact account of each State, on the 1st of March, 1864, as regards the filling of the quotas under the several calls for troops. This statement is very conclusive. The credits to the States include everything but the veteran reenlistments, and the "deficiency" includes the number for which the States are yet in arrears to the Government on previous calls. From this statement it will be seen that Illinois is the only State whose quota under all calls is full -- and she has, it seems, twelve thousand surplus, not counting veteran enlistments at that. Several other States are nearly full, viz., Indiana, Kansas, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Vermont and New-Hampshire; counting the veteran reenlistments, their quotas will all be full, and most of them will have a surplus for future demands. But the populous States of Massachusetts, New-York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Ohio and Kentucky, are largely behind. In the cases of New-York and Pennsylvania, the credits are not yet computed, but the total quota and deficiency is, in the case of New-York, nearly 60,000; and in the case of Pennsylvania, nearly 75,000. The figures are quite instructive.

abstract: Proposal to Observe
lead_paragraph: A very large number of the Protestant clergymen of New-York have united in a public proposition to secure a general agreement among the Christians of this City in the observance of Good Friday this year. The names appended to the document represent not only Episcopal clergymen, but many of the most distinguished divines of the Presbyterian, Methodist, Baptist, Dutch Reformed, Lutheran and other denominations, together with theological professors and heads of the great religious societies. They conjointly agree to observe a day so widely observed throughout the Christian world, not only "in solemn remembrance of the crucifixion of our Lord," and the unity of their faith thereupon, but as a "day of fasting, humiliation and prayer, in view of our national troubles," impelled thereto by "our sins as individuals and as a people, the intense worldliness among us, the rapid and appalling growth of luxury and extravagance, with all their attendant evils, and these in the midst of the direst calamities and chastisements that can befall a people."
headline: {'main': 'GOOD FRIDAY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GOOD FRIDAY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Children's Department of the Metropolitan Fair will be one of the specially attractive features. The little ones will occupy a liberal share of the building erecting on Seventeenth-street and Union-square. There will be abundance of room for display of all articles, and beside this there will be a stage for tableaux, singing, &c., &c. Mrs. JAMES B. COLGATE has taken an active interest in this department, and it will be a decided success. The building is being rapidly completed under the supervision of P.B. WIGHT, Esq., architect, and will accommodate twenty-five hundred children. All who feel disposed to contribute to the display the little ones are anxious to make -- and who does not feel so disposed? -- can send articles to the Moffat Building on Seventeenth-street, opposite Union-square.This building has been generously tendered by Mr. R.E. MOUNT, executor of Dr. MOFFAT'S estate. Do not forget the Children's Department.

abstract: At the meeting of the Commissioners of Health, yesterday, a communication was received from the City Inspector, in regard to the prevalence of ship fever in certain localities of the City, which is attributed to an unusual amount of emigration, and large numbers of emigrants taking lodgings in the narrow by-streets.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Commissioners of Health, yesterday, a communication was received from the City Inspector, in regard to the prevalence of ship fever in certain localities of the City, which is attributed to an unusual amount of emigration, and large numbers of emigrants taking lodgings in the narrow by-streets. The City Inspector says he has done all in his power to prevent the spread of disease, and invokes the aid of the Commissioners of Health, and, if necessary, of the Board of Health, to take further precautionary measures. Mr. BRADY, the Deputy Superintendent of Sanitary Inspection, appeared before the board and gave a detailed account of the action taken by the City Inspector's Department to purify the places where the infection exists. On suggestion of the President, (Mayor GUNTHER,) it is understood the medical members of the board were directed to draft an ordinance embodying such regulations as they may think are necessary to further combat the disease. This action implies that the Mayor may soon convene the Board of Health.

abstract: The reenlisted veterans of this corps are expected here to-day from the Department of the South, by the Arago. Should they arrive, the Mayor and Common Council will give them a public reception at the City Hall at 2 o'clock P.M. The Seventh Regiment New-York National Guard will act as escort. Many distinguished persons have been invited to participate in the reception, among them Gens. DIX, STANNARD, HAYS, and Gen. TURNER, Chief of Staff of the Department of the South, and the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of New-York, who presented the colors planted by this corps on Pulaski, Wagner and Gregg. The line of march will be up Broadway to Eighth-street, thence to Sixth-avenue and to Jefferson Market drill-room, where a banquet will be provided.

abstract: There arrived at this port, yesterday, the brig Diana, of Jersey, ARTHUR, (late TOUZEL,) Rio Janeiro 63 days, with coffee to E. D. MORGAN & Co.- Feb. 8, at 7:30 A.M., Las Roccas, bearing W. by S., distant 10 miles, saw a wreck on the rocks. Capt. TOUZEL made up his mind to go and see what it was; at 10 A.M. anchored to the westward of the Roccas; got the two boats out and proceeded on shore; went up to the wreck, which was named Glentanner, of London, and began to work about it till 6 P.M.; loaded the tugboat and proceeded to the brig. Capt. AZTHUR says:

abstract: OLYMPIC THEATRE -- BUCKSTONE's comedy of "Leap-Year" was produced here last evening with very decided success. It is familiar to our theatregoers, and on some occasions has been rendered more judiciously and harmoniously than by the members of Mrs. WOOD's company. There were, however, exceptions to this remark. The fair manager is a host in herself, and cannot be surpassed or approached by any other artist on the Metropolitan stage. Her impersonation of the rollicking, good-natured, match-making Miss O'Leary, was hearty and spirited in the highest degree, and was the main element of the evening's success. Miss HENRIETTA IRVING supported Mrs. WOOD in several expensive dresses. Her delivery of the language of the part was not always accurate -- in an elocutionary point of view, seldom. There can be no reason for twisting up the end of each sentence into a vocal query where no question is at issue. The practice is one of the least admirable of MATILDA HERON's many affectations. In its way it is as bad as the extraordinary nasalities and high tragic-twang of Miss WALTERS -- an intelligent and painstaking young artist in other respects, but intolerable from this East-side and Museum vice. How enjoyable is the contrast afforded by Mrs. SEDLEY BROWN! This pleasant and pert interpreter of buxom chambermaids, although by no means blessed with a good speaking voice, contrives, by a quiet adherence to honest nature, to give more significance to her lines than the most vociferous of her companions. She was admirable as Miss Crisp -- a little over-dressed, perhaps, but still admirable.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC THEATRE -- BUCKSTONE's comedy of "Leap-Year" was produced here last evening with very decided success. Miss HENRIETTA IRVING supported Mrs. WOOD in several expensive dresses. Her delivery of the language of the part was not always accurate -- in an elocutionary point of view, seldom. There can be no reason for twisting up the end of each sentence into a vocal query where no question is at issue. The practice is one of the least admirable of MATILDA HERON's many affectations. In its way it is as bad as the extraordinary nasalities and high tragic-twang of Miss WALTERS -- an intelligent and painstaking young artist in other respects, but intolerable from this East-side and Museum vice. How enjoyable is the contrast afforded by Mrs. SEDLEY BROWN! abstract: has no Connection with the Vache Colonization Scheme
snippet: has no Connection with the Vache Colonization Scheme
lead_paragraph: The Herald, in a dispatch from Washington, speaking of the "recently exploded colonization scheme" in the Island of Vache, says that "prominent among the parties interested in it are understood to be LEONARD W. JEROME and HENRY J. RAYMOND, of New-York." So far as the person last named, at least, is concerned, there is not the slightest foundation for the statement. He has not now, never did have, and never expects to have, any interest whatever, direct or indirect, positive or contingent, immediate or remote, actual, probable or possible in this scheme, or in any other contract, project or proceeding with which the Government is in any way connected. Mr. JEROME's interest, we believe, is limited to having expended, in connection with Messrs. FORBES and TUCKERMAN, with whom the agreement by the Government was made, some sixty or seventy thousand dollars, in an effort to carry out the proclaimed views of the Government on the subject of colonization, -- without having received in return a single dollar of the money which the Government agreed to pay.

abstract: Leaders in Earnest; Gov. Vance's Speech
snippet: Leaders in Earnest; Gov. Vance's Speech
lead_paragraph: Nobody who read the speech of Gov. VANCE, of North Carolina, which we published on Saturday, can help seeing that whatever the feelings of the people at the South may be, the leaders are bitterly and terribly in earnest. He makes much of the desire of his audience either to return to the Union or remain neutral. He admits that they are in a bad scrape, but asks them jeeringly how they propose to get out of it. He assures them that the provision of the Confederate Constitution permitting secession, on which some of them propose to rely, is a delusion and a snare; that the Confederate Government would certainly permit their withdrawal, but only in order that their assumption of the character of a foreign Power might authorize their being attacked and cut to pieces. He tells them that come what will there can be no peace for them until the whole Confederacy is either victorious or vanquished, and that their complaints, either of the war or of the rebel Government, are but as the idle wind; that willing or not willing, their blood and money must be forthcoming as long as JEFFERSON DAVIS is pleased to call for them.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. HARRIS presented the remonstrance of the members of the New-York Legislature against the extension of the Goodyear patent. Mr. CLARK, of New-Hampshire, called up the bill relative to the weight and character of American copper coins, which was passed. The bill authorizes the issue of bronze two-cent pieces. Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, offered a resolution calling upon the Secretary of War for information as to how many nine months' men have been raised under the militia law of last Congress, whether the $25 bounty has been paid to them, and, if not, why it has been withheld from any of them, and whether any bounty has been paid to drafted men, which was adopted. Mr. MCDOUGALL, of California, offered a series of resolutions, deprecating the French occupation of Mexico. A bill was introduced for the increase of the United States Marine Corps. Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill to prohibit the inter-State slave-trade. The bill, promoting enlistments came up, when Mr. WILLEY spoke at length, when the Senate adjourned.
