abstract: Newbern, N.C., advices to the 19th inst., mention that a great commotion was caused among the rebel troops in that region when Richmond was menaced by Gen. KILPATRICK. PICKETT, the rebel General, sent off several of his regiments in great haste to defend the city, and stopped pending military operations within his command. These regiments are now reported to be coming back.
lead_paragraph: Newbern, N.C., advices to the 19th inst., mention that a great commotion was caused among the rebel troops in that region when Richmond was menaced by Gen. KILPATRICK. PICKETT, the rebel General, sent off several of his regiments in great haste to defend the city, and stopped pending military operations within his command. These regiments are now reported to be coming back. In one of his recent speeches Gov. VANCE urges the importance of the North Carolina railroads to the preservation of LEE's army, and says that should they be destroyed the troops could not remain in Virginia forty-eight hours. The Wilmington Journal has an article on the success of blockade-running, which it fortifies with statistics showing that only one out of twenty blockade-runners have been captured. An experienced rebel naval officer is reported to have said that, owing to the peculiar situation of the channels leading to Wilmington, embracing an area of thirty miles, all the vessels of the United States Navy would be insufficient to prevent the illicit trade.

abstract: Shall they Sit in Congress
lead_paragraph: It is said that a committee is about to report favorably on the bill admitting the heads of the various departments to seats in the House, and giving each the right of speaking on any subject connected with their branch of the public service. Such a measure would remedy a great defect in our national system of legislation. There is no good reason why our Congress should be the only representative body of any nation that is deprived of personal communication with those to whom is intrusted the administration of the affairs upon which the body legislates. This system, which is peculiar to ourselves, sprang from a jealousy of the Executive power. It was fancied that the personal participation of the cabinet officers in the debates of Congress would give the President undue influence. We do not believe that any such effect would follow. The assumption implies that the representatives of the people either have not understanding, to save them from being cajoled, or have not firmness to save them from being intimidated. If it is indeed true that our representatives must be fools or cravens, who have to be specially guarded, lest they be deceived or daunted, the sooner we give up the representative system altogether, and take an autocrat for a ruler, the better. The representation that has no more character than that would indicate, is worse than nothing.

abstract: London Letter, March 8
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 7th March, Mr. ROEBUCK gave notice that on the 11th he should put a question to the Government on American affairs. Earl RUSSELL had stated that Her Majesty's Government had remonstrated with the Confederate Government on its enlisting sailors and attempting to purchase vessels in England; but as the noble Lord had also stated that the Government desired to preserve a strict neutrality, he should ask whether it would remonstrate with the Federal Government on the employment by it of agents for the purpose of enlisting Her Majesty's subjects in Ireland as soldiers.

abstract: Railroads, Underground Project, The
lead_paragraph: We see it announced that the Railroad Committee in the State Assembly has decided to report against allowing the Harlem Road to lay a track through Broadway. We hope they will also report against any railroad through that great thoroughfare. The truth is, the chartering and building of street railroads in this City is likely to be overdone, -- not that they are not all needed, but because they don't answer the purpose. Too many of them block the City traffic, instead of aiding and relieving it. A certain number of them, running across the town as well as up and down, are imperatively necessary; but to devote all the streets to railroads is simply to shut or block up all other kinds of traffic. There is a great deal of traveling which railroads will not accommodate. All the freighting business of the City, which is enormous, -- and all the private carriages, which are very numerous and on the increase, require accommodation and are entitled to it; and streets must be left open for their use.

lead_paragraph: -- It seems that poor old Gen. PRICE, who has not been heard of since he was so badly whipped by our negro troops at Helena, last Summer, gain threatens to take the field. He has issued an address to his men, promising soon to lead them against their "cowardly and boasting foes," and prophecying that he and they will retrieve past reverses, reoccupy lost territory, &. Gen. PRICE should not talk in this style. He cannot possibly do what he says he will do. He is stationed somewhere in the southern part of Arkansas with a small force; but it matters little whether his force be large or small. We hold firmly the line of the Arkansas River with our garrisons and gunboats, and that forms a sufficient barrier against all the rebels south of that stream.

abstract: East and West! We look alternately across the North Sea and the Atlantic. abstract: The United States transport Arago, HENRY A. GADSDEN, commanding, from Port Royal, S.C., at 6 P.M. Saturday, March 19, arrived yesterday morning. Affairs before Charleston and at other points in the department were quiet. The rebels had successfully launched another iron-clad in Charleston Harbor, called the Ashley. A successfulreconnoissance to Bull's Bay, S.C., had been made. On the night of the 11th the rebels attempted to surprise our pickets, but were repulsed. The rebel blockade-runner Sophia had been captured by the Huron.
lead_paragraph: The United States transport Arago, HENRY A. GADSDEN, commanding, from Port Royal, S.C., at 6 P.M. Saturday, March 19, arrived yesterday morning. Affairs before Charleston and at other points in the department were quiet. The rebels had successfully launched another iron-clad in Charleston Harbor, called the Ashley. A successfulreconnoissance to Bull's Bay, S.C., had been made. On the night of the 11th the rebels attempted to surprise our pickets, but were repulsed. The rebel blockade-runner Sophia had been captured by the Huron.

abstract: In the American Journal of Science and Arts for March, Prof. J.D. DANA continues the series of articles upon the classification of animals based upon the principle of cepalization, which are creating such a stir in the scientific world. The paper in this number of the Journal is devoted to the Classification of Herbivores. An elaborate discussion of Celestial Dynamics, by J.R. MAYER, follows. Among the other papers may be mentioned one by D. TROWBRIDGE, on the Invisibility of Nebulous Matter; on Fossils from the Potsdam of Wisconsin and Lake Superior, by Prof. ALEX. WINCHELL; Remarks on the Family Pteriidoe; on the Theory of the Tides by WM. DENNIS; and Contributions to Luthology, by T. STERRY HUNT, M.A.

abstract: Members of Congress, Disturbances Between
lead_paragraph: -- The House of Representatives was yesterday the scene of another of those terrible rows between the Missouri members, which have so frequently disgraced the present session of Congress. This time it was BLAIR vs. McCLURG, and the language and epithets they applied to each other were of a nature that must astound respectable people. Two weeks ago yesterday, MCCLURG consumed two hours in abusing BLAIR for a speech abusing MCCLURG, delivered by BLAIR a week or two before; and between each of these great periodical jousts there has been a ceaseless series of bitter, though thus far bloodless, contests.

abstract: In consequence of the impossibility of completing the arrangements for the opening of the Metropolitan Fair on the 28th inst., it has been determined to postpone the inauguration until the 4th of April. Letters have recently been received from Europe stating that a large number of contributions are enroute for this country, many of which cannot reach New-York before the 4th. The donations received have been far more extensive than was anticipated -making it necessary to considerably change many of the original arrangements determined upon for the display of articles for exhibition. The contributions from the country and neighboring States are extensive. The Otisville Mining Company, of New-York, have presented a ton of their richest specimens of quartz. The value of the gift, with transportation expenses, (defrayed by the company,) is estimated at eight hundred dollars. Delhr, a small town in Delaware County of less than 1,000 inhabitants, sends $200 in money and $70 worth of produce. Geneva contributes $500. Buffalo and Rochester have intimated their intention to send valuable "tables"; also Ulster and Dutchess Counties. Harlem has contributed liberally. The cities and many of the villages of Connecticut have sent donations; conspicuous among the number is Hartford. The City authorities have consented to the closing of Union-square during the holding of the Fair; and the Central Park Committee have offered the use of their tents, which will be erected in Union-square for the use of musicians and such other purposes as they may be adapted to. The Philharmonic Society and several bands have volunteered their services. The music at the fair will be the best ever furnished on any occasion in this City. A large number of things are wanted for the Knickerbocker Kitchen, especially an antique dresser. Any person having one will oblige the Committee of Arrangements by forwarding it to the receiving rooms on Fourteenth-street.

abstract: The steamships Olympus, City of Washington and Germania all arrived at this port yesterday, bringing four day's later advices from Europe, the dates bing to the 10th instant. The news is more than ordinarily interesting. A severe fight had taken place between the Austrians and Danes, near Veile, in which the losses on both sides were heavy, and the Danes were driven from their position. The Allies have invaded Jutland, and at last advices were advancing in great force toward Fredericia. The consideration of the Danish question had occupied a large part of the time in the British Parliament, and in the debate on the 8th instant, in the House of Lords, Earl RUSSELL characterized the conduct of Austria and Prussia in inaugurating the war as "most unjustifiable," Earl RUSSELL further said that propositions for a conference were still pending between the belligerents, but Denmark had not replied to the overtures. The debate was considered as being the most hostile demonstration which Parliament has yet made. Elections to the Folksthing were held in Denmark on the 5th, and the candidates demanded the energetic prosecution of the war, declaring the abrogation of the November Constitution to be now impossible. The Danes seem to possess an indomitable spirit, which is determined upon preserving the integrity of the monarchy, and the sympathies of the liberal nations are cyrstalizing around them. The British press are greatly exercised over a rumored alliance between Russia, Prussia and Austria, ostensibly on the ground of opposing revolution, but really against constitutional liberty, and opinions were expressed that England would certainly drift into war, it being impossible to remain neutral while Europe is convulsed by a struggle against despotism. The rumored alliance had affected the money market. The Archduke MAXIMILIAN still remained at Paris and was engaged in preparing for his regal state in Mexico. In Warsaw, the Imperial decree of Russia, announcing the emancipation of the peasantry and the entire severance of the ties which bind them to the nobility, was publicly proclaimed on the 6th. The latest market reports advise a steadiness in the bread stuffs, provision and produce markets. Consols for money closed at 91@91 1/4. The steamship China also arrived at midnight with three days later news. On the 28th of February the pirate steamer Florida arrived at Madeira from Brest, and was allowed to receive twenty tons of coal, besides water and provisions. She left the port on the following day. The U.S. corvette St. Louis was at Madeira when the Florida arrived. The King of Bavaria died on the 11th inst. There was little additional war news. A tremendous gunpowder explosion had occurred in the Calabar River, Africa, and the underwriters were heavy sufferers.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a unanimous report was presented against the passage of the Harlem Broadway Railroad Bill, but on motion of Mr. DUTCHER the question of agreeing with the report was postponed, to enable him to make some remarks upon the bill. Among the bills reported were the following; Respecting an amendment to the State Constitution, authorizing the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeal; for the better protection of seamen of the port of New-York; authorizing the New-York Infirmary for Indigent Women to confer the title of M.D.: authorizing the New-York authorities to convey certain real estate on Ward's Island; The following bills were passed: Providing for the sale of real estate belonging to lunatics; amending the charter of the Morrisania Fire Department; relative to the West Farms Town Hall; authorizing the New-York authorities to convey certain real estate to the Hebrew Benevolent Society; relative to criminal records in New-York. Adjourned. In the Assembly the following bills were reported complete: To incorporate the American Literary Fund Association in New-York; to incorporate the Tom Moore Association of New-York; to incorporate the Wire-Drawers' Association of New-York: relative to counterfeit bank bills; to consolidate the Boston and Hartford and Erie Extension Railroad Companies. The following bills were passed: To incorporate the Grand Hotel Company, New-York. To regulate the freight and passenger tariffs on the Hudson River Railroad. Relative to the National Academy of Design; recommitted, with instructions to strike out the clause exempting property from taxation. To incorporate the Mechanics' Dime Savings Bank in New-York. To incorporate the Central Park Hotel Company. Relative to the National Academy of Design; amended by the committee as instructed. Mr. INGRAHAM introduced a bill to confirm certain ordinances of the Mayor and Commonalty of New-York, relative to the Harlem Railroad ground.

abstract: Legislature--Grinding Committees
lead_paragraph: -- The Legislature is just now having its annual spasm over the appointment of a "Grinding Committee." Toward the close of every Session the same debate is had on the subject -- the same struggle is renewed between apprehensive virtue and impatience to secure the passage of bills, and the same result is reached: -- the committee is appointed and the work goes on.

abstract: The Promptness of Different States
lead_paragraph: The tabular statement in our last issue, exhibiting the debts and credits of the different States on all the calls made upon them for soldiers, including the last, say what we may of it, is an invidious document. On some States it reflects honor, on others not. The real facts cannot be too plainly presented. The States which are delinquent may shut their eyes to them, if they please, but posterity will not The record made will stand as long as the Republic stands, and will ever be a traditional glory or reproach. It will be taken as a sure index of the different qualities of the patriotism of the different States, in the time that tried men's souls.

abstract: The condition of Mr. LOVEJOY was reported last evening to be such that his physicians gave no hope, whatever of his recovery. He is slowly sinking under an affection or the heart and kidneys. He retains possession of his faculties, and is perfectly aware of his condition. Mr. LOVEJOY is the representative in Congress from the Fifth District of Illinois, having been first elected in 1860, taking his seat in the Thirty-fifth Congress. He was born in Albion, Kennebec County, Me., Jan. 6, 1811, and is consequently fifty-three years of age.

abstract: A grand sacred concert, of which Mr. WILLIAM BERGE will be the organist and conductor, will be given at the Madison-avenue Baptist Church, corner of that avenue and Thirty-first-street, on Thursday evening. Besides Mr. BERGE, the services of Messrs. THOMAS and GEARY and Mrs. MOZART, Mrs. BARCLAY and Mrs. COLVER have been engaged, and ROSSINI'S "Stabat Mater" will be performed. The concert is for the benefit of a mission school, the object as well as the merits of the artists tending to attract a full audience.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Want of Judgment; Cruelty to Child; Its Fairs and Affairs
snippet: Want of Judgment; Cruelty to Child; Its Fairs and Affairs
lead_paragraph: People are now asking every day what the Sanitary Commission wants with the money it expects to get from the great Fairs, and what it does with the money it has already got; and, of course, the larger the funds that are raised for it, the more earnestly these questions are put; and many persons seem ready to draw the darkest conclusions, simply because they are themselves unable to answer them. It must be borne in mind, however, that the commission cannot publish the reports of its agents in the newspapers, because no newspaper could afford to print them except as advertisements, and the cost of publishing such masses of matter as advertisements would far outweigh the advantage to be derived from it.

abstract: Drs. Sayres' and Murphy's Report
lead_paragraph: Dr. SAYRE, the Resident Physician, and Dr. MURPHY, the Health Commissioner, who was requested by his Honor, the Mayor, to visit Long Branch and examine into the character of the disease there prevailing, made a report to him this morning, (24th inst.,) on the subject. These gentlemen state that they arrived at Long Branch on the afternoon of the 22d inst., and devoted two nights and a day to the examination of the disease. There have been 90 cases, and 37 deaths at Long Branch and its vicinity since the breaking out of the disease. The popular impression that recoveries have taken place after an attack, is thus seen to be erroneous.

abstract: Subsequent to the arrival of the steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool, on last Saturday, the 19th inst., JOHN HARVEY, a third-class passenger, who had been ill during the voyage, died just previous to the landing of the passengers at Castle Garden.
lead_paragraph: Subsequent to the arrival of the steamship City of Baltimore, from Liverpool, on last Saturday, the 19th inst., JOHN HARVEY, a third-class passenger, who had been ill during the voyage, died just previous to the landing of the passengers at Castle Garden. The Purser of the vessel, as is the practice on the line, on being notified of the death, took possession of the effects, amounting to a silver watch and gold chain, and a purse containing a half-crown. While the passengers were being transferred in a tug to the Emigrant Depot, the officer from Castle Garden was informed by two passengers, JOHN FORTMUN and WM. CARNE, that they had heard HARVEY say, a few days previous to arrival, that he had enough to support him for a year, in case he did not recover his health, and they believed he had money, although they never saw any, and that their suspicions were directedagainst four passengers, THOMAS TREZONA, GEORGE TERMUNE and EDWARD THOMAS and son, who berthed with deceased. The officer, in performance of his duty, brought all the parties before the General Agent, who in reply to inquiries as to the money, could learn nothing, the four stoutly denying any knowledge of it. On being requested to produce what money they had in their possession, TREZONA took out of his pocket 14 1/2 sovereigns, and TERMUNE 17 1/2 sovereigns, each claiming the money as his own, and denying having any more. By examining the parties separately, and finding the parties contradicting each other, it was brought out that TERMUNE and TREZONA had, previous to leaving Liverpool, borrowed from HARVEY 12s., and that they had also borrowed, while there, from THOMAS, a half sovereign, going to prove that these parties could not have had any money before sailing. The General Agent pushed the inquiries further, being satisfied there was more money, and finally induced TERMUNE to give up a bag containing 62 sovereigns, which he admitted belonged to HARVEY. The whole 92 sovereigns were retained and handed over to the Public Administrator, where TREZONA and TERMUNE were advised to go and prove the ownership of the respective amounts claimed by them. TERMUNE, however, did not deem it advisable to push any claim, but left the City early next morning, and TREZONA has since gone also.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the bill to increase the rank, pay and emoluments of the Provost-Marshal-General was favorably reported. The bill to prevent military interference in elections was taken up, and Mr. HOWARD, of Michigan, concluded his speech. Mr. SAULSBURY also spoke, but without concluding he gave way for the introduction of a joint resolution from the Wisconsin Legislature, asking aid for certain railroads in that State, after which the Senate adjourned.

abstract: For Spring
lead_paragraph: March played this year a scurvy trick on the milliners, coaxing them with false looks and deceitful smiles to the belief that Spring had really come, setting people wild after new Spring bonnets and plaid cloaks, and then turning literally a cold shoulder upon its friends, and pouring, literally also, cold water upon the hopes it had fostered into existence.

abstract: AN ENGINE COMPANY DISBANDED. -- The Board of Commissioners of the New-York Fire Department held a special meeting at Firemen's Hall on Tuesday evening last, for the purpose of investigating the charges made by Hose Company No. 19 against Engine Company No. 47. The complaint was that on several occasions Engine Company No. 47 ran Hose Company No. 19 into the sidewalk, thereby breaking up their rope and endangering the lives and limbs of those who were on it. The case was a very important one, and was very thoroughly investigated. Ex-Judge PHILLIPS appeared on behalf of Engine Company No. 47. The board examined over 60 witnesses, and did not adjourn until 2 o'clock in the morning. It is said that after the trial was over the members of Engine Company No. 47 attacked the members of Hose Company No. 19, and that some of them were beaten very badly. On Wednesday the board held a special meeting and announced their decision which is as follows: "Ordered, That Engine Company No. 47 be disbanded, and that MICHAEL DWYER, Assistant Foreman, be expelled from the Department." The Board of Commissioners have acted very promptly in this matter, and deserve the thanks of the public as well as of the department. The firemen, generally, will support them in their action, and uphold them for the fearless manner in which they administer justice. The firemen are a noble set of men who thoroughly dislike and discourage all such actions, and it would be a pity for the department to suffer from the actions of a few men.

abstract: Citizens' Association, The Formation of and City Reform
snippet: Citizens' Association, The Formation of and City Reform
lead_paragraph: The grand difficulty in any attempt to reform our City Government has always been that the "better classes" could not be induced to do anything persistently in them. They would turn out occasionally under some great excitement, and put in a "reform candidate;" but this spasmodic exertion has usually satisfied them, and they have fallen back into their old indifference, and let the knavish wire-pullers have everything their own way. It was too much trouble to attend primary meetings or to canvass a ward, or to follow up some great public "job" in all its intricacies. Most men in business supposed they had not the time for such matters. They would rather lose two per cent. of their incomes yb the peculations and follies of the City authorities than thus exhaust their energy and leisure. Besides, any attempt at reform always seemed Quixotic and useless. The persons who were thus plundering and trampling on the public, had been skilled for years in all the tricks of their trade; they had organization and a great constituency behind them. It was extremely difficult to convict them: still more to displace them. The Reformers never had a permanent organization, or means, or a well-established constituency. There was no regular party in each ward whose object it was truly to reform the City Government. There were no persons who could be constantly employed in tracing out and exposing public jobberies and abuses. Whenever an organization was formed it had not names of sufficient character, or means enough, to command the attention of the City for any length of time.
headline: {'main': 'A New Movement for City Reform.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A New Movement for City Reform.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Macarte vs. Platt; Discharge of Actress; Shipman vs. Ferris. Foreclosure
snippet: Macarte vs. Platt; Discharge of Actress; Shipman vs. Ferris. Foreclosure
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. John L.H. Cargill. -- The accused was put on trial, charged with secreting and embezzling a letter from the Post-office, in which he was employed. The evidence showed that a decoy letter, containing marked bills, was dropped into the Post-office at the station in which he was employed; that shortly afterward the accused went home to dinner, when a search was made for the letter, but it could not be found in the office. The officers then started to go to his house, but on the way met him coming back. They took him into an oyster saloon, and, telling him that there had been complaints of letters being missed from that office, they called upon him to produce his money, which he did, but none of the marked money was found. They asked him if he had any other articles upon his person, and he said he had not. They then asked if he had not an inside pocket in his vest. He at first said he had not, but on being pressed, admitted that he had; and on searching it, they found in it the missing letter and another letter addressed to a young woman. The missing letter was unopened, and Cargill, on being questioned about it, said he was taking it down town to have it registered.

abstract: Prospects of the Future
lead_paragraph: It is natural that even those who have no moral or patriotic interest in the war, should peer into the misty future with intense anxiety as to its duration and its probable ending. In a financial point of view alone, immense interests depend on the mode in which this struggle shall close; and every man who has property invested, or is engaged in business, is eager to catch some clear view, (if possible,) for an instant, of the tremendous events which this Summer is to witness. It is right and wise for us to put together all the known conditions of the case, and so frame the most satisfactory theory of the future which is possible under the circumstances. Such judgments, imperfect as they may be, must guide all men in the present management of their affairs.

abstract: The expedition which left Vicksburgh about two weeks since, composed of Admiral PORTER's iron-clad gunboats and a force of infantry, under Gen. A.J. SMITH, has been heard from, and the tidings are very good. The land forces debarked a few miles from Fort de Russey, on the Red River, and an effort was made by Gen. DICK TAYLOR's rebel army to attack the Union forces in the rear. Gen. SMITH paid no attention to this manoeuvre, but marched boldly forward and captured the fort, with its entire garrison of 300 men and armament of eleven guns, four of which are Parrotts. This bit of superior strategy gives our troops a strong foothold in that region, and enables Admiral PORTER to go on to Alexandria, Western Louisiana, without opposition. DICK TAYLOR must have been rather astonished at such a "Yankee trick."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, among other bills reported were the following: Against amending the act establishing the Board of Commissioners of Emigration. Agreed to. Relative to the Erie Railroad Steamboat Company. The adverse report on the Harlem-Broadway Railroad Bill was called from the table by Mr. FIELDS, but was again tabled on Mr. DUTCHER's motion, that he might offer some remarks, for which he would not be ready until to-day. A communication was received from the Clerk of the New-York Common Council, transmitting the tax law and directing attention to the discrepancies between the Common Council and Board of Aldermen. It was laid on the table. Among the bills introduced were the New-York Underground Railroad Bill, and a bill enlarging the powers of the Institute for the Orphans of Patriots. The bill incorporating the Union Trust Company was passed. The bills relative to State Prisons, and making appropriations for the payment of bounties to volunteers, were advanced to a third reading.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  Your recent article upon extravagance interested us in the country exceedingly, expressing our sentiments exactly. Now, we live in the land of steady habits, where, during this war, the price of cotton has so appalled us, that we actually mend up, and "top over" articles of wearing apparel in a way that I suppose would be perfectly shocking to the taste of your city ladies.

abstract: There is now, we suppose, not the shadow of a doubt that had the Army of the Potomac been simply allowed to walk on up the Peninsula, it would have been able to walk over all the force which Gen. MAGRUDER had to oppose it. We now know how contemptible that force was. Gen. MAGRUDER's official report of his operations on the Peninsula shows that his whole army consisted of eleven thousand men; of these, six thousand were useless to him, being placed in garrison at Gloucester Point, Mulberry Island, etc.: "So that it will be seen," adds he, "that the balance of the line, embracing a length of thirteen miles, was defended by about five thousand men."

lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the result of the official canvass of the election on the 8th inst., relative to soldiers voting, was announced, showing that of 305,435 ballots cast, 48,079 were against the amendment. A petition was presented for a railroad in Fifty-ninth-street, New-York, and also from the Staten Island Ferry Company for a new ferry slip. A number of reports of not very general interest were made, after which Mr. DUTCHER called from the table the adverse report on the Harlem-Broadway Railroad Bill, and moved a disagreement with it, and a reference of the subject to the Committee of the Whole. A vote was taken and the motion was lost, by 24 against 4. A bill was introduced to incorporate the Nyack and Piermont Railroad.

abstract: Private William Vongster, One Hundred and Seventy-eighth New-York Volunteers, sentenced to be shot for falling asleep on his post as a guard of the Forest Hall Prison, in Georgetown, has been pardoned by the President firstly, because the kindhearted President can't help pardoning soldiers, and secondly, because it was proved that Vongster was the best soldier in his company, and was tired when unexpectedly placed on duty.

abstract: -On Saturday last THOMAS CORCORAN, of this village, was arrested on a warrant issued by ROBERT MURRAY, Esq., United States District-Attorney,New-York City, on a charge of counselling and by force of arms resisting the execution of the act entitled "An act enrolling and calling out the national forces and for other purposes," or, in other words, resisting the draft. Our readers will remember that during the riots in New-York, in July last, a parcel of men and boys gathered together in this village, and after marching to the office of the Provost-Marshal and turning the furniture, etc., out of doors, and threatening the life of the Marshal and others who were in the employ of the Government, they turned toward the building where a large quantity of Government property was stored, consisting of soldiers' clothing and accoutrements, bursting in the door, and, after throwing in the street, burned and stole upward of $3,000 worth. The accused was the leader of this riot and was the man who forced open the door and in other ways assisted in destroying the property. CORCORAN, a few days after the riot, left the place, and, as it was said, went to Ireland. He returned a few days ago and was arrested as above stated. He was taken before the Marshal of New York and admitted to bail in the sum of $500 to appear for examination. -- Jamaica (L. I.) Farmer.

abstract: Report of Missippi Campaign of 1863; Speech to Paroled Rebel Soldiers at Richmond; speech to paroled rebel soldiers
snippet: Report of Missippi Campaign of 1863; Speech to Paroled Rebel Soldiers at Richmond; speech to paroled rebel soldiers
lead_paragraph: The paroled prisoners which Gen. BUTLER sent up from Fortress Monroe a few days ago, had a grand time upon their arrival. A procession conducted them to Capitol square, and JEFF. DAVIS was called on for a speech. Taking his stand on the platform of the Washington monument, he welcomed the soldiers to their native land. He had often heard of the severe trials to which they had been subjected in their captivity, and his heart had yearned for the brave "boys" who had proved true under every trial, and had resisted every offer made to them to desert the fortunes of their country. Though they had passed through so many bitter trials, there were, perhaps, many yet in store for them, but he knew that they would not shrink from them -- that they would all assist in achieving the independence of the country, and in driving away the hated foe now polluting our soil. [Cheers.] After a brief respite, said the President, you will be again called to the battlefield. "I know you will come." [Responsive shouts and cheers.] He hoped that they would all find their families better provided for than they might expect to do. The President closed by invoking the blessing of God upon those he addressed.

abstract: -An affair occurred behind the scenes of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, on Wednesday night, during the performance of the "Duke's Motto," which has since created no little stir in certain circles. Shortly after the rising of the curtain, a friend of one of the actors presented his card at the stage-door, and, with another gentleman in his company, was admitted to the stage. During the third act, while Mlle. VESTVALI was awaiting her call behind the scenes, one of these men, affecting to admire her appearance in men's clothes, is said to have laid his hand upon her person and called her a "bully boy," which indignity the lady promptly resented by administering to the offender a severe castigation, and driving him into the street. She also compelled the other man to vacate the premises by most convincing arguments, after, which she resumed her duties before the footlights and took her part until the end of the play -- no one in the audience suspecting that anything unusual had occurred. The excitement, however, had the effect of prostrating Miss VESTVALI with illness, and the play announced for the subsequent night was postponed in consequence.

abstract: Richmond files from March 15 to March 21, inclusive, were received yesterday. The papers discuss the prospects of the opening campaign with their usual bitterness, and draw highly rose-colored conclusions as to what the results will be. They affect to believe that the strength of the National Army is soon to be greatly reduced, and draw much consolation from this belief -- a thing which we can very safely encourage them in. GRANT is spoken of with contempt, though the undeniable fact of his enormous successes in the West is reluctantly confessed. In brief, the rebel papers are at their old work of bolstering up their sinking cause by holding out false hopes, and while so doing, comes an ominous movement from Georgia, hitherto one of the most radical of the seceded States, whose Governor, State Legislature and press propose to test the validity of the late sweeping acts of the rebel Congress by the action of Georgia's own courts, particularly the act suspending the habeas corpus. The war news is not important. The released rebel prisoners had been received with an ovation, including speeches by JEFF. DAVIS and Gov. SMITH. Gen. JOE JOHNSTON's report of the disastrous rebel operations in Mississippi last summer, is printed, in which he throws the whole blame upon Gen. PEMBERTON. The rebels profess to be rapidly reparing the damage done to Mississippi railroads by Gen. SHERMAN. Another raid by Gen. AVERILL was feared, and the rebel Gen. JONES had gone into Kentucky by way of an unfrequented gap to try another raid.

abstract: The Monitor Wolf-Krabe
lead_paragraph: Two of our "Yankee notions" have already been tried in the present war of Denmark with the allies. We allude to the monitor ship and the use of artificial light for siege operations by night. It was calcium light that was used by Gen. GILLMORE for illuminating the harbor of Charleston, so that he could carry on artillery operations and watch the enemy's movements at night; and the Danes, in their defence at Sonderborg, experimented with electric light to watch the enemy's night movements, and to enable the artillery of the forts to fire when it was dark. The low iron-clad used by the Danes had also points of variation from ours. The Rolfe Krake, which suffered considerable damage in an attack on the Prussian pontoon bridge, at their position at Egersund, is described as a powerful iron-clad, with two turrets or cupolas, armed each of them with two 64-pounders. She is 120 feet in length by 34 feet broad, is of 250 horse-power, and can run nine knots an hour in smooth water; but her officers think that the attempt to combine sailing power with the efficiency of a monitor, has been crowned with but indifferent success. While, on one hand, she would have a poor chance in heavy weather in the Baltic, on the other she is too deep in the water to be of great use in shallow inland seas.

abstract: The Constitutionnel of this morning, a paper which speaks more correctly for the Government than any of the semi-official papers, declares that the new Holy Alliance is a phantom, and the loud cries of the English journals so many false alarms. The conditions of such an alliance, according to this journal, no longer exist.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  Among the many towns doing nobly for our soldiers, Flushing, L.I., takes a high rank. Here is the record, so far, this year: When the Metropolitan Fair was proposed, Flushing immediately made up in cash $2,000. Next the ladies united with other Long Island towns, and sent $1,700, in salable articles, hospital stores and money, to the Brooklyn Fair.

abstract: The colored people of New-York are making active preparation to join in the parade of the Twenty-sixth United States Colored Regiment, which leaves for the seat of war to-day. They assemble in societies under their respective leaders, and with appropriate banners, &c., at 11 o'clock, in Lafayette-place, then march up Eighth-street and Fifth-avenue to Madison-square, where they will meet the regiment and escort it down Broadway at 3 1/2 o'clock P.M.

abstract: "JOE COBURN," of this City, who claims to be the champion of America, and "JIM MACE," who claims the championship of England, have agreed upon a match, which will come off in Ireland at a time to be agreed upon, $1,000 is to be paid COBURN for expenses, and the amount fought for, not yet fixed upon, will be from $1,500 to $2,500. Considerable excitement is existing in sporting circles in consequence, and COBURN will be freely backed.

abstract: The bill of which we spoke the other day, authorizing the construction of an Underground Railroad from Central Park to the Battery, has been introduced into the Legislature. In addition to the main line, it is proposed also to construct branches, connecting it with the Harlem, New-Haven and Hudson River Railroads.
lead_paragraph: The bill of which we spoke the other day, authorizing the construction of an Underground Railroad from Central Park to the Battery, has been introduced into the Legislature. In addition to the main line, it is proposed also to construct branches, connecting it with the Harlem, New-Haven and Hudson River Railroads. There are to be stations at convenient points, say at the City Hall, Canal-street, Astor-place, Union-square, Madison-square, etc., etc. The corporators, fifty in number, embrace some of our most substantial and respectable citizens, among whom we may name Jonathan Sturges, John J. Astor, Jr., Moses Taylor, Francis Skiddy, John J. Phelps, James B. Johnson, and J.F.D. Lanier.

abstract: Report of Last Winter's Operations
lead_paragraph: W.T. SHERMAN'S late report of his operations oflast Winter furnishes a satisfactory explanation of a portion of his conduct, that was at the time and has continued to be made the subject of considerable censure. We refer to his failure to pursue LONGSTREET, after that General had given up the siege of Knoxville in December last. The object of Gen. SHERMAN's march to Knoxville was to relieve Gen. BURNSIDE, whose position was invested by the rebels, and who, on account of the shortness of supplies, found himself in an extremely critical situation. The day before the arrival of Gen. SHERMAN's column, and doubtless in consequence of having received intelligence of its approach, LONGSTREET withdrew from BURNSIDE's front. In this state of facts Gen. BURNSIDE himself judged best that Gen. SHERMAN, instead of attempting to follow up LONGSTREET, should countermarch to Chattanooga, where, on account of the great diminution of force, Gen. THOMAS' position was not accounted entirely secure. Gen. BURNSIDE simply requested of Gen. SHERMAN that he would leave with him the two divisions under command of Gen. GORDON GRANGER, and this was freely done. Gen. BURNSIDE's opinion is expressed in the following terms:

abstract: -- The approaching Spring New-York Trade Sale of Books, Stereotype Plates, Stationery, &c. commences on March 29, and is an event of general interest to the book trade. Though some firms are, in principle, opposed to the system of these sales, on the ground that it destroys uniformity in prices, &c., the convenience of them is so great, both to buyers and sellers, that there is little doubt they are as firmly rooted as any other part of the trade machinery, whereby the circulation of books through this vast country is effected. Mr. COOLEY'S present catalogue indeed marks the adhesion to the plan of the eminent firm of Messrs. HARPERS. whose names, after five or six years absence, again figure in its pages. This catalogue forms a portly volume of nearly four hundred pages, and embraces probably two hundred thousand dollars' worth of books, all of which will be deposed of by the hammer of the presiding auctioneer. Some well-known and formerly constant buyers at these sales have disappeared since the commencement of the Southern troubles, but the loss has been more than made up by the growing demands of the great West, including California and Canada, which latter county is now generally represented by many considerable purchasers, and in a business point of view is fairly "annexed" and tributary to the Empire City of New-York. Some large lots of stereotype plates, including the stock of two Philadelphia houses (WILLIS P. HAZARD and LINDSAY & BLACKISTON,) who are making changes in their business, are in the present catalogue, and come more purely under the head of speculative property than books -- the current value of which is generally understood to within a small fraction by both buyer and seller. The sale continues for over a week, and the steady attendance it commands, though a tedious and even exhaustive process to an outsider, shows how important it is considered by those for whose benefit it is specially appointed.

abstract: -- PARSON BROWNLOW, in his Knoxville Whig and Rebel Ventilator, says of the Tennessee aristocracy: "Through the mercy of God, the firmness of Mr. LINCOLN and the madness of the Southern Confederacy, we are all about to find a common level, where we can at least boast that the Lord is the maker of us all. He has not heretofore been the maker of us all, but the times are changing! It will require lamps and gaslights in the daytime to find the aristocracy of this town."

abstract: -In many parts of the State we hear that the wheat crop has been seriously damaged by the severe weather of the past Winter. It is said, too, that this is the case in some of the great wheat growing regions of the Wes. We would urge upon all our farmers, in view of the probability of at least a partial failure of the next wheat crop, to plant as great a breadth of corn as they possibly can. It will all be needed before another year. -- Wheeling Intelligencer, May 19.

abstract: Isaac W. Edsall vs. James Brooks and Erastus Brooks. -- This was an action for libel against defendants, proprietors of the New-York Express. The case was tried yesterday for the second time, and has already been reported in the TIMES. The evidence taken on the former trial was read to the jury, and Mr. James Brooks, defendant, in person, summed up for the defence. The evidence vindicated the character of the plaintiff completely, and the jury rendered a verdict in his favor for $300 and costs.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Vice-President submitted a communication from the President, inclosing a report from the Secretary of State, in relation to the establishment of a monarchical Government in Central and South America. Referred, and ordered to be printed. Mr. TRUMBULL introduced a bill to construct a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the Vice-President submitted a communication from the President, inclosing a report from the Secretary of State, in relation to the establishment of a monarchical Government in Central and South America. Referred, and ordered to be printed. Mr. TRUMBULL introduced a bill to construct a ship canal from Lake Michigan to the Mississippi River. Mr. COLLAMER introduced a bill to authorize the Postmaster-General to contract for carrying the overland mails from Atchison, Kansas, to Folsom's, California. The bill to prevent military interference in elections was taken up, and Mr. SAULSBURY addressed the Senate at great length in its favor. The Senate then agreed to the report of the Conference Committee on the West Point Military Academy Bill, and then adjourned until Monday.

abstract: Magazines for March
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine, among its noticeable features, presents us with the first portion of Mr. THACKERAY's unfinished story, "Denis Duval," the occupation of his latest hours, that, in the opinion of DICKENS, is "in respect of earnestness of feeling, far-seeing purpose, character, incident and a certain living picturesqueness, blending the whole, much the best of his works." An interesting analysis of Capt. SPEKK's discovery of the Nile source, with some of the original illustrations, prepares readers for the entire work about to be published by Messrs. HARPERS.

abstract: Soon after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out on the second floor of the extensive wooden and willow warehouse of Messrs. EARLY & LANE, situated at No. 189 Washington-street, near Fulton. The flames were first seen issuing from the packing-room, on the second floor. On account of the highly combustible nature of the goods, the fire spread with rapidity, and in a short time the entire building was enveloped. The building, which was a four-story brick one, was entirely destroyed, together with a large portion of the contents.

abstract: Miscegenation, What the Dems. Say
lead_paragraph: The pressure on our space of other matter has prevented us from recurring to the serious and important topic of "Miscegenation." We regret very much, however, having allowed our attention to be even temporarily diverted from it, as we find from the earnest discussion which it is receiving at the hands of our cotemporaries, that it has lost none of its importance. In fact, if we are to believe what we hear, especially from the recognized and authoritative organs of the Democratic party, the rage for marrying black people, which has taken possession of the Republican party, is rather on the increase. It is said, we know not with what truth, that the Union League Club has fitted up a night-bell at its door in Union-square, and keeps a black minister on the premises, who marries all couples of different colors at any hour of the day or night. An effort is said to have been made by the leaders of the party to stave off these alliances until after the meeting of the Convention next July, when the campaign would have fairly commenced; but it was all in vain. The radicals have carried everything before them, and, if things go on at their present rate, it is feared that in three months every white man who is not connected by marriage with a colored family, will be "read out" of the party. The gusto with which the young people go into this insane movement is something at once disgusting and alarming. Two duels are said to have been already fought about one middle-aged black washerwomen, the rivals being young men of the best society; and those families whose colored servants have remained with them up to the present, have been compelled to give them notice, owing to the crowds of wealthy but degraded white men who throng the basement for the purpose of soliciting the honor (!) of their hands. We shrink from putting on paper the stories which reach us as to the prevalence amongst young white ladies of a preference for colored men -- pure blacks having the precedence in all cases where there is room for choice. We will only say that there will very soon be hardly a family in the City belonging to the Republican persuasion, which will not be glorying in the possession of a negro son-in-law; and what is most horrible about the matter is, that a fund has been raised by members of the Loyal League for the transportation from the South, of colored beaux and belles, with the truly fiendish design of guarding against the possibility of an exhaustion of the supply in this quarter.

abstract: FIRE AND EXPLOSION ONE MAN KILLED  Loss $15,000. An explosion in the Kerosene Oil Re  finery of the New-York Coal Oil Company, whose office is at No. 104 Maiden-lane, occurred about halfpast 8 o'clock on Thursday evening, at Hunter's Point, L.I. One of the night watchmen named JAMES NOONEN entered the room where the oil is refined, with a lighted lamp, when instantly an explosion occurred, and the building was set on fire.
lead_paragraph: FIRE AND EXPLOSION -- ONE MAN KILLED -- Loss $15,000. -- An explosion in the Kerosene Oil Re finery of the New-York Coal Oil Company, whose office is at No. 104 Maiden-lane, occurred about halfpast 8 o'clock on Thursday evening, at Hunter's Point, L.I. One of the night watchmen named JAMES NOONEN entered the room where the oil is refined, with a lighted lamp, when instantly an explosion occurred, and the building was set on fire. NOONEN was so covered with a falling wall that he could not extricate himself, and standing nearly upright, he burned to death before those who, from the fierceness of the flames, were powerless to aid or remove him. His age was 37 years, and he leaves a wife and four children. The damage to the establishment, including the loss of refined oil, machinery, buildings, etc., will reach fully $11,000. The Chemical Works adjoining, of Messrs. LANGMAN & Co., were set on fire and consumed. Their loss will reach $4,000, mostly prepared chemicals.

abstract: Potomac Army and its Reorganization
lead_paragraph: It is hardly possible, without some acquaintance with the interior constitution of an army, as modern armies are organized, to appreciate how profoundly the entire structure of the Army of the Potomac will be affected by the brief order of the War Department yesterday made public. The official document simply announces a consolidation of the First and Third Corps with the three remaining corps of that army, which will henceforth be composed of the Second, Fifth and Sixth Corps.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner NAUMANN, at the Second Precinct Station-house, on the body of GEORGE W. ALBRO, late Captain and owner of the canal-boat Pride of the West. On Thursday afternoon deceased was engaged in loading his boat with coal, from the ship John H. Ryerson, lying at Pier No. 20, East River. While the Captain was in the hold of his boat, engaged in shoveling away coal, he was struck on the head with a large piece of coal, injuring him so badly that he died soon after.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner NAUMANN, at the Second Precinct Station-house, on the body of GEORGE W. ALBRO, late Captain and owner of the canal-boat Pride of the West. abstract: THE FATAL AFFRAY IN THE SIXTH WARD. -Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest yesterday, at the Sixth Precinct Station House, on the body of THOMAS MCGOWAN, who died on Wednesday morning, from the effects of injuries inflicted by his partner PATRICK BRENNAN. The testimony given went to show that while the two were engaged in a quarrel, BRENNAN seized a pane of common window glass, twelve by fourteen inches in size, and struck his partner on the left side of the head. A small piece of the glass went entirely through the skull, ruptured a blood-vessel and penetrated the brain. The jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that THOMAS MCGOWAN came to his death by compression of the brain, from a blow with a pane of glass in the hands of PATRICK BRENNAN." The latter yesterday gave himself up to the authorities of the Sixth Precinct. When asked the usual questions, he said that he was 28 years of age, native of Ireland, lived at No. 155 Second-street, Williamsburgh, and a peddler by occupation. He further said that MCGOWAN abused him and called him names, and struck him some blows. He said, "I am not guilty." The Coroner committed him to the Tombs to await an indictment by the Grand Jury.

abstract: By way of Havana and New-Orleans, we have interesting news from Mexico. Gen. SANTA ANA, who only last month returned to Mexico and gave in his adhesion to the French invervention, has been already expelled by Gen. BAZAINE and is now at Havana.
lead_paragraph: By way of Havana and New-Orleans, we have interesting news from Mexico. Gen. SANTA ANA, who only last month returned to Mexico and gave in his adhesion to the French invervention, has been already expelled by Gen. BAZAINE and is now at Havana. The cause of this action on the part of the French authorities was a manifesto which Gen. SANTA ANA had issued to his countrymen explaining why he had accepted without restrictions the new order of affairs. The correspondence between SANTA ANA and BAZAINE shows that the order of exile was entirely unlooked for by the Mexican General. A report from New-Orleans says that the French are on the eve of attacking Matamoras and have nine vessels of war at the mouth of the Rio Grande. A letter was published in the New-Orleans Era from a Mexican source, which puts a brighter aspect on the Liberal cause than we have been able to look upon from the French standpoint. It says that Guadalajara has been captured by the Mexicans, under URAGA, with 24 cannon and 700 prisoners. The traitor MEJIA was at San Luis de Potosi with 3,000 troops, expecting to be attacked. It is also said that Puebla is besieged by the Mexicans and must fall, as the invaders have no reinforcements that can reach there in time to aid the garrison. VIDAURRI is positively said to have declared for the French, and CORTINAS and DOBLABO, with strong forces, are marching to attack him, the former from Matamoras and the latter from Saltillo. CORTINAS is very popular in Tamaulipas. Before leaving he consecrated his battle-flag. Music, cannons and fandangoes prevailed quite extensively in Matamoras during the operation.

abstract: GENERAL: His Excellency, Gen. ALMONTE, has just sent me a supplement to No. 68 of the newspaper, Indicador, published in Orizaba, and in which there appears in full the proclamation that you have sent to Mexico, signed by you.

abstract: Brief Sketch of
lead_paragraph: commanding the Department of the Tennessee, was, at the breaking out of the rebellion, a Lieutenant of Engineers, and was employed in the survey of the bay and harbor of San Francisco. He is a very young man, being only thirty-one. The present Congress has confirmed him as a Brigadier-General in the United States Army, the youngest who ever hold that position. Maj.-Gen. JOHN A. LOGAN, was formerly Colonel of the 31st Illinois infantry, which position he obtained on the breaking out of the rebellion. He is a native of Illinois, and thirty-five years of age. Maj.-Gen. STEPHEN A. HURLBUT, formerly a lawyer, is a South Carolinian by birth. He was one of the first Brigadier-Generals made by the President when this war broke out, was assigned to duty in Missouri, and was relieved by Gen. FREMONT and ordered home. He afterwards was appointed to the command of the old 4th division, and distinguished himself at Shiloh and the Hatchie. He is the older Major-General in the Department of the Tennessee, and, should any accident befall Gen. SHERMAN, would, by virtue of his commission, command the Department.

abstract: FOR SOLDIERS WIVES AND CHILDREN.--While the comfort of the soldiers is being so well and liberally cared for, their wives and children are not forgotten.
lead_paragraph: FOR SOLDIERS WIVES AND CHILDREN. -- While the comfort of the soldiers is being so well and liberally cared for, their wives and children are not forgotten. A very large amount has been raised for them, and great good been accomplished. The Musaeola Association of Brooklyn gave a grand entertainment at the Academy of Music on Friday evening, in aid of the disabled veterans, their families, and those of deceased members of the Fourteenth, Forty-eighth and Sixty-seventh Regiments of Brooklyn, now in the service of the United States. The house was handsomely filled, and many tickets were disposed of which were not used. The Chair was occupied by G.L. SANDERSON, Esq., who, in a brief address, explained the object of the entertainment. The programme consisted of music by Helmsmuller's Band, singing by Mr. S.C. Campbell, Mrs. Maria Abbott, Mrs. Mozart, Master Emil Mollenhauer, Mr. Wm. Castle and Mr. Frederick Mollenhauer. Addresses were made by Rev. F.W. HATFIELD and Rev. A.A. WILLETTS. Gen. BURNSIDE was expected, but being called elsewhere by order of the Government, was unable to be present. The amount realized above expenses will be upward of one thousand dollars.

abstract: Dispatches from  Gen. SIBLEY'S scouts at the head of the Coteau de Prairie, northwest from Lake Traverse, indicate that buffaloes are coming down the valleys of the James and Cheyenne Rivers, and that the half-starved Indians are following them.
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Gen. SIBLEY'S scouts at the head of the Coteau de Prairie, northwest from Lake Traverse, indicate that buffaloes are coming down the valleys of the James and Cheyenne Rivers, and that the half-starved Indians are following them. There are different reports as to the views and intentions of the great prairie bands, but there is no doubt that while some of them are disposed to make peace, there is a large portion who are in favor of the continuance of the war.

abstract: The rebel Gen. FORREST, with 2,000 men, whose advance upon Union City, Tenn., was reported a few days since, attacked that outpost on the 24th inst., and captured the small force of Union troops garrisoning the town.
lead_paragraph: The rebel Gen. FORREST, with 2,000 men, whose advance upon Union City, Tenn., was reported a few days since, attacked that outpost on the 24th inst., and captured the small force of Union troops garrisoning the town. This force consisted of 400 of the Seventh Tennessee Cavalry, and they made a vigorous defence, repulsing their assailants three times before they surrendered to superior numbers. The enemy destroyed the defences and hurried southward with their prisoners. Gen. BRAYMAN, commanding the Union forces in this district, says that he shall recommend an abandonment of the outposts of Union City and Hickman, as being useless for military purposes.

abstract: "A short time since, several ladies connected with the New-York Sanitary Fair called upon Mrs. AUGUSTUS BELMONT, and requested her to hold a concert for the benefit of the Fair, among her friends. She took it under advisement and consented to do so, and made arrangements accordingly. She found her house would accommodate about three hundred guests. She issued her tickets for that number, at $5 a ticket. She was shortly visited by the same committee, who informed her that the price of tickets must not exceed $2 each. They were informed that Mrs. BELMONT's friends would as soon give five or ten dollars as two -- that the house was small, the expenses would be the same, and the receipts to the Fair very much diminished. But the lady managers were persistent -- two dollars and no more must be the extent, or they would have nothing to do with the concert. Mrs. BELMONT, who has much of the spirit of her heroic father, informed the ladies that she was quite competent to manage her own affairs, in her own house, and that they might consider themselves as discharged from all further duty in regard to her concert. Her husband, on learning this state of things, handed his wife $1,500 in greenbacks, took all her tickets and carried them down town, sold some and gave the rest away to his friends, and made [???] a provision to have the concert a success. It [???] off -- the rooms were brilliant and crowded -- [???] [???]e[???]ty and fashion and wealth of New-York were [???] in a [???] l their glory -- GOTTSCHALK and kind[???]ed per[???] [???] the [???] audience, and Mrs. [???] [???]500 in her bands to contribute to the [???] [???]sion."

abstract: For several weeks past it has been the habit of twenty or thirty young men and half grown boys to congregate every night on the corner of Seventhavenue and Nineteenth-street, and there talk, ...
lead_paragraph: For several weeks past it has been the habit of twenty or thirty young men and half grown boys to congregate every night on the corner of Seventhavenue and Nineteenth-street, and there talk, caronse and quarrel among themselves after having imbibed large quantities of bad liquor obtained from the rum-shops in the neighborhood. If the fighting among themselves had been the only thing annoying to the public, the police might have had less cause to interfere. It appears, however, that this gang of ruffians have been in the uniform practice of interfering with passers-by, and often using profane and obscene language when respectable females were walking along the avenue. Several cases have also occurred wherein working girls have been grossly insulted and abused by this same gang of outlaws.

abstract: Denmark and England. Crown Prerogatives
lead_paragraph: It is more than probable that undue importance is attached to the reports which come in different shapes, and from various sources, representing Her Majesty the British Queen as actively employed in thwarting the policy of her ministers on the question of the Danish war. Those who are most eager and laborious in presenting this view of the case evidently do not trouble themselves to inquire into British constitutional history. The Queen's prerogative is possibly not so absolutely defined as some other principles of the Constitution, because in the case of each successive sovereign since the Revolution it has been modified -- sometimes by undue straining, sometimes by singular relaxation -- according to the personal temperament and habits of those who exercised it.
headline: {'main': 'England and Denmark--The Crown Prerogatives.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England and Denmark--The Crown Prerogatives.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Senator CHRISTIE introduced a bill amending section 282 of the Code as follows: On filing judgment-roll upon a judgment directing the payment of money, it may be docketed with the clerk of the county where it was rendered, and in any other county upon the filing with the clerk thereof a transcript of the original "docket," and shall be a lien on the real property in the county where the same is docketed, of every person against whom such judgment shall be rendered, and which he may have at the time of the docketing thereof in the county in which such real estate is situated, or which he may acquire ten years thereafter, &c. &c.

abstract: Early yesterday morning a large number of colored men, belonging to the various societies which proposed to take part in the reception of the Twentysixth Colored Regiment, met at the headquarters in ...
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning a large number of colored men, belonging to the various societies which proposed to take part in the reception of the Twentysixth Colored Regiment, met at the headquarters in Broome-street; but, after consulting with Col. SILLIMAN, the officers of the Union League Club concluded to postpone the presentation, and the assembly dispersed. Should the weather prove favorable, the Committee of the Union League will proceed to Riker's Island to-day, and present the colors. A copy of Mr. JAY's address and Col. SILLIVAN's reply will be given to each man; also copies of the ladies' address, and the Anglo-African, containing the names of each member of the regiment. The regiment will be conveyed from the island to the steamer at the foot of Canal-street on barges, and [???] departure for Annapolis.

abstract: CHILDREN'S DEPARTMENT OF THE METROPOLITAN FAIR.--The children's department will occupy the easterly wing of the buildings on Union-square, and will be contained in a hall ninety feet square, arranged with booths on the sides and a stage for performances.
lead_paragraph: CHILDREN'S DEPARTMENT OF THE METROPOLITAN FAIR. -- The children's department will occupy the easterly wing of the buildings on Union-square, and will be contained in a hall ninety feet square, arranged with booths on the sides and a stage for performances. The object of this department is to afford daily entertainments for children, consisting of concerts, tableaux, and exhibitions of various kinds, as well as to offer for sale articles particularly adapted to the wants of children. There will be ten booths, as follows: No. 1. Will contain a Miniature Skating Pond. No. 2. Will embrace contributions from charitable institutions. No. 3. Will be for the sale of fancy articles. No. 4. Will be furnished by the Madison-av, Baptist Church. No. 5. Will be provided with articles contributed by the Public Schools. No. 6. Will be for the sale of children's toys. No. 7. Will be for refreshments and confectionery. No. 8. Will be furnished by the ladies of Staten Island. No. 9. Will be for the sale of books. No. 10. Will be provided with articles contributed by the private schools. It is hoped that every individual and institution, irrespective of locality, will manifest an especial interest in this department, by forwarding without delay contributions of all articles suitable for and calculated to interest children. The Executive Committee will be happy to acknowledge the receipt of all donations sent to their rooms, No. 32 East 17th-st., Union-square.

abstract: Nomination, and Cheers for Jeff. Davis
snippet: Nomination, and Cheers for Jeff. Davis
lead_paragraph: The Commercial Advertiser has been commenting severely on the fact, as reported both by the World and Herald, that at the late McClellan meeting at the Cooper Institute, when Mr: LINCOLN's name was mentioned in the same sentence with JEFFERSON DAVIS, the former was hissed and the latter received a respectful silence. We do not, however, consider the circumstance of any great importance. The World explained it with great justice and accuracy, when it said that "the meeting was not called to discuss the conduct of JEFF. DAVIS, and any special mark of disapprobation toward him would have been as out of place as it would toward the King of Timbuctoo, or the Man of the Moon."

abstract: The Metropolitan Police authorities have been very busy, within the last few days, in perfecting their arrangements relative to the approaching fair, A new line of police telegraph has been strung from Headquarters, at No. 300 Mulberry-street, to Palace Garden, in Fourteenth-street, at which latter point are to be established the headquarters of the policemen who are detailed to keep order during the continuance of the fair. Inspector LEONARD is commissioned to take the sole charge of all the force, and Sergt. M.B. WILSON, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, is appointed to act as his assistant. The Detective force will be on hand, and if they exercise their usual vigilance and industry, there will be very little opportunity for thieves, shoplifters and pickpockets to successfully practice their nefarious business.

abstract: European Mutterings of War
lead_paragraph: The murmurings that come over the water from England, have an ominous and threatening sound, not certainly foretelling the shock of arms, but, as before the Crimean "drifting" into war, they betoken the uneasiness and the slow up-working of the popular feeling on a question which may at any moment plunge the nation into a tremendous struggle. Mr. KINGLAKE, in his singular chronicle of England's last great war, has shown conclusively how much her slow and conservative population are moved to important measures by mere feeling and passion. It is commonly supposed that Democracies alone are plunged into dangerous wars through sympathy and martial instinct. But the impartial and careful records of the Crimean struggle, show that no riotous and impulsive mob ever were urged on to a dangerous crisis more by mere feeling, without regard to interests or wisdom, than were the English nation at that momentous emergency. England, it is true, can sift down her popular passions through the medium of a governing aristocracy; but even they are deeply affected by a prejudice extending through the middle classes.
headline: {'main': 'Mutterings of War in Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mutterings of War in Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Roebuck, J. A., M. P.; Abuse of U. S.
snippet: Roebuck, J. A., M. P.; Abuse of U. S.
lead_paragraph: The discussions on American affairs in the British Parliament, during its present sitting, have been mostly dull and stupid; but we have by yesterday's steamer the report of a debate that took place in the House of Commons a fortnight ago to-day, which must have been as entertaining there as it will be here. Mr. ROEBUCK assailed the Ministry, or at least one member of it, and this country, or at least the Union part of it, with a ferocity worthy of his reputation. It was Earl RUSSELL and his foreign policy that he attacked declaring that the tone used at first by the Foreign Secretary was like the "scream of a cockatoo," but that subsequently he "crouched before the menace" of the American Minister. He turned in absolute disgust from the "hypocrisy of the Northern States of America," finding them "corrupt, base, cowardly and cruel," and so forth -- some of which epithets the Southern rebels have now learned too much to be so foolish as to employ. Lord PALMERSTON replied to the assault on his colleague, and defended the foreign policy of the Government. He would not accept of a compliment to himself at the expense of Earl RUSSELL, and declared that he was equally responsible with his colleague for every step taken in the conduct of every diplomatic negotiation. He declared that Her Majesty's Ministers had proclaimed the neutrality of Great Britain, and that they had kept their word and acted on their declaration; and gave his opinion that this neutrality had been of far greater advantage to the North than to the South. Mr. KINGLAKE then arose, and, in referring to the language applied to the United States by the "honorable and learned gentleman," (Mr. ROEBUCK,) "wished to state that, in his opinion, the charges of the honorable and learned gentleman did not represent the opinion of this House, or of any party or fraction of a party in this House, but simply represented that for which the honorable and learned gentleman had, no doubt, a great respect -- namely, the opinion of the honorable and learned gentleman. If the people of America were rendered indignant by language like this, it would be easy to explain to them by what manner of man it had been used. The honorable and learned gentleman was not consulted, so far as he knew, by any party, any fraction of a party, or any group of men. The American people," continued Mr. KINGLAKE, "should also be reminded that the same speaker who used this language of them applied the language which the House had just heard to Lord RUSSELL, declaring that his utterances were like the screamings of a cockatoo and the anger of a scolding woman. It was to be hoped," repeated Mr. KINGLAKE, "that the Americans would be as indifferent to the language used by the honorable gentleman as he was sure Lord RUSSELL would be when he heard that be had been vilipended by the honorable and learned gentleman." We can assure the cool-headed Crimean historian that the people of the United States will not get at all excited nor enraged at the language of the "honorable and learned" ROEBUCK, but will remain even more indifferent than Lord RUSSELL to such assaults. And much as the character of the American Congress is abused abroad, we do not think there is a member of it who would apply to Mr. ROEBUCK or his country such language in such a spirit as he uses in Parliament upon us.

abstract: Ministerial Crisis in
lead_paragraph: The politicians of the adjacent British Provinces are enjoying the periodical relaxation of a crisis in their party arrangements. Two years ago the Parliament of the Colony outvoted the Conservative or Tory party, and there was formed in place of the outgoing Ministry, a Government supposed first of all to represent a liberal policy, and next, to put down its foot upon further advances to the Grand Trunk Railway. The incomers had an easy time of it, during a lengthened parliamentary recess. But they exhibited feebleness of purpose, and incapacity for work when the local Legislature reassembled. The consequence was a premature break-down. To mend matters temporarily, the party leader, Mr. SANDFIELD MACDONALD, retained his own portfolio by consent of the Governor-General, after discarding the unpopular element (so-called) from the Cabinet, and a repaltrage was made up by the introduction of new members of more extreme opinions. The Premier hereupon appealed to the constituencies for their indorsation of his arrangements. A general election resulted in the return of an almost equal number of Ministerialists and Opposition members, and the present parliamentary session, now some six weeks gone, has developed from the opening day, the ministerial disorder which reached a crisis a week ago, when the Premier succumbed to the adverse opinion of the Legislature, threw up his seat, and by constitutional rule, involved his colleagues in the general collapse.

abstract: and Railroad Monopoly
lead_paragraph: Congress is trying very hard to secure for the people and Government of the United States the right of traversing the soil of NewJersey on the same terms as they have always been allowed to traverse every other State. A proposition is pending to declare the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad a postal route -- so that mails, troops and munitions of war can be carried over it. The Legislature of New-Jersey objects, and insists that whatever, in the shape of freight or mails, crosses that State, shall go over the Camden and Amboy route, because she has given that road a monopoly of transportation, and tribute must be paid accordingly.

abstract: An express wagon belonging to BLUNDELL's New-York and Patterson Express, was taken about 3 o'clock on Saturday afternoon from the front of the Express office, No. 271 Washington-street, by some unknown party, and driven away. The man must have become suddenly frightened, as the wagon was found broke-down at the corner of Franklin and Centre streets shortly afterward. It contained about $4,000 worth of silks and other goods, Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, took possession of the property and delivered it to the owners.

lead_paragraph: The announcements for to-night, Easter Monday, are full of interest. The Academy reopens under the approved direction of Mr. MAX MARETZEK. "Faust" is the work selected for the occasion, cast the same as heretofore. This popular opera -- for such it may be called -- will be played three times during the week, the remaining evenings being devoted to "Robert le Diable," in which Signor BRIGNOLI will, we suppose, appear.
