abstract: A telegram from Copenhagen of March 11, says: "The Prussians have arrested HERR STOCKFLETH, the Aintmann of Hadersteben. The use of the Danish stamped paper with the King's initials has been prohibited in Schleswig, as has also the use of the prayers for the King of Denmark in the churches. Danish coinage has been abolished in Schleswig, and German introduced instead.
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Copenhagen of March 11, says: "The Prussians have arrested HERR STOCKFLETH, the Aintmann of Hadersteben. The use of the Danish stamped paper with the King's initials has been prohibited in Schleswig, as has also the use of the prayers for the King of Denmark in the churches. Danish coinage has been abolished in Schleswig, and German introduced instead. A German office for the supervision of the Schleswig postal arrangements has been established in Flensburg, at the head of which is an official from the Prussian post-office." A telegram of March 12 says: "The enemy, whose vanguard was yesterday at Horsens, pursued Gen. HEGERMANN's army corps, with twenty-one battalions of infantry, cavalry and artillery, as far as Fredericia. The enemy is in force."

abstract: Lovejoy, Hon. Owen, of Illinois; Gooderson, Mathias N.
snippet: Lovejoy, Hon. Owen, of Illinois; Gooderson, Mathias N.
lead_paragraph: OWEN LOVEJOY, the Member of Congress from the Fifth Illinois District, died in Brooklyn at half-past 11 o'clock Saturday night. He had been complaining since last January, but came to this City from Washington on the 15th, and the following day was out of doors; since then he has been confined to his bed with an affection of the liver and kidneys. He was attended in his last illness by his wife and daughter, and by many sympathizing friends.

abstract: Paducah was captured by the rebels under Gen. FORREST, on Friday morning, at an early hour. They sacked the city and then burned it, destroying it almost entirely. They also attacked the fort held by our forces, but were repulsed with heavy loss, 1,300 killed and wounded, including a Brigadier-General. Subsequently the rebels retreated ...
lead_paragraph: Paducah was captured by the rebels under Gen. FORREST, on Friday morning, at an early hour. They sacked the city and then burned it, destroying it almost entirely. They also attacked the fort held by our forces, but were repulsed with heavy loss, 1,300 killed and wounded, including a Brigadier-General. Subsequently the rebels retreated southward, apparently much crippled by their severe repulse.

abstract: After the mate left the vessel, the Captain, finding that she was likely to become a total wreck, got out a boat, and, together with the remainder of the crew, (excepting one man who could not swim and refused to leave the vessel,) got into her; they had no sails, oars, &c., and were drifting about the bay, and all would have no doubt been drowned, as there was a very heavy sea on at the time, had not the steamtug Odd-Fellow, Capt. TOM HILL, who saw them and immediately put after them, and succeeded in rescuing them from their perilous position, at the risk of his own life and those of his crew. Capt. HILL deserves great credit, as but few men would run the risk that he did in rescuing the above men. They were brought to the City last evening. A steamboat was sent to the relief of the man left on board; but he had been taken off by a surf-boat from the shore. The Scandinavian has since sunk, her lower masts just appearing above water.

abstract: Detectives SLOWEY and VAUGHN, of the Central Office, made the arrest on Saturday of a man named LOUIS KRAUSSNER, employed as a valet in the family of Mr. HENRY A. ROBERTS. Valuables to the amount of $1,500 were missed from the house, comprising diamonds and jewelry, and the detectives were called in to aid in ferreting out the guilty party. Suspicion fell upon the accused, and upon being taken to Police headquarters, pawn-tickets, for the stolen property were found on his person. He was locked up for examination.

abstract: -Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday upon the body of Mr. ALEXANDER FRASER, a wealthy gentleman of this City. Deceased was riding in a Sixth-avenue car on Saturday afternoon, and was taken suddenly ill. He was at once removed to a drug-store, but died on the way. Dr. BOUTON made a post-mortem examination of the body and discovered that apoplexy was the cause of death. A verdict was rendered in accordance with the fact. Deceased was 55 years of age, and a native of Connecticut.

abstract: The Memorial Diplomatique says: The draft of a treaty was agreed upon at the Tuileries, to be ratified as soon as the Emperor MAXIMILIAN I. shall have ascended the Mexican throne and announced his accession to the Court of the Tuileries.
lead_paragraph: The Memorial Diplomatique says: The draft of a treaty was agreed upon at the Tuileries, to be ratified as soon as the Emperor MAXIMILIAN I. shall have ascended the Mexican throne and announced his accession to the Court of the Tuileries. If we are rightly informed, the treaty definitively settles two important questions. First, the French occupation; and secondly, the claims of the French Treasury on the Mexican Government. It is already known that the pay and maintenance of the troops engaged in the expedition have, since Jan. 1, 1864, been borne by Mexico. This will continue until their recall, which will gradually be effected as the regimental lists of the Mexican army are completed.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship America at this port yesterday, we have three days' later advices from Europe. An important debate took place in the House of Commons on the 14th inst., in which Mr. ROEBUCK took the British Government severely to task for what he called one-sided neutrality -- for giving certain privileges to the Federal Government which he claimed were denied to the Confederates. He denounced the American war, the Government and the people, and expressed his joy that American commerce was being swept from the ocean. Lord PALMERSTON replied, ably defending the British Government, and explaining its position relative to the treatment extended to belligerents. Messrs. BRIGHT and KINGLAKE both denounced Mr. ROEBUCK. A terrible calamity had occurred at Sheffield, in the North of England, by the bursting of an immense reservoir of over one hundred acres, which inundated the country for many miles, and drowned nearly three hundred people. MAXIMILIAN reached London on the 13th, and held an audience with the King of the Belgians, and afterward the Duke and Duchess rode and dined with the Prince and Princess of Wales. The draft of a treaty for Mexico, upon the accession of MAXIMILIAN, has been agreed upon by Mexico. The Danish war presented no new features. Military preparations and some slight movements were still going on. The London Times affects to believe that there is still a good prospect that England's proposal for a conference will be accepted.

abstract: Godey's Lady's Book, just out for April, thus speaks of the new novel, Cudjo's Cave: "Mr. TROWBRIDGE has already gained celebrity by his writings. This last work will give him a wider reputation. The scene is laid in Tennessee in the beginning of the war excitement, and gives terrible pictures of the stormy passions of men and the sad scenes enacted. * * * The descriptions of natural scenery are vivid, and often beautiful and noble characters, and lovely works of mercy are brought out on the dark canvas of civil war.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, complied from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The Common Council, yesterday, passed over the Mayor's veto, the resolution granting to the Third-avenue Railroad Company permission to extend their tracks through certain streets. It is now a law. Resolutions were adopted relative to the death of MATTHIAS GOODERSON, Superintendent of Markets. It was resolved to close all the public offices, and to attend the funeral in a body, to-day.

abstract: - We have learned by telegraph from Washington that a "highly distinguished Senator," being unable to get the ear of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, addressed himself the other day to the wife of that officer, and through her volunteered a bit of advice concerning military matters. "When you see your husband again," remarked the Senator, "present my regards to him and tell him that he ought to" -- and the Senator gave his opinion as to what Gen. GRANT ought to do to insure success in future military operations. We believe that Gen. GRANT has heretofore got along without Senatorial advice, and evidently he is not anxious for it now that he has got to Washington, or he would put himself in the way of obtaining it at first hand. But we doubt not he will take our advice, which is to take Richmond -- if he think proper.
lead_paragraph: - We have learned by telegraph from Washington that a "highly distinguished Senator," being unable to get the ear of Lieut.-Gen. abstract: The steamship North Star, Capt. LEFEVRE, arrived at this port last evening from a cruise in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, which vessel was spoken at sea in a sinking condition.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North Star, Capt. LEFEVRE, arrived at this port last evening from a cruise in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, which vessel was spoken at sea in a sinking condition. The North Star sailed from this port on the 17th inst., and cruised as far south as Bermuda, and east to lon. 55° lat. 33°, making a zigzag course, running two hours one way and three hours the other, both on the southern and eastern cruises. Steered northeast to Sable Island, from lat. 33°, and from thence to the vicinity of Halifax, and passed directly over the spot where the frigate was last seen; but not a vestige of any wreck or materials were in view. On the 24th and 25th, in lat. 40° 17, lon. 56° 54, encountered a hurricane, and from southwest to northeast run south thirty six hours, and hove to. The gale lasted nearly three days, and Capt. LEFEVRE reports it exceedingly severe. The North Star has sailed over about 2,800 miles of sea during the cruise.

abstract: THE SIXTY-NINTH REGIMENT. The Division Court of Inquiry, instituted on the 17th of February last to inquire whether the Sixty-ninth volunteered into the service of the United States, and whether the Sixty-ninth became a part of the Corcoran Legion, have adjourned.
lead_paragraph: THE SIXTY-NINTH REGIMENT. -- The Division Court of Inquiry, instituted on the 17th of February last to inquire whether the Sixty-ninth volunteered into the service of the United States, and whether the Sixty-ninth became a part of the Corcoran Legion, have adjourned. Adjt.-Gen. SPRAGUE decides, upon the evidence given, that the Sixty-ninth twice entered the service of the United States for three months, but were mustered out. Only nine officers and forty-seven non-commissioned officers and privates entered the Corcoran Legion. It is, therefore, decided that the Sixty-ninth of this City, commanded by Col. BAGLEY, is the real Sixty-ninth New-York National Guard, and the name of the other is changed to the One Hundred and Eighty-second Regiment, New-York State Volunteers.

abstract: -There is something wrong -- very far wrong -- in West Tennessee, when a body of rebels that fought us not long since in Mississippi, can ride up from thence across Tennessee and Kentucky and attack our posts on the Ohio River. We have a great force of cavalry and mounted infantry in that section. Indeed, SMITH, who failed so badly in Mississippi, was there the other day with his ten thousand cavalry, if he be not there yet. We should think FORREST, and his everlasting mauraders, might now be caught before they got back to Mississippi.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. FOSTER reported a bill giving revolutionary soldiers an additional bounty of one hundred dollars, which was passed. A bill was reported to enable the people of Nebraska to form a State and maintain a territorial government. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill providing for the appointment of two additional cadets from each State. Candidates must have served honorably two years in the army. The Senate then took up the special order -- the resolution to amend the Constitution by prohibiting Slavery -- and Messrs. TRUMBULL, WILSON and SHERMAN spoke at length. Adjourned.

abstract: Santa Anna and the Empire
lead_paragraph: Among the kaleidoscopic changes which Mexico is now constantly exhibiting, one of the strangest is the sudden emergence of SANTA ANA from his obscurity of the last nine years, his flitting a moment as a flaming partisan of the new Empire, and then his equally sudden projection back into the shades. What sent him from his retreat into Mexico at this peculiar time? He says that it was his concern for the welfare of his country, and to strengthen the new Government which he hoped would regenerate it. Why then did those who act in the name of the new Government so quickly compel his departure?
headline: {'main': 'Santa Ana and the New Mexican Empire.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Santa Ana and the New Mexican Empire.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -Mr. MARETZEK's new season opened last night with a crowded house, and an admirable performance of "Faust." The artists were in good voice, and Mr. HEERMANNS sustained the role of Mephistopheles in an exceedingly striking and effective manner. Beyond this bare record there is nothing whatever to say. Nothing is so successful as success, and this inauguration of the season seems to promise a rich harvest for the energetic and deserving manager.

abstract: -It is understood that the Naval Commission favors the return of the Naval Academy to Annapolis. This is much better than the proposition to erect new buildings at Newport, where the Academy has been located since the outbreak of the war. Newport is in every respect unsuited to such an institution; it is a watering-place and a factory town, presenting every possible opportunity and incitement to dissipation and indolence. The interests, both of economy and morals, indicate the wisdom of the return to Annapolis.

abstract: -- "M. Guizot," says the Independence, "has read to the French Academy an interesting fragment from the volume of his Memoirs, which is to be published shortly. The extract contains an account of M. Guizot's entry into the Ministry in 1840, and a relation of the conveyance of the remains of the Emperor Napoleon I. to Paris. M. Guizot, in referring to the profound security which Louis Philippe appeared to enjoy at that period, admits the imprudent confidence which governments often place in themselves."

abstract: Cavalry of the Potomac Army
lead_paragraph: In the changes lately made in the Corps Commanders of the Army of the Potomac, though Gen. PLEASONTON was relieved from the command of the Cavalry Corps, no officer was nominated to fill the vacant place. We take it this arose from the fact that the military authorities were not immediately able to pitch upon the proper man for this important and peculiar command.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board was held last night. Several communications from the Mayor were presented -- one relative to the renting of the James-street Market, in regard to which he solicited the advice of the Common Council; and the other recommending the improvement and proper care of Washington Park, which is now in a state of dilapidation. Both communications were referred to appropriate committees. Some routine business was transacted, and the Board adjourned.

abstract: There is not the slightest evidence that the Constitution designed to prohibit any such thing. On the contrary, it makes it not only the privilege but the duty of the President to try to influence Congress, for it says: "He shall [not may] from time to time, give to the Congress information of the state of the Union, and recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient." He can do that in writing or orally just as he pleases; and in the early days of the Republic it was the custom for him to do it personally. If the Constitution allows him to do this in person, it is no violation either of the letter or of the spirit of the Constitution for him to give that "information" through his Secretaries, in their person. It would be simply realizing more fully that constitutional idea; for the Secretaries, if they are worthy of their place, are far better acquainted with the details than he possibly can be, and can make that "information" far more complete. The end which the Constitution aims to secure for Congress is the "information" from the Executive. The more effective the means of imparting that information, the better is the Constitution fulfilled.
lead_paragraph: There is not the slightest evidence that the Constitution designed to prohibit any such thing. He can do that in writing or orally just as he pleases; and in the early days of the Republic it was the custom for him to do it personally. If the Constitution allows him to do this in person, it is no violation either of the letter or of the spirit of the Constitution for him to give that "information" through his Secretaries, in their person. It would be simply realizing more fully that constitutional idea; for the Secretaries, if they are worthy of their place, are far better acquainted with the details than he possibly can be, and can make that "information" far more complete. The end which the Constitution aims to secure for Congress is the "information" from the Executive. The more effective the means of imparting that information, the better is the Constitution fulfilled.

abstract: From the dispatches of Fleet-Captain PENNOCK, from Cairo, to the Navy Department, it appears that the rebels did not get possession of the city, of Paducah, being driven off by three gunboats which laid at that point. Only a portion of the city was destroyed, and that was done by the shells of the gunboats. The rebels lost very heavily, and finally retreated southward. Gen. A.P. THOMPSON, (rebel,) was killed. FORREST's force was reported at 6,500 men.

abstract: The steamship City of Manchester, with one day's later news from Europe, arrived at this port yesterday. The Alexandra case was resumed in the House of Lords on the 14th of March, the part of the defendants being argued by Sir HUGH CAIRNS, who contended that the Court of Error was right in refusing to hear the appeal from the Court of Exchequer.
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Manchester, with one day's later news from Europe, arrived at this port yesterday. The Alexandra case was resumed in the House of Lords on the 14th of March, the part of the defendants being argued by Sir HUGH CAIRNS, who contended that the Court of Error was right in refusing to hear the appeal from the Court of Exchequer. The Attorney-General replied in behalf of the Crown, and it was expected that on the 17th inst. the Lord Chancellor would announce when judgment would be delivered. In commenting upon the case, the London Times says that there is a possibility that the House of Lords may decline jurisdiction. Such a disgraceful result would be owing to the slovenly way in which acts of Parliament are drawn and modified in Committee. Six seamen were brought up at the Cork Assizes on the 14th, indicted for an infraction of the Foreign Enlistment Act, in agreeing to enter the United States service as sailors on board the Kearsage. The prisoners pleaded guilty, and were released on promising to appear for judgment when called upon. The bodies of the victims of the Sheffield disaster, to the number of 178, had been recovered, leaving 80 yet missing. Another shocking casualty had occurred from the breaking of a pump at Spittlewell Pits, by which fourteen men were drowned. The Conservatives in the British Parliament had determined upon a strenuous effort to overthrow the Ministry after Easter. Mr. ROEBUCK's diatribe against the North had been editorially denounced by the London Times. There had been a further exchange of shots between the Danes and allied German forces, with unimportant results. The Prussians had occupied the Island of Femein, capturing the garrison of 100 Danes. It is said to be authentically asserted that Denmark is indisposed to accept the armistice and conference propositions in their essential points. A Paris rumor says that Austria and Prussia eventually intend to occupy Copenhagen and dictate terms of peace from that city. The King of Sweden had indicated his intention to assist Denmark in certain emergencies, and had asked for an extraordinary loan. In Rome conflicts between the Papal and French troops continued, the populace siding with the former. The rumor of a revival of the Holy Alliance was refuted by the Journal de St. Petersburg.

abstract: Corsen Zack vs. William Barnard. -- This was an action brought by one of the crew of the brig William Henry against the master of that vessel to recover $500 for an alleged assault committed on a voyage from Malaga to New-York. The plaintiff alleges that on the voyage the defendant assaulted and beat him, put him in irons and kept him confined without sufficient air, food or water. The defendant denied the assault and ill-usage, and justified his confinement on the ground that plaintiff had been insubordinate and insolent.

lead_paragraph: Martin Stepanovit, Jr., vs. Edmund Gellibrand and 4,922 bushels of Wheat. -- This was a libel filed by the master of the Austrian ship Imperatrice Elizabetta upon a charter party. The vessel being in this port, the master, on the 9th of September, 1863, chartered her to Gellibrand by a written charter party to carry a full cargo of wheat and flour to London. By a clause in the charter, the libelant was to have a lien on the cargo for freight, dead freight and demurrage. Thirty-five lay days were allowed for loading and discharging, to begin on Sept. 11.

abstract: Vallandigham "the Martyr," and Ohio Copperhead State Convention; Ohio Copperhead State Convention
snippet: Vallandigham "the Martyr," and Ohio Copperhead State Convention; Ohio Copperhead State Convention
lead_paragraph: People looked forward to the doings of this collection of Copperheads with a good deal of curiosity. Of course these doings, of whatever character, will be of very little practical consequence, for there can be no consequence without power, or at least a possibility of power. No State in this Union is more immovably loyal, and more inflexibly faithful to the war against the rebellion, than the great State of Ohio. Yet, though it was of no public moment what these Copperheads might do, it was a matter of curious speculation what they would do. How would they treat VALLANDIGHAM, "the martyr?" Last year they made common cause with him -- held him out as the immolated embodiment of all the sanctities of the Constitution -- and, with absolute confidence, proclaimed their purpose to avenge him with a sweeping extinction of both LINCOLN and the war. The people settled the matter, when the time of trial came, by striking them to the dust, and piling over them a majority never before heard of -- one hundred thousand clean. It has been a question what would be the effect of this popular visitation. Would it impel these fomenters of faction to desert their great martyred apostle, or not? It all depended upon the quality of their own martyr spirit. If it were genuine, of course they would adhere to his name and faith with a fidelity only made the stauncher by tribulation. If it were spurious, why then there would be faltering and shuffling, and probably an abandonment outright.
headline: {'main': 'The Ohio Copperhead State Convention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Ohio Copperhead State Convention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The sale by the Comptroller of several ferry franchises, which was to have followed the sale of wharves, for various reasons has been put off till Monday, April 11, and yesterday, in consequence of the death of the late Superintendent of Markets, MATHIAS W. GOODERSON, the sale of other leases of Corporation property -- chiefly of market cellars -- was postponed till 1 o'clock P.M. to-day. Among other five-year leases to be disposed of to-day will be the lease of the hotel at the foot of Eighty-sixth-street, North River.

abstract: Last evening Count JOANNES delivered a public oration before a rather limited audience at Cooper Institute. He spoke very bitterly of the actions of the present Administration and the conduct of the war, disliked drafting, believed one volunteer to be worth seven drafted men, thought our great mistake had been in underrating our enemy, whom he considered a brave and valiant class of men. He believed President LINCOLN to be an honest man, but thought him so surrounded by bad men as to be unable to do as he ought. Secretary SEWARD he believed to be a gentleman and a scholar, but very deceitful and not to be trusted. His address was rather rambling and disconnected, and was interrupted frequently by hisses and applause. One person, who was rather demonstrative, was removed by the police. Other than that the lecture passed off quietly.
lead_paragraph: Last evening Count JOANNES delivered a public oration before a rather limited audience at Cooper Institute. abstract: The Secretary of the Navy has given the command of the great iron-clad Puritan, now in course of completion at Greenpoint, and sister ship to the Dictator, to Commodore RADFORD. This is the most
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Navy has given the command of the great iron-clad Puritan, now in course of completion at Greenpoint, and sister ship to the Dictator, to Commodore RADFORD. This is the most exalted command at the disposal of the Navy Department. The Puritan has twice the offensive power of the Dictator, and will have four enormous guns, instead of two. Commodore RADFORD has been the commander of the Brooklyn Navy-yard for some years. He entered the service on a Missouri appointment on the 1st of April, 1825, and has consequently been in the navy nearly forty years. He was thirteen years at sea, having last been Captain of the steam-sloop Dacotah. He was a schoolmate of Admiral DAHLGREN, Commodores ROWAN and ROGERS, Capts. MEADE, DRAYTON and others,

abstract: Arkansas and Extermination
lead_paragraph: The rebels are perpetually telling us that we will have to exterminate the whole population of the South before we can bring their territory back into the Union. Now, at the late election for State officers in Arkansas, held under the National flag and authority, there were polled seventeen thousand votes -- being one-third the entire vote of the State at the last Presidential election. Yet in other days we heard the like rebel cry from Arkansas, that we would have to exterminate everybody there before it would submit. Probably these rebel malignants simply mean that they themselves must be exterminated, which is quite likely to be true. NOAH WEBSTER tells us that to exterminate means, primarily, "to drive from within the limits or borders," and we shall have no peace until all malignant traitors are driven either to the other side of Jordan or of the Rio Grande.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, adverse reports were received and recommitted relative to the Brooklyn Fire Department Bill, the petition of the Staten Island Ferry Company for a new ferry slip, and the incorporation of the Long Island Water Works Company. Also, adverse reports were made and agreed to, concerning the New-New-York Aldermanic Tax Levy Bill; the Bill for a Market in the Eighth-avenue; the Brooklyn Park-avenue Bill; the amendment of the charter of Brooklyn. Several new bills were introduced, and the following were advanced to a third reading: The General Appropriation Bill for the support of the State Government; for the payment of the interest on certain canal drafts and awards; incorporating the Central Park Hotel Company.

abstract: Miscegenation, Misplaced Confidence
lead_paragraph: We are afraid we have been swindled. It looks very much as if we bad been the victims of a misplaced confidence. Trusting entirely, as we stated at the time, to the assertions of the Copperhead press, we have made mention of sundry movements alleged to be in process for the more wide-spread diffusion of the new political gospel of Miscegenation, and for the general elevation of the whole world and the rest of mankind to the sublime level of the African race. Catching, perhaps, somewhat of the enthusiasm with which this subject has been discussed by our contemporaries, we have also ventured to picture some of the glories of the coming state, when all men should be of one color, and all shades and crinkles should have disappeared forever.
headline: {'main': 'Victims of Misplaced Confidence.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Victims of Misplaced Confidence.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday completed the sale of five-year leases of market cellars and other Corporation property, the leases for which had expired or will expire by May 1. The sale was a very successful one.
lead_paragraph: Comptroller BRENNAN yesterday completed the sale of five-year leases of market cellars and other Corporation property, the leases for which had expired or will expire by May 1. The sale was a very successful one. The attendance was not so large as at the sale of wharf property on Monday, but the bidding was more spirited. The seventy-one pieces of property on the catalogue, which now rent at an aggregate of $24,785 per year, sold at rates aggregating $44,455 per year an increase of $19,670, or about eighty per cent. The hotel at the foot of Eighty-sixth-street, East River, which is bringing but $400 per year, went off at $575. One cellar at Washington Market, now bringing $470 per year, sold for $2,550 -- an increase of $2,080. The brick building at the southeast corner of Fulton and West streets, now renting for $1,000, sold for $6,100 per annum.

abstract: Last evening, Excelsior Hose Company No. 14 held a reception at their house in West Thirteenth-street, to exhibit the goods they have collected for the fair, and entertain the ladies who have so liberally and promptly contributed to their collection. Owing, however, to the inclemency of the weather, the ladies were unable to attend, and it was therefore decided to have another reception for their benefit this evening. This company have worked well for the fair, and their efforts have been very successful. They have a large number of articles, some very handsome and valuable -- several paintings, numerous articles of worsted and needle work, and a variety of articles of ladies' manufacture, are among them. They are working hard, and will endeavor to be second to none in their contributions to the grand collection to be made by the New-York Fire Department to the Metropolitan Fair.

abstract: During yesterday the wind was from east northeast and blew heavily with rain througdout the day. From pilots come in from sea we learn the gale was severe outside. The pilot-boat M.E. Fish, No. 4, when off the Highlands, picked up three barrels of kerosene marked No. 2, from a lot of about twenty barrels; saw no other wrecked stuff.
lead_paragraph: During yesterday the wind was from east northeast and blew heavily with rain througdout the day. From pilots come in from sea we learn the gale was severe outside. The pilot-boat M.E. Fish, No. 4, when off the Highlands, picked up three barrels of kerosene marked No. 2, from a lot of about twenty barrels; saw no other wrecked stuff. Off Barnegat she saw a barkentine with all topmasts gone, and boarded a foreign bark with bulwarks and stancheons gone. The ship Norway, from Liverpool, is at anchor in the Lower Bay, with fore and mizzen topmasts gone, and enough of the main mast standing for one yard only. The ship. City of Brooklyn, while at anchor off Bedloe's Island. was fouled by another ship and somewhat chafed the other ship; lost jibboom; they were towed apart by tugs. The schooner Union arrived from Baltimore, and bound to Belfast, Me., encountered on March 26, when off Montauk, a severe gale from east to northeast, which continued with unabated fury until the 28th, driving the schooner to the southward of Cape Henlopen, during which she had her sails torn badly, bulwarks and galley stove, carried away the bobstay, broke skylight, shifted cargo, filled the cabin, and done other damage.

abstract: Richmond, Brutal Treatment
lead_paragraph: A chapter will be written by some future historian on the horrors of the "Libby Prison," which will almost equal in fearful interest the records of the Bastile. We shall hear of brave and enthusiastic young men who entered those gloomy walls, and who gradually, as month after month passed away of the dreary and filthy confinement, became depressed in spirit and broken in body, until when release came at last, it came too late. There will be stories of petty persecutions, of brutal indignities practiced on persons helpless and weak, of cruelties, of hopes deferred month by month, of weariness and sickness, and the lonely death of gallant men, which will make, in the future, that Richmond prison, or the place where it had been, one of the most painful places in the American memory.
headline: {'main': 'The Richmond Prisons How Prisoners are Treated on Both Sides.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Richmond Prisons How Prisoners are Treated on Both Sides.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: About twelve o'clock on Tuesday night a fire broke out in the chapel connected with the Fourth-avenue Presbyterian Church, situated at Nos. 288 and 290 Fourth avenue, corner of Twenty-second-street. Much difficulty was experienced by the firemen in getting water on the flames, and, before they could be extinguished, damage to the amount of about $6,000 was done to the premises. The fire originated around the register of the hot-air furnace, and burned through the flooring into several of the pews; it also burned the floors and beams considerably. The building is reported to be fully insured in City companies.

abstract: A NEW SPECIES OF VILLANY. -- Previous to the establishment of the depot for the reception of emigrants at Castle Garden, one of the evils complained of was the enticing of young girls, recently landed, to disreputable quarters. After the charge of emigrants was placed in the hands of the Commissioners of Emigration, the evil alluded to was abated. Recently, however, it has been renewed, but in a different form. The General Agent of the Commissioners of Emigration had yesterday the following facts brought to his notice: Two German girls, ELIZABETH LETTSING and MARIAH OTTO, arrived Monday on the steamer America, from Bremen. They were hired at that city, and their passage paid to this country by a man who represented he engaged them as servants for his brother in New-York. The "brother" was probably notified of the arrangement by some faster vessel than the America, for, upon the arrival of that ship in this harbor, he presented himself on board the vessel and claimed the charge of the girls as their "friend." The police officer sent from Castle Garden to look out for such cases, refused to allow the girls to accompany their new-found friend, but took them before the agent, Mr. BERNARD CASSERLY, who, upon investigation, found that the brother was the keeper of one of the vilest dens in the City. Consequently, Mr. CASSERLY refused to let the claimant have the girls, but secured for them respectable employment in private families.
lead_paragraph: A NEW SPECIES OF VILLANY. -- Previous to the establishment of the depot for the reception of emigrants at Castle Garden, one of the evils complained of was the enticing of young girls, recently landed, to disreputable quarters. Consequently, Mr. CASSERLY refused to let the claimant have the girls, but secured for them respectable employment in private families.

abstract: The Register alludes to the Northern denial of the authenticity of the documents said to have been found on the body of Col. DAHLGREN, and declares that the papers as published were entirely genuine, and that they are "substantiated by citizens on the line of the road, to whom the design was boastingly announced, and confirmed by a mass of evidence, which, when published and given to the world, as shortly will be done, will not leave a twig of question for the originators of the barbarous scheme to grasp at, as they plunge to the abyss of lasting infamy, or a single doubtful strand in the rope that swings them to the execration of the civilized world."

abstract: The Navy Department has issued an order establishing a new rendezvous near the Navy yard, Brooklyn, where seamen transferred from the army under the new law will be quartered. This depot will be opened on the first of April, or as soon after as possible. It was first intended to have all the transferred recruits sent on board the receiving-ship North Carolina, but Capt. MEADE of that vessel made such well-grounded objections that the project was not carried out.

abstract: ALFRED W. CRAVEN, Esq., Chairman of the Committee on Machinery, Metropolitan Fair, has received from the employes in the Manhattan Gas Company Works, at the foot of Eighteenth-street, North River, four hundred dollars as their contribution to the Fair. From the employes of the same Company, at the works foot of Fourteenth-street, East River, he has received three hundred and thirty-three. This handsome and creditable liberality is being emulated in a large number of workshops, factories, &c., and the aggregate amount from such sources will be very large. The committee have been organized but a short time, but great success is promised them.

abstract: JOHN CARSON was arrested on Tuesday evening by Officer HILLMAN of the Fifth Precinct, charged with being concerned in the robbery of EDWARD FITZGERALD, of No. 44 Greenwich-street. From the affidavit of Mr. FITZGERALD, we learn that the latter was in a porter-house on the corner of Desbroses and Washington streets, in a partially intoxicated condition when CARSON and another man whose name is unknown, entered,and volunteered to see FITZGERALD home. About the time they started, the stranger thrust his hand suddenly into his victim's pocket, and stole therefrom $98 in bills, with which he made his escape, and has not been arrested. CARSON was committed to the Tombs by Justice DOWLING, in default of $500 bail.

abstract: -- Table No. 9 having been assigned to the Seventh Police Precinct, by the Metropolitan Fair Committee of Arrangement, the members of the police of that district have been industriously engaged for several days, assisted by the citizens of the Seventh Ward, in preparing and purchasing articles to fit up their table in a manner worthy of their precinct. They have already a large variety of articles collected. Most of the contributions are very valuable, and evince a disposition on the part of the members of the Seventh Police Precinct to do all that lies in their power to promote the noble object of the Metropolitan Fair.

abstract: The report of an outbreak of the Copperheads, published yesterday, and located at Charleston, Missouri, should have read Illinois, the disturbance having occurred in one of the most Copperhead regions of "Egypt." Yesterday troops were dispatched from Mattoon, Ill., to suppress the outbreak. The rebels were reported to number three hundred, and to be intrenched at a point ten miles northeast of Charleston. Pickets were out on all the roads, and there seems to be war in earnest.

abstract: -- The famous oak tree, under which Gens. GARNT and PEMBERTON met, and agreed upon terms for the surrender of Vicksburgh, on the 3d of July last, has been cut to pieces by soldiers who wished to obtain souvenirs of the memorable event. The trunk and branches failing to supply the demand, the roots were dug up.

abstract: A few days since, a member of the firm of Messrs. BELL  WHEELOCK, wholesale shoe dealers at No. 69 Worth-street, went to Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, to whom he stated that for several months past large quantities of their goods had disappeared, in some mysterious manner, from time to time. The gentleman had suspicions that a porter in their employ, named JOHN FARLOW, was in some way ...
lead_paragraph: A few days since, a member of the firm of Messrs. BELL WHEELOCK, wholesale shoe dealers at No. 69 Worth-street, went to Capt. JOURDAN, of the Sixth Precinct, to whom he stated that for several months past large quantities of their goods had disappeared, in some mysterious manner, from time to time. The gentleman had suspicions that a porter in their employ, named JOHN FARLOW, was in some way connected with the theft, and he therefore desired that Capt. JOURDAN and his men, who have recently been quite successful in similar cases, should take charge of the matter, and, if possible, secure the guilty parties and recover the goods. Capt. JOURDAN and Officer GOLDEN accordingly set to work, and, for two or three nights and mornings they watched the premises very closely. They knew that the porter, FARLOW, not only carried the keys of the store, but he also had charge of the keys to the safe. Suspicion, therefore, rested more strongly on him than upon any other employe of the firm. Moreover, he had, upon several occasions, been seen to leave the premises, after closing the store at night, with packages under his arm. On Tuesday evening last, he closed the store as usual, and started across Broadway with a bulky parcel. Officer GOLDEN, who was watching on the opposite side of the street, followed FARLOW several blocks, until he became satisfied that he had the right man, when he took him into custody. The prisoner and parcel were taken to the station-house. On making an examination of the bundle there, twenty-eight pairs of ladies' shoes, valued at $75, were found therein. FARLOW was questioned by Capt. JOURDAN as to how he had come by them, and the prisoner stated that he had received express permission from the firm to take them away; also that he had never stolen an article from the store. In order to satisfy himself as to the right of the prisoner to take the shoes from the store, Capt. J. sent for one of the firm, when it was ascertained, beyond all question, that FARLOW's design was to steal the goods. He was locked in the station-house during the night, and the next morning he was willing to disclose something of his proceedings. He said that about three times each week, since June last, he had stolen goods from his employers, the great portion of which he had sold to one CONRAD UNDERMACH, a boot and shoe dealer at No. 115 Bowery. A search-warrant was then obtained, and several cases and boxes of ladies' and childrens' shoes and gaiters, all belonging to Messrs. BELL & WHEELOCK were found in the store of UNDERMACH. The value of the goods thus recovered is over $1,200. UNDERMACH stated to the officers that he had purchased them all from FARLOW. He was consequently arrested as a receiver of stolen property.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. FESSENDEN reported back the House bill making appropriations for the legislative, judicial and executive expenses of the Government. Mr. WILSON reported a bill for the payment of the expenses of the Minnesota Indian war. Mr. HARLAN, of Iowa, reported a bill to aid a railroad in Iowa, from McGregor, along the forty-third parallel, to a point on the Missouri River, with a branch up Cedar Valley, toward Mankota, Minn., and one from Sioux City to Mankota, giving five alternate sections per mile. The bill providing a temporary Government for the Territory of Montano was taken up, but no progress made. The resolution for amending the Constitution so as to prohibit Slavery, coming up as the special order, Mr. DAVIS spoke at length against the resolution, when the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. FESSENDEN reported back the House bill making appropriations for the legislative, judicial and executive expenses of the Government. The bill providing a temporary Government for the Territory of Montano was taken up, but no progress made. The resolution for amending the Constitution so as to prohibit Slavery, coming up as the special order, Mr. DAVIS spoke at length against the resolution, when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: An editorial in the Enquirer is devoted to a discussion of Mexican affairs. It reviews the history of that unfortunate country, and declares that her people are utterly incapable of self-government, and lauds NAPOLEON for his efforts to produce peace and good government there, and says "he is doing the very best thing for Mexico that could possibly be done. He is rescuing the country from utter ruin." Of MAXIMILIAN the Enquirer says: "The agent chosen by NAPOLEON for the regeneration of Mexico is eminently qualified for the efficient accomplishment of the work before him. He belongs to the Loraine branch of the proud, imperial house of Hapsburg -- one of the oldest dynasties in Europe. He is, therefore, invested with all the prestige which high birth can give."

abstract: The movement now on foot for municipal reform is the first really earnest and systematic one that has been made. The people have taken hold of the matter, as the already large and yet growing organizations in the different Wards attest. The movement is one entirely irrespective of party. There are no politicians in it, and no politician will find favor from it. Those who have taken hold most earnestly are the mechanics and the workingmen, who have now brought home to them, in increased rents, been use of increased taxes, and in other ways, the knowledge that a reform is necessary. But all classes of citizens are interested and all classes are engaged. Meetings are being held and are always well attended, where facts and figures are given as to how the public moneys go, how valuable franchises are given away, and how the best interests of the City and of citizens are wholly ignored. These facts and figures cannot be controverted, and they are setting men to thinking and to acting. The present movement for reform is decidedly a strong and popular one.

abstract: -- PETER BADEAU, Esq., the oldest Sunday-school teacher in this City, and probably in the United States, if not in the world, departed this life on March 16, at his late residence in Eleventh-street. He was in his eighty-ninth year, and had been an active Sunday-school teacher from the first formation of Sunday schools in this City up to the time of his death.

abstract: -- WALTER Low, whose elegant little establishment at No. 823 Broadway is the natural resort of the lovers of whatever is fresh, and good, and beautiful in the literary world, has issued, in very neat style, a volume of private poems entitled Nests at Washington, and Other Poems, by JOHN J. and SARAH M.B. PIATT. These productions, so modestly put forth, are of such excellent merit, that had they only the name of a Longfellow to herald them, they would be accepted without criticism. The names of the authors, however, are already associated with a number of beautiful poems, and these fragments worthily add to their modest claims. "The Monk's Vision of Christ," "The Golden Hand," and "A Disenchantment," are quite gems of excellence.

abstract: The Hon. L.Q.C. LAMAR, late Minister to Russia from the Confederate States, delivered an address in Milledgeville, Ga., a few nights ago, on the sentiment of Europe toward the Cenfederacy. Mr. LAMAR went to Europe over a year ago, and had good opportunities of ascertaining the tone of European opinion. He found the intelligent people everywhere candid in expression of sympathy with the Confederates, and of admiration for the dignity and statesmanship of our rulers, and the valor, endurance and fortitude of our soldiers und people, but there were considerations of a political character operating to deter official recognition or intervention by the Governments of Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Hon. L.Q.C. LAMAR, late Minister to Russia from the Confederate States, delivered an address in Milledgeville, Ga., a few nights ago, on the sentiment of Europe toward the Cenfederacy. Mr. LAMAR went to Europe over a year ago, and had good opportunities of ascertaining the tone of European opinion. abstract: By the arrival of the Africa at Halifax, yesterday, we have European news to the 20th -- three days later. Lord PALMERSTON had said in the House of Commons, on the 17th inst., in regard to the proposed "conference," that the reply of Denmark was still awaited, but he had good reason to believe that the Danish Government would assent. The Lord Chancellor announced that the House of Lords would give judgment in the Alexandra case soon after Easter. The Manchester Examiner publishes a letter from sundry persons in New-York, emphatically denying the assertions of the correspondent of the London Herald, that, owing to the prevalence of kidnapping, there was no security for emigrants landing at New-York. They denounce the assertion as a gross falsehood. The ship Gibraltar had sailed for New-York with 1,000 tons of coal, given by Mr. GEORGE ELLIOTT, of the firm of GLASS, ELLIOTT & Co., in aid of the United States Sanitary Commission. The Atlantic Telegraph Company Directors have announced that they have made a contract with GLASS, ELLIOTT & Co. to manufacture the improved cable, unanimously recommended by the Scientific Committee, and to lay the same in the Summer of 1865. The London News of the 18th announced, on authority, that Denmark had accepted the conference proposal, but the consent of the German Confederation was yet to be obtained, which was doubtful. The war in Denmark was progressing slowly. The Allies were laying siege to Duppel, and a vigorous bombardment was begun on the 16th, but without effect. A sharp naval engagement had taken place on Rugen Island, between five Danish steamers and two Prussian men-of-war and several gunboats, resulting in the withdrawal of the Prussian ships, closely pursued by the Danes. The Prussian vessels, however, succeeded in reaching port safely. It is asserted that Sweden is hastening her armaments.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN on the body of the lad, JOHN DONNELLY, who was accidentally run over on Monday evening by a car of the East River Railroad line, in First-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street. The testimony showed the occurrence to be purely accidental, and the jury rendered a verdict accordingly.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN on the body of the lad, JOHN DONNELLY, who was accidentally run over on Monday evening by a car of the East River Railroad line, in First-avenue, near Twenty-sixth-street. The testimony showed the occurrence to be purely accidental, and the jury rendered a verdict accordingly.

abstract: Contract to supply Rebel Armies
lead_paragraph: Some six weeks ago it was stated in some of the Western newspapers that Gen. E. KIRBY SMITH, of the rebel army in the Department of the Mississippi, had been negotiating with certain parties in the United States, with the knowledge and consent of the rebel Government at Richmond, to exchange cotton for provisions, army clothing and other articles of which the rebel troops were in most pressing need. The statements on this subject were at once denied, apparently on official authority, and the matter rested for a time; but it has more recently been revived, and the same statements have been repeated in the Western journals.

abstract: The Ladies of the Soldiers' Aid Societies of Livingston County presented to the Metropolitan Fair, yesterday, through their committee, Messrs. CHARLES H. CARROLL, JASPER BARBER and RICHARD PECK, a mammoth ox, yclept the "Pride of Livingston County." The animal is, literally, a splendid one; is a high-grade Durham, six years old, and weighs 3,600 pounds. His color is pure white, neither spot or blomish about him. He was raised by W.G. MERKLE, from whom he was purchased by the ladies for $1,000. It is claimed that this is the largest and finest ox ever seen in this City, and one of the largest in the world. It would be a good idea for the committee to whom he will be surrendered to place him on exhibition, at a trifling admittance fee. The ladies of Livingston County have, indeed, made a liberal and mammoth contribution.

abstract: The Kentucky Court of Appeals in the case of NORRIS vs. DONPLEON, on appeal from Mason County, have decided the following points in reference to the act of Congress to confiscate the property of certain classes of rebels, Judge BULLITT delivering the ...
lead_paragraph: The Kentucky Court of Appeals in the case of NORRIS vs. DONPLEON, on appeal from Mason County, have decided the following points in reference to the act of Congress to confiscate the property of certain classes of rebels, Judge BULLITT delivering the opinion of the court, in which he held that "the act under consideration is unconstitutional, because it attempts to authorize the confiscation of the property of citizens as a punishment of treason and other crimes, without due process of law by proceedings in rem in any district in which the the property may be, without presentment or indictment by a Grand Jury, without arrest or summons of the owner, and upon such evidence of his guilt as would be sufficient proof of any fact in admiralty or revenue cases. (Constitution, article 3, section 2; sub-sec. 3 and section 3, sub-sec. 1; and articles 5th and 6th of Amendments.)

abstract: -Three weeks since, EDWARD SCHAFFER arrived in this country from Germany. Immediately after landing at Castle Garden, he was induced to enlist by a bounty broker. He received $25, but was swindled out of the balance of his money. After spending three days on Riker's Island, he joined a veteran regiment attached to the Army of the Potomac. Five days after his arrival with the army, he lost a leg and an arm in a skirmish. Yesterday, a letter was received from him at Castle Garden, saying that he would like to have his baggage sent to him at one of the Washington hospitals.

abstract: The French steam corvettee Phligiton, Commander MAUD, from a cruise in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, made a thorough search, but saw nothing of her. The Phligiton has been absent fifteen days, during which time she has encountered furious gales, lost quarter boats and sustained other damage.
lead_paragraph: The French steam corvettee Phligiton, Commander MAUD, from a cruise in search of the Italian frigate Re Galantuomo, made a thorough search, but saw nothing of her. abstract: Information had been received by the military authorities at Lake City, Fla., on Sunday evening last, that the Yankees had landed a force at Palatka. The force landed at that point is not known, but it was rumored that it was large. Gen. FINNEGAN had dispatched forces to meet them, consisting of cavalry, infantry and artillery. Our pickets in front of Jacksonville confirm previous intelligence that the greatest portion of the enemy's troops had left that place. Everything continued quiet in the neighborhood of Jacksonville.
lead_paragraph: Information had been received by the military authorities at Lake City, Fla., on Sunday evening last, that the Yankees had landed a force at Palatka. The force landed at that point is not known, but it was rumored that it was large. Gen. FINNEGAN had dispatched forces to meet them, consisting of cavalry, infantry and artillery. Our pickets in front of Jacksonville confirm previous intelligence that the greatest portion of the enemy's troops had left that place. Everything continued quiet in the neighborhood of Jacksonville.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK, if not always fortunate in the matter of weather, is at all events happy in the number of lieges who turn out in his honor when the elements are against him. Considering the almost impassible state of the streets, the attendance last night was quite flattering. We are glad to add that the performance was worthy of the sacrifice made to hear it. We have seldom heard the opera ("Martha") given with more spirit. Miss KELLOGG was in admirable voice, and acted the role of Lady Henrietta with charming ease, grace and spirit. It is and always must remain one of her best efforts. Sig. BRIGNOLI made his rentree as Lionel, and was, of course, the centre of attraction. It was this gentleman's misfortune to sing last season under adverse circumstances of health, that were painful to himself, and the cause of apprehension to his friends. It was rather harshly suggested that he had lost his voice, and a few, who had never, perhaps, enjoyed it, rejoiced at an accident that had apparently deprived the public of a favorite artist. These grumblers were happily silenced last evening. Sigor BRIGNOLI was in capital voice, and sang throughout with unabated. power and sweetness. We hardly remember to have ever heard him to greater advantage. The romansa in the third act was superbly delivered, and more than merited the rapturous encore which Signor BRIGNOLI so reluctantly accepted.

abstract: A few evenings since, a large delegation from the Newsboys' Lodging House assembled in front of the well-known establishment of KNOX, the hatter, and gave him a serenade. The musical instruments employed were voices given them by Nature, and the songs sung consisted of national and patriotic ads. The occasion of this novel entertainment, was in return for a handsome donation of hats and caps given to the institution by this gentleman, for which the boys desired to show their gratitude. This incident proves that such donations are appreciated.
